(a)        Date of institution of case            :     25.11.2022
(b)        Date on which order reserved           :     12.02.2026
(c)        Date on which order pronounced         :     27.02.2026

                                  ORDER ON CHARGE

           Introduction:

      1.                    At the outset, it is appropriate to record that the
           investigating agency, namely the Central Bureau of Investigation
           (hereinafter referred to as “CBI”), has filed one principal charge-sheet
           together with four supplementary charge-sheets in the present matter.
           For the purposes of clarity, uniformity and ease of reference, the
           accused persons, as enumerated hereinabove, shall hereinafter referred
           to as Accused Nos. “A-1 to A-23” respectively, unless the context
           otherwise requires. The Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988 shall

hereinafter referred to as “PC Act, 1988”. M/S Brindco Sales Private
       Limited shall be referred to as “M/S BSPL”, M/S Khao Gali
       Restaurant Private Limited as “ M/S KGRL”, Pernod Ricard India
       Private Limited as “M/S PRI”, and the code of Criminal Procedure,
       1973 as “Cr. P.C.”

  2.                       The allegations sought to be projected by the CBI, as
       emanating from the aforesaid charge-sheet and the supplementary
       charge-sheets, are set out and examined in the paragraphs that follow.
       It is clarified that the facts set out in the chargesheets are noted herein
       in brief. The detailed particulars, with requisite specificity, shall be
       examined under the respective heads of allegations while evaluating
       and analyzing the material placed on record by the Investigating
       Agency and the role attributed to each accused.

       Main Charge sheet, dated 24.11.2022 (filed on 25.11.2022)

  3.                       According to the prosecution, as set out in FIR No.
       RC0032022A0053 dated 17.08.2022, lodged by CBI/ACB, New Delhi
       on the complaint of Shri Praveen Kumar Rai, Director, Ministry of
       Home Affairs, certain public servants of the Excise Department,
       GNCTD, acting in concert with private individuals and liquor
       businessmen, entered into a criminal conspiracy during the framing
       and implementation of the Delhi Excise Policy 2021-22 (hereinafter
       referred to as “DEP-21/22”). It is alleged that this arrangement was
       intended to secure unlawful pecuniary advantage for themselves and

for favoured private entities, thereby attracting offences under Section
       120-B of the Indian Penal Code (hereinafter referred to as “IPC”) read
       with Sections 7, 7A and 8 of the PC Act, 1988.

  4.                       The policy, brought into force on 05.07.2021, is stated to
       have been designed to curb monopoly and cartel formation by
       separating the functions of manufacturer, wholesaler (L-1 licensee)
       and retail zone licensee. The tender conditions barred wholesalers
       from holding or funding retail licences and imposed restrictions on
       entities with overlapping directors or controlling shareholding across
       manufacturing, wholesale or retail entities. Retail zones were to be
       allotted by e-tender against substantial participation fees and Earnest
       Money Deposits (hereinafter referred to as “EMD”), and a Tender
       Evaluation Committee (hereinafter referred to as “TEC”) was
       constituted for scrutiny of bids. Twenty zones were awarded in the first
       round; twelve remained and were tendered afresh, in which M/S
       KGRL emerged as H-1 for Zones 2 and 3, leading to issuance of letters
       of award with the approval of the then Deputy Chief Minister.

  5.                       The case put forward is that in May/June 2021, at the
       instance of A-3, a meeting was held at Gauri Apartments near
       Claridges Hotel, Delhi. It is stated that approver PW-20; Dinesh Arora,
       A-4, A-5 and others attended the meeting. The liquor policy was
       discussed and it was indicated that 7–10 retail zones in Delhi would
       be taken by the group. A-3 is stated to have introduced approver

PW-20 as his close associate who would deal with excise matters in
       Delhi, coordinate with the others and keep him informed. It is alleged
       that between 18–20 June 2021, another meeting took place at ITC
       Kohenoor, Hyderabad, attended by the same persons. During this
       meeting, it was stated that ₹20–30 crores would be sent by A-4 to A-3
       in Delhi, and that approver PW-20 would coordinate the transfer.
       Reliance is placed on hotel records to show their presence during this
       period. It is stated that in the said meeting it was decided that the
       wholesale distributorship in Delhi of M/S PRI and M/S DIAGEO
       would go to M/S Indospirits of A-7 and M/S BSPL of A-9, enabling
       these entities to earn the 12% wholesale margin on Indian Made
       Foreign Liquor (hereinafter referred to as “IMFL”). It is contended
       that the amount of ₹20–30 crores, described as “upfront money”, was
       to be adjusted through business arrangements. A 65% partnership of
       A-5 in M/S Indospirits was to be secured. Further, 6% out of the 12%
       margin of M/S BSPL was to be returned by way of credit notes to retail
       zones controlled by A-4 and, after repayment, shared equally between
       A-4 and A-3. Approver PW-20 was assured a 25% share in M/S
       Indospirits, though no such share was ultimately given, and was told
       that he would be accommodated in future. It is stated that between July
       and September 2021, ₹20–30 crores were sent in cash through hawala
       channels to A-3 and his associates. A-4 is said to have communicated

phone numbers and currency note details to Approver PW-20, who
       would pass the same to the team of A-3.

  6.                       It is further alleged that A-3 used his influence to
       pressurize M/S PRI not to appoint M/S BSPL as its distributor in Delhi
       and to instead appoint M/S Indospirits, despite reservations about
       Indospirits’ past financial record. A meeting is stated to have been held
       on 20.09.2021 at Hotel Taj Mansingh, New Delhi, attended by officials
       of M/S PRI along with A-7, A-5 and A-4, wherein the latter two
       allegedly projected themselves as investors in M/S Indospirits with
       support from prominent business houses in the South. Following this,
       M/S PRI appointed M/S Indospirits as its wholesale distributor and
       granted brand registrations.

  7.                       Regarding public servants, the charge-sheet alleges that
       A-1 (then Deputy Commissioner, IMFL) and A-2 (then Assistant
       Commissioner, IMFL) became part of the conspiracy while dealing
       with M/S Indospirits’ L-1 licence and in handling complaints relating
       to alleged cartelisation and cross-funding. Indospirits’ first L-1
       application dated 09.09.2021 drew certain deficiency memos, and a
       complaint dated 18.10.2021 alleging cartel practices and blacklisting
       was received. It is alleged that A-1 directed that important allegations
       concerning “cross-funding/EMD funding” of M/S KGRL by M/S
       Indospirits not be included in the show-cause notice and that no

meaningful enquiry was undertaken. M/S Indospirits then sought
       withdrawal of this application, which was allowed on 05.11.2021.

  8.                       The prosecution states that a second L-1 application
       dated 29.10.2021, substantially similar in structure, was processed
       unusually swiftly on 05.11.2021, the first working day after Diwali,
       notwithstanding the pendency of related proceedings before the
       Hon’ble Supreme Court and the subsisting allegations of cartelisation.
       It is alleged that the file contained deficiencies and that the Section
       Officer and Assistant Section Officer had proposed issuance of a
       deficiency memo, but A-2 directed them not to issue it, stating that he
       would obtain the necessary documents himself. It is claimed that the
       documents were then inserted into the file on the same day, without
       any covering letter or proper receipt, at a time when A-7 was present
       in the Excise office. A note was thereafter prepared, and with the
       approval of A-1, the L-1 licence was granted on the same day. In this
       context, the prosecution alleges that A-7 caused ₹30 lakhs to be paid
       as illegal gratification to A-2, on the instructions of A-3 and with the
       involvement of approver (PW-20) Dinesh Arora, for securing and
       expediting the licence.

  9.                       The charge-sheet further asserts that the anti-cartel
       provisions of the policy were deliberately undermined by permitting
       and concealing cross-funding between M/S Indospirits (wholesaler)
       and M/S KGRL (retailer). It is alleged that during the first round of

bidding, ₹10.80 crores were transferred from the account of M/S
        Indospirit Marketing Private Limited (hereinafter referred to as
        “IMPL”) to the account of M/S KGRL, and demand drafts towards
        EMD were prepared out of the said amount. It is stated that in the
        second round of bidding, twelve demand drafts of ₹10 lakhs each
        towards application fee were prepared from the account of M/S
        KGRL, after transferring funds in two instalments of ₹60 lakhs each
        from M/S IMPL. It is further stated that a demand draft of ₹5 crores
        towards EMD was prepared from the account of M/S KGRL after
        money was transferred in three instalments from M/S IMPL. The
        authorised signatory and net banking operator of the bank accounts of
        M/S IMPL are stated to be A-7, his wife and his father.

  10.                      On the financial front, it is alleged that between
        November 2021 and September 2022, M/S Indospirits recorded a
        turnover of about ₹1,333 crores, earning gross margins of around ₹111
        crores and net distributable profits of ₹47.68 crores, of which nearly
        61% (₹29.29 crores) was transferred to or for the benefit of A-5, far
        exceeding his declared investment and share in the joint venture. The
        prosecution refers to complex fund movements from M/S Indospirits
        to A-5, and from him to A-6 and companies associated with A-4,
        including media and broadcasting firms such as India Ahead News
        Pvt. Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as “IANPL”), Andhra Prabha
        Publication Pvt. Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as “APPL”), CDG

Broadcasting Pvt. Ltd. and Zeus Networking Pvt. Ltd. Certain “loan
        agreements” produced to explain these transfers are alleged to be
        sham, with employees stating that they were made to sign without
        understanding the contents. These transactions, according to the
        prosecution, represent the routing and utilisation of proceeds
        generated from the alleged excise policy scheme.

  11.                      On this foundation, supported, according to the main
        charge-sheet, by witness statements (including that of approver Dinesh
        Arora), banking and corporate records, digital material, CDRs, hotel
        documents and other seized articles, seven persons have been arrayed
        as accused A-1, A-2, A-3, A-4, A-5 A-6 and A-7. It is also stated that
        the requisite sanction for prosecution under Section 19 of the PC Act,
        1988 has been granted in respect of accused public servants A-1 and
        A-2.

        First Supplementary Charge-sheet, dated 25.04.2023 (filed on
        25.04.2023)

  12.                      In the first supplementary charge-sheet, the prosecution
        maintains that A-8, the then Deputy Chief Minister and was heading
        the Excise Department in concert with certain public servants and
        private individuals to improperly influence the framing and
        implementation of the DEP-21/22. It is alleged that the policy was
        steered in a manner intended to benefit a select group of liquor,
        wholesalers and retailers, in return for unlawful gratification.

13.                      The prosecution case is that an Expert Committee
        headed by Sh. Ravi Dhawan submitted its report on 13.10.2020
        recommending continued Government control over wholesale,
        complete privatization of retail vends to individual and allotted
        through lottery and other safeguards to prevent cartelisation.
        According to the CBI, this report was not processed in the normal
        course and was kept aside, as A-8 allegedly intended to follow a
        different model favouring private entities. Public comments were
        invited from 31.12.2020 to 21.01.2021. During this period, it is alleged
        that PW-92 Zakir Khan helped generate fabricated “public feedback”
        emails at the behest of A-8, to create an impression of public support
        for allotment of retail liquor licence through auction, reduction of
        Excise and VAT as well as enhancement of license fee and increase
        in number of liquor vends.

  14.                      A draft Cabinet Note dated 28.01.2021 was thereafter
        prepared, containing the Expert Committee report, public feedback
        and legal opinions from Hon’ble Justice (Retd.) Ranjan Gogoi,
        Hon’ble Justice (Retd.) K.G. Balakrishnan and Senior Advocate Shri
        Mukul Rohatgi obtained by Delhi ALCOBEV Retailer Association, all
        of whom are stated to be in favour of status quo. This file, allegedly,
        was never placed before the Council of Ministers and subsequently
        went missing. Based on the file-movement register, witness statements
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
and digital material, the CBI alleges that the file was last in the
        conscious possession of A-8 and was deliberately removed.

  15.                      It is further alleged that after the disappearance of this
        file, a fresh note was initiated on 02.02.2021, omitting the earlier legal
        opinions, and directions were given to the then Excise Commissioner
        to prepare a new Cabinet Note aligned with A-8 preferred model. On
        05.02.2021, a Group of Ministers (hereinafter be referred to as
        “GoM”) was approved to frame the new regime headed by A-8.
        Although several meetings were claimed to have taken place, no
        formal minutes were maintained and even the Excise Commissioner
        was largely kept out of the core deliberations. Forensic examination of
        computers seized from the office of the Deputy Chief Minister
        allegedly yielded various draft GoM reports, in which he is shown as
        the main author, with edits attributed to him by witnesses. In the
        second draft GoM report dated 19.03.2021, the wholesale margin was
        abruptly increased from 5% to 12% and the eligibility criteria for
        turnover for wholesaler was also increased from Rs. 100 Crore to Rs.
        500 Crore, every year for past 5 years, which is based upon the printout
        of 36 pages taken by member of south group and handed over to A-3
        which was further handed over to A-8.

  16.                      Relying on these drafts, it is alleged that A-8 introduced
        key policy changes, in final GoM report dated 22.03.2021, including
        raising the wholesale margin to 12%, relaxing eligibility norms,

diluting the related-entity restriction and reviving the zonal licensing
        system, and turnover criteria was reduced to Rs. 250 Crore every year
        for past 3 years, contrary to Expert Committee recommendations.
        These changes are alleged to have been made to favour a lobby of
        liquor businessmen referred to as the “South Group”, in pursuance of
        a prior understanding.

  17.                      It is stated that emphasis on the alleged role of A-3 as
        the intermediary between A-8 and the South Group. It is alleged that
        he, along with A-4, A-5, A-6 and A-23, negotiated illegal gratification
        of ₹90-100 crores, part of which was to be routed through hawala.
        Meetings at various hotels and travel records are cited to support this
        allegation. It is further alleged that a draft of the GoM report was
        photocopied at Hotel Oberoi, as reflected in the photocopy logs.

  18.                      A-7 of M/S Indospirits is described as a major
        beneficiary. The prosecution claims that M/S Indospirits was
        structured to represent the South Group, with A-5 holding beneficial
        interest on their behalf. To address cross-ownership concerns, the
        resignation and later induction of Smt. Geetika Mahendru into M/S
        Indospirits are stated to have been used to conceal links with retail
        entities. M/S Indospirits allegedly earned profits of ₹29.29 crores,
        forming part of the funds circulated as bribe money. It is alleged that
        A-3 in the meeting at Hotel Taj on 01.03.2021 with Sh. I.P. Suresh

Menon (PW-101) demanded undue gratification for favourable
        clauses

  19.                      The prosecution also relies on banking records, credit-
        note ledgers and fund flows. A-9 is alleged to have issued un-
        authorised credit notes amounting to ₹4.97 crores to retail firms out of
        which 2.58 Crore to retail firm linked with the South Group, enabling
        cash generation for hawala transfers. Payments from M/S Indospirits
        to media companies linked with A-6 and A-10 are described as sham
        transactions intended to layer the proceeds of crime.

  20.                      A-11 is alleged to have assisted the South Group
        incorporating favorable clauses and to have been involved in policy-
        draft discussions. A confidential Excise Department tender document
        recovered from him is cited to suggest unauthorised access to official
        records.

  21.                      The prosecution further alleges destruction of electronic
        evidence, stating that two mobile phones used by A-8 during the
        relevant period were discarded shortly before he was summoned,
        thereby attracting Section 201 IPC. Digital evidence, such as
        recovered draft policy files, email headers of feedback, WhatsApp
        chats and metadata indicating authorship of drafts, has been produced
        with Section 65-B certification. Sanction for prosecution of the
        concerned public servants has also been obtained.

22.                      On this basis, the prosecution asserts that a prima facie
        case exists that A-8, accused public servants A-1 and A-2, A-3, South
        Group members A-4, A-5, A-6 and A-11, and other private accused
        persons including A-7, A-9 and A-10, entered into a conspiracy
        punishable under Sections 120-B, 420 and 201 of IPC and the
        provisions of Section 7, 7A, 8 and 12 of the PC Act, 1988 to
        manipulate the excise policy for wrongful gain and to conceal or
        destroy material evidence.

        Second Supplementary Charge-sheet (Final Report No. 03), dated
        08.07.2023 (filed on 10.07.2023)

  23.                      The second supplementary charge-sheet (Final Report
        No. 03) dated 08.07.2023 was filed under Section 173 of Cr.P.C in
        continuation of the earlier charge-sheets already submitted in the same
        FIR.

  24.                      The prosecution case is that the DEP-21/22 was
        allegedly manipulated and tweaked with a preconceived design to
        extend undue benefit to certain private persons/entities described as
        the “South Group” and allied intermediaries. It is alleged that such
        purported policy favour was extended in consideration of illegal
        gratification quantified by the agency at approximately ₹90–100
        crores, allegedly paid for the benefit of A-3, described as an associate
        of A-8. It is further alleged that part of the said illegal gratification was
        arranged and routed through hawala/angadiya channels and utilised

for political campaign expenditure, including the Goa Assembly
        Election campaign of 2022.

  25.                      In substance, the supplementary report alleges that
        members of the so-called “South Group”, including A-5, A-4, A-6 and
        their Chartered Accountant/associate A-11, paid illegal gratification
        for being favoured under the policy framework. The alleged policy
        benefits include, inter-alia, enhancement of the wholesaler margin
        from 5% to 12%, adoption of a model allegedly restricting distribution
        to “one wholesaler per manufacturer”, zonal structuring and
        auctioning of vends, and the creation of commercial mechanisms such
        as rebates or credit-notes linked to up-front payments. It is alleged that
        inputs attributed to such private persons found reflection in official
        recommendations and/or appeared in substance in GoM-related
        material, which, according to the prosecution, indicates a direct role of
        south group in policy shaping.

  26.                      It is further alleged that A-9, connected with M/S BSPL,
        facilitated interactions and meetings between A-3 and certain
        stakeholders/manufacturers, and that through business arrangements,
        including additional credit-notes and other transfers, funds were
        generated and channelled, allegedly by way of commission sharing
        and cash transfers, for the benefit of the “South Group” and for onward
        movement through informal channels.

27.                      A central plank of the present supplementary report is
        the alleged diversion and utilisation of a substantial portion of the
        purported illegal gratification for election-related expenditure. It is
        alleged that out of ₹90–100 crores, an amount of approximately
        ₹44.54 crores was utilised for the Aam Aadmi Party’s Goa Assembly
        Election campaign (2022), and that the same was moved from Delhi
        to Goa through hawala/angadiya operators in multiple tranches, using
        different conduits and cash handlers.

  28.                      For this purpose, the supplementary report relies upon
        alleged financial, documentary and digital material, including records
        recovered during Income-tax action in Goa relating to angadiya
        entities, statements of persons connected with such angadiya firms,
        and call-detail records, location data and WhatsApp/digital linkages,
        to suggest coordination in relation to cash transfers. It is alleged that
        cash was routed through various angadiya entities/firms, including
        M/S Asil Corporation and M/S R. Kantilal Finance & Courier
        Services, as well as other Delhi-based channels, and that the recipients
        in Goa included persons stated to be associated with the election
        campaign.

  29.                      It is specifically alleged that A-12 (Director, M/S
        Chariot         Productions    Media   Pvt.   Ltd.),   A-13    and        A-14
        (employees/associates connected with the said media agency), along
        with A-15 (then connected with IANPL) and A-16, acted as conduits

and cash handlers for receiving, transferring and disbursing the alleged
        illegal funds for campaign purposes in Goa Election. The report states
        that cash payments were made to campaign workers, vendors and
        managers in Goa, including towards salaries and logistics, and that the
        aforesaid accused persons were involved in arranging and effecting
        such disbursements in cash.

  30.                      The report further alleges that certain public-relations
        consultants or individuals connected with agencies engaged by the
        Directorate              of   Information   and     Publicity,     GNCTD,          were
        simultaneously utilised for party or campaign work, thereby
        suggesting misuse or diversion of public-funded PR machinery.
        According to the prosecution, such alleged use, when viewed along
        with the purported hawala movement and cash disbursements, forms
        part of the overarching conspiracy said to have arisen from the alleged
        manipulation of the excise policy and the generation of illicit funds.

  31.                      On the basis of the aforesaid allegations and the material
        collected during further investigation, the CBI, through the present
        second        supplementary          charge-sheet    dated       08.07.2023,      seeks
        summoning and trial of the newly arraigned accused i.e. A-12, A-13,
        A-14, A-15 and A-16 for offences alleged to be made out under Section
        120-B IPC and Sections 7, 7A, 8 and 12 of the PC Act, 1988, along
        with allied provisions as set out in the report.

Third Supplementary Charge-sheet, dated 06.06.2024 (filed on
        07.06.2024)

  32.                      The supplementary charge-sheet alleges that A-17
        emerged as a key conspirator in the criminal conspiracy relating to the
        formulation, manipulation and implementation of the DEP-21/22. It is
        alleged that she demanded, collected and caused payment of ₹100
        crores as upfront money to the Aam Aadmi Party for securing
        favourable provisions and business opportunities for liquor
        businessmen from South India. The prosecution relies primarily on the
        statements of Sh. Magunta Sreenivasulu Reddy, (PW-225) his son and
        approver Sh. Raghav Magunta (PW-226), and approver Sh. Dinesh
        Arora (PW-20) to project the demand, payment and utilisation of the
        alleged upfront money.

  33.                      According to the prosecution, A-17 operated through her
        associates A-4, A-5 and A-11, who coordinated with A-3 in furtherance
        of the conspiracy. It is alleged that ₹25 crores out of the upfront money
        was paid in cash by approver Sh. Raghav Magunta, ₹10 crores in
        March 2021 and ₹15 crores in June 2021, through persons identified
        by the said associates, on the demand of A-17, for securing favourable
        provisions in the Excise Policy.

  34.                      The charge-sheet alleges that A-17 was aware of, and
        referred to, the meeting of Sh. Magunta Sreenivasulu Reddy with the
        Chief Minister of Delhi (A-18) on 16.03.2021. It is further alleged that

she conveyed that ₹100 crores was to be paid as upfront money for
        favourable policy provisions.

  35.                      It is alleged that her associates were actively involved at
        the policy-formulation stage and influenced draft GoM Reports,
        resulting in the increase of the wholesaler margin from 5% to 12% and
        the raising of turnover eligibility for L-1 wholesale licences. These
        changes are attributed to A-17 through her associates. The prosecution
        relies on WhatsApp chats recovered from A-11, described as her
        Chartered Accountant and close associate, which allegedly contain
        discussions on policy tweaking, appointment of consultants, repeated
        Delhi visits and structuring of business opportunities. It is alleged that
        the provisions discussed in WhatsApp chats dated 06.03.2021 and
        20.03.2021 were incorporated verbatim in the final GoM Report dated
        22.03.2021.

  36.                      The prosecution further alleges that during the period
        14.03.2021 to 17.03.2021, associates of A-17 stayed at Hotel Oberoi,
        New Delhi, used business-centre facilities, meeting rooms,
        photocopying services and hotel vehicles, and that hotel records, bills,
        vehicle GPS data, mobile phone location analysis and Call Detail
        Records establish coordination between her associates and A-3. It is
        alleged that her associates met A-3 on 14.03.2021 and 16.03.2021,
        coinciding with A-3’s visit to the Chief Minister’s residence where A-8
        was also present.

37.                      It is alleged that M/S PRI appointed M/S Indospirits as
        wholesaler under the influence of A-3, and that pressure was exerted
        on company officials when they were reluctant. The prosecution
        alleges that A-17 held a 32.5% stake in M/S Indospirits through her
        proxy A-5, while approver Sh. Raghav Magunta was also given a
        32.5% stake through his proxy Prem Rahul Manduri (PW-270) in lieu
        of upfront money, with M/S Indospirit Distribution Ltd. holding the
        remaining share. It is alleged that A-17 arranged funds for A-5’s
        investment of ₹3.4 crores in Indospirits, including funds sourced from
        persons stated to be close to her, one of whom allegedly transferred ₹1
        crore on her directions. It is further alleged that her relative received
        payments from Indospirit Distribution Ltd. without commensurate
        work.

  38.                      The charge-sheet alleges that A-17’s role also surfaced
        in the transfer of alleged ill-gotten money to Goa through hawala
        channels for the AAP Goa Assembly Election. It is alleged that her
        associates A-4 and her PA Ashok Kaushik (PW-195) were involved in
        hawala transfers, that A-15 acted as a conduit for transferring ₹7.10
        crores from Delhi to Goa through hawala channels based on statements
        of a hawala operator, and that A-16 received and distributed the money
        in Goa. It is further alleged that ₹30 crores was routed through
        approver Sh. Dinesh Arora via hawala channels, and that Ashok
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
Kaushik collected and delivered multiple bags of cash during June–
        August 2021.

  39.                      It is alleged that A-17 used M/S Indospirits as a vehicle
        to recoup the upfront money and that between January 2022 and
        August 2022, approximately ₹29.29 crores was transferred from M/S
        Indospirits to A-5, representing about 61% of the profits of the firm
        despite his limited capital contribution. It is further alleged that funds
        were further routed from M/S Indospirits through A-5 to A-6 and A-11
        and to A-17.

        (A) POSITION IN LAW---PRINCIPLES FOR APPRECIATING
        PROSECUTION MATERIAL AT THE STAGE OF CHARGE:

        1. Stage of charge: limited scrutiny, but real application of mind

  57.                      At the stage of consideration of charge, the Court is not
        required to undertake a detailed evaluation of evidence or to test the
        probative value of the material as at trial. The Court proceeds on the
        premise that the prosecution material, as presented, is prima facie true
        and uncontroverted. Cross-examination and defence rebuttal are not
        part of this stage. At the same time, the law is equally clear that the
        Court is not to act merely as a post office or a mouthpiece of the
        prosecution. The Court must apply its judicial mind to the record to
        assess whether the material, taken at face value, discloses the essential

ingredients of the alleged offence and raises grave suspicion, as
        distinct from a mere suspicion.

  58.                      The governing principles have been authoritatively
        summarised by the Hon’ble Supreme Court in Sajjan Kumar v. Bureau
        of Investigation (2010) 9 SCC 368. The relevant extract is reproduced
        for ready reference:

               “….21. On consideration of the authorities about the scope of
               Sections 227 and 228 of the Code, the following principles
               emerge:
               (i) The Judge while considering the question of framing the
               charges under Section 227 CrPC has the undoubted power to
               sift and weigh the evidence for the limited purpose of finding
               out whether or not a prima facie case against the accused has
               been made out. The test to determine prima facie case would
               depend upon the facts of each case.
               (ii) Where the materials placed before the court disclose grave
               suspicion against the accused which has not been properly
               explained, the court will be fully justified in framing a charge
               and proceeding with the trial.
               (iii) The court cannot act merely as a post office or a
               mouthpiece of the prosecution but has to consider the broad
               probabilities of the case, the total effect of the evidence and the
               documents produced before the court, any basic infirmities,
               etc. However, at this stage, there cannot be a roving enquiry
               into the pros and cons of the matter and weigh the evidence as
               if he was conducting a trial.
               (iv) If on the basis of the material on record, the court could
               form an opinion that the accused might have committed
               offence, it can frame the charge, though for conviction the
               conclusion is required to be proved beyond reasonable doubt
               that the accused has committed the offence.
               (v) At the time of framing of the charges, the probative value
               of the material on record cannot be gone into but before

framing a charge the court must apply its judicial mind on the
               material placed on record and must be satisfied that the
               commission of offence by the accused was possible.
               (vi) At the stage of Sections 227 and 228, the court is required
               to evaluate the material and documents on record with a view
               to find out if the facts emerging therefrom taken at their face
               value disclose the existence of all the ingredients constituting
               the alleged offence. For this limited purpose, sift the evidence
               as it cannot be expected even at that initial stage to accept all
               that the prosecution states as gospel truth even if it is opposed
               to common sense or the broad probabilities of the case.
               (vii) If two views are possible and one of them gives rise to
               suspicion only, as distinguished from grave suspicion, the trial
               Judge will be empowered to discharge the accused and at this
               stage, he is not to see whether the trial will end in conviction or
               acquittal….”.
  59.                      In essence, the Court must examine whether the
        prosecution material, if taken at face value and accepted in its entirety,
        discloses a prima facie case giving rise to grave suspicion. If such
        grave suspicion exists, that suffices for framing of charge. Conversely,
        if the material discloses only a mere suspicion and not grave suspicion,
        discharge follows. At this stage, the Court is required to see whether
        the material, if uncontroverted, discloses the essential ingredients of
        the alleged offences.

        2. Strong suspicion: must be based on material capable of becoming
        evidence

  60.                      Recently, the Hon’ble Supreme Court in Tuhin Kumar
        Bishwas @ Bumba v. State of West Bengal, 2025 SCC OnLine SC
        2604 reiterated that, absent a strong suspicion founded on material

capable of becoming evidence, an accused can be discharged, while
        emphasising that the Court must outline and apply the settled
        principles governing discharge/charge.

  61.                      The decision, after referring to Ram Prakash Chadha v.
        State of UP (2024) 10 SCC 651 and earlier authorities including Stree
        Atyachar Virodhi Parishad v. Dilip Nathumal Chordia (1989) 1 SCC
        715, P. Vijayan v. State of Kerala (2010) 2 SCC 398, and Union of
        India v. Prafulla Kumar Samal (1979) 3 SCC 4, reiterates that the
        “ground” under Section 227 of CrPC is not a ground for conviction
        but a ground for putting the accused on trial, and that where two views
        are possible and one gives rise only to suspicion and not grave
        suspicion, the Court is empowered to discharge.

  62.                      The said judgment also cites with approval M.E.
        Shivalingamurthy v. CBI, Bengaluru (2020) 2 SCC 768, which
        summarises that:

        (i) if two views are possible and one gives rise to suspicion only, as
        distinguished from grave suspicion, discharge is justified;
        (ii) the Court is not a mere post office;
        (iii) the Court sifts the statements/documents produced by the
        prosecution to see if there is sufficient ground to proceed;
        (iv) if the evidence proposed, even if fully accepted, cannot show
        commission of offence, there is no sufficient ground for trial; and
        (v) there must exist some material for entertaining a strong suspicion
        which can form the basis for drawing up a charge.

63.                      Thus, while the threshold at this stage is not proof
        beyond reasonable doubt, the suspicion required must still be strong
        and grounded in material, and not in conjecture or narrative
        convenience.

        4. Documentary material: file notings and policy deliberations

  64.                      A substantial part of prosecutions arising out of policy
        decisions centres on internal file notings, administrative observations,
        and governmental deliberations. Such notings, by their nature, record
        internal discussions and divergent views. They do not, without more,
        constitute incriminating material, nor do they indicate dishonest
        intention or an overt criminal act.

  65.                      The mere fact that a policy may not have yielded the
        expected results cannot, in the absence of substantive evidence, be
        elevated to criminal culpability. Criminal law cannot be invoked to
        revisit or punish administrative discretion, particularly when the
        record shows that the actions in question were confined to policy
        formulation and implementation undertaken in the ordinary course of
        governance.

  66.                      While a detailed evaluation of evidence is impermissible
        at the stage of charge, it is equally true that where the case is
        predominantly documentary and rests substantially on internal notings

and policy papers, the Court must undertake the limited scrutiny
        mandated by law to ensure that criminal process is not employed as a
        vehicle to challenge executive decisions under the guise of
        prosecution. The Court is therefore required to see whether the
        documents relied upon, taken at face value, disclose the ingredients of
        the alleged offences, and whether there exists independent material
        pointing to mens rea, quid pro quo, or abuse of office, beyond mere
        administrative processing.

        5. Policy decisions: limits of criminal prosecution

  67.                      In a developing economy, policy changes are routine and
        often necessary for increasing revenue, improving regulatory
        frameworks, or advancing public welfare objectives. Policies
        concerning licensing, taxation, distribution models, privatisation, or
        private participation inherently involve the exercise of executive
        discretion. The mere circumstance that a particular policy does not
        yield the expected outcomes, or that private participants lawfully earn
        profits under such policy, cannot, without more, justify criminal
        prosecution.

  68.                      It is now well settled that economic and administrative
        decisions taken in good faith cannot be criminalised in the absence of
        clear prima facie material disclosing mala fides, quid pro quo, or abuse
        of office. Accordingly, while appreciating prosecution material at the
        stage of charge in policy-related matters, the Court must maintain a

clear distinction between an allegation which is essentially a critique
        of policy wisdom or an administrative lapse, and an allegation
        supported by material indicating corruption or conspiracy.

  69.                      To assess the limits of criminal liability in matters
        involving formulation of government policy, the Court must also bear
        in mind the internal architecture of governmental decision-making,
        which is regulated by the Transaction of Business Rules, the
        Allocation Rules, and the Central Secretariat Manual of Office
        Procedure. These instruments structure how proposals are initiated,
        how files move, how consultations are undertaken, and how decisions
        are recorded, thereby ensuring orderly governance, institutional
        discipline, and traceability of decision-making.

  70.                      The Transaction of Business of the Government of
        National Capital Territory of Delhi Rules, 1993 (ToBDR), prescribe
        the manner in which the business of the Government is to be transacted
        and identify matters requiring consideration at different institutional
        levels. This framework incorporates mandatory consultations,
        institutional checks, identification of matters requiring prior approval
        or submission, and structured movement of files through a prescribed
        hierarchy. These rules are intended to ensure orderly governance and
        collective responsibility. They are not penal provisions. A deviation
        from procedure may, at the highest, amount to an administrative lapse,

but cannot, by itself, be treated as criminal misconduct unless
        accompanied by prima facie material indicating dishonest intent.

  71.                      Similarly, the Business of Delhi (Allocation) Rules,
        1993, distribute subjects across departments and identify the
        department competent to initiate and process a policy, as well as the
        authority responsible for approval. Where a policy is framed and
        processed by the competent department in accordance with these
        Rules, its initiation cannot be criminalised merely because it reflects a
        new, reform-oriented, or revenue-driven approach.

  72.                      The Central Secretariat Manual of Office Procedure
        (CSMOP) governs file management and the mechanics of
        administration, including recording of notings, drafting of proposals,
        inter-departmental consultations, and preservation of records. Its
        purpose is to ensure transparency, uniformity, and traceability in
        governmental functioning. Non-compliance with administrative
        procedure, in the absence of material showing corrupt intent, does not
        by itself constitute a criminal offence.

  73.                      From the standpoint of criminal liability, policy-
        formulation cases broadly fall into three categories. The first category
        relates to alleged violations of statutory rules or mandatory procedure.
        Criminal liability may arise only where the prosecution is able to
        prima facie demonstrate deliberate and conscious bypassing of
        mandatory procedural safeguards, actions taken by a department

outside its competence, or suppression or manipulation of material
        notings or consultations. Even in such cases, a procedural deviation
        alone is insufficient; there must be material indicating dishonest
        intention.

  74.                      The second category concerns cases of formal procedural
        compliance masking mala fide intent. There may be situations where
        the file movement appears regular, the competent department acts
        within its jurisdiction, and the prescribed procedural route is
        ostensibly followed. However, if the substance of the policy, viewed
        in light of the material placed on record, prima facie demonstrates that
        it was consciously designed to confer undue advantage upon specific
        private parties, criminal prosecution may be justified, provided such
        intent is supported by cogent and independent material, and not merely
        inferred from the outcome of the policy.

  75.                      The third and most common category concerns bona fide
        policy decisions unaccompanied by evidence of corruption. This is
        where the prescribed procedure is followed, the competent department
        initiates and processes the proposal, file movement is transparent, and
        there is no prima facie indication of quid pro quo, personal benefit, or
        collusion. In such cases, the policy decision is protected as a bona fide
        exercise of administrative discretion. The wisdom, efficacy, or
        eventual success or failure of a policy is not a matter for criminal
        adjudication. Administrative errors or incorrect judgments, without

material        suggesting    corrupt   intent,   cannot   attract    criminal
        prosecution.

  76.                      Certain broader guardrails must also inform the Court’s
        approach in policy-related prosecutions. Policy formulation is
        inherently experimental; a policy may succeed or fail, and failure by
        itself is not evidence of criminality. Profit earned by private
        participants is not illegal per se; it becomes suspect only when it is
        shown to flow from collusion, undue favour, or manipulation of
        process. The Transaction of Business Rules, Allocation Rules, and the
        Central Secretariat Manual of Office Procedure are mechanisms of
        accountability and institutional discipline; their purpose is to structure
        decision-making, not to convert administrative infractions into
        criminal misconduct. Above all, criminal liability continues to require
        mens rea. Excessive criminalisation of policy decisions risks
        paralysing governance, as decision-makers may be deterred from
        taking bona fide decisions in public interest.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

  77.                      Accordingly, where a policy is initiated by the
        department competent under the Allocation Rules, processed through
        the structured mechanism mandated by the Transaction of Business
        Rules, and reflects transparent file movement in accordance with the
        Central Secretariat Manual of Office Procedure, its framers, whether
        bureaucratic or political, cannot be subjected to criminal prosecution

merely because the policy did not yield the expected results or because
        private entities lawfully earned profit under it. Criminal prosecution is
        justified only where the material discloses either a conscious and
        deliberate violation of mandatory procedure coupled with dishonest
        intent, or dishonest or collusive intent camouflaged behind formal
        procedural compliance. In the absence of these elements, the domain
        of policy-making remains a matter of governance, not criminal
        liability.

        6.     Bribe / upfront / kickback allegations: what must prima facie
        appear

  78.                      Where the prosecution alleges that file movement and
        policy decision-making were influenced by bribes, upfront payments,
        or kickbacks, the Court must examine whether the prosecution
        material, even if accepted as true at this stage, discloses:

        (i) a prima facie demand/arrangement/payment and its linkage to an
        official act;
        (ii) a discernible quid pro quo;
        (iii) a nexus between the alleged gratification and the policy clauses or
        file outcomes; and
        (iv) material connecting the accused to such influence, beyond
        assumptions arising from the existence of file notings or the eventual
        policy outcome.
  79.                      In such cases, file movement and policy documentation
        may provide context, but cannot substitute the requirement of prima
        facie material indicating corrupt intent. Absent such linkage, a

prosecution founded largely on administrative record risks converting
        governance review into criminal adjudication.

        7.    Conspiracy in policy/economic cases: agreement is the core

  80.                      The Court is conscious that criminal conspiracy is rarely
        proved by direct evidence and may be inferred from surrounding
        circumstances. However, the difficulty in proving conspiracy does not
        dilute the threshold even at this stage. The Court must assess whether
        the record discloses grave suspicion of a conscious agreement to
        commit an illegal act or to achieve a lawful object by illegal means,
        and not merely conjecture or suspicion.

  81.                      This   scrutiny   assumes   particular   importance          in
        prosecutions arising from policy formulation or regulatory reform.
        Policy outcomes often result from multi-tier institutional processes
        involving consultations, departmental inputs, Cabinet-level decisions,
        and statutory/constitutional oversight. Criminal law cannot be used to
        retrospectively criminalise policy choices or market consequences
        unless the prosecution is able to prima facie demonstrate a meeting of
        minds to subvert the policy framework for an unlawful purpose.

  82.                      The gravamen of Section 120-B IPC lies in the
        agreement itself. Economic gain, uneven commercial outcomes, or
        subsequent profitability cannot, by themselves, constitute conspiracy.
        What must prima facie emerge is consensus ad idem: who agreed with

whom, what illegal act or illegal means was agreed upon, when the
        agreement arose, and how subsequent acts were in furtherance of that
        agreement. Where the narrative rests on fragmented circumstances and
        invites the Court to “join the dots” by presumption, the legal threshold
        is not met.

  83.                       Upon considering the material placed on record for the
        limited purpose of framing of charge, it is often seen that the
        prosecution seeks to project its case as a coherent and well-knitted
        narrative. While it may superficially appear so, a closer examination
        within the contours permitted at this stage may reveal that facts have
        been arranged to support a predetermined conclusion. The Court is
        required to guard against being carried by presentation alone, and must
        instead test whether the record discloses a consistent and legally
        sustainable sequence suggestive of the commission of an offence.
        Reliance is placed upon the judgment of Hon’ble Supreme Court in
        case       titled        as   Karnataka   vs.   L.   Muniswamy     and        Ors.
        MANU/SC/0143/1977.

  84.                       Where the prosecution relies on circumstantial evidence,
        the alleged chain of circumstances must, even at this preliminary stage,
        appear prima facie continuous and legally coherent. When such
        material is tested against settled principles, the chain cannot be
        incomplete, fragile, or dependent upon conjectural inferences. Several

links cannot rest on speculative extrapolations rather than established
        facts.

  85.                      Where     the     prosecution   substantially     relies        on
        circumstantial           evidence,    the   settled   principles      governing
        circumstantial proof squarely applies. The law mandates that:

        (i) the circumstances relied upon must be fully established;
        (ii) they must be consistent only with the guilt of the accused;
        (iii) they must exclude every reasonable hypothesis of innocence; and
        (iv) the chain must be so complete as to leave no reasonable ground
        for a conclusion consistent with innocence.
  86.                      If the record falls significantly short and does not even
        give rise to credible suspicion, the criminal process cannot be
        permitted to continue merely to see whether something may emerge at
        trial. Meetings, communications, and tower-location indicators, often
        relied upon in such cases, are frequently neutral in policy contexts.
        Meetings between stakeholders and officials may be consistent with
        consultation and governance. Tower-location/CDR indicators, even
        when admissible, indicate approximate presence and do not establish
        the purpose or content of interaction. They cannot be used as
        substitutes for evidence of agreement, nor can they be employed to
        bridge substantive gaps in the alleged conspiratorial chain.

  87.                      The proposition that conspiracies are “hatched in
        secrecy” cannot be stretched to justify dilution of standards in policy-

related prosecutions where the process is typically documented and
        traceable. To allege a secret unlawful agreement within such a
        framework, the prosecution must prima facie show how institutional
        procedure was subverted pursuant to a prior meeting of minds.
        Otherwise, secrecy remains a rhetorical explanation rather than a
        legally sustainable inference.

  88.                      Tested on this anvil, the prosecution material, at the
        threshold stage, must prima facie disclose:

        (i) the identity of the alleged conspirators inter se, namely, who agreed
        with whom;
        (ii) the content of the alleged agreement, namely, what precise illegal
        act or illegal means was agreed upon;
        (iii) the temporal and causal linkage, namely, when such agreement
        was formed and how subsequent acts were in furtherance thereof;
        and
        (iv) the exclusion of innocent hypotheses, namely, how the
        circumstances relied upon are incompatible with lawful, neutral, or
        institutional explanations.
  89.                      In the absence of these foundational elements, the
        allegation of conspiracy remains indeterminate and amorphous,
        lacking the legal specificity required even at the threshold stage.

        8. Scrutiny of statements and documents

  90.                      Ultimately, at the stage of charge, the Court’s role is
        neither to conduct a trial nor to accept the prosecution narrative as

gospel truth. Justice at this stage is achieved by a disciplined scrutiny
        of the statements and documents relied upon by the prosecution, to see
        whether, if accepted as they stand, they disclose the ingredients of the
        alleged offences and raise grave suspicion warranting trial.

  91.                      Where the record consists predominantly of file notings,
        administrative           observations,   policy   papers,   and     subsequent
        commercial outcomes, with allegations of bribe, upfront money,
        kickbacks, and conspiracy superimposed upon such material, the
        Court needs to be careful to identify whether the prosecution has
        placed independent incriminating material linking the accused to
        corrupt intent and unlawful agreement, as distinct from a critique of
        governance or a disagreement with policy choices. If the material
        discloses only a possible suspicion, and not grave suspicion, the law
        empowers the Court to discharge; if it discloses grave suspicion
        grounded in material capable of becoming evidence, charge may
        follow.

        (B) Nature of Witness Statements and the Manner of Their
        Appreciation at the Stage of Charge

  92.                      At the stage of consideration of charge, the Court is
        required to examine whether the prosecution material, if taken at its
        face value, discloses prima facie suspicion against the accused as
        would justify putting them to trial. For this limited purpose, the Court
        must first identify the nature of the statements relied upon, because the

evidentiary character of each category is not identical, and the degree
        of reliance that can be placed at this stage depends upon that
        character.

  93.                      On a careful assessment of the record, it is apparent that
        the prosecution material broadly comprises three types of statements,
        each requiring separate appreciation:

                           First, there are statements of general witnesses, i.e.,
        witnesses who claim awareness of facts relevant to the case but who
        are not themselves participants in the alleged offence. Their statements
        are to be examined in the ordinary course as prosecution evidence,
        keeping in view the limitations of scrutiny at this stage.

                           Second, there are statements of pardoned accused
        persons, commonly referred to as approver statement. Such statement,
        as emerging from the record, appears in three sub-forms:
        (i) Pre pardon confessional statement-the confessional statement
        recorded under Section 164 of Cr.P.C., wherein the witness, before the
        Judicial Magistrate, discloses his own involvement and also implicates
        co-accused; (ii) Post pardon confessional statement-the confessional
        statement recorded under section 306 (4) of Cr.P.C. during
        investigation and after grant of pardon and (iii) other statements of
        similar narrative recorded before or after the grant of pardon under
        Section 161 of Cr.P.C. during investigation.

Third, there are statements of those witnesses who, while
        not shown as accused and not granted pardon, nevertheless make
        statements which are incriminating both to themselves and to the
        accused persons. Such witnesses occupy a distinct position, because
        they are not treated by the prosecution as accused, yet their versions
        disclose self-incriminating participation, and their statement must
        therefore be appreciated with due caution.

  94.                      The Court finds it necessary to analyse the evidentiary
        worth of the above categories in order to answer the central question:
        whether the prosecution has been able to cross the threshold of prima
        facie case for the purpose of framing of charge.

        1. Statement of the Approver

        (a) Confession Recorded Under Section 306 (4) of Cr.P.C. in terms of
        Section 164 of Cr.P.C. of an accused who has been granted pardon

  95.                      At the stage of consideration of charge, where the
        prosecution places predominant reliance upon the statement of
        approvers, the Court is required to assess such material within a clearly
        settled statutory and jurisprudential framework. The issue is not
        confined to admissibility alone, but extends to the sufficiency and
        probative worth of such statement at the threshold stage. The central
        enquiry, therefore, is how the evidence of an approver is to be
        evaluated at the stage of framing of charge, and whether such

statement, standing by itself, is capable of sustaining the continuation
        of criminal proceedings against an accused. The answer necessarily
        lies in a correct appreciation of the concept of an accomplice or
        particeps criminis, read alongside the provisions of the Indian
        Evidence Act, 1872, the Cr.P.C., 1973, and the Delhi High Court Rules
        and Orders.

  96.                      The expression “accomplice” or particeps criminis is a
        well-recognised concept in criminal jurisprudence and comprehends
        all persons who consciously participate in the commission of an
        offence, irrespective of the degree, nature, or mode of such
        participation. Participation may take the form of principal offending,
        abetment, conspiracy, or assistance before or after the fact. Though the
        Indian Evidence Act does not define the term “accomplice”, judicial
        interpretation has consistently held that any person knowingly and
        voluntarily associated with the commission of the offence falls within
        its sweep.

  97.                      Where such persons are prosecuted together, they
        assume the procedural status of co-accused and may be tried jointly in
        terms of Section 223 of the Cr.P.C, 1973. This procedural description,
        however, does not dilute or alter the substantive character of their
        involvement. In essence and in law, they continue to remain
        accomplices whose association with the crime is either admitted or
        alleged.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
98.                      A material procedural shift occurs when one such co-
        accused is tendered pardon under Section 306 of Cr.P.C. Upon
        acceptance of pardon and subject to the statutory obligation of making
        a full and true disclosure, such person ceases to be an accused for the
        purposes of trial and is examined as a prosecution witness, commonly
        described as an approver or government approver. From that stage
        onwards, he is removed from the array of accused persons and enjoys
        immunity from prosecution so long as the pardon remains operative.

  99.            This procedural transformation, however, does not efface or
        neutralise the substantive character of the approver as an accomplice.
        The grant of pardon itself proceeds on the admitted participation of the
        approver in the offence. The change is confined to his position in the
        trial process and does not elevate his statement to that of an
        independent or untainted witness. It is well settled that an approver is
        merely an accomplice who has been granted conditional immunity,
        and       his      statement   must,   therefore,   be     approached         with
        circumspection.

                                                                 (emphasis supplied)

  100.                     Judicial exposition has also recognised that participation
        in crime may occur in different forms. An accomplice broadly
        classified as principals in the first degree, principals in the second
        degree, accessories before the fact, and accessories after the fact, each
        category reflecting a distinct mode of conscious association with the

criminal act. This classification only reinforces the breadth of the
       concept and the reason why accomplice evidence has traditionally
       been viewed with caution.

  101.                     Against this settled legal backdrop, the Court, at the
       stage of framing of charge, is required to examine whether the material
       placed on record discloses a prima facie case giving rise to grave
       suspicion against the accused. While the standard at this stage is not
       that of proof beyond reasonable doubt, it is equally settled that the
       Court is not to function as a mere post office for the prosecution. A
       real, though limited, application of judicial mind is required to
       determine whether the material rises above conjecture or mere
       suspicion.

  102.                     Where the prosecution case rests substantially, or indeed
       exclusively, on the statement of an approver, this duty of scrutiny
       assumes greater significance. An approver is a witness who has
       admittedly bargained for pardon and immunity from prosecution. His
       statement is, therefore, inherently self-interested. If the incriminating
       material consists solely of the uncorroborated statement of such a
       witness, it cannot ordinarily be regarded as sufficient to justify the
       framing of charge. To hold otherwise would be to accept that a single
       statement of a tainted witness, motivated by the prospect of immunity,
       is adequate to subject an accused to the rigours of a full criminal
       trial.

(emphasis supplied)

  103.                     The position in law at this stage is well settled. If two
       views are reasonably possible on the material before the Court, and the
       view favourable to the accused gives rise only to suspicion and not to
       grave suspicion, the accused is entitled to discharge. An
       uncorroborated approver’s statement, unsupported by independent
       material on material particulars, ordinarily remains within the realm
       of mere suspicion. It assumes the character of grave suspicion only
       when reinforced by credible, independent evidence tending to connect
       the accused with the offence.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

  104.                     The Supreme Court, in Ravinder Singh v. State of
       Haryana (1975) 3 SCC 742, characterised an approver as “a most
       unworthy friend, if at all”, and emphasised that a witness who has
       bargained for immunity must affirmatively establish his credibility.
       The Court laid down a two-fold test for appreciation of approver
       evidence: first, the approver’s narrative must implicate himself and
       present a natural, coherent, and probable account of events; secondly,
       once this threshold is crossed, his statement insofar as it implicates
       others must inspire reasonable assurance of guilt. While recognising
       that, in rare cases, a conviction may rest on uncorroborated approver
       statement if it is found wholly reliable, the ordinary and salutary rule

remains that such statement must be corroborated in material
       particulars.

  105.                     This approach reflects long-standing judicial experience.
       Accomplice evidence has consistently been regarded as inherently
       unsafe. An accomplice is a particeps criminis, a witness tainted by his
       own involvement in the offence and burdened by an ongoing incentive
       to minimise his own role, exaggerate the role of others, or mould his
       narrative to suit the prosecution in the hope of securing or retaining
       the benefit of pardon. This structural unreliability is grounded in the
       practical realities of criminal prosecution.

  106.                     Illustration (b) to Section 114 of the Indian Evidence Act
       embodies this accumulated judicial wisdom by recognising that an
       accomplice is ordinarily unworthy of credit unless corroborated in
       material particulars. Though Section 133 of the Evidence Act declares
       that a conviction founded on uncorroborated accomplice statement is
       not illegal, Illustration (b) to Section 114 governs the manner in which
       such evidence is to be appreciated. The Supreme Court, in Bhiva
       Doulu Patil v. State of Maharashtra (AIR 1963 SC 599), reconciled
       these provisions by holding that while Section 133 lays down a rule of
       law, Section 114(b) embodies a rule of prudence which courts are
       bound to observe in practice. Corroboration, therefore, is not a matter
       of indulgence but a practical necessity.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

107.                     It is equally well settled that, in the absence of
       independently established foundational facts, the statement of an
       approver cannot, by its own force, assume the status of legally
       sustainable incriminating material. An approver’s statement is not
       substantive evidence in the ordinary sense; it is evidence of a tainted
       character, received on the premise that the prosecution has first laid a
       factual foundation demonstrating the existence of the alleged crime.
       Where such foundational facts are absent, the approver’s statement
       does not fill the evidentiary vacuum; it merely exposes it.

                                                             (emphasis supplied)

  108.                     This principle assumes particular importance in complex
       economic or policy-related prosecutions involving multiple alleged
       components, such as manipulation of policy, payment of illegal
       gratification, generation and laundering of proceeds of crime, and
       utilisation of such proceeds. Each allegation constitutes a distinct
       factual assertion requiring independent substantiation through
       objective material, including contemporaneous official records,
       statutory documents, financial trails, or statement of untainted
       witnesses. In the absence of such primary material, the approver’s
       version remains a narrative superstructure unsupported by a factual
       base. Law does not permit the superstructure to substitute the
       foundation.

109.                     An approver may corroborate facts otherwise proved; he
       cannot be the source from which the very existence of those facts is
       presumed. If alleged policy manipulation is not borne out from official
       records, if no contemporaneous material evidences the demand,
       quantification, payment, or receipt of illegal gratification, or if
       financial transactions stand explained by documentary commercial
       records, an approver’s ipse dixit cannot displace objective evidence.
       The same principle applies with equal force to allegations of money
       laundering and political utilisation of funds, where the existence of
       proceeds of crime and a demonstrable money trail are foundational
       requirements.

                                                             (emphasis supplied)

  110.                     The infirmity is further aggravated by the admitted
       position that the approver is himself a participant in the alleged offence
       and stands to gain personal liberty by turning approver. His statement
       is therefore inherently self-serving. Where the prosecution has failed
       to first establish the corpus of the alleged crime, the approver’s
       statement degenerates into a narrative aimed at deflecting personal
       culpability.

  111.                     Permitting an uncorroborated approver’s statement to
       substitute for foundational facts would invert settled principles of
       criminal jurisprudence. It would legitimise a process where arrest
       precedes proof, narrative precedes evidence, and facts are sought to be

moulded to fit a confession. Criminal law does not countenance such
       an approach. The existence of the offence, the participation of the
       accused, and the requisite mens rea must be demonstrated through
       objective material before the Court can legitimately form even a prima
       facie view.

  112.                     Viewed thus, the statement of an approver, standing
       alone and unsupported by independent corroboration, does not
       ordinarily disclose legally sustainable incriminating material at the
       stage of charge. At best, it gives rise to suspicion; it does not generate
       grave suspicion. To treat such statement as sufficient even at the
       threshold would be to substitute sufficient ground to proceed with
       narrative convenience, an approach wholly alien to criminal
       jurisprudence and destructive of the rule of law.

       (b) Statements Recorded Under Section 161 of Cr.P.C. of an approver
       after grant of pardon and its evidentiary value:

  113.                     The Court observes that, in the instant matter,
       notwithstanding the recording of the confessional statement of the
       approver under Section 164 of the Cr.P.C. before the Ld. Judicial
       Magistrate, and subsequent to the recording of the approver’s
       statement under Section 306(4) of the CrPC following the grant of
       pardon, the investigating agency has proceeded to record multiple
       supplementary statements of the same approver under Section 161 of
       the CrPC. This gives rise to an important issue for the purpose of

evidentiary appreciation at the stage of charge: how are such Section
       161 statements to be classified, and what weight can they carry?

  114.                     To answer this, the Court considers the legal position by
       applying a simple test: what would have been the evidentiary position
       if the person had not been granted pardon at all?

  115.                     If the person had not been granted pardon, he would
       have remained a co-accused and faced trial. In such a situation: (i) his
       confession would have been treated only as a confession of a co-
       accused within the limited scope of Section 30 of the Evidence Act;
       and (ii) any confession or incriminating statement made to police, or
       in police custody, would attract the bar under Sections 25 and 26 of
       the Evidence Act, rendering such confession inadmissible, except to
       the limited extent permitted by law.

  116.                   The Court notes that the evidentiary value of a co-accused
       confession is inherently weak. Such confession is not substantive
       evidence and does not even fall within the ordinary definition of
       “evidence” in the manner in which statement of a witness does. It can
       be used only in a limited way: where there is independent evidence
       against the accused which, if believed, is sufficient to support
       conviction, then the confession of the co-accused may be used only as
       an additional circumstance and not as the foundation.

117.                     It is for this reason that it is well settled that a charge
       cannot be framed solely on the confession of a co-accused, since such
       confession is not the kind of evidence which can, by itself, create grave
       suspicion. The same logic applies to confessional statements recorded
       by police in custody. Such statements are inadmissible in law, and the
       inadmissibility does not depend on what status the maker later
       acquires. The inadmissibility flows from the source and manner of
       recording. Therefore, what was inadmissible or legally weak when the
       maker was a co-accused cannot be elevated into stronger incriminating
       material merely because later he is tendered pardon. Reliance is placed
       upon the judgment of Hon’ble Supreme Court in case titled as Suresh
       Budharmal Kalani vs. State of Maharashtra, (1998) 7 SCC 337.

  118.                     This is precisely why the law contemplates that pardon
       is tendered on the basis of a disclosure under Section 164 of CrPC, and
       not on the basis of a police statement under Section 161 of CrPC. The
       Court, therefore, observes, confined strictly to statements recorded
       under Section 161 of CrPC, that what was not admissible or reliable
       as confessional material earlier cannot become admissible or reliable
       merely due to the grant of pardon.

                                                                (emphasis supplied)

  119.                     Accordingly, the Court holds that the statements of an
       approver recorded under Section 161 of CrPC, insofar as they contain
       self-incriminating           or    co-accused-incriminating       confessional

assertions, cannot be automatically treated at par with the approver’s
       judicial disclosure. Even if the Court were to look at them, their
       evidentiary worth would remain closer to the limited value attached to
       co-accused confession-type material and cannot be elevated to the
       same plane as approver statement in its proper form.

  120.                     The Court further notes that if, after pardon, the
       approver is again examined before a Magistrate under Section 164 of
       CrPC, then such statement may fall within the category of approver
       disclosure having a distinct footing. This distinction is material
       because approver statement, when properly recorded and later tested,
       carries a higher evidentiary value than a mere police statement.

  121.                     Recently, the Hon’ble Supreme Court has crystallised
       the legal position governing the evidentiary value of statements
       recorded under Section 161 of the Cr.P.C., the treatment of inculpatory
       and exculpatory statements attributed to an accused, and the
       confession of a co-accused, in the case titled P. Krishna Mohan Reddy
       v. State of Andhra Pradesh, 2025 SCC OnLine SC 1157, and has
       observed that:-

               “53…. From the above exposition of law, the following
               emerges:—
               (i) A person who is accused of an offence or named in the
               first information report, can be examined by the police and
               his statement may be recorded under Section 161 of the Cr.
               P.C., as held in Nandini Satpathy (supra).
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
(ii) A statement of an accused under Section 161 of the Cr.
               P.C., would ordinarily be of two kinds, it may be inculpatory in
               nature or may be exculpatory in nature.
               (iii) An inculpatory statement again may be in the form of an
               admission or a confession. If such statement admits either a
               gravely incriminating fact or substantially all the facts which
               constitute the offence, respectively, as held in Pakala Narayana
               Swami (supra), then it amounts to confession.
               (iv) Where such police statement of an accused is confessional
               statement, the rigour of Section(s) 25 and 26 respectively will
               apply with all its vigour. A confessional statement of an
               accused will only be admissible if it is not hit by Section(s) 24
               or 25 respectively and is in tune with the provisions of
               Section(s) 26, 28 and 29 of the Evidence Act respectively. In
               other words, a police statement of an accused which is in the
               form of a confession is per se inadmissible and no reliance
               whatsoever can be placed on such statements either at the stage
               of bail or during trial. Since such confessional statements are
               rendered inadmissible by virtue of Section 25 of the Evidence
               Act, the provision of Section 30 would be of no avail, and no
               reliance can be placed on such confessional statement of an
