               accused to implicate another co-accused.
               (v) A confessional statement of one accused implicating
               another co-accused may be taken into consideration by the
               court against such co-accused in terms of Section 30 of
               the Evidence Act, only at the stage of trial, where (1) the
               confession itself was relevant and admissible in terms of the
               Evidence Act; (2) was duly proved against the
               maker; (3) such confessional statement incriminates the maker
               along with the co-accused and; (4) both the accused persons in
               question are in a joint trial for the same offence.
               (vi) Furthermore, because such confessional statements are not
               “evidence” in terms of Section 3 of the Evidence Act as held
               in Bhuboni Sahu (supra), such a confession as held
               in Kashmira Singh (supra) can only be pressed into
               consideration by the court as a rule of prudence, to lend
               assurance to the other evidence against such co-accused,
               provided that aforesaid ingredients or conditions of Section

30 read with Section(s) 24 to 29 of the Evidence Act, are
               fulfilled.
               (vii) Where the police statement of an accused is in the form of
               an admission, such inculpatory statement even if it implicates
               another co-accused cannot be taken into consideration against
               such co-accused in terms of Section(s) 17 read with 21 of
               the Evidence Act, as doing so would militate against the
               general principle, that an admission may be given as evidence
               against the maker alone. The exceptions to the aforesaid
               general principle carved out under the Evidence Act, do not
               permit the usage of such admission against a co-accused in any
               scenario whatsoever.
               (viii) Where the police statement of the accused is an
               exculpatory statement i.e., it is neither a confession nor an
               admission, the statement being one under Section 161, would
               immediately attract the bar under Section 162 of the Cr. P.C.,
               and the same may be used only for the very limited purpose
               provided in the Proviso for the purpose of contradiction or re-
               examination of such accused person alone, as held in Mahabir
               Mandal (supra). Even if such exculpatory statement of one
               accused, implicates another co-accused, the same cannot be
               taken into consideration against such co-accused, as there can
               be no credibility attached to an exculpatory statement of an
               accused implicating another co-accused, more particularly
               because it is neither required to be given on oath, nor in the
               presence of the co-accused, the same cannot be tested by cross-
               examination and the exculpatory nature of such statement
               militates against the foundational principle that permits taking
               into consideration a statement of one accused person against
               another co-accused as explained in Bhuboni Sahu (supra), i.e.,
               ‘when a person admits guilt to its fullest extent either to a
               certain incriminating fact or substantially all the facts which
               constitute the offence, and in doing so exposes himself and in
               the process other co-accused persons to the pain and penalties
               provided for the guilt, there exists a sincerity and semblance of
               sanction for the truthfulness of such statement….”.

122.                     At this stage, it becomes necessary for the Court to
       clearly understand and delineate the legal distinction between a
       “confession” and an “admission”, particularly in the context of
       statements of an accused recorded by the police under Section 161 of
       the Cr.P.C.

  123.                     A confession is a statement by an accused which
       amounts to an admission of the offence itself, or at least of
       substantially all the facts which constitute the offence. In other words,
       a confession is a direct acknowledgment of guilt. An admission, on the
       other hand, stands on a different footing. An admission does not
       amount to acceptance of guilt for the offence as a whole, but relates
       only to the acknowledgment of one or more gravely incriminating
       facts which may form part of the prosecution case. This distinction has
       been judicially recognised, including in Pakala Narayana Swami v.
       Emperor, (1939) PC 47, where it was emphasised that every
       incriminating statement is not a confession.

  124.                     The legal consequences flowing from this distinction are
       significant. It is well settled that even a confession made by one
       accused cannot be used against a co-accused, except within the limited
       scope of Section 30 of the Indian Evidence Act, and that too only if
       the strict conditions prescribed therein are satisfied.

  125.                     As a natural corollary, any statement made by an
       accused under Section 161 of Cr.P.C. which merely amounts to an

admission, that is, an acknowledgment of an incriminating fact or a
       statement implicating another person, would be governed by Section
       17 of the Evidence Act, read with the settled prohibition on the use of
       admissions against third parties. Such an admission is relevant, if at
       all, only against its maker, and even then subject to the statutory
       limitations governing police-recorded statements.

  126.                     It is trite law that an admission made by one accused
       cannot be used as evidence against another co-accused. The law does
       not permit the prosecution to rely upon statements of an accused,
       recorded by the police under Section 161 of Cr.P.C., to implicate a co-
       accused. Such statements are not substantive evidence and are hit by
       the well-established restrictions contained in the Evidence Act.

  127.                     Therefore, any statement of an accused recorded under
       Section 161 of Cr.P.C., insofar as it seeks to implicate a co-accused,
       whether by way of confession or by way of admission, cannot be
       looked into by the Court against such co-accused. To permit otherwise
       would amount to indirectly doing what the law expressly prohibits,
       namely, using police-recorded statements of one accused as evidence
       against another.

  128.                     It thus follows that any statement of an approver
       recorded under Section 161 of Cr.P.C. is rendered inadmissible by
       operation of Section 25 of the Indian Evidence Act, for the reason that
       a confessional statement, if at all, can be validly recorded only under

Section 164 of Cr.P.C. by a Judicial Magistrate. The prosecution
       appears to proceed on the assumption that, upon tender of pardon, the
       approver is transmuted into an independent witness. Such an
       assumption is fundamentally flawed and untenable in law for the
       purpose of determine evidentiary value of such statement.

  129.                     In the first place, the statement of an approver is never
       assessed on the same footing as that of a general witness; it is
       scrutinised with circumspection, having regard to his admitted
       participation in the offence and the settled statutory and judicial
       safeguards governing approver evidence. In the second place, the
       status of an approver is itself conditional and precarious. Any
       infraction of the terms on which pardon is tendered exposes him to
       forfeiture of that status, rendering him liable to be tried once again as
       an accused. The taint of participation, therefore, continues to attach
       and cannot be wished away.

  130.                     The statutory scheme under Sections 306 and 308 of
       Cr.P.C casts a clear and substantive obligation upon the prosecution to
       ensure that an accused, upon being tendered pardon, “makes a full and
       true disclosure of the whole of the circumstances within his
       knowledge relative to the offence and to every other person concerned,
       whether as principal or abettor. “This condition cannot be treated as a
       mere formality, as it is intended to ensure that the approver is
       mandatorily required: (i) to make a full and true disclosure; (ii) of the

whole of the circumstances within his knowledge; (iii) relative to the
       offence; and (iv) concerning every other person involved, whether as
       principal or abettor. These are the conditions subject to which pardon
       is tendered to the approver. Where, after the recording of the statement
       under Section 306(4) of Cr.P.C on this condition, the investigating
       agency proceeds to record further supplementary statements of the
       same approver under Section 161 of Cr.P.C., a serious issue arises as
       to compliance with the foundational requirement of full and true
       disclosure. If the material on record were to indicate otherwise, the
       statutory course available to the prosecution was to consider recourse
       to Section 308 of Cr.P.C for withdrawal of tender of pardon. The
       decision instead to record multiple subsequent supplementary
       statements under Section 161 of Cr.P.C. is, on the face of the record, a
       matter warranting close judicial scrutiny.

  131.                     That being so, this Court is unambiguous in holding that
       any statement of an approver recorded under Section 161 of Cr.P.C.
       after tender of pardon cannot be treated as substantive material, even
       for the purposes of consideration of charge. However, in order to test
       the prosecution case at its highest, and while extending the maximum
       latitude permissible at this preliminary stage, the Court deems it
       appropriate to examine such statements only as the version of an
       accomplice. This limited exercise is undertaken solely to assess
       whether, even on such an indulgent footing, the material on record

crosses the legally mandated threshold for framing of charge. If the
       prosecution case fails to meet that standard even on this premise, it
       necessarily follows that no case for charge is made out.

  132.                     This discussion is necessitated by the heavy reliance
       placed by the prosecution on the supplementary statements of the
       approver recorded by the investigating agency under Section 161 of
       Cr.P.C., both prior and subsequent to the recording of his confessional
       statement under Section 164 of Cr.P.C. (pre pardon). and his
       confessional statement under Section 306(4) of CrPC (post pardon).
       The general foundational principles governing the evidentiary value
       of such statements have been set out hereinabove. Their specific
       inconsistencies, infirmities, and probative limitations shall be
       examined at the appropriate stage while considering those statements
       in detail.

       2. Statement of a Witness Making Incriminating Assertions Against
       Himself as well as against the accused persons in a Statement recorded
       under Section 161 of Cr.P.C.

  133.                     The issue that arises for consideration concerns the
       evidentiary value of a witness who is alleged to have participated in
       the crime, yet has neither been arrayed as an accused nor tendered as
       an approver, but has instead been examined as a prosecution witness.
       The question is whether such a witness can be treated at par with an
       ordinary witness who merely deposes to facts within his knowledge,

or whether his statement stands on a distinct and legally circumscribed
       footing.

  134.                     This question assumes particular significance at the
       stage of framing of charge, where the Court is required to assess
       whether the material on record crosses the minimum threshold
       necessary to proceed against the accused. The complexity arises
       because the witness, examined under Section 161 of Cr.P.C., makes
       statements which are incriminating not only against the accused
       persons facing prosecution but also against himself.

  135.                     Recently, the Hon’ble Supreme Court, in Criminal Appeal
       No. 454 of 2015 (arising out of SLP (Criminal) No. 9928 of 2014), R.
       Dineshkumar @ Deena v. State, has categorically held, while referring
       to the judgments in Laxmipat Choraria and ors. vs. State of
       Maharashtra, 1968 SCR (2) 624 and A.R. Antulay vs. R.S. Nayak &
       another (1988) 2 SCC 602, that the prosecution is at liberty to examine
       one of the participants in the offence as a witness. However, the
       statement of such a witness is required to be assessed with the caution
       applicable to accomplice evidence. In other words, such statement is
       to be treated as being in the nature of accomplice evidence and cannot
       be accepted at face value without appropriate corroboration. The
       relevant extract is reproduced below for ready reference without any
       alteration:                                           (emphasis supplied)

“54…. We have already taken note of the relevant facts and the
               decision of this Court in Choraria case. The relevant facts of
               A.R. Antulay case are as follows. Before the ‘trial Court’ it was
               contended by Antulay that the examination of some of his
               alleged co-conspirators as witnesses and proposal to examine
               some more of them is legally not tenable and they must be
               arrayed as accused. Such a contention was negated by the trial
               Judge. Aggrieved by the same, Antulay carried the matter in
               appeal to this Court. Unfortunately, the majority judgment did
               not consider this aspect. It is only Justice Venkatachaliah, as
               His Lordship then was, who in his dissenting judgment
               considered this aspect and held as follows:
               ‘133. ……… An accused person cannot assert any right to a
               joint trial with his co-accused. Normally it is the right of the
               prosecution to decide whom it prosecutes. It can decline to
               array a person as a co-accused and, instead, examine him as a
               witness for the prosecution. What weight is to be attached to
               that evidence, as it may smack of the statement of a guilty
               partner in crime, is a different matter. Prosecution can enter
               nolle prosequi against any accused person. It can seek to
               withdraw a charge against an accused person. These
               propositions are too well settled to require any further
               elaboration. Suffice it to say that the matter is concluded by the
               pronouncement of this Court in Laxmipat Choraria v. State of
               Maharashtra : 1968 Cri LJ 1124 where Hidayatullah, J. referred
               to the argument that the accomplice, a certain Ethyl Wong in
               that case, had also to be arrayed as an accused and repelled it,
               observing:
               Mr. Jethmalani’s argument that the Magistrate should have
               promptly put her in the dock because of her incriminating
               answers overlooks Section 132 (proviso).
               …The prosecution was not bound to prosecute her, if they
               thought that her evidence was necessary to break a smugglers’
               ring. Ethyl Wong was protected by Section 132 (proviso) of the
               Indian Evidence Act even if she gave evidence incriminating
               herself. She was a competent witness although her evidence
               could only be received with the caution necessary in all
               accomplice evidence.

134. On this point, really, the appellant cannot be heard to
               complain. Of the so-called co-conspirators, some have been
               examined already as prosecution witnesses; some others are
               proposed to be so examined; and two others, it would appear,
               had died in the interregnum. The appeal on the point has no
               substance and would require to be dismissed. We must now
               turn to the larger issue raised in the appeal.’
               55. In the light of the above two decisions, the proposition
               whether the prosecution has a liberty to examine any person as
               a witness in a criminal prosecution notwithstanding that there
               is some material available to the prosecuting agency to indicate
               that such a person is also involved in the commission of the
               crime for which the other accused are being tried requires a
               deeper examination….”.
                                                            (emphasis supplied)

  136.                     The Hon’ble Supreme Court has recognised that the
       prosecution is not denuded of its liberty to examine such a participis
       criminis as a witness, even where some material exists to indicate his
       involvement in the offence. However, the law equally mandates that
       the evidence of such a witness cannot be placed on the same pedestal
       as that of a neutral or independent witness. The statement of such a
       witness can only be received with the caution applicable to accomplice
       evidence.

  137.                     The expression “all accomplice evidence” is of particular
       significance. The concept of an accomplice is not confined only to an
       approver but extends to any participant in the crime whose statement
       implicates himself. This includes, in principle, statements analogous
       to confessions of co-accused or approvers, though the evidentiary
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
treatment accorded to each category differs, as explained in the
       preceding discussion. The distinction is material, since the probative
       value and the degree of corroboration required vary depending on the
       precise legal character of the statement relied upon.

  138.                     The jurisprudential basis for treating the statement of a
       witness who incriminates himself while also implicating other accused
       persons as accomplice evidence lies in the inherent nature of such
       statement, and not merely in the nomenclature assigned by the
       investigating agency. The mere circumstance that the prosecution has
       chosen to treat such a person as a “general witness” does not, in law,
       efface the taint arising from his admitted participation in the alleged
       offence.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

  139.                     Where a witness acknowledges his own involvement in
       the commission of the crime, his statement is inevitably coloured by
       self-interest. In such a situation, the incentive to align with the
       prosecution case is, if anything, stronger than that of a formal
       approver. An approver, though tendered pardon, is required to undergo
       a statutorily prescribed and judicially supervised process under the
       Cr.P.C., and remains exposed to the risk of forfeiture of pardon upon
       any deviation from full and truthful disclosure. In contrast, a self-
       confessed participant who is extended the benefit of being examined
       as a regular witness, and is thereby insulated from prosecution without

undergoing the rigours of the pardon procedure, enjoys complete
       immunity without corresponding safeguards.

                                                            (emphasis supplied)

  140.                     It would be wholly unrealistic to presume that a person
       who has admittedly participated in the offence would not avail such an
       opportunity to secure his own protection by supporting the prosecution
       narrative. The motivation to testify in a manner favourable to the
       prosecution, in order to avoid penal consequences, is thus manifest and
       cannot be ignored. The credibility of such a witness is, therefore,
       inherently suspect and stands on no higher footing than that of an
       accomplice.

  141.                     Consequently,    settled   principles    of      criminal
       jurisprudence mandate that the statement of such a witness must be
       approached with the same degree of circumspection as accomplice
       evidence. It is well-established that an accomplice is a witness
       unworthy of implicit reliance, and his statement cannot be acted upon
       unless it is independently corroborated on material particulars
       connecting the accused with the crime.

  142.                     This principle assumes particular significance in the
       present case, where the prosecution rests substantially upon the
       statements of a large number of witnesses who have, on their own
       showing, admitted participation in the alleged offence. To accept such

statement at face value, without insisting upon independent
       corroboration on material particulars, would be to dilute well-settled
       safeguards evolved to prevent miscarriage of justice. The Court is,
       therefore, duty-bound to subject such evidence to heightened scrutiny
       and to apply the settled rule of corroboration with full rigour.

  143.                     The above legal position thus governs the appreciation
       of statements under Section 161 of Cr.P.C. made by witnesses who are
       themselves implicated in the offence, particularly at the stage of
       consideration of charge.

       (3) Accomplice, Accomplice-like Witness and Approver- Comparative
       and Inter Se Analysis of Evidentiary Value.

  144.                  The position of law governing accomplice and accomplice-
       like statement stands settled by authoritative pronouncements of the
       Hon’ble Supreme Court. In Laxmipat Choraria (supra) and A.R.
       Antulay (supra), it has been recognised that a witness who
       incriminates himself and other accused persons, though not formally
       tendered pardon as an approver, remains a competent witness.
       However, such evidence is required to be scrutinised with the same
       caution as that of an accomplice. The consequence is that, while
       admissible, it must receive independent corroboration on material
       particulars, in the same manner as approver statement.

145.                     In that background, the issues fall for consideration in
       the form of the following queries:

       (a) Whether accomplice-like statement can be treated as “independent
       corroboration” of the approver on material particulars?

  146.                     The corroboration required for approver evidence must
       be independent in character and must connect the accused with the
       commission of the offence in material particulars. Such corroboration
       cannot proceed from a source equally tainted or similarly interested.
       Where a witness himself stands in the position of an accomplice or
       accomplice-like participant, being exposed to criminal liability in the
       same transaction, his statement carries the same infirmity. As a rule of
       prudence, therefore, accomplice-like statement cannot constitute
       independent corroboration of an approver. Evidence emanating from a
       tainted source does not acquire independence merely because it
       supports another tainted witness.

       (b) Whether accomplice-like statement can corroborate another
       accomplice-like statement and thereby lend credibility to the
       approver?

  147.                     If two witnesses are participants in, or complicit with,
       the same transaction, both stand on an identical evidentiary footing.
       The infirmity attaching to one equally attaches to the other. It is well
       settled that one accomplice cannot corroborate another within the

meaning of Illustration (b) to Section 114 of the Evidence Act. Mere
       repetition of a version by similarly placed witnesses does not
       transform suspicion into reliability; it only reproduces evidence of the
       same quality. Consequently, accomplice-like statement cannot be
       relied upon to bolster another accomplice-like statement so as to
       furnish the independent assurance required for acting upon approver
       evidence.

       (c) Whether the statement of one approver can be used to corroborate
       the statement of another approver ?

  148.                     It has been consistently held that the statement of one
       approver is not sufficient corroboration of another. The doctrinal basis
       is that corroboration must come from an independent source. An
       approver is, by definition, a tainted source. Corroborative evidence
       must (i) be independent of accomplice evidence, (ii) connect the
       accused with the offence, (iii) relate to material particulars, and (iv)
       provide assurance of the truthfulness of the accomplice regarding the
       participation of the accused. Evidence of another accomplice does not
       satisfy these requirements, as it lacks the essential element of
       independence.

  149.                     The position stands settled in K. Hashim v. State of T.N.,
       (2005) 1 SCC 237, subsequently followed by the Bench of three
       Judges of the Hon’ble Supreme Court in Somasundaram alias Somu v.
       State, (2020) 7 SCC 722, wherein it was observed that corroboration

must come from independent sources and ordinarily the statement of
       one accomplice would not suffice to corroborate that of another.
       Though in exceptional circumstances a conviction so based may not
       be illegal, the rule of prudence requiring independent assurance
       remains unaffected.

  150.                     The significance of the aforesaid principles assumes
       particular importance at the stage of determination of charge in the
       present case, where the prosecution relies upon statements of
       approvers as well as witnesses who are themselves alleged participants
       in the transaction. It is well settled that the confession of a co-accused
       cannot be the sole basis for framing of charge, as held by the Hon’ble
       Supreme Court in Suresh Budharmal Kalani (supra). Where the
       material consists predominantly of approver statements and
       accomplice-like statement, the Court is required to examine whether
       there exists independent material connecting the accused with the
       alleged offence. At the stage of charge, the prosecution must cross the
       threshold of grave suspicion; if two views are reasonably possible on
       the material placed on record. In the absence of independent
       corroboration on material particulars, reliance upon mutually
       reinforcing tainted statement would not satisfy the standard required
       even for proceeding to trial.

       C. Rationale for Close Judicial Examination of Witness Statements in
       a Policy-Driven Conspiracy Case

151.                     From the very outset, it becomes necessary to delineate
       why this Court is required to closely examine the statements of
       witnesses relied upon by the prosecution. The nature of the case itself
       makes such scrutiny unavoidable, as the prosecution narrative is
       founded substantially on the statement of approvers rather than on
       direct, self-proving documentary or physical evidence of statements of
       witnesses recorded during the course of investigation.

  152.                     The prosecution case, as projected, rests predominantly
       on oral versions to establish serious allegations relating to
       manipulation of a public policy, demand and payment of alleged up-
       front illegal gratification and their subsequent laundering. These
       allegations are sought to be supported by a set of circumstances which,
       according to the prosecution, point towards the existence of a criminal
       conspiracy. Such circumstances are neither self-evident nor self-
       proving and, by their very nature, invite close judicial scrutiny even at
       the threshold.

  153.                     The prosecution further seeks to draw a chain of
       circumstances from the evolution of the excise framework by
       juxtaposing clauses of the earlier excise policy with provisions
       introduced under the DEP-21/22, and to project these changes as
       tailor-made to benefit select private parties. In doing so, the case enters
       a technically complex domain involving regulatory provisions,
       licensing conditions, and structural changes in the excise regime. The

allegations also span a wide commercial canvas, implicating a large
       number of entities operating at different levels of the excise supply
       chain, manufacturers, wholesalers and retail licensees, whose
       respective roles and inter se relationships form an integral part of the
       prosecution narrative.

  154.                     At the stage of consideration of charge, the Court is not
       expected to undertake a roving or exhaustive enquiry into these
       matters, nor to adjudicate upon the correctness of the prosecution’s
       inferences. At the same time, the Court cannot be reduced to a passive
       recipient of the prosecution version. The settled position of law
       mandates that the Court must apply its judicial mind to the material
       placed on record and examine whether the circumstances relied
       upon, taken cumulatively and at their face value, disclose the essential
       ingredients of the alleged offences and give rise to a grave suspicion,
       as opposed to a mere suspicion founded on conjecture or hindsight
       analysis.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

  155.                     Where the prosecution alleges a complex conspiracy
       involving policy formulation, alleged clandestine monetary flows, and
       multi-layered commercial transactions across numerous entities, the
       Court is necessarily required to test whether the circumstances relied
       upon are proximate, coherent and capable of forming a prima facie
       chain. This exercise involves examining whether the statements of

approvers and witnesses, read with the surrounding circumstances
       relating to policy clauses, licensing structures, and the participation of
       wholesalers and retailers, prima facie lend assurance to the prosecution
       case. Such scrutiny, confined strictly to the parameters of prima facie
       assessment, does not amount to a “mini trial”, as the Court neither
       weighs competing versions nor tests credibility through cross-
       examination.

       (D) Relied-Upon Documents and Statements of Witnesses

  156.                     The investigating agency is entitled to rely upon such
       documents and statements of witnesses as it considers relevant for
       supporting the prosecution case and the conclusions claimed to emerge
       from the investigation. These relied-upon materials alone form the
       foundation of the prosecution at the stage of consideration of charge.

  157.                     It is well settled that, at this stage, the Court confines its
       examination to the documents and statements expressly relied upon by
       the prosecution. Unrelied documents or statements are not taken into
       consideration for determining whether a prima facie case or grave
       suspicion is disclosed. Though such unrelied material is ordinarily not
       supplied to the defence along with the charge-sheet, the investigating
       agency is nevertheless required to furnish a list of unrelied documents
       and to permit inspection thereof, so as to ensure fairness and
       transparency in the investigative process.

158.                     This legal position enables the defence to demonstrate,
       on the basis of the prosecution’s own relied-upon material, that the
       evidence is insufficient to raise grave suspicion against the accused, or
       that the record does not disclose the foundational facts necessary to
       attract the essential ingredients of the alleged offences. At this stage,
       the defence is not required to establish its case or prove innocence; it
       is sufficient to show that even if the prosecution material is taken at its
       face value, it does not warrant the framing of charge.

                                                             (emphasis supplied)

  159.                     Accordingly, the relied-upon documents and statements
       must be examined in their entirety to assess whether they, taken
       cumulatively, disclose a prima facie case. Where any document or
       statement relied upon by the prosecution does not support its case, or
       runs contrary to the prosecution narrative, such material cannot be
       ignored. Being part of the prosecution’s own evidentiary basis, it is
       entitled to due consideration, and the prosecution cannot be permitted
       to rely selectively upon favourable portions while disregarding
       material that dilutes or undermines its own case.

                                                             (emphasis supplied)

  160.                     The purpose of this limited judicial examination is to
       ensure that the criminal process is not set in motion on the strength of
       broad allegations or technical assertions divorced from a coherent
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
factual foundation. A reasoned assessment of whether the prosecution
       material, even if assumed to be true, is capable of sustaining the
       alleged offences is an integral part of the statutory duty of the Court at
       the stage of framing of charge. Any contention that such an exercise
       amounts to conducting a mini trial is, therefore, misplaced.

       (E) Consideration of Submissions and Scope of Adjudication

  161.                     The Court has had the benefit of extensive arguments
       advanced by the Ld. Special Public Prosecutor for the CBI as well as
       by the Ld. Counsel appearing on behalf of the respective accused. The
       submissions addressed before the Court covered the allegations set out
       in the charge-sheets, the material placed on record, and the legal
       objections raised at this stage. The written submissions filed by the
       parties have also been examined. All contentions, whether on facts or
       in law, have been taken into consideration and are dealt with in the
       paragraphs that follow. It is made clear that the scrutiny undertaken at
       this stage is strictly confined to the documents and statements of
       witnesses relied upon by the prosecution.

  162.                     For the sake of continuity and to avoid repetition, the
       brief gist of the submissions of the parties is set out in Annexure-A and
       shall form part of this order. The discussion that follows proceeds on
       the basis of the material so placed before the Court, without restating
       the submissions in detail.

163.                     Having regard to the fact that as many as twenty-three
       accused persons have been arrayed in the present case, the
       appreciation of the prosecution material is being undertaken in a
       structured and phased manner to ensure clarity and coherence. At the
       outset, the material relating to the public servants, namely Accused
       Nos. A-8, A-1, A-2 and A-18, shall be examined individually, having
       regard to the distinct nature of the allegations attributed to them in
       their official capacity.

  164.                     Thereafter, the Court shall proceed to consider the role
       attributed to Accused Nos. A-3, A-4, A-5, A-6, A-7, A-9, A-10, A-11,
       A-17 and A-23, whose alleged involvement is projected primarily in
       relation to the formulation, implementation and ancillary transactions
       connected with the policy.

  165.                     Lastly, a consolidated analysis shall be undertaken qua
       Accused Nos. A-12, A-13, A-14, A-15, A-16, A-21 and A-22, who are
       alleged to be connected with the movement of the purported upfront
       money, stated to have been routed to Goa and utilised for election-
       related purposes.

  166.                     The sequencing is adopted purely for analytical
       convenience and does not imply any pre-judgment on the merits of the
       allegations against any of the accused.

Approach to Evaluation of Alleged Conspiracy — Cumulative and
       Individual Assessment

  167.                     Before adverting to the specific allegations, it is
       necessary to note that the prosecution case rests substantially on a
       series of alleged meetings stated to have been held at different places
       and attended by multiple accused persons. The narrative presented
       seeks to knit these meetings and surrounding circumstances into a
       continuing conspiracy. The same set of events has been relied upon to
       attribute both a collective design and specific roles to individual
       accused.

  168.                     In examining the material on record, this Court shall
       analyse the facts from two perspectives. First, cumulatively, to assess
       whether the circumstances taken together disclose the ingredients of a
       criminal conspiracy in law. Second, individually, to determine whether
       the material qua each accused satisfies the threshold required at this
       stage. Since the allegations are interlinked and overlapping, the same
       meetings, documents, statements and surrounding circumstances may
       require consideration more than once, at times collectively, and at
       times in the context of a particular accused.

  169.                     The Court is conscious that such an approach may
       involve repetition, including reference to the same facts and even to
       the same legal principles. However, given the structure of the
       prosecution case and the manner in which common circumstances are

projected against different persons, a truncated discussion would not
       subserve the ends of justice. As observed by the Hon’ble Supreme
       Court in Ramesh Kumar Bhagchandaka v. State of Uttar Pradesh,
       ARISING FROM SLP (CIVIL) NOS.20045-20046/2024, “No doubt,
       brevity is the soul of precision but not at the cost of completeness.”

  170.                     Guided by the aforesaid principle, the discussion that
       follows may, at places, revisit the same material; such reiteration is
       undertaken to ensure clarity, completeness and proper evaluation of
       the case as against each accused.

       APPRECIATION                OF     PROSECUTION           MATERIAL             FOR
       DETERMINATION OF A PRIMA FACIE CASE

       Allegation against A-8

  171.                     The   allegation   relating   to   the   formulation        and
       implementation of the DEP-21/22 has, in substance, been placed at the
       doorstep of A-8, who, at the relevant time, was serving as Deputy
       Chief Minister and was holding the portfolio of the Excise
       Department. The prosecution narrative consistently projects him as the
       principal architect and controlling force behind the alleged conspiracy,
       as well as the central decision-making authority in matters of policy
       design, approval and implementation. In that view of the matter, and
       in order to preserve continuity and analytical clarity, it is appropriate

to first examine the case qua A-8 before adverting to the role attributed
       to the remaining accused.

  172.                     Broadly stated, the case against A-8 rests on four
       interlinked pillars. First, it is alleged that during the process of
       formulation of the policy, certain recommendations of the Ravi
       Dhawan Committee report dated 13.10.2020 were deliberately
       sidelined, modified or not adopted, and that such departures were
       calculated to favour select private liquor interests. The prosecution has
       placed reliance upon the first draft GoM report dated 15.03.2021, the
       second draft report dated 19.03.2021 and the final report dated
       22.03.2021. It has been asserted with emphasis that the report dated
       19.03.2021 was nothing but a document handed over by members of
       the ‘South Group’ and prepared at their instance. The prosecution
       further seeks to suggest that key provisions, such as the 12% wholesale
       margin, the one-wholesaler-per-manufacturer structure, relaxed
       eligibility norms and dilution of related-entity restrictions, were
       introduced or structured in a manner conferring undue advantage,
       contrary to Expert Committee recommendations and without
       documented deliberation. It is further alleged that fabricated public
       feedback was generated in January 2021 in order to create an artificial
       basis for such departures. The gravamen of the charge, therefore, is not
       mere deviation from recommendations, but deviation accompanied by
       intent to confer pecuniary benefit.

173.                     Secondly, reliance is placed upon the alleged removal or
       non-placement of a draft Cabinet Note dated 28.01.2021, which,
       according to the prosecution, contained adverse legal opinions not
       aligned with the final policy framework. It is contended that A-8
       suppressed such opinions by removing and causing the disappearance
       of the said Cabinet Note, the last conscious custody of which is
       attributed to him. The prosecution further alleges that he thereafter
       initiated a fresh Cabinet Note and orchestrated the constitution of a
       GoM as a façade, personally authoring and finalising GoM drafts on
       the basis of 36 pages allegedly handed over by A-3 and recovered from
       devices seized from his office.

  174.                     Thirdly, the prosecution alleges a broader criminal
       conspiracy between A-8 and certain private individuals and business
       entities described as members of the “South Group.” It is alleged that
       during the policy-drafting phase, A-8 maintained back-channel
       communication with A-3 (Vijay Nair) and exercised overarching
       influence over the Excise Department to facilitate licence grants and
       suppress scrutiny, particularly in favour of M/S Indospirits belonging
       to A-7. Though it is not alleged that he directly handled cash, he is
       accused of having knowledge of, and consenting to, the generation and
       recovery of illegal gratification of approximately ₹90-100 crores
       through intermediaries.

175.                    Fourthly, the theory of proceeds of crime is superimposed
       upon the policy narrative. It is alleged that once the policy enabled
       higher margins or concentrated control in the wholesale and retail
       segments, funds were generated and routed through intermediaries and
       later utilised for electoral purposes. It is further alleged that A-8
       obstructed the investigation by discarding or destroying mobile
       phones and suppressing material records, thereby attracting offences
       under Sections 120-B and 201 IPC read with the relevant provisions
       of the PC Act. The alleged financial trails are thus sought to be traced
       back to policy-level decisions attributed to him.

  176.                     It is evident that, in the prosecution’s presentation, the
       alleged acts of the other accused are portrayed as flowing from, or
       being facilitated by, the policy architecture attributed to A-8. If the
       foundational allegation of manipulation at the stage of formulation
       does not withstand scrutiny, the derivative allegations concerning
       conspiracy, generation of illegal gratification and alleged proceeds of
       crime would necessarily require independent and convincing material
       to sustain them.

  177.                     Equally, the institutional setting in which the policy
       came to be framed cannot be overlooked. The formulation of an excise
       policy is not an isolated ministerial act. It ordinarily involves
       recommendations of expert bodies, deliberations within the
       Department, examination by the Finance and Law Departments,

consideration by the Council of Ministers and, within the
       constitutional framework governing the National Capital Territory of
       Delhi, interaction with the office of the Hon’ble Lieutenant Governor
       (hereinafter be referred to as “Hon’ble LG”). The attribution of
       criminal intent to a policy decision must therefore be tested against
       this collective and layered decision-making process, and not viewed
       in isolation.

  178.                     For these reasons, it would be appropriate to examine, in
       a structured manner, the material placed on record qua A-8. This would
       require scrutiny of the documentary trail, including committee reports,
       departmental notings, GoM deliberations, Cabinet approvals and
       communications with the Lieutenant Governor’s Secretariat;
       assessment of whether the alleged deviations amount to policy choices
       within administrative discretion or disclose prima facie mala fides; and
       evaluation of whether any cogent linkage is established between the
       impugned policy clauses and the alleged monetary transactions.

  179.                     Only after such an examination can the role attributed to
       the other accused be meaningfully considered, since, on the
       prosecution’s own showing, their alleged participation is premised
       upon the central role ascribed to A-8 in the formulation and
       implementation of the DEP-21/22.

  180.                     Before proceeding to examine the specific allegations
       against A-8, this Court considers it appropriate to first undertake a

prima facie examination of the relevant policy documents, namely, the
       Ravi Dhawan Committee Report dated 13.10.2020, the first draft GoM
       Report dated 15.03.2021, the subsequent draft dated 19.03.2021, the
       GoM Report dated 22.03.2021, and the Minutes of Meeting dated
       05.04.2021.

  181.                     This exercise is undertaken for a limited purpose. The
       documents are to be read sequentially and on their own terms, without,
       at this stage, importing the allegations surrounding the formulation
       process. The object is to ascertain whether the progression reflected in
       these reports discloses an organic and incremental development of
       policy. The endeavour in the ensuing discussion is confined to a plain
       reading of these reports to assess whether the trajectory of policy
       change, as emerging from the documents themselves, prima facie
       discloses any design indicative of conspiracy, preferential treatment to
       any particular group, or the creation of cartelisation or monopoly.

       (A) Scope and Limits of Judicial Scrutiny-Preliminary Clarification
       Before Examination of Policy Reports

  182.                     At the outset, this Court deems it appropriate to clarify
       the limited compass within which the Ravi Dhawan Committee
       Report, the GoM Report, and the documents culminating in the
       DEP-21/22 are being examined. It is not the province of a criminal
       court to evaluate the wisdom, advisability, or economic soundness of
       a public policy. The formulation of policy falls within the executive

domain, and courts do not substitute their views for those of the policy-
       maker.

  183.                     The present scrutiny arises only because the prosecution
       alleges that the very formulation and implementation of the
       DEP-21/22 were tainted by criminal conspiracy. In that context, it
       becomes necessary for this Court, at least on a prima facie appraisal,
       to consider whether the material on record suggests that the policy was
       the result of a structured and consultative administrative process, or
       whether it discloses circumstances indicative of a pre-conceived
       conspiracy. The exercise undertaken is thus confined to determining
       whether the threshold required for framing of charge,namely, the
       existence of grave suspicion, is satisfied.

  184.                   It is significant that the Ravi Dhawan Committee Report,
       the GoM Report, and the subsequent policy documents are not
       disputed by either side. Their authenticity is not in question. They form
       part of the admitted documentary record. Where such documents are
       contemporaneous and form part of the official decision-making
       process, they must be read in their plain terms. While oral statement
       may vary in quality and reliability, documentary records, especially
       those generated in the ordinary course of governmental functioning,
       provide an objective account of events and deliberations.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
185.                   The assessment that follows is, therefore, undertaken only
       to ascertain whether the prosecution’s allegation of conspiracy finds
       prima facie support in the admitted documentary framework, or
       whether the record reflects an institutional policy development. This
       Court reiterates that it is neither adjudicating upon the merits of the
       policy nor expressing any opinion upon its desirability; the enquiry is
       confined strictly to the question whether the material discloses the
       essential ingredients of conspiracy at this stage.

       (i) Structural Framework of the Supply Chain (Earlier Policy vis-à-vis
       DEP-21/22)

  186.                     Before adverting to the specific recommendations
       contained in the Ravi Dhawan Committee Report, the successive draft
       reports of the GoM, and the eventual crystallisation of those
       deliberations into the DEP-21/22, it is considered appropriate, for the
       sake of analytical clarity, to first delineate the structural framework
       within which the excise regime operated. A comparative depiction of
       the supply chain under the earlier policy, as contrasted with the
       framework introduced under DEP-21/22, facilitates a clearer
       understanding of the structural realignment that is the subject of
       scrutiny in the present proceedings.

  187.                     This exercise is undertaken only to place the competing
       policy frameworks in perspective. It is not intended to pronounce upon
       the relative merits of either regime, but to provide a neutral structural

backdrop against which subsequent policy modifications may be
       examined.

188.                     The above depiction sets out, in schematic form, the
       architecture of the two regimes. It clarifies the operational structure
       prevailing prior to DEP-21/22 and the structural adjustments
       introduced thereafter. The examination of the Ravi Dhawan
       Committee recommendations, the draft GoM reports dated
       15.03.2021, 19.03.2021 and final GoM report dated 22.03.2021, and
       the final GoM Minutes culminating in the DEP-21/22 must be viewed
       against this foundational framework.

  189.                     The comparative flow chart thus serves as an analytical
       aid, enabling the Court to assess subsequent clauses and alleged
       deviations within their proper structural context.

       (ii) Structural Vulnerabilities in the Pre-Policy Wholesale–Retail
       Architecture and the Committee’s Recommendation for Functional
       Separation by Ravi Dhawan Committee Report

  190.                     A cumulative reading of the Report indicates that the
       Committee identified a structural vulnerability in the prevailing
       architecture, wherein the supply chain functioned as: “Distillery
       outside Delhi → Wholesale licenses (L-1) → Retail licenses.” Within
       this structure, the Committee recorded: “Manufacturers may be able
       to acquire retail licenses through proxy ownership in the existing
       system,” and further observed: “As a result of depot operations,
       significant savings in terms of overhead costs, labour costs and rentals

shall be made by the manufacturers who are also presently engaged in
       wholesale operations.”

  191.                     The Report therefore recognises that manufacturers were
       not confined to production alone but were “presently engaged in
       wholesale operations,” and, by way of proxy ownership, were in a
       position to influence the retail layer as well. Such vertical alignment
       inevitably resulted in structural concentration of control and the
       retention of financial advantages across different tiers of the
       distribution chain.

  192.                     The magnitude of the financial incentive inherent in the
       system was also candidly acknowledged: “The incentive to cheat is
       huge because of the very nature of the commodity, fast selling and
       highly taxed. A single bottle of liquor, where duty is not paid, not only
       leaves the state high and dry in terms of revenue but also pushes the
       profit margins from 10-15% to 65-70%, as the major component of the
       price is duties viz. Excise duty and VAT…”

  193.                     The Report further records: “Non-duty paid liquor having
       duplicate barcodes were found in retail stores which is not possible
       without the complicity of the wholesaler…”. Thus, duplication of
       barcoding and the circulation of non-duty paid liquor were identified
       as systemic concerns, and the role of the wholesaler was treated as
       central to such irregularities.

194.                     The Report also makes a comparative revenue
       observation: “The revenue contribution by the Government vends is
       almost equal to private sector inspite of 40% more government vends.
       The average contribution per vend of government corporation in terms
       of Excise Duty is Rs. 5 crores p.a. in comparison to Rs. 8 crores p.a.
       per private vend.” While the Report does not expressly connect the
       lower per-vend revenue of corporation outlets with duplication or Non
       Duty Paid Liquor, the revenue differential, when viewed alongside the
       admitted presence of barcode duplication in retail stores, reflects that
       vulnerability within the system was not demonstrably confined to one
       category of outlet. The document records the disparity but does not
       conclude that corporation-operated vends were insulated from similar
       risks.

  195.                     In response to the perceived concentration of control and
       the attendant risk of leakage, the Committee recommended: “IMFL
       trade should be revamped by bringing the entire wholesale
       operations under one government entity,” so as to: “break the link
       between manufacturers and retailers by ensuring that all stocks are
       now routed only through this corporation.”

  196.                     However, when the acknowledgement of lower revenue
       performance of corporation vends is considered together with the
       identified issues of duplication and Non Duty Paid Liquor, the
       assumption that a Government corporation, by its character alone,

would function free from the possibility of corruption or leakage does
       not arise as a finding supported by comparative material within the
       Report. The Committee points to structural deficiencies in the earlier
       vertically integrated model and proposes functional separation; yet the
       proposition that wholesale control by a Government entity would, by
       itself, eliminate the risks of duplication, evasion or mismanagement is
       not established on any empirical analysis contained in the Report.

       (iii) Evolution of Wholesale Margin Structure in Draft Reports-
       Examination of Alleged Enhancement

  197.                     The prosecution seeks to construct a narrative that the
       draft dated 19.03.2021 was not an institutional document but a
       privately prepared text, allegedly printed at the instance of A-4, routed
       through A-3 and handed over to A-8, thereby suggesting that the
       wholesale margin of 12% was inserted at the behest of the so-called
       “South Group” to facilitate recoupment of alleged upfront payments.

  198.                 When the two drafts are placed side by side, the foundation
       of this hypothesis requires careful scrutiny. The draft dated 15.03.2021
       expressly provided: “6. There will be no cap on distributor margin
       set by the Govt. and brands can individually set that with their chosen
       distributor. A 5% minimum distribution fees will be mandatory to
       ensure no undercutting takes place between L1 license holders which
       will indirectly affect the quality of liquor being supplied and to ensure

no malpractices take place under the guise of a lower distribution
       %.”.

  199.                     A plain reading of this clause reveals three clear
       features:
       (i) No upper cap was prescribed by the Government;
       (ii) The distributor margin was left to be negotiated between brand and
       distributor; and
       (iii) Only a minimum distribution fee of 5% was mandated to prevent
       undercutting.

  200.                     Thus, under the first draft, the margin was open-ended,
       subject only to a minimum threshold. There was no ceiling. The
       wholesaler could, in theory, negotiate margins beyond 12%, if the
       commercial arrangement so permitted.

  201.                     It is in this backdrop that the investigating agency has
       sought to project that in the second draft report there was an abrupt
       increase of wholesale margin from 5% to 12% from the first draft
       report to the second draft report. The relevant portion of para 16.16 of
       the first supplementary charge-sheet reads: “… It has been revealed
       that in this draft GoM report, the profit margin for wholesalers (L-1
       licensee) was abruptly increased from 5% to 12% of EDP + Import
       Fee. Further, the eligibility criterion of turnover for wholesalers (L-1
       licensee) was also increased from Rs.100 crores to Rs.500 crores,
       every year for the past 05 years.”

202.                     The above assertion proceeds on the premise that the
       first draft report dated 15.03.2021 fixed the wholesale margin at 5%.
       The document itself does not support that reading. The clause in the
       first draft report categorically records that there would be no cap on
       distributor margin and that brands could individually set the margin
       with their chosen distributor, subject only to a minimum of 5%. In
       contrast, the draft dated 19.03.2021 records: “GoM recommends
       simplification of the price fixation. A standard distribution fee to be
       fixed @ 12% of EDP + Import Fee. The 12% distributor margin will
       cover the significantly higher level of investment required for global
       distribution standards, freight & insurance and a reasonable profit for
       the distributor. The reasonable margin will eliminate the need to
       indulge in unethical practices.”

  203.                     What emerges, therefore, is not a transition from a fixed
       5% to 12%, but a transition from no cap (with a 5% minimum) to a
       standardised 12%. The first draft did not prescribe a 5% ceiling; it
       prescribed only a floor. The second draft replaced a flexible regime
       with a uniform rate. It is also of significance that the investigating
       agency has not alleged manipulation in the first draft. The allegation
       of manipulation is directed only against the second draft, and that too
       on the premise that the wholesale margin was enhanced to facilitate
       recoupment. If the first draft had culminated into the final policy, the
       wholesaler entities such as M/S Indospirit and M/S BSPL, who are

alleged to be part of the conspiracy for recoupment, would have
       operated under a regime with no upper cap on distributor margin. Such
       an arrangement, in theory, provided a wider commercial latitude and a
       greater opportunity to accumulate higher margins. The second draft,
       by introducing a standardised 12% margin, curtailed that flexibility.

                                                             (emphasis supplied)

  204.                     It is difficult to reconcile this with the prosecution’s
       hypothesis that the so-called conspirators were engineering a policy
       solely to maximise recoupment. A policy that replaces an uncapped
       negotiable margin with a fixed standard cannot, on its face, be said to
       enlarge the scope for windfall accumulation. If anything, it narrows
       discretion. The suggestion that a group would design a framework
       disadvantageous to its own alleged objective renders the theory
       internally inconsistent.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

                Conduct of Investigating Officer and impact on fair
                 investigation.

  205.                     The portrayal of this change as an “abrupt increase from
       5% to 12%” is not borne out from the text of the document. A
       conclusion of manipulation cannot rest upon attributing to the earlier
       draft a position it never adopted. An investigating agency is expected
       to place the record before the Court fairly and in its correct context. A

selective reading that ignores the explicit statement that there would
        be no cap on distributor margin and proceeds as though the earlier
        draft fixed the margin at 5% does not assist the Court. The record must
        be read as it stands. On a plain reading of the two drafts, the hypothesis
        of conspiracy, built upon an alleged increase from 5% to 12%, does
        not withstand textual scrutiny.

        (iv) Enhancement of Turnover Criteria for L-1 Licence-Examination of
        Prosecution’s Theory of Elimination of Competition.

   206.                     Another circumstance relied upon by the prosecution is
        the enhancement of the eligibility criteria for grant of L-1 licence in
        the second draft. It is suggested that the turnover requirement was
        increased from ₹100 crores every year for the past five years (as
        reflected in the first draft report) to ₹500 crores every year for five
        years in the subsequent second draft report, and that such enhancement
        was introduced at the instance of the so-called “South Group” to
        eliminate competition. It is further relevant that in the final GoM report
        the threshold was moderated to ₹250 crores every year for three years,
        and in the final DEP-21/22 it stood reduced to ₹150 crores every year
        for past three years.

   207.                     The prosecution projects the second draft as the decisive
        stage where competition was allegedly sought to be curtailed by
        raising the turnover benchmark. However, this position does not
        appear to align with the factual material on record. The very entity
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
alleged to be beneficiaries of the conspiracy, M/S Indospirit, were
        themselves confronted with difficulty in meeting the turnover
        requirement. The material placed before the Court indicates that M/S
        Indospirit Marketing Private Limited (M/S IMPL) struggled on the
        turnover criterion and was unable to satisfy even the reduced
        benchmark of ₹150 crores in the final policy, leading to withdrawal of
        its application and a subsequent attempt under the name of M/S
        Indospirit. If the prosecution theory is that the eligibility threshold was
        deliberately raised to eliminate competitors and secure advantage for
        conspirators, the fact that the alleged conspirators themselves faced
        disqualification on the very same turnover condition introduces a
        serious inconsistency. A clause that renders the supposed beneficiaries
        ineligible cannot, on its face, be described as a provision crafted
        exclusively for their benefit.

                                                            (emphasis supplied)

   208.                     The sequence of drafts further shows a movement in
        figures, from ₹100 crores to ₹500 crores, then to ₹250 crores for three
        years, and ultimately to ₹150 crores in the notified policy. This
        progression reflects revision and recalibration rather than a one-
        directional enhancement intended to permanently exclude market
        participants. Numerical thresholds in policy formulation are often
        reassessed in light of feasibility and market considerations.

209.                     Viewed in this context, the allegation that the turnover
        clause was engineered solely to eliminate competition and facilitate
        recoupment becomes difficult to sustain. The very premise of
        conspiracy, that the framework was structured to secure wholesale
        profits for particular entities, stands diluted if those entities were
        themselves rendered ineligible under the proposed conditions. A
        conspiracy theory that rests on provisions which disqualify its alleged
        beneficiaries cannot be accepted at face value. The shifting turnover
        criteria, read in their entirety, do not by themselves establish that the
        second draft was manipulated to eliminate competition for the benefit
        of a predetermined group. On the contrary, the record indicates that
        the eligibility clause operated uniformly and did not carve out any
        express or implied exemption in favour of the alleged conspirators.


        (v) Related Entities (51% Ownership/Control)

   210.                Upon a careful and holistic consideration of the material on
        record, this Court finds that the incorporation of the “related entities”
        concept, anchored in a majority ownership/control threshold of 51%
        (or more than 50%), in clause 3.1.2 (vii) of the DEP-21/22 cannot, by
        any stretch of reasoning, be characterised as a novel, arbitrary, or
        conspiratorial innovation. A plain reading of the draft reports shows
        that while the principle of separation between manufacturer,
        wholesaler and retailer existed from the beginning, the specific

definition of “related entities” did not form part of the earlier drafts.
        The drafts dated 15.03.2021, 19.03.2021 and 22.03.2021 referred in
        general terms to “sister concerns,” “proxy entities,” and indirect
        ownership, but did not prescribe any quantified or structured test. The
        detailed formulation, incorporating the 51% majority ownership
        criterion, prohibition of common proprietors/partners/directors, and
        exclusion of holding, subsidiary relationships, appears for the first
        time       in     the    Minutes   dated   05.04.2021,    when     the       GoM
        recommendations were considered at the level of the Council of
        Ministers.

   211.                     This sequence is of relevance. The definition of “related
        entities” was not embedded in any of the earlier draft reports, including
        the draft dated 19.03.2021 which is alleged to have been created by
        the so-called “South Group.” It was introduced subsequently during
        governmental deliberation. On the face of the documents, what
        emerges is institutional formalisation at the stage of ministerial
        consideration, not insertion at the draft stage attributed to private
        individuals. On the contrary, the adoption of a majority-control test is
        a well-recognised and time-tested regulatory technique employed
        across Central Government statutes, procurement frameworks, and
        competition-law jurisprudence to address the mischief of cartelisation,
        concentration of economic power, and circumvention of eligibility
        norms through proxy or group entities.

212.                  It is a matter of record that Indian regulatory architecture
        repeatedly treats entities under common control or majority ownership
        as belonging to the same economic group. Statutory and policy
        instruments, ranging from company law (holding–subsidiary
        relationships), foreign-exchange regulations (beneficial ownership
        exceeding 50%), to Government tender and PPP documents
        (definitions of “associate” or “affiliate” based on control through more
        than 50% voting rights), consistently adopt this threshold to ensure
        that competition is real and not illusory. The rationale is self-evident:
        where control vests in the same controlling mind, formal corporate
        separateness cannot be permitted to defeat the object of fair
        competition. Viewed in this backdrop, the 51% criterion employed in
        the DEP-21/22 is not an outlier but falls squarely within the
        mainstream of Indian regulatory practice.

   213.                          Equally significant is what preceded the DEP-21/22.
        Neither the earlier Excise Policy nor the Ravi Dhawan Committee
        Report recommended or even contemplated a structured “related
        entities” prohibition. In such a framework, absent an express
        restriction on common ownership or control, manufacturers, by
        deploying subsidiaries, group companies, or front entities, would have
        had a clear and unhindered pathway to vertically influence or
        indirectly control retail operations, thereby frustrating both
        competition and consumer-interest objectives.

214.                 The Court cannot lose sight of the fact that policy design
        must respond not only to past experience but also to foreseeable
        market behaviour. The introduction of the “related entities” clause in
        the DEP-21/22 addresses precisely this regulatory gap. It operates as a
        preventive safeguard, ensuring that privatisation of retail does not
        degenerate into disguised vertical integration or group dominance, and
        that the market structure remains competitive rather than cartel-prone.
        Far from being a suspicious deviation, the clause represents a course
        correction aligned with competition principles and administrative
        prudence.

   215.                  Viewed thus, the “related entities” concept based on 51%
        ownership/control serves a legitimate, rational, and policy-consistent
        purpose. It strengthens the architecture of the DEP-21/22 by closing
        avenues of indirect control, promotes genuine competition, and
        protects against monopoly formation. The absence of such a provision
        in earlier policies or advisory reports cannot be weaponised to impugn
        its later introduction; rather, it underscores the necessity and maturity
        of the reform undertaken. In the considered opinion of this Court, the
        clause confers benefit and robustness upon the DEP-21/22, and cannot
        prima facie be read as indicative of any ulterior design or
        conspiratorial intent.

   216.                     At this juncture, it must also be noted that the
        prosecution’s attack on the DEP-21/22 is, in its very formulation, self-

destructive. The very clauses projected as arbitrary, tailor-made, or
        conspiratorial, namely those relating to the definition of related
        entities, structural separation, and competitive safeguards, operate in a
        manner that negates, rather than advances, the allegation of
        cartelisation or group-centric benefit. Measures designed to dismantle
        common control, prevent vertical integration, and restrict dominance
        cannot logically be invoked as instruments to favour a particular
        group. The prosecution’s narrative thus collapses under its own
        weight: the policy features assailed as suspicious are, in substance and
        effect,       those      which   strengthen   competition    and     constrain
        concentration. Far from lending support to the theory of undue benefit
        to the so-called “South Group”, these provisions, when examined in
        their correct regulatory context, affirm the defence case that the
        DEP-21/22 was structured to disperse control, curb monopoly, and
        promote a level playing field.


        (vi) Retail Vends: Alleged Cartelisation and Adoption of Auction Model

   217.                     Upon consideration of the material placed on record, this
        Court finds that the recommendations of the Ravi Dhawan Committee
        report and those of the GoM are substantially aligned on the question
        of privatisation of retail vends. The GoM, in essence, adopted the
        Committee’s recommendation that retail trade in Delhi be privatised.
        The divergence projected by the investigating agency pertains not to

privatisation per se, but to the method of allocation, the adoption of an
        auction-based model in place of the lottery-based mechanism adverted
        to in the Committee’s report.

   218.                     The prosecution asserts that the shift to auction-based
        allocation facilitated cartelisation in the retail segment by enabling
        concentration of retail zones in the hands of certain entities. However,
        the mere selection of auction as a mode of allocation, in preference to
        lottery, cannot by itself be elevated to a circumstance indicative of
        criminal design. The choice between auction and lottery lies within the
        domain of policy and economic governance. Each model is capable of
        yielding varied market outcomes. In the absence of material
        demonstrating manipulation of bids, distortion of eligibility, or
        procedural impropriety in allocation, the inference of conspiracy
        cannot rest solely upon the adoption of one permissible allocation
        mechanism over another.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   219.                     It is also of relevance that the policy simultaneously
        introduced safeguards to address apprehensions of cartelisation and
        vertical integration. The stipulation that manufacturer, wholesaler
        (L-1), and retailer could not be held by “related entities” constitutes an
        express structural barrier against cross-tier concentration. The
        incorporation of such disqualification norms reflects a regulatory
        intent to prevent consolidation across levels. The existence of these

anti-concentration safeguards does not readily match with the
        allegation that the framework was consciously structured to enable
        cartel formation.

   220.                     This Court also cannot overlook the contextual backdrop
        in which the DEP-21/22 was formulated. The policy emerged during
        a period marked by unprecedented fiscal strain occasioned by the
        Covid-19 pandemic. State revenues had suffered severe contraction
        owing to lockdown measures, while expenditure obligations expanded
        significantly to address public health exigencies. Governments across
        the country, confronted with similar constraints, recalibrated revenue-
        generating mechanisms. The choice of an auction-based model, which
        ordinarily assures competitive bidding and potentially enhanced
        revenue realisation, cannot be divorced from that fiscal context. Policy
        formulation must be appreciated as a response to the economic
        realities prevailing at the relevant time.

   221.                     An instructive feature of the record is the statement of
        the prosecution’s own witness, Sikander Mann (PW-2). He has stated
        that he is the owner of ADS Spirits Private Limited, manufacturer of
        the brand “Royal Green,” and that he and his family members operate
        approximately 60 liquor retail vends in the State of Haryana. This
        statement discloses that a manufacturing entity and its promoters are
        simultaneously associated with a considerable number of retail outlets
        within a single State.

(emphasis supplied)

   222.                     This Court is neither required nor inclined to examine
        the excise framework of the State of Haryana. The significance of the
        statement lies in the factual position it reveals. The presence of
        substantial retail concentration in the hands of one family, which is
        also connected with manufacturing activity, demonstrates that such
        aggregation is not a phenomenon confined to the DEP-21/22. It is also
        borne out from the policy record that the structural changes introduced
        in DEP-21/22 were expressly aimed at addressing concerns of
        monopoly and cartelisation. In that backdrop, mere concentration
        cannot, by itself, sustain an inference of policy-driven impropriety.
        Structural concentration may emerge under varied regulatory models,
        and its existence alone does not establish criminality.

                                                                (emphasis supplied)

   223.                      From the standpoint of the prosecution’s own case, it is
        significant that no allegation has been advanced that the bidding
        process of retail vends in Delhi was vitiated by manipulation, irregular
        evaluation, or misconduct on the part of the TEC. There is no assertion
        that bids were unlawfully structured, that eligibility criteria were
        selectively relaxed, or that the allocation process was procedurally
