        compromised. The challenge is directed at the model itself, not at its
        implementation.

224.                     The allegation of cartelisation is further attenuated by
        the factual matrix concerning M/S KGRL. The record indicates that
        M/S KGRL was unsuccessful in the initial round of bidding, wherein
        only 20 vends were allotted. The remaining vends were subsequently
        re-bid, and it was at that stage that M/S KGRL succeeded. This
        sequence does not, prima facie, reflect a pre-arranged or assured
        allocation.

   225.                     Beyond M/S KRGL and Magunta Farms Ltd., the
        prosecution has not established that any other entity was directly or
        indirectly connected through ownership interest in an L-1 wholesaler.
        Nor is it the case of the prosecution that manufacturers were
        structurally linked to wholesalers or retailers in contravention of the
        related-entity norms. When the broader narrative is examined,
        manufacturers, who were central to the concerns recorded in the Ravi
        Dhawan Committee Report regarding vertical integration, do not
        emerge as beneficiaries of the alleged cartelisation under the new
        framework.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   226.                     On an overall appraisal, what emerges from the material
        is not demonstrable evidence of a cartel engineered through auction-
        based allocation, but a policy shift accompanied by express anti-
        concentration safeguards, implemented through a bidding process that
        has not been shown to be procedurally flawed. The theory that the
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
adoption of auction-based retail allocation was itself a vehicle for
        cartelisation does not find prima facie support from the reports
        anyalised above.


        (vii) Concluding Assessment on the Evolution of the Policy Framework

   227.                     A cumulative reading of the Ravi Dhawan Committee
        Report, the draft GoM reports dated 15.03.2021, 19.03.2021 and final
        report dated 22.03.2021, together with the Minutes of Meeting dated
        05.04.2021, indicates a visible progression in policy formulation
        rather than any abrupt or discontinuous shift. On a plain and sequential
        reading of the documents placed, the draft dated 15.03.2021, followed
        by the drafts dated 19.03.2021 and final GoM report dated 22.03.2021,
        and thereafter the Minutes incorporating suggestions on 05.04.2021,
        what emerges is continuity in structure with calibrated refinement in
        detail.

   228.                     Certain core elements remain consistent throughout:
        (i) Separation of manufacturer from wholesale (no manufacturer to
        hold L-1);


        (ii) Prohibition on L-1 owning retail vends;
        (iii) Requirement of a professionalised wholesale structure;
        (iv) Introduction of mechanisms to curb spurious or non-duty paid
        liquor;

(v) Consolidation of L-1/L-1F permissions into a unified L-1
        framework;
        (vi) Exclusive sale by L-1 to retail vends;
        (vii) Provision for cancellation and forfeiture upon violation.

   229.                     These structural pillars do not appear to have been
        introduced suddenly at a later stage; rather, they persist across drafts.

   230.                     At the same time, there are discernible calibrations in
        quantitative thresholds:


        Wholesale Turnover threshold:
        • 15.03.2021 – ₹100 crores every year for past 5 years;
        • 19.03.2021 – ₹500 crores every year for past 5 years;
        • 22.03.2021 – ₹250 crores every year for past 3 years (excluding the
        Covid year);
        • 05.04.2021– ₹250 crores every year for past 3 consecutive years.


        Wholesale Experience requirement:
        • 15.03.2021 – 10 years;
        • 19.03.2021 – 10 years;
        • 22.03.2021 – reduced to 5 years;
        • 05.04.2021 – framed in broader terms, linked to professional
        standards with turnover criteria retained.


        Wholesale Annual licence fee:

• 15.03.2021 – ₹10 crores;
        • 19.03.2021 – ₹10 crores;
        • 22.03.2021 – reduced to ₹5 crores;
        • 05.04.2021 – no material contradiction.


   231.                     Such variation suggests calibration in response to
        internal deliberation, economic feasibility, and anticipated market
        participation. The exclusion of the Covid year in the 22.03.2021 GoM
        report is contextual and reflects a pragmatic adjustment rather than a
        structural deviation. There is no material in these successive drafts
        indicating introduction of an entirely new structural concept at a late
        stage, removal of safeguards in favour of a particular class, sudden
        tailoring of eligibility criteria for a named entity, or abandonment of
        the principle of separation between manufacturer and retail.

   232.                 Instead, the trajectory reflects tightening, loosening, and re-
        balancing of quantitative thresholds, turnover, years of experience,
        licence fee, while retaining the same architectural framework of the
        wholesale model. When this evolution is read alongside the concerns
        recorded in the Ravi Dhawan Committee Report, namely, vertical
        integration of manufacturers into wholesale and retail, concentration
        of control, vulnerability to non-duty paid liquor and duplication of
        barcodes, and systemic incentives for evasion, the subsequent drafts
        appear to respond to identified deficiencies. The separation of

manufacturing from wholesale, prohibition of cross-ownership,
        structured eligibility norms, and refinement of distribution margins
        reflect attempts to address monopoly tendencies and regulatory
        leakages under the earlier regime.

   233.                     At the same time, while the policy sought to break
        manufacturer-level dominance and curb circulation of non-duty paid
        liquor, the restructuring inevitably shifted operational control towards
        entities qualifying at the wholesale and retail levels. In practical terms,
        commercial influence moved from manufacturers to large-scale
        wholesalers and retailers capable of meeting eligibility benchmarks.
        The earlier vertical monopoly was sought to be dismantled; however,
        concentration of economic weight at downstream tiers was a
        foreseeable regulatory consequence.

                                                                  (emphasis supplied)

   234.                     From a neutral analytical standpoint, what is visible is an
        iterative drafting process, proposals examined, modified, and refined
        over a short span, culminating in the Minutes dated 05.04.2021, which
        incorporate earlier suggestions in structured form.


   235.                     Whether         such   evolution   amounts    to      organic
        development or manipulation cannot be inferred merely from the
        presence of modification. Fiscal and regulatory policy formulation
        commonly                 involves   balancing   revenue   objectives,      market

participation, administrative feasibility, and legal safeguards. The
        mere alteration of thresholds or licence fees, absent material
        demonstrating targeted tailoring or concealed insertion, does not by
        itself establish manipulation.


   236.                     On the material presently examined, the sequence
        reflects progressive crystallisation of a wholesale model in response to
        earlier systemic concerns. A conclusion of criminal manipulation
        would require independent material demonstrating that the changes
        were introduced to favour identified beneficiaries or were inconsistent
        with the declared objectives of reform. Such inference does not arise
        solely from the textual progression of these drafts. At this stage, the
        Court is concerned only with whether the broad structural shift, taken
        in isolation, gives rise to a prima facie inference of criminality. On
        such limited scrutiny, no such inference arises merely from the fact of
        privatisation or the incorporation of new regulatory clauses.



        (B) Analysis on the Specific Allegations against A-8

   237.                     The prosecution has levelled specific allegations against
        A-8 alleging manipulation and criminal conspiracy during the
        formulation of the policy. Those allegations are required to be
        examined independently and on their own evidentiary footing. The
        inquiry at this stage is confined to determining whether the material

placed on record, if taken at face value, is sufficient to cross the
        threshold for framing of charge.

   238.                     The Court shall, therefore, proceed to consider each
        imputed allegation qua A-8 separately, confining itself to the material
        placed on record, for the limited purpose of determining whether the
        ingredients of the alleged offences are disclosed and whether a prima
        facie opinion warranting framing of charge is made out.


   239.                     In order to appreciate the sequence in which events
        unfolded, from the constitution of the Ravi Dhawan Committee to the
        eventual coming into force of the DEP-21/22, it becomes necessary to
        set out the chronology in a structured manner. The formulation of the
        policy was not a singular act but the result of a series of steps,
        deliberations, draft reports, inter-departmental exchanges, and
        approvals extending over a defined period of time.


   240.                     To bring clarity to this progression, and to avoid any
        disjointed appreciation of isolated documents, the date-wise sequence
        and flow chart of material events is delineated below in a structured
        form. This chronological presentation is intended to provide a coherent
        narrative of the policy-making process, enabling the Court to assess
        the allegations in their proper temporal context rather than in
        fragmented isolation.

(i) Allegation Regarding Suggestions Attributed to the Hon’ble Lieutenant
        Governor (Qua A-8)

   241.                     Turning now to the allegations against A-8, the Court
        first considers the issue arising from the statement of Sh. Anil Baijal

(PW-86), who was the Hon’ble LG at the relevant time when the
        DEP-21/22 was under formulation.

   242.                     The prosecution case is that although the concerned file,
        along with notings, was sent to the office of the Hon’ble LG for his
        views, only one suggestion was in fact made by him. It is alleged,
        however, that seven suggestions were subsequently reflected as having
        been proposed by the Hon’ble LG. This forms a central plank of the
        prosecution’s case on the aspect of alleged manipulation.

   243.                     The allegation assumes significance, as it concerns the
        acts and recorded views of a constitutional authority and places two
        versions in direct contest. The matter therefore requires careful
        scrutiny, particularly at the stage where the Court is required to
        examine whether the material on record discloses grounds to proceed
        further in accordance with law.

   244.                     The statement of the Hon’ble LG, examined as PW-86,
        is of primary relevance and must be read along with the
        contemporaneous official record. Equally material are the statements
        of the senior officers associated with the Lieutenant Governor’s
        Secretariat, namely PW-87 (Smt. Ankita Mishra Bundela, Secretary to
        the Hon’ble LG) and PW-88 (Sh. Ajay Kumar, Additional Secretary to
        the Hon’ble LG), who were entrusted with the examination, movement
        and recording of file notings in the ordinary course of governmental
        business.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
245.                     Before adverting to the statements of the witnesses
        bearing on the present allegation, it would be apposite to reproduce the
        relevant file notings as contained in D-138. For ease of reference, the
        scanned notings relating to the above discussion are set out below:-

246.                     PW-88,    who     was    directly   responsible     for       the
        examination and movement of the file, explains the constitutional
        framework governing the subject in the following terms:

        “…Excise comes under the ‘Transferred Subject’, which comes under
        the domain of GNCT of Delhi as per the provisions of Article 239 AA
        of the Constitution of India. Further, as per Sub-Clause (4) of the
        Article 239 AA of the Constitution of India, in case of difference of
        opinion between the Lieutenant Governor and his Ministers on any
        matter, the Lieutenant Governor shall refer it to the President for
        decision and act according to the decision given thereon by the
        President and pending such decision it shall be competent for the
        Lieutenant Governor in any case where the matter, in his opinion, is
        so urgent that it is necessary for him to take immediate action, to
        take such action or to give such direction in the matter as he deems
        necessary….”

   247.                     He further clarifies, with reference to Rule 23(viii) of the
        Transaction of Business Rules, that the submission of matters of
        administrative importance to the Lieutenant Governor is contemplated
        by the Rules: “…On being asked, I have to say that as per Rule 23
        (viii) of Transaction of Business of the Government of National
        Capital Territory of Delhi Rules 1993, any proposal or matter of
        administrative importance which the Chief Minister may consider

necessary can be submitted to the Lieutenant Governor through the
        Chief Secretary and the Chief Minister before issuing any orders
        thereon.”

   248.                     Thus, the forwarding of the file to the Lieutenant
        Governor cannot be characterised as extraordinary; it was consistent
        with the governing Rules.

   249.                     PW-88 also describes the procedure adopted during the
        Covid period for file processing within the LG Secretariat:
        “…..considering his health condition, necessary precautions were
        taken while processing the files received in the LG Secretariat for the
        perusal / approval of the Hon’ble LG. During this period, after
        receiving any file in the LG Secretariat for perusal / approval of the
        Hon’ble LG, generally the same used to be analyzed and processed by
        the concerned staff officer with assistance of the concerned section.
        However, physical files were normally not used to be sent to the
        Hon’ble LG. Instead of the same, internal notes used to be prepared
        and processed on the computer system (Google docs) by the staff
        officer to the Secretary / Principal Secretary to LG. The internal notes
        used to include the brief of proposal, preliminary scrutiny of the
        proposal, if required, legal aspects if any etc. The internal notes used
        to be sent through Google docs to the Hon’ble LG by me through the
        Principal Secretary/Secretary to Hon’ble LG. Then, as per the
        directions/approval of the Hon’ble LG, the decisions/observations

were used to be conveyed on the physical file to the concerned
        department/Minister/CS by the Senior Officers of LG Secretariat. The
        hard copies of the internal notes containing directions/approval of
        the Hon’ble LG used to be kept in the records in the LG Secretariat. I
        have to further say that on some occasions, keeping in view the
        requirement and the urgency of the matters, some physical files were
        also used to be sent to the Hon’ble LG for his perusal / signature.”

   250.                     PW-88, in his statement, supports the administrative
        sequence reflected from the record and explains the manner in which
        files were handled during the relevant period. He states that, owing to
        the Covid-19 situation, internal processing was largely undertaken in
        digital form instead of the usual physical circulation of files. Proposal
        briefs, scrutiny notes and legal comments were prepared electronically
        and forwarded to the office of the Hon’ble LG through the Principal
        Secretary/Secretary concerned. He further clarifies that the internal
        notes were first generated and shared digitally, and upon receipt of
        directions or approval, the same were printed and placed in the
        physical file. The hard copies containing such directions were retained
        as part of the official record in the ordinary course.

   251.                     The statement of PW-88, therefore, indicates that the
        procedure adopted during that period involved digital transmission
        followed by physical incorporation in the file, consistent with

administrative functioning under the constraints prevailing at the
        time.

   252.                     PW-87 corroborates this institutional engagement. She
        further states: “The proposed excise policy was deliberated in detail in
        the LG Secretariat and the apparent deficiencies in the policy were
        discussed with Hon’ble LG in multiple meetings along with the
        officers of the LG Secretariat.”. She clarifies: “I also state that
        informal discussion notes were prepared by the LG Secretariat for the
        discussion. However, as far as I remember, such notes for discussion,
        being informal, are generally not kept on record.”

   253.                     This part of the statement indicates that multiple
        meetings took place and the excise policy was deliberated in detail.

   254.                     Significantly, PW-87 also states that on 19.05.2021, the
        Hon’ble LG informed her that the matter had been discussed with the
        Hon’ble Chief Minister and the Hon’ble Deputy Chief Minister and
        that the policy could not be concurred with in its present form,
        pursuant to which she returned the file with the contemporaneous
        noting: “The instant matter was discussed by Hon’ble Lt. Governor
        with Hon’ble Chief Minister and Hon’ble Deputy CM. The file is
        being returned accordingly.”

   255.                     Although PW-87 clarifies that she “was not privy to the
        discussion,” her official noting remains the sole contemporaneous

documentary record of the outcome of that discussion. This
        contemporaneous endorsement assumes significance, as it evidences
        consultation at the highest executive level prior to further processing.

   256.                     Similarly, PW-88 states: “In the said file, there was a note
        put up by Dy.CM Sh. Manish Sisodia, Dy.CM on 20.05.2021, in which
        he mentioned seven points to be incorporated in the draft Excise
        Policy in pursuance of discussions among Hon’ble LG, Hon’ble CM
        and Dy. CM. In the said Note, Dy. CM asked Secretary Finance to
        prepare a proposal for the Cabinet incorporating the seven changes
        and marked the file to the Secretary Finance. Thereafter, fresh
        approval of the Council of Ministers was taken on the Cabinet Note
        and on 21.05.2021, Dy. CM noted in the file that “suggestions made
        by Hon’ble LG, in our meeting with him, have been approved by the
        Council of Ministers” and sent the file to CM, who marked the file to
        Hon’ble LG on the same day, i.e., 21.05.2021. On 24.05.2021, I as
        Additional Secretary to the Hon’ble LG noted in the file that “Hon’ble
        LG has been apprised” and sent the file to Secretary to CM for further
        necessary action.”

   257.                     PW-88 further states that the note dated 20.05.2021
        recorded by the Deputy Chief Minister reflected points arising out of
        discussions held with the Hon’ble LG and the Worthy Chief Minister.
        He deposes that on 21.05.2021 it was noted that the suggestions
        attributed to the Hon’ble LG had received approval of the Council of

Ministers. The file was thereafter returned on 24.05.2021 with the
        endorsement, “Hon’ble LG has been apprised.”

   258.                     This sequence of contemporaneous notings indicates that
        the inputs were treated within the administrative record as having
        emanated from the Hon’ble LG and were processed accordingly in the
        course of official decision-making. PW-88 and PW-87 both confirm
        the receipt and return of the file with the endorsement “Hon’ble LG
        has been apprised.” The documentary trail thus consistently reflects
        that seven suggestions were recorded as having arisen from
        discussions and were thereafter incorporated upon approval by the
        Council of Ministers.

   259.                     Significantly, neither PW-87 nor PW-88 has disputed the
        contents of these notings. The record further shows that the file
        remained under consideration in the LG Secretariat for a considerable
        duration, indicating institutional scrutiny rather than mechanical
        processing. Upon return of the file, it was categorically recorded that
        the suggestions stood incorporated in the policy, and the Deputy Chief
        Minister expressly noted their approval by the Council of Ministers.
        The subsequent endorsement “Hon’ble LG has been apprised,”
        recorded by PW-88 in discharge of official duty, demonstrates that the
        developments were communicated and placed before the Hon’ble LG.
        No allegation of fabrication, interpolation or tampering of these
        notings has been made by any witness.

260.                     It further emerges that the Excise Policy file was
        received in the LG Secretariat on multiple subsequent occasions,
        namely on 09.11.2021, 30.11.2021, 01.04.2022 and 05.04.2022; yet,
        no contemporaneous objection was recorded disputing the reference
        to seven suggestions.

   261.                     The next question that arises for consideration concerns
        the impact of the denial attributed to the Hon’ble LG in respect of the
        six suggestions alleged not to have emanated from him. This aspect
        must be examined within the confined scope of scrutiny permissible at
        the stage of framing of charge. At this juncture, the Court is not
        expected to undertake an exhaustive assessment of rival versions; its
        inquiry is limited to examining whether the material placed on record,
        if accepted at face value, warrants further consideration in accordance
        with law.

   262.                     Viewed in that light, the contemporaneous official
        notings assume central significance. The record contains specific
        endorsements and entries made in the regular course of governmental
        functioning, forming part of the official file. Equally relevant are the
        statements of the officers who dealt with and processed the file in the
        LG Secretariat. Their depositions, rendered in discharge of official
        duties, and the official notings recorded by them, do not support the
        version now attributed to the Hon’ble LG. On the contrary, they reflect

a consistent administrative narrative that discussions were held and
        that consequential entries were made in the file.

   263.                     The core question, therefore, is whether the Hon’ble LG
        can be permitted, in law, to deny the contents of official notings which
        stand explained, processed and effectively accepted by PW-87 and
        PW-88 in their statements. When the officers who handled the file
        have categorically spoken to the notings and have not alleged any
        fabrication or misattribution, the permissibility of a subsequent denial
        must be examined against the binding evidentiary value of the official
        record.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   264.                     In the limited enquiry permissible at this stage, where
        the Court is not to weigh evidence, but only to ascertain whether the
        material discloses a prima facie position, the contemporaneous
        documentary trail and the consistent statements of the officers dealing
        with the file assume determinative significance. Where the official
        record and the version of the responsible officers run contrary to the
        subsequent denial, the latter cannot be viewed in isolation from the
        institutional record.

   265.                     The notings forming part of the governmental file are
        official records maintained in the regular course of business by a
        public authority. They fall within the ambit of public documents as

contemplated under Section 74 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872.
        Section 35 of the Act, 1872 as under:

                “An entry in any public or other official book, register or
                record, stating a fact in issue or relevant fact, and made by a
                public servant in the discharge of his official duty, or by any
                other person in performance of a duty specially enjoined by the
                law of the country in which such book, register or record is
                kept, is itself a relevant fact.”
   266.                     Certified copies thereof are admissible under Sections
        76 and 77. The entries in the present file were made by public servants
        while discharging official functions and form part of a regularly
        maintained governmental record. They record, contemporaneously,
        the movement of the file, the noting of suggestions and the
        endorsements made in the course of decision-making. Such entries,
        having been made in discharge of official duty, attract the statutory
        recognition contemplated under Section 35.

   267.                     Once the record is produced from proper custody and no
        plea of fabrication, interpolation or tampering is raised, its existence
        and tenor cannot be brushed aside. The weight to be attached to the
        contents is a matter of appreciation; however, the authenticity of an
        official record maintained in the ordinary course of governmental
        business cannot be casually disputed. In the absence of any challenge
        to its genuineness, the contemporaneous notings stand unimpeached
        and cannot be displaced at a later stage by a mere oral variation.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
268.                     The evidentiary scheme of the Indian Evidence Act
        reinforces this position. Where the terms of a transaction, deliberation
        or official act have been reduced to writing, the document itself
        constitutes the best evidence of its contents. It is well-settled principle
        that when the contents of a document are in issue, oral evidence cannot
        be admitted to contradict, vary, add to or subtract from the written
        record, save in limited circumstances specifically provided by law. The
        official file notings in the present case are contemporaneous,
        authenticated and form part of the statutory record of governmental
        functioning. They expressly record that discussions took place with
        the Hon’ble LG and that “suggestions” emanating from such
        discussions were incorporated and approved.

   269.                     In the absence of any plea of fabrication, interpolation or
        want of authority, the law does not permit the contents of such a
        document to be nullified by a subsequent oral denial. An oral statement
        disputing the existence or number of suggestions, when the written
        record speaks otherwise, cannot override the documentary evidence.
        The proper course, if the record were inaccurate, would have been to
        challenge its authenticity or to plead and prove tampering. No such
        case is set up.

   270.                     Accordingly, so long as the official notings remain
        unchallenged in their genuineness, a mere oral assertion that only one
        suggestion was made cannot be treated as legally sufficient to displace

a written record that reflects seven suggestions having been discussed
        and incorporated. The law accords primacy to the document itself. The
        statement of the Hon’ble LG disputing the seven suggestions, in the
        face of the contemporaneous official record, cannot therefore prevail
        in law over the contents of the document.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   271.                     PW-86, while stating that he did not issue “suggestions”
        in the sense of prescribing policy clauses or commercial parameters,
        does not deny that observations or views were conveyed during
        scrutiny. His statement, read harmoniously with the documentary
        record, can only be understood in the limited sense that he did not
        dictate commercial specifics. It cannot be read as a negation of the
        deliberative inputs contemporaneously recorded by PW-87 and
        PW-88. Where the terms of a transaction or event are reduced to
        writing, the document itself constitutes the best and exclusive
        evidence of its contents. The official file notings, contemporaneous
        and authenticated, expressly record that discussions took place with
        the Hon’ble LG and that “suggestions” emanating from such
        discussions were approved by the Council of Ministers. Any
        subsequent oral assertion that no suggestion was given cannot, in law,
        override or contradict this written record, particularly at the threshold
        stage of framing of charge.

272.                     The administrative engagement of the Hon’ble LG did
        not cease with policy formulation. The subsequent handling of files
        relating to L-7 vends in non-conforming areas, where the Hon’ble LG
        imposed conditions regarding DDA/MCD approvals, responded to
        further notes of the Deputy Chief Minister, and constituted
        committees,              demonstrates   continued   involvement      in       the
        implementation phase. When the file was again routed to the Hon’ble
        LG in relation to these matters, the earlier chain of notings remained
        intact and undisputed.

   273.                     Even in the complaint dated 20.07.2022 (D-61)
        forwarded by the Hon’ble LG Shri V.K. Saxena, which preceded the
        registration of the FIR, there is no allegation that the suggestions were
        recorded without consultation or that the official notings were
        fabricated or misrepresented. The complaint does not allege any
        fabrication of the official notings. This omission assumes significance.
        If the contemporaneous official record reflecting consultation and
        apprisal is neither disowned nor challenged at the inception, the
        subsequent projection of unilateralism or concealment stands
        materially weakened. Juxtaposed with the statement of PW-3, Shri
        Praveen Kumar Rai, Director, Ministry of Home Affairs, who deposes
        that the Office Memorandum dated 22.07.2022 was issued for
        forwarding “the complaint received from Hon’ble LG of GNCTD,
        Shri Vinai Kumar Saxena,” to the Director, CBI “for necessary

action”, it becomes evident that the very constitutional office that was
        institutionally involved in the policy process later initiated the
        complaint.

                                                                      (emphasis supplied)

   274.                     This aspect, though perhaps not decisive in isolation,
        assumes considerable importance when examined in the broader
        context of the prosecution’s theory of conspiracy. The position taken
        by PW-86 must be viewed against the institutional and legal
        consequences that would inevitably follow from an unqualified
        acknowledgment             that    specific     suggestions   were    made          and
        subsequently incorporated. If it were to be accepted that seven
        suggestions emanated from the Hon’ble LG and were duly
        incorporated into the policy after discussion, then the deliberative
        process would stand institutionally shared. In that eventuality, any
        allegation that the incorporation of those suggestions formed part of a
        criminal design would logically extend to Sh. Anil Baijal, who was the
        constitutional authority and the Hon’ble LG at the relevant time, and
        to the officers of the LG Secretariat who processed, recorded and
        communicated those inputs.

   275.                     This   Court     refrains    from   making       any     adverse
        observation against the office of the Hon’ble LG. The office is a
        constitutional one, and judicial restraint is both appropriate and
        necessary. However, when the statements of PW-87 and PW-88 are

read conjointly and examined alongside the contemporaneous file
        record, a clear divergence becomes apparent. Both these witnesses
        were senior officers entrusted with the day-to-day functioning of the
        Secretariat and with supervising the movement and processing of
        official files. Their statements are in harmony with the notings
        recorded on the file in the ordinary course of official business. The
        sequence reflected in those notings, endorsement, consideration and
        onward transmission, stands explained by them as part of established
        administrative procedure carried out in discharge of official duty.

   276.                     PW-86, who held the office of the Hon’ble LG at the
        relevant time, has stated a position which does not fully accord with
        the tenor of the official record as elucidated by the officers responsible
        for handling and maintaining the file. The divergence concerns the
        attribution and reflection of certain suggestions in the notings. At this
        juncture, the Court does not propose to enter into a deeper examination
        of that inconsistency. The present exercise is confined to the limited
        scrutiny permissible at the stage of framing of charge. The matter is,
        therefore, left at that, and the Court restricts itself to assessing whether
        the material on record, taken at face value, discloses grounds sufficient
        to proceed.

   277.                     It is therefore not without significance that none of the
        witnesses from the LG Secretariat has alleged fabrication of the
        notings, nor has any plea been taken that the recorded endorsements

were unauthorised or falsely attributed. A categorical admission that
        such suggestions were made and incorporated could potentially
        expose PW-86 to criminal scrutiny under the very theory now
        advanced. In that backdrop, a guarded or qualified denial cannot be
        viewed in isolation from the consequences that a contrary admission
        would entail.

   278.                     Conversely, if the prosecution were to accept that the
        suggestions did, in fact, emanate from the Hon’ble LG and were
        formally incorporated following discussion and approval by the
        Council of Ministers, the foundational premise of unilateral
        manipulation stands fundamentally eroded. The theory of conspiracy,
        predicated upon concealment or misattribution of inputs, cannot
        logically survive if the official record reflects consultation,
        communication and institutional concurrence at the highest executive
        level. The prosecution cannot, on the one hand, rely upon the sanctity
        and authenticity of official records, and on the other, disown the same
        record when it evidences shared deliberation.

                                                                (emphasis supplied)

   279.                   Thus, the matter presents a structural inconsistency in the
        prosecution narrative: either the suggestions were genuinely part of an
        institutional process, in which case the allegation of unilateral criminal
        design loses force; or the official record is to be doubted, in which
        event the prosecution would have to confront the far more serious

implication of institutional falsification, a case neither pleaded nor
        supported by evidence. At the present stage, the contemporaneous
        documentary record, unchallenged in its authenticity, assumes
        primacy and substantially weakens the conspiracy theory as
        projected.

   280.                     At the limited stage of consideration for framing of
        charge, the documentary trail and contemporaneous file notings
        assume primacy. Tested against this record, the defence contention that
        there was transparency, institutional consultation and continuous
        involvement of the LG Secretariat finds substantial support in the
        prosecution’s own witnesses. The material, as it presently stands, does
        not disclose a prima facie case of policy concealment, unilateralism or
        exclusion of the constitutional authority. On the contrary, the record
        reflects a process marked by consultation, communication and
        administrative caution.

   281.                     In the light of the discussion above, the prosecution
        version stands eroded. The contemporaneous record shows that the
        DEP-21/22 was formulated and processed with consultation at the
        highest executive level, including the involvement of the Lieutenant
        Governor’s Secretariat. The file notings record discussions,
        incorporation of inputs, approval by the Council of Ministers and
        subsequent apprisal of the Hon’ble LG.

282.                     In these circumstances, a charge of conspiracy founded
        on concealment or unilateral manipulation cannot be sustained against
        A-8 in isolation when the same documentary record reflects
        deliberation and movement of the file through constitutional channels.
        The material indicates institutional participation rather than an
        individualised exercise of authority. It is clarified that this observation
        is not intended to attribute liability to any other authority. The limited
        conclusion, at this stage, is that the record does not disclose prima
        facie material to show that A-8 acted unilaterally or engineered any
        concealed manipulation in the formulation of the policy.

   283.                     Lastly, what renders the entire discussion untenable is
        that the prosecution itself departs from its own foundation. The seven
        suggestions are attributed solely to A-8, yet the record reflects that
        these suggestions were stated to have arisen during deliberations with
        the Hon’ble LG. If A-8 was, as alleged, the sole architect of a draft
        prepared and supplied by the so-called South Group, there was no
        apparent reason for him not to incorporate those very suggestions in
        the draft policy. The prosecution’s position, therefore, lacks internal
        consistency.

   284.                     More importantly, even if the prosecution case is taken
        at its highest, only one out of the seven alleged suggestions is linked
        to any supposed benefit. That suggestion concerns the reduction of the
        turnover requirement for grant of L-1 licence from ₹250 crores per

year for the preceding three years (excluding the Covid year) to ₹150
        crores. According to the prosecution, this reduction enabled M/S
        Indospirit to become eligible for the L-1 licence, which it otherwise
        would not have secured.

   285.                     However, this contention conflicts with the broader
        conspiracy theory advanced by the prosecution itself. It is also alleged
        that the second draft GoM report dated 19.03.2021 was prepared and
        supplied by the South Group. Significantly, the turnover criterion in
        that draft was ₹500 crores per year for the preceding five years, far
        higher than both ₹250 crores and ₹150 crores. The prosecution further
        suggests that this higher threshold was intended to eliminate smaller
        competitors.

   286.                     These two positions cannot stand together. On one hand,
        the South Group is alleged to have proposed a ₹500-crore threshold to
        exclude competition. On the other, the reduction to ₹150 crores is said
        to have been introduced to benefit the same group. Such diametrically
        opposite assertions erode the credibility of the conspiracy theory.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   287.                     The record also shows that M/S Indospirit, associated
        with A-7 and projected as the vehicle for alleged recoupment, had
        initially applied for an L-1 licence but withdrew its first application as
        it did not meet even the ₹150-crore eligibility criterion. This fact is of

considerable significance. If the reduction to ₹150 crores had been
        specifically engineered to favour that entity, it is difficult to explain
        why it failed to qualify under the very condition allegedly tailored for
        its benefit.

   288.                     The documentary record therefore indicates that the
        turnover requirement functioned as an objective eligibility condition
        and not as a pre-designed mechanism to secure a predetermined
        outcome. When the prosecution’s own material is read as a whole, it
        reveals clear internal contradictions which materially weaken, indeed,
        demolish, the allegation that the turnover clause was inserted pursuant
        to a pre-conceived conspiracy. Consequently, the prosecution has
        failed to disclose even a prima facie case against A-8 on this aspect.

        (ii) Alleged Suppression of Adverse Legal Opinions by removal of the
        Cabinet Note dated 28.01.2021

   289.                   The prosecution alleges that A-8 deliberately removed an
        office note containing legal opinions which were not in favour of the
        proposed policy. According to the prosecution, those opinions created
        a hurdle because the DEP-21/22 ultimately adopted differed from the
        recommendations made in the Ravi Dhawan Report.

   290.                     The case of the prosecution is that the Ravi Dhawan
        Committee had recommended that wholesale trade should remain with
        a government-controlled entity functioning through a cooperative
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
structure, and that retail vends should be allotted by lottery. In contrast,
        the DEP-21/22 provided for privatisation of the wholesale segment
        and allocation of retail zones through competitive bidding. It is on this
        basis that the prosecution asserts that the office note containing the
        legal opinions was intentionally removed so that the policy could
        proceed in the desired form.

   291.                   This allegation forms the foundation of the prosecution’s
        case on this issue and will now be examined in the light of the material
        placed on record.

   292.                  The issue assumes importance when para 16.10 and 16.12
        of the First Supplementary Charge-sheet and para 16.5 of the Third
        and Fourth Supplementary Charge-sheets are read in the manner the
        investigating agency has presented them. The prosecution’s case is that
        the “03 legal opinions of Sh. Ranjan Gogoi… Sh. Mukul Rohatgi…
        and Justice KG Balakrishnan…” were “mostly in favour of
        maintaining the status-quo,” and that “after the said Cabinet Meeting
        on 28.01.2021, the accused Manish Sisodia called Sh. Rahul Singh
        and expressed his anger for incorporating the comments of the legal
        experts in the Cabinet Note.” It is further alleged that “these facts
        establish that the accused Manish Sisodia, in criminal conspiracy…
        was working with a pre-conceived idea… and dishonestly and
        deliberately did not put up the cabinet note… and destroyed/cause
        disappearance of the file… because it was not suiting their ulterior

designs,” and that “a vital file containing the opinion of three legal
        experts, which was against his pre-conceived ideas was deliberately
        destroyed by him.”

   293.                     The exact Extracts from the Supplementary Charge-
        Sheets are reproduced herein below for ready reference:-

        First Supplementary Charge-Sheet

                 “ 16.10… In the said draft Cabinet Note; along with the
                summary of the comments/suggestions received from
                public/stakeholders, the 03 legal opinions of Sh. Ranjan Gogoi,
                Former Chief Justice of India; Sh. Mukul Rohatgi, Senior
                Advocate & Former Attorney General for India and Justice KG
                Balakrishnan, Former Chief Justice of India, obtained by Delhi
                ALCOBEV Retailers Association, and forwarded by them to
                the Excise Department on the dedicated email ID, were also
                mentioned by the Excise officials and Shri Rahul Singh in the
                forwarding Note for the Council of Ministers and copies of
                these legal opinions were also annexed with the Cabinet note.
                It is revealed that these legal opinions were mostly in favour of
                maintaining the status-quo……. It has been also revealed that
                after the said Cabinet Meeting on 28.01.2021, the accused
                Manish Sisodia called Sh. Rahul Singh and expressed his anger
                for incorporating the comments of the legal experts in the
                Cabinet Note.”
                “16.12…..These facts establish that the accused Manish
                Sisodia, in criminal conspiracy with other accused persons,
                was working with a pre-conceived idea to formulate the excise
                policy in a particular manner to suit the designs of co-accused
                persons and dishonestly and deliberately did not put up the
                cabinet note containing comments of legal experts as annexure
                in the Cabinet meeting dated 28.1.2021 and destroyed/cause
                disappearance of the file of the said Cabinet Note, because it
                was not suiting their ulterior designs.”

Third & Fourth Supplementary Charge-Sheets

                “16.5…..A vital file containing the opinion of three legal
                experts, which was against his pre-conceived ideas was
                deliberately destroyed by him.”\
   294.                     In substance, the charge-sheet is framed to convey that
        the opinions were “against his pre-conceived ideas,” and that the
        accused removed or destroyed the file to prevent any impediment to
        his alleged design. The language employed, “pre-conceived idea,”
        “criminal conspiracy,” “dishonestly and deliberately,” and “vital
        file… deliberately destroyed”, is clearly directed towards attribution
        of motive and intent, and it is presented in a manner which invites the
        Court to treat the alleged removal of the file as conduct reinforcing the
        broader conspiracy theory.

   295.                  The allegation requires consideration on two aspects.

   296.                   Firstly, it has to be examined whether the legal opinions
        contained in the office note were of such a nature that they could have
        actually obstructed the formulation of the DEP-21/22. A legal opinion,
        by itself, does not automatically prevent a policy decision. It must be
        seen whether the opinion was binding or prohibitory in character, or
        whether it merely expressed reservations or suggested an alternative
        course. Unless the opinion clearly barred the proposed policy
        measures, it cannot be assumed that it stood as an insurmountable
        obstacle.

297.                    Secondly, even if the opinions were adverse to certain
        features of the proposed policy, it must be established that the office
        note was deliberately removed. The allegation of removal cannot rest
        on conjecture. There must be material to indicate conscious and
        intentional suppression. In the absence of such material, no adverse
        inference can be drawn merely on the basis of an alleged
        disappearance.

   298.                    Both these questions require examination on the strength
        of the record.

                 Constitutional Concerns Expressed in the Legal Opinions allegedly
                  to have been concealed

   299.                    Before examining the contents of the legal opinions, it is
        necessary to record that these three opinions were obtained by the
        Alcobev Retail Association and forwarded as suggestions when the
        Ravi Dhawan Report was placed in the public domain for comments.
        They were not opinions sought by the Government in the course of its
        internal decision-making, but were inputs received during the
        consultation process.

   300.                    The fact that these opinions were sent is reflected from
        D-125, which shows the email along with attachments. However, the
        printouts of the legal opinions were not placed on record as standalone
        documents. They are traceable only from the email dump contained in

D-108, which consists of a CD containing more than 14,000 emails.
        At this stage, this Court leaves that aspect open and shall revert to it,
        if required, after examining the report and the surrounding material.

   301.                  For examining whether the opinions were of such a nature
        as to obstruct the proposed policy, it is necessary to go through them
        in their entirety. Any conclusion must rest on a reading of the opinions
        as a whole. They cannot be read in fragments.

   302.                The features now alleged to be the outcome of a conspiracy
        are stated to have been discussed in these opinions. For proper
        appreciation, the relevant extracts are reproduced below so that their
        contents may be assessed in their correct context.

        1. Limiting grant of retail licenses to individuals

        Justice Ranjan Gogoi records: “I am of the opinion that the rationale
        given by the new committee in limiting grant of licenses to only
        individuals - that this would minimize the chances of proxy ownership
        that lead to creation of cartels - would not pass muster of Article 14 of
        the Constitution of India.” (Para 4)

        He further observes: “While avoidance of cartelization and proxy
        ownership is surely a laudable objective, the end to achieve such
        means i.e. limiting grant of licenses to individuals does not appear to
        bear a reasonable or rational nexus with that objective. This would
        violate the doctrine of proportionality…” (Para 5)

Shri Mukul Rohatgi states: “There is no valid reason as to why
        Companies, Partnerships and Co-operative Societies are excluded
        while such entities are permitted to carry any other form of
        business…. There is no restriction on family members obtaining
        license and in fact, any individual can obtain two licenses and further
        transfer / sale of license is permitted.”

        Justice K.G. Balakrishnan adds: “ The combined effect of these
        clauses would mean, for example, that in a family of, say, A, his wife
        B, and one son C and one daughter D, each of A, B,C,D and hold 2
        licenses each and in fact even purchase licenses. Thus, a single family
        could end up having 8 licenses, and none of these may actually be
        obtained from the initial lottery but may be purchases from others who
        may have succeeded in the lottery only based on speculative
        applications. This would in fact be not only lead to cartelization and
        proxy ownership but would also”

        2. Lottery system and Clause 1.3.12 – Permitting transfer of ownership
        (exit option)

        Shri Mukul Rohatgi observes: “Policy of lottery have been proposed.
        The same will lead to complete uncertainty as to who will be
        successful and where. The location of the vend is also not within the
        choice of the applicant.”

Justice K.G. Balakrishnan notes: “Clause 1.3.12 permits sale of
        interest in the vend obtained through lottery.” and further: “It
        contemplates and grant sort of official recognition to a situation where
        a non-serious applicant with little or no knowledge could actually
        succeed in the lottery and then sell it off to anyone else.”

        Justice Ranjan Gogoi observes: “In fact, the logic of Clause 1.3.12 -
        that permitting transfer of ownership would ‘provide an exit option to
        a non-serious applicant who has little or no knowledge or liquor
        trade - is incongruous…” (Para 8) “…there shall be no limit on the
        number of applications which an individual may make…” (Para 8
        referring to Clause 1.3.4)

        3. Revamping pricing mechanism (letting L1 licensees define the
        MRP)

        Justice K.G. Balakrishnan notes: “After letting the L1 licensee
        decide the MRP, the government would work backwards…” and
        further states that “this would put the select manufacturers in a
        dominant position to decide pricing, would be violative of fair
        competition.”

        Justice Ranjan Gogoi similarly observes: “…competition is being
        reduced to 4 companies only… and then the pricing regime is being
        changed… I am of the opinion that this would put the select
        manufacturers in a dominant position to decide pricing…”

303.                     The record shows that the legal opinions were obtained
        by the Association in the backdrop of the suggestions contained in the
        Ravi Dhawan Report. The proposed clauses, particularly those
        concerning the retail segment, formed the basis on which the opinions
        were sought. The queries were largely confined to issues relating to
        retailers and the manner of allotment of retail vends.

   304.                   A reading of the opinions as a whole shows that they raise
        concerns regarding arbitrariness, absence of rational nexus, possible
        concentration of licences, proxy ownership, cartelisation and
        dominance in pricing. They do not record any categorical objection to
        structural reform, privatisation of wholesale trade, or allocation of
        retail zones through competitive bidding. On the contrary, in relation
        to retail allotment by lottery, the opinions express reservations about
        the lottery framework. None of the experts stated that wholesale must
        remain with a government corporation, nor did they opine that
        privatisation was impermissible.

   305.                   Even if these opinions had been annexed to the Cabinet
        Note, it is difficult to see how they would have created any obstacle.
        The opinions themselves described aspects of the lottery-based model
        as arbitrary and constitutionally vulnerable. Far from hindering a
        change in approach, such observations could have provided a basis for
        reconsidering the suggested framework and for the constitution of a
        GoM to examine the matter further.

306.                   In this background, the Court is unable to appreciate how
        the legal opinions could be treated as an impediment to the DEP-21/22
        that was later framed. The prosecution has placed considerable
        emphasis on the Ravi Dhawan Report and on these opinions. However,
        on a plain reading, the principal criticism in the opinions was directed
        against the lottery system for allotment of retail vends. The policy that
        ultimately emerged replaced the lottery system with allocation through
        bidding.

   307.                  Seen in this light, the assertion that the legal opinions stood
        in the way of the policy, particularly the clauses now alleged to
        constitute the core of the supposed modus operandi for recoupment of
        ₹90–100 crores as upfront payment, does not find support in the text
        of the opinions themselves.

              Suppression by Obscurity: Placement of Allegedly Vital Material
                  Within a Voluminous Electronic Record - Conduct of the
                  Investigating Officer and Its Impact on Fair Investigation

   308.                     This Court considers it necessary to resume and clarify
        what was earlier left incomplete regarding the manner in which the
        legal opinions were placed with the charge-sheet.

   309.                     The way in which these opinions have been brought on
        record is of relevance. They have not been filed as separate relied-
        upon documents. What has been formally exhibited is only the first

page of the email forwarded to the official email ID, marked as D-125.
        The actual text of the opinions has not been placed as independent
        annexures. They are traceable only through the email dump marked as
        D-108, which consists of a compact disc containing more than
        fourteen thousand emails.

   310.                     If these opinions were truly regarded as material of
        central importance, they would ordinarily have been placed on record
        distinctly and in a form enabling ready reference. That course was not
        adopted. The contents were not set out separately or highlighted in the
        charge-sheet. During arguments, the opinions did not readily present
        themselves for consideration, as they remained embedded within a
        voluminous electronic record. Their retrieval required sifting through
        the entire email dump rather than referring to a clearly identified
        relied-upon document.

   311.                     In effect, material now described as “vital” was not
        presented in a manner consistent with such characterisation. Instead,
        it remained part of a large pool of electronic data. The manner in which
        it was placed on record assumes significance when the prosecution
        seeks to attach decisive weight to it.

   312.                     At the same time, it is to be fairly recorded that when the
        Court specifically sought the material, and it became difficult to locate
        the opinions within the electronic record, the prosecution did trace and
        furnish copies, thereby enabling scrutiny. That aspect is duly noted.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
313.                     However, the manner in which the material was
        originally placed on record requires examination. Even at the cost of
        repetition, it is evident that the charge-sheet places considerable
        emphasis on motive and intent, employing expressions such as “pre-
        conceived            idea,”   “criminal   conspiracy,”   “dishonestly         and
        deliberately,” and “vital file… deliberately destroyed.” Yet the very
        document said to form the basis of such an inference was not distinctly
        presented in a manner that would permit it to be readily examined and
        tested at the same stage.

   314.                     The prosecution case proceeds on the footing that the
        legal opinions were deliberately removed because they were adverse
        and stood in the way of the alleged conspiracy. An allegation of
        deliberate removal of official record, particularly against a person
        holding the office of Deputy Chief Minister (A-8), is of serious
        consequence. If such an allegation is founded upon the contents of
        certain legal opinions, those opinions ought to have been placed before
        the Court clearly and distinctly.

   315.                     Instead, the material remained embedded within a
        voluminous electronic dump. The charge-sheet itself runs into
        thousands of pages and refers to several hundred witnesses. In that
        setting, material not distinctly identified is liable to remain unnoticed
        for a considerable time. The presentation gives the appearance that the
        conclusion is foregrounded, while the supporting material is left to be

discovered only upon deeper scrutiny , almost as if one were searching
        for a needle in a haystack.

   316.                     At this stage, the Court finds itself in a certain dilemma
        as to where the element of “pre-conceived idea” truly lies, whether in
        the conduct attributed to the accused or in the manner in which the
        material has been presented by the investigating officer. The manner
        in which the record has been structured does not sit comfortably with
        the obligation to ensure fairness in the process. A fair trial is a
        fundamental right of every citizen, and the presentation of material
        must reflect that obligation.

                                                                 (emphasis supplied)

   317.                     In view of the foregoing discussion, the allegation of
        suppression of adverse legal opinion does not, prima facie, sustain
        itself on the material presently examined. The contents of the opinions,
        as they stand, do not justify the inference that their alleged non-
        placement or disappearance was actuated by a design to conceal
        binding or prohibitory advice.

   318.                     However, the matter cannot rest there. Since the
        prosecution has attached considerable significance to this allegation
        and seeks to draw a wider inference of motive and conspiracy from it,
        it would be appropriate to examine the relevant witnesses and
        surrounding circumstances so as to have a complete view of the matter.

The       oral      evidence,   the   sequence   of   file   movement,          the
        contemporaneous conduct of officers, and the manner in which
        documents were processed will therefore require scrutiny, before a
        final conclusion is drawn on the evidentiary worth of the allegation.

   319.                     The most significant statement in this regard is that of
        Ashok Daryani (PW-80), who was Assistant Commissioner (Policy)
        during the relevant period and was appointed as the Nodal Officer to
        process the comments received from the public on the Expert
        Committee (Rajeev Dhawan) Report. On a considered appraisal of the
        statement of PW-80, the record reflects that he occupied a pivotal
        administrative position in the formative stage of the DEP-21/22,
        having served in that capacity from mid-December 2020 to
        15.02.2021. His deposition establishes that the consultative exercise
        initiated pursuant to the Dy. CM’s noting dated 16.12.2020 was
        undertaken under clear and detailed ministerial directions, which
        required publication of the Expert Committee Report, invitation of
        comments, issuance of advertisements, creation of a dedicated e-mail
        ID and appointment of a Nodal Officer. PW-80 confirms that “Sh.
        Manish Sisodia, Dy. CM vide noting dated 16.12.2020 directed…”
        these steps and that, in consequence, he was appointed to receive,
        scrutinise and summarise all stakeholder inputs.

   320.                     PW-80 further states that a substantial corpus of
        responses, “14,671 numbers of emails”, was received and examined

through three internal teams. He specifically records that strict
        instructions were already in place “not to mention the names/identity
        of the mail senders as well as the number of persons sending same type
        of comments/suggestions.” This requirement of anonymity constituted
        an important safeguard embedded in the ministerial directions. The
        statement, however, discloses that the draft Cabinet Note prepared on
        27-28.01.2021, at the instance of the then Commissioner Rahul Singh
        and executed through PW-80, departed from these anonymity
        requirements.            PW-80   acknowledges   that   while   summarising
        stakeholder comments, certain suggestions received from the Delhi
        ALCOBEV Retailers Association “along with the opinions of Sh.
        Ranjan Gogoi… Sh. Mukul Rohatgi… and Justice K.G.
        Balakrishnan” were placed as separate annexures, Annexure-C and
        Annexure-D, to the draft Cabinet Note dated 28.01.2021. This
        inclusion, despite express directions to anonymise all inputs, places
        the role of the departmental officers, particularly Rahul Singh and
        PW-80, into sharper focus.

   321.                     Significantly, PW-80 records that the Dy. CM “has taken
        it otherwise that the department has put up the comments of the legal
        experts separately along with the Cabinet Note,” indicating that this
        deviation was viewed adversely at the ministerial level and did not
        emanate from any instruction or desire of the Dy. CM. In this
        backdrop, the preparation of a draft note expressly identifying expert

opinions, contrary to standing directions, emerges as a departmental
        deviation rather than a ministerial act. PW-80 also narrates that the
        draft Cabinet Note was prepared in unusual haste following a late-
        night phone call, with the format forwarded to his WhatsApp and
        approval obtained “in the hospital… as his wife was expecting and
        admitted there.” The file was thereafter taken to the CM’s Camp
        Office, where PW-80 states that the Cabinet “did not consider” the
        note and the file was withheld. This sequence underscores the
        procedural irregularity surrounding the first draft.

   322.                     After Sanjay Goel assumed charge as Commissioner on
        03.02.2021, PW-80 confirms that a revised and structured approach
        was adopted in line with the Dy. CM’s note dated 02.02.2021,
        directing that the Expert Committee Report and the summary of public
        and stakeholder comments be submitted to the Council of Ministers.
        Sanjay Goel (PW-78) instructed the removal of the descriptive
        portions of Annexure-C and Annexure-D and their hard copies,
        clarifying that the material was to be assimilated into the main
        summary and that “no name or identity of any stakeholder/legal expert
        has to be mentioned.” PW-80 explains that the legal opinions were not
        discarded or suppressed; they were retained in substance but
        anonymised and merged into the consolidated summary in accordance
        with the earlier directions proved by PW-78 that “to include all the
        suggestions              and   comments   received   in   the   summary           of

comments/suggestions of general public stakeholders without
        specifying comments received from any corner. Accordingly, the
        dealing hand put up a draft cabinet note on 04.02.2021 along with
        revised summary incorporating all comments/suggestions received.”.
        The final Cabinet Note dated 04.02.2021 thus contained the complete
        inputs, including the legal opinions, presented in conformity with the
        anonymity protocol established on 16.12.2020.

   323.                     The revised note was duly processed through the
        administrative hierarchy, approved by the Dy. CM and the Chief
        Minister on 05.02.2021, and placed before the Cabinet as a tabled
        item, resulting in Cabinet Decision No. 2942 dated 05.02.2021
        constituting a GoM to examine the Expert Committee Report and all
        stakeholder feedback. PW-80 concludes by stating that he was
        transferred w.e.f. 15.02.2021 and was therefore not aware of
        subsequent developments. His statement thus delineates the
        administrative flow and reveals that the only clear deviation from the
        Dy. CM’s directions, particularly on anonymity, occurred at the
        departmental drafting stage under Rahul Singh and PW-80.

   324.                     The statement of PW-82, Pravesh Ranjan Jha, further
        reinforces this position. On a considered evaluation of his evidence,
        no circumstance emerges from which an adverse inference can be
        drawn against the political executive in relation to the preparation,
        approval or placement of the draft note dated 28.01.2021. PW-82

categorically states that although officials of the Excise Department
        approached him around 01:00 PM on 28.01.2021 with a request to
        send an Excise proposal for placement before the Council of
        Ministers, “no matter of Excise Policy was mentioned in the agenda
        for the aforesaid Cabinet Meeting.” He further clarifies that the
        proposal “was not considered by the Council of Ministers on that
        day” and that the file was never returned to him and remains
        untraceable, with both the Chief Minister Office and the Chief
        Minister’s Camp Office certifying that it is not available with them.
        Even assuming, for the sake of argument, that the draft note enclosed
        in the missing file contained formulations not strictly conforming to
        the Dy. CM’s anonymity directions, the record does not establish that
        such a note was ever approved, signed, endorsed or acted upon by the
        Dy. CM or placed before the Cabinet. PW-82’s statement is categorical
        that the proposal was not considered.

   325.                     The consistent position emerging from PW-80 and
        PW-82 is that the substance of all suggestions, including expert legal
        opinions and public inputs, was ultimately collated and incorporated
        in the subsequent Cabinet Note dated 04.02.2021 without omission or
        alteration, thereby negating any allegation of suppression or filtration
        at the ministerial level. Accordingly, the non-traceability of the
        physical file dated 28.01.2021 does not advance the prosecution’s
        case. The draft note never attained the status of a placed, processed or

approved Cabinet document, nor does the evidence disclose any act of
        the Dy. CM conferring legitimacy upon its contents. Once the legal
        opinions and stakeholder inputs stood incorporated in anonymised
        form in the Cabinet Note dated 04.02.2021 and were duly placed
        before the Cabinet, the very premise of suppression or removal ceased
        to survive.

   326.                     Finally, the ancillary allegation that the Dy. CM
        expressed displeasure with certain notings and allegedly “displaced”
        the file also fails to disclose any criminal culpability. The Transaction
        of Business Rules, 1993 (TOBR) prescribe a detailed, institutional
        framework for conduct of governmental business, leaving no scope for
        unilateral derailment of policy-making by an individual Minister. The
        Rules cast a clear duty upon the Secretary concerned to escalate any
        impediment to the Chief Minister and, under Rule 30, to the Hon’ble
        LG. The record is silent on any such escalation, further undermining
        the prosecution narrative.

   327.                     Viewed cumulatively, the material on record does not
        disclose suppression of adverse legal opinions, any deliberate removal
        of material, or any mens rea attributable to the Dy. CM (A-8). At the
        highest, the evidence points to a procedural deviation at the
        departmental             drafting   stage,   subsequently   corrected     through
        institutional processes, which falls far short of meeting the threshold
        required for framing of charge.

(iii) Assessment of the Alleged 36-Page Draft in Light of the Record
        and its Impact on Fair Trial

   328.               The prosecution has attempted to construct a narrative
        concerning the preparation of the draft GoM report dated 19.03.2021.
        The substance of the allegation is that a set of 36 printed pages was
        generated externally, allegedly by members of the “South Group,” and
        that this very set of 36 pages ultimately travelled through the accused
        persons and became the basis of the second draft GoM report. The
        insinuation is that the draft report was not the result of internal
        deliberation within the Government, but was supplied from outside
        and thereafter formalised within the office of the Dy. CM. The
        allegation thus strikes at the integrity of the policy formulation process
        and seeks to attribute external authorship to the draft itself.

   329.           The charge-sheet relies upon the following extracts:

                “ 16.15 – The investigation further revealed that on 18.03.2021,
                the accused Manish Sisodia, the then Dy. CM, handed over to
                Sh. C. Arvind a hard copy of a draft report of GoM for typing
                and proper formatting. The said draft of GoM report was got
                typed by Sh. C. Arvind on the desktop computer installed at the
                conference room of Dy. CM office with the assistance of his PS
                Sh. Sunil Singhal on two days i.e. 18th & till late night on 19th
                March 2021….
                16.16 ….As per the property of the said 38 pages (including 01
                page label + 01 page index + 36 pages report) word file, it was
                last modified at 10:28 PM on 19.03.2021, which corroborates
                the versions of Sh. C. Arvind and Sh. Sunil Singhal, the
                typist, who have confirmed that the typing work of the draft

GoM report was completed at around 10:30 PM on
                19.03.2021.
                16.18 …….. The said accused persons also used the computer
                kept at the Business Center of Oberoi Hotel and took a photo
                copy of 36 pages from the hotel, which matches (minus the
                index and title pages) with the number of pages of draft of the
                GoM report retrieved from the computer installed in the
                Conference Hall of Dy. CM’s office….”
   330.                     Placed in sequence, these extracts are intended to
        convey that the 36 pages photocopied at the Oberoi Hotel business
        centre were the very same 36 pages (excluding index and title pages)
        that later formed part of the draft GoM report typed in the Dy. CM’s
        office. The similarity in page count is projected as proof of identity.
        The narrative thus suggests a continuous chain, preparation of a 36-
        page document outside the Government office, its movement through
        certain accused persons, its delivery for typing, and its emergence as
        the draft GoM report dated 19.03.2021. The intended inference is that
        the draft report was externally prepared and internally processed.

   331.                     This chain of inference, however, stands contradicted by
        the prosecution’s own witnesses. PW-71, through whom the alleged
        transmission is sought to be established, clearly states: “ I saw that sh.
        Sisodia was present there alongwith sh. Satyendra Jain and Sh.
        Kejriwal in the camp office . In their presence, dy cm sh. Shisodia gave
        me a printed hard copy of a draft report of GoM of about 20-25 pages
        “ and further clarifies that the printed hard copy handed over to him
        by A-8 consisted of “about 20–25 pages.” This is a categorical
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
assertion regarding the volume of the document allegedly received by
        him at the camp office. The same is reflected in his statement recorded
        under Section 164 of Cr.P.C. (D-187). There is no scope in this
        statement for equating the document received by PW-71 with a 36-
        page printout.

   332.                     The position is further supported by PW-72, the
        stenographer who typed the draft report. On a specific query, PW-72
        states that he typed “25–30 pages.” This statement assumes
        significance, as it emanates from the person directly involved in the
        preparation of the draft. If the draft supplied to PW-71 had been a 36-
        page document, there is no explanation as to why both PW-71 and
        PW-72 consistently refer to a substantially smaller document.

   333.                     The documentary record reinforces this conclusion. The
        first draft GoM report dated 15.03.2021 (Ex. D-196) consists of 24
        pages. The subsequent second draft GoM report dated 19.03.2021 (Ex.
        D-195) expands to 38 pages, and the final GoM report (Ex. D-197)
        runs into 49 pages. This progressive increase in volume reflects an
        evolving drafting process. It is inconsistent with the prosecution’s
        theory of a pre-existing 36-page document being merely circulated and
        adopted. The attempt to correlate the 36-page hotel printout with the
        38-page draft dated 19.03.2021 is speculative and unsupported by the
        record.

334.                     The allegation, when tested against the record, stands
        substantially undermined by the very content of the second GoM draft
        report. The introduction of the turnover eligibility clause requiring
        ₹500 crores per annum for the preceding five years is wholly
        inconsistent with the prosecution’s theory of a pre-designed
