        conspiracy intended to benefit M/S Indospirit.

   335.                     It is a matter of record that such a stringent threshold, if
        applied, would have rendered M/S Indospirit ineligible at the very
        threshold. A requirement of ₹500 crores annual turnover for five
        consecutive years is not a marginal or cosmetic stipulation; it is a
        substantial financial benchmark that effectively excludes entities
        lacking sustained high-value operations. Far from facilitating entry,
        such a clause would have operated as a clear disqualification.

   336.                     Even when the final DEP-21/22 ultimately prescribed a
        significantly reduced criterion of ₹150 crores per annum for the
        preceding three years for the grant of an L-1 licence, the material
        indicates that M/S IMPL still faced difficulty in meeting the
        qualification parameters. If an entity struggled to satisfy a
        comparatively lower eligibility norm, it is inconceivable that a much
        higher threshold of ₹500 crores for five years could have been
        designed to advance its interests.

   337.                     This aspect strikes at the core of the alleged conspiracy.
        The prosecution theory proceeds on the premise that the draft clauses

were tailored to favour specific private entities and to enable
        recoupment of alleged “upfront” payments. However, a clause that
        objectively disqualifies the very entity said to be a beneficiary defeats
        the suggested motive. A conspiratorial design to extend unlawful
        advantage cannot logically coexist with the insertion of an eligibility
        condition that blocks entry altogether.

                                                                   (emphasis supplied)

   338.                     Accordingly, the turnover clause in the second GoM
        draft not only fails to support the allegation of external manipulation
        but, on the contrary, frustrates the very object attributed to the alleged
        conspirators. It renders the theory of deliberate policy tailoring for
        recoupment commercially and logically untenable.

                 Conduct of Investigating officer and Impact on fair investigation

   339.                     The prosecution’s allegation stands in direct conflict with
        the statements of PW-71 and PW-72 and is further contradicted by the
        very documents relied upon by the prosecution. The suggested identity
        between the hotel printout and the GoM draft rests on conjecture,
        selectively emphasising page counts while overlooking the
        contemporaneous record.

   340.                     In conclusion, the allegation that a 36-page draft
        prepared by the South Group was transmitted through A-4 and A-3 to
        A-8 and thereafter handed over to PW-71 is not borne out by the

material on record. On the contrary, it is contradicted by the
        prosecution’s own evidence. The record does not disclose any basis
        for the alleged inference and is insufficient to sustain even a prima
        facie conclusion of external authorship or influence in the formulation
        of the GoM report.

   341.                     Notwithstanding this, the 36-page photocopy has been
        projected as a decisive circumstance. The juxtaposition of paragraphs
        16.15, 16.16 and 16.18 creates an impression of certainty which the
        record does not support. A circumstance that merely indicates that 36
        pages were photocopied at a hotel has been treated as a conclusive link
        in the alleged chain of conspiracy. When inferential coincidences are
        framed as established facts or when an inference unsupported by the
        primary statements and documents is presented with such finality, it
        risks distorting the appreciation of evidence at the threshold stage. A
        fair trial requires a balanced and faithful presentation of material;
        selective emphasis or overstatement of circumstances undermines that
        standard and directly affects the right of the accused to an impartial
        adjudication.

        (iv)Framing of the Excise Policy, Procedural Infraction

   342.                     On a careful and holistic appraisal of the statement of
        PW-74, Shri Arva Gopi Krishna, read alongside the contemporaneous
        documentary record, this Court finds that the framing of the
        DEP-21/22 does not disclose any procedural infraction. The evidence

on record reflects a structured, traceable, and multi-tiered
        administrative process, commencing with pre-existing departmental
        studies, proceeding through the recommendations of the GoM, and
        culminating in successive approvals by the Council of Ministers and
        scrutiny by the Hon’ble LG. Each stage of the process is supported by
        written notings, Cabinet Decisions and formal ministerial directions,
        which were acted upon by the Excise Department in the ordinary
        course of administration. The material placed before the Court thus
        negates any suggestion of unilateralism, opacity or deviation from the
        established procedure, and instead affirms that the Excise Policy was
        framed through a lawful and institutionally compliant decision-making
        process.

   343.                     In his further statement, PW-74 confirms that the Excise
        Department’s role commenced only after the recommendations of the
        GoM had already been approved by the Council of Ministers. He
        categorically states that the Cabinet-note file “has been dealt by me as
        Excise Commissioner, after approval of the recommendations of GoM
        report… by the Council of Ministers vide Cabinet Decision No. 2983
        dated 22.03.2021,” and that only thereafter did the Excise Department
        prepare the draft DEP-21/22 and submit the proposal to the Finance
        Department on 06.04.2021. This statement clearly situates the
        Department’s role within an implementation framework, rather than at
        the stage of originating policy parameters.

344.                     The subsequent file movement, as narrated by PW-74,
        reflects structured decision-making across multiple constitutional and
        institutional levels. He records that the Draft Cabinet Note was
        approved by the Deputy Chief Minister on 08.04.2021; the revised
        Cabinet Note was approved by the Council of Ministers on 15.04.2021
        vide Cabinet Decision No. 2994; and the proposal was thereafter
        forwarded to the Hon’ble LG. On 20.05.2021, the Deputy Chief
        Minister noted that the Hon’ble LG had given certain suggestions and
        directed revision of the Cabinet Note accordingly. The revised
        proposal was thereafter approved by the Council of Ministers vide
        Cabinet Decision No. 3003 dated 21.05.2021, following which the file
        was sent to the Excise Department for implementation. This sequence
        evidences layered scrutiny and collective decision-making, wholly
        inconsistent with allegations of unilateral action. A similar pattern of
        documented approvals and oversight emerges in relation to the issue
        of opening liquor vends in non-conforming wards.

   345.                     PW-74 records that on 28.09.2021, the Deputy Chief
        Minister directed that a proposal be put up for in-principle approval of
        the Government for opening liquor vends in wards lacking conforming
        areas. The Cabinet approved this proposal vide Cabinet Decision No.
        3047 dated 05.11.2021, and the Hon’ble LG thereafter approved the
        same subject to requisite approvals from the DDA and the concerned
        MCD. Subsequently, the LG constituted a High-Powered Committee

on 06.12.2021, whose report dated 10.12.2021 noted that conforming
        areas were available in 205 wards and suggested limited adjustments
        for the remaining wards, though ultimately no vends could be opened
        in non-conforming wards. The record thus shows enhanced scrutiny
        and corrective oversight, not procedural impropriety.

   346.                     The manner of implementation through ministerial
        directions is further illustrated by the note dated 03.02.2022, wherein
        the Deputy Chief Minister, having regard to the recommendations of
        the High-Powered Committee and revenue considerations, recorded
        that the only viable option was to allow retail licensees to open
        additional retail vends in conforming wards, with approval of the
        Council of Ministers to be obtained in due course. Pursuant to this
        direction, the Excise Department issued its circular dated 09.02.2022.
        An identical institutional approach is reflected in the grant of Covid-
        period licence-fee relief: although the Department had initially opined
        that such relief was not envisaged in the tender document, the Deputy
        Chief Minister, after calling for and examining sales-impact data,
        directed on 01.02.2022 that pro-rata licence-fee relief be granted,
        which direction was implemented by the Department through its order
        dated 08.02.2022.

   347.                     The extension of the Excise Policy also followed express
        and recorded ministerial directions. PW-74 states that on 28.02.2022
        the Deputy Chief Minister directed that the policy required further

time to stabilise and resolve teething problems, and again on
        20.05.2022 directed that the policy be extended up to 31.07.2022,
        pursuant to which the Excise Department issued the formal order dated
        23.05.2022. These steps further demonstrate that implementation
        consistently followed written directions placed on file and acted upon
        administratively.

   348.                    As regards the pricing structure and the 12% wholesale
        margin, PW-74 clarifies that the policy-prescribed pricing mechanism
        required wholesalers to bear the full landed cost, including EDP,
        Export Pass Fee, Import Pass Fee, freight, handling and insurance
        charges, and that only thereafter was a 12% profit margin added to
        arrive at the wholesale price, with excise duty and VAT payable to the
        Government by the wholesaler. He further explains that his order dated
        28.10.2021 levying 2% CST did not prohibit manufacturers from
        billing wholesalers for freight, insurance and handling charges, and
        that manufacturers never submitted such bills to the Excise
        Department, whose concern was confined to excise duty and VAT.

   349.                     Against this evidentiary backdrop, the allegation that the
        GoM finalised the Excise Policy without any departmental inputs,
        particularly with respect to the 12% margin or the definition of
        “related entities”, does not withstand scrutiny. PW-74’s statement
        establishes only that he personally did not originate the numerical
        margin or the definition of related entities, not that the Department was

excluded from the deliberative process. This inference is further
        dispelled by the statement of PW-71, Shri C. Arvind, who affirms that
        the draft GoM report was internally worked upon with participation of
        CM fellows/researchers and that departmental officers, including Shri
        Ajay Gambhir, provided inputs for rationalisation of licence
        categories. The broader institutional chronology reinforces this
        conclusion. Even prior to the constitution of the GoM, a Committee
        under the chairmanship of the then Excise Commissioner had been
        constituted on 04.09.2020 and had submitted its detailed report on
        13.10.2020. Departmental material, studies and analysis were thus
        already in existence and available for consideration during the GoM
        deliberations.

   350.                     Viewed cumulatively, the very evidence relied upon by
        the prosecution negates its own allegation. The statements of PW-74
        and PW-71 disclose a multi-layered and consultative policy-making
        process, informed by prior departmental work and subjected to
        repeated institutional approvals. The record therefore fails to disclose
        any prima facie basis to infer that the determination of the 12% margin
        or the definition of related entities was tainted by concealment,
        conspiracy or procedural impropriety so as to justify the framing of
        charge.

        (v) Uniform 12% Wholesale Margin under the DEP-21/22

351.                     A careful, cumulative and contextual appreciation of the
        statements of PW-110 (Sh. Kiran Kumar Gurpur, Chief Sales Officer,
        United Breweries Limited), PW-107 (Sh. Hari Ram Khatri, Retail
        Licensee), PW-108 (Sh. Puneet Ahuja, Retail Participant), PW-109
        (Ms. Neha Juneja, State Head, Sales, United Breweries Limited),
        PW-111 (Senior Executive, United Breweries Limited) and PW-112
        (Sh. Prathmesh Mishra, Chief Commercial Officer, M/S DIAGEO,
        United Spirits Limited), when read conjointly with the DEP-21/22,
        establishes a consistent and coherent economic narrative which
        fundamentally undermines the prosecution’s theory that the uniform
        12% wholesale margin was a source of assured profitability or undue
        benefit. The evidence, viewed as a whole, demonstrates that the
        margin was structurally and commercially inadequate, particularly for
        beer and other high-volume, low-value products and, in practice,
        operated as a loss-making margin across the supply chain.

   352.                     The statement of PW-110 forms the economic starting
        point of this analysis. He categorically deposes that although the
        policy prescribed a uniform 12% wholesale margin, it failed to provide
        a separate cost card for beer, despite beer having a markedly different
        and higher cost structure. PW-110 quantifies that the actual cost of
        distributing beer in Delhi was approximately Rs. 108.8 per case,
        whereas the policy-permitted margin translated to only about Rs. 54
        per case. The consequence of this mismatch was inevitable: strict
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
adherence to the policy margin resulted in a built-in loss for the
        wholesaler. His evidence makes it clear that the margin did not even
        cover basic distribution costs such as freight, handling, insurance,
        breakages, warehousing, credit exposure and working-capital
        financing. Far from conferring any undue enrichment, the 12% margin
        became a source of sustained commercial stress, compelling
        wholesalers merely to seek measures to remain operational. This
        economic unviability at the wholesale level is reinforced by the
        statement of PW-111, who provides a detailed comparison between
        liquor and beer distribution under the policy. He explains that while
        for IMFL and foreign liquor, with landed prices of approximately Rs.
        1500-1600 per case, the 12% margin yielded around Rs. 180-192 per
        case, the landed price of beer was only about Rs. 450 per case,
        resulting in a distributor margin of merely Rs. 54 per case. PW-111
        further explains that beer distribution entails substantially higher
        operational costs than liquor, including specialised warehousing,
        segregation of stock sourced from multiple breweries, larger storage
        space due to seasonality, and additional handling requirements. During
        the policy period, BSPL was compelled to operate three warehouses
        for beer as against one for liquor, significantly escalating costs. He
        quantifies that the cost of operations was approximately Rs. 109 per
        case, almost double the beer margin, and expressly characterises the
        margin as “unrealistic and loss-making.” Unlike earlier policy

regimes, where manufacturers themselves undertook distribution and
        could internally absorb losses against manufacturing profits, the DEP
        2021-22 prohibited manufacturers from distributing directly, leaving
        distributors with no mechanism to offset losses.

   353.                     It is in this economic backdrop that the evidence
        explains the commercial conduct of manufacturers. PW-110 and
        PW-111 both make it clear that the structural defect in the policy
        placed pressure on manufacturers, including United Breweries
        Limited, to enter into compensatory commercial arrangements, such
        as permitting retention of freight, insurance and handling charges or
        extending limited per-case support, not as a matter of profit-sharing or
        favour, but as a bare necessity to keep the distribution chain functional.
        PW-111 specifically explains that recovery of freight, handling and
        insurance charges from BSPL would have rendered beer distribution
        commercially impossible under the already loss-making margin. He
        clarifies that approximately Rs. 13.8 crores accrued to M/S BSPL on
        account of these components purely as a consequence of UBL’s
        decision to ensure continuity of supply in a structurally adverse policy
        environment, and not as any policy-linked or assured benefit.

   354.                     This narrative of economic compulsion is further
        corroborated by the statement of PW-109, who provides a structured
        and documentary explanation for the issuance of incentives, rebates
        and credit notes. She establishes that market schemes were centrally

sanctioned by the manufacturer’s corporate office, budgeted in
        advance, and implemented uniformly on objective parameters such as
        volume           and     market   share,   without   any   retailer-specific
        customisation. She further explains that a special scheme introduced
        in August 2022 was driven solely by the need to liquidate stock in
        anticipation of the policy’s expiry on 31.08.2022, a commercial
        exigency arising from policy uncertainty rather than any embedded
        benefit to wholesalers. PW-109 also clarifies that M/S BSPL, as
        distributor, merely operationalised these manufacturer-approved
        schemes, and that any unilateral deviation, such as advance issuance
        of a credit note, was unauthorised and driven by recovery concerns
        when a retailer was exiting the business.

   355.                     The statements from the retail end complete the picture
        of a stressed commercial ecosystem. PW-107, a retail licensee,
        candidly acknowledges that retail operations under the DEP-21/22
        were themselves commercially onerous and often loss-making,
        necessitating post-sale adjustments through credit notes and rebates
        merely to sustain operations. His evidence reflects a market
        characterised by continuous liquidity pressure rather than assured
        profitability. PW-108 corroborates this position by unequivocally
        denying any cash dealings or illegal payments and placing rebates and
        adjustments squarely within the realm of ordinary commercial
        accounting. His statement is conspicuously silent on any demand,

offer or transmission of illicit consideration and instead reflects the
        practical necessity of such adjustments in a struggling market.

   356.                     The evidence of PW-112 further reinforces that the
        impugned commercial conduct was driven by operational necessity
        and competitive pressures, not by any corrupt design. He explains that
        upon the coming into force of the new policy, there existed genuine
        commercial ambiguity regarding the treatment of insurance, freight
        and handling charges, which historically accrued to the L-1
        wholesaler. To ensure that supplies commenced without disruption, a
        senior-level commercial discussion on 10.11.2021 led to a conscious
        decision not to insist upon recovery of these components from M/S
        BSPL Sales Pvt. Ltd. PW-112 expressly records that this was a
        commercial decision taken to ensure immediate commencement of
        invoicing and continuity of supply. He further clarifies that prevailing
        market realities and competitive considerations, including the
        apprehension that M/S BSPL might exit the distributorship, also
        informed this decision, underscoring that the continuation of the
        wholesale relationship was guided by ordinary commercial prudence
        in a newly restructured and economically strained market.

   357.                Taken together, the statements of PW-110, PW-107, PW-108,
        PW-109, PW-111 and PW-112 present a consistent, industry-wide
        narrative. The uniform 12% wholesale margin under the DEP-21/22
        was economically unviable, particularly for beer, and resulted in loss-

absorbing operations rather than surplus profitability. Manufacturers
        and distributors were compelled to adopt compensatory commercial
        mechanisms, rebates, credit notes and absorption of logistics costs,
        purely to keep the supply chain functional. The evidence uniformly
        depicts a stressed, survival-driven market rather than a rent-seeking
        arrangement. At the stage of consideration of charge, in the face of this
        unimpeached and internally consistent evidence led by the
        prosecution’s own witnesses, the assertion advanced by the
        prosecution that the flat 12% wholesale margin on the landed price of
        IMFL, beer and wine yielded “huge profits” to wholesalers is exposed
        as demonstrably erroneous, economically illiterate and legally
        unsustainable.

   358.                 The material relied upon by the prosecution not only fails to
        substantiate this allegation but affirmatively disproves it. The evidence
        establishes that the uniform application of a 12% margin, particularly
        to beer and high-volume products, resulted in a structural mismatch
        between revenue and cost, producing losses rather than surplus. The
        prosecution has neither identified any admissible material showing
        actual profit accrual nor demonstrated, even prima facie, that the
        margin translated into excess gains capable of being appropriated as
        illegal gratification. To persist with such an allegation in the teeth of
        categorical statement explaining cost structures, losses and survival-
        driven commercial adjustments is to substitute conjecture for

evidence. The prosecution’s theory, resting on a superficial
        arithmetical assumption divorced from economic reality, thus
        collapses at the threshold and cannot, in law, sustain an inference of
        undue benefit, quid pro quo or corrupt intent.

   359.                    Even otherwise the increase in wholesale margin from 5%
        to 12% has to be viewed in the backdrop of a fundamentally altered
        distribution framework and the substantial escalation in operational
        and logistical responsibilities cast upon L-1 licensees.

   360.                     Under      the   earlier   policy   regime,    manufacturers
        themselves held L-1 licences and exercised end-to-end control over
        storage, transportation, and distribution. The costs of warehousing,
        logistics,         handling,     breakages,     compliance,       and    inventory
        management were embedded within an integrated manufacturer-led
        system. The DEP-21/22 dismantled this structure and introduced an
        independent wholesaler as a distinct intermediary, entrusted with
        extensive statutory and operational obligations expressly enumerated
        in clause 3.1.11 (vii) of the DEP-21/22. These included establishment
        and maintenance of compliant warehouses, deployment of logistics
        infrastructure, handling and transfer of liquor bottles, adherence to
        stricter regulatory standards, and assumption of risks earlier borne by
        manufacturers.

                                                                   (emphasis supplied)

361.                     Any new entrant into a distribution business of this scale
        is necessarily required to incur significant upfront expenditure to
        create infrastructure, manpower, logistics chains, and compliance
        systems in conformity with the new policy framework. Such costs are
        neither incidental nor avoidable; they are intrinsic to the redesigned
        model. A policy that brings about a complete systemic shift cannot be
        expected to function effectively without addressing the economic
        realities of the new responsibilities it creates. Significant structural
        change, by its very nature, demands corresponding economic
        recalibration.

   362.                     At this juncture, it bears emphasis that the enhancement
        of the wholesale margin to 12% cannot, in any manner, be construed
        as a facet of any alleged conspiracy. As already discussed, and as borne
        out from the evidence on record, the uniform 12% margin was, in fact,
        economically unviable, particularly in the case of beer and wine,
        where the costs of storage, handling, refrigeration, transportation,
        breakages and higher volume-to-value ratios rendered the margin not
        merely inadequate but onerous for wholesalers. If the enhancement of
        margin were the outcome of a carefully orchestrated conspiratorial
        design or a policy tweak at the behest of the so-called “South Group”,
        it defies logic as to why such a margin structure would be retained
        uniformly even for beer and wine, where it resulted in sustained losses
        rather than assured profitability. The very fact that the margin failed to

yield commercial viability across categories militates against the
        theory of any tailor-made or conspiratorial benefit.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   363.                     The prosecution case, when examined in the context of
        the statutory scheme, discloses a basic inconsistency. It proceeds on
        the premise that a wholesaler, out of the notified 12% margin, would
        agree to part with 6% as an “upfront” payment and yet continue to
        operate viably under the same regime. On its own showing, this would
        reduce the effective margin by half even before accounting for
        infrastructure costs, routine operational expenses, compliance
        requirements and market risks.

   364.                     This premise becomes even more questionable when the
        structure of the DEP-21/22 is kept in view. Under the earlier regime,
        the system was manufacturer-led. The DEP-21/22 altered that
        arrangement and introduced an independent wholesaler as a separate
        intermediary, entrusted with defined statutory and operational
        responsibilities under Clause 3.1.11 (vii).

   365.                     These responsibilities were substantial. The wholesaler
        was required to establish and maintain compliant warehouses, develop
        logistics infrastructure, handle and transfer consignments, adhere to
        stricter regulatory standards, and assume risks that were earlier borne
        by manufacturers. The financial burden attached to these obligations

was considerable. Warehousing expenses, manpower, transportation,
        insurance, regulatory liabilities, and even the setting up of facilities for
        testing and checking spurious liquor at the warehouse level formed
        part of the operational framework. The 12% margin, therefore, was not
        an unencumbered surplus but a return structured against these
        commitments.

   366.                     In this backdrop, the suggestion that a wholesaler would
        voluntarily surrender half of its assured margin at the outset and
        thereafter operate under significant financial and regulatory
        obligations, without any demonstrable compensating advantage, does
        not accord with ordinary commercial conduct. In allegations of
        financial conspiracy, the element of gain is fundamental. There must
        be a reasonable and discernible expectation of profit. Where the
        structure described leaves little scope for viable return and instead
        renders the business economically strained, the theory of conspiracy,
        as projected, appears internally flawed and inconsistent with the very
        objective it is said to achieve.

   367.                     The enhancement of the wholesale margin must also be
        seen in conjunction with the introduction of provisions such as the
        EDP (Ex-Distillery Price) clauses, which were designed to ensure that
        efficiencies and competitive pricing ultimately benefit the consumer.
        The object was not merely to alter margins but to create a sustainable

and transparent supply chain capable of functioning independently of
        manufacturer dominance.

   368.                     Significantly,      the    investigating    agency      has       not
        undertaken any comparative analysis between the old and the new
        policy frameworks to contextualise the increase in the wholesale
        margin.           Without examining the qualitative and quantitative
        differences in obligations, cost structures, and risk allocation between
        the two regimes, any assertion that the revised margin is excessive
        remains conclusory.

                                                                       (emphasis supplied)

   369.                     Viewed thus, the increase in wholesale margin
        represents a policy response to a transformed regulatory and
        commercial               environment.    The     introduction     of   independent
        wholesalers, who were entirely absent in the earlier system, inevitably
        entailed costs that could not be sustainably absorbed without a
        corresponding adjustment in margins. In the absence of such
        adjustment, the new distribution model itself would have been
        rendered economically unviable.

        (vi) Purported Sponsorship and Orchestration of Public-Consultation
        Emails on the Ravi Dhawan Report

   370.                     The allegation against A-8 is that he orchestrated certain
        emails purportedly sent in support of specific clauses which, according
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
to the prosecution, were intended to benefit the so-called “South
        Group.” It is alleged that when the Ravi Dhawan Committee Report
        was placed in the public domain and comments were invited from the
        public, certain emails received during that consultative process were
        sponsored rather than independent expressions of opinion.

   371.                     At the threshold, the Court is guided by the settled
        parameters governing the stage of framing of charge. The prosecution
        material, if taken at face value, must disclose a prima facie case against
        the accused. In a situation where two views are possible from the
        material relied upon by the prosecution, the prosecution must
        demonstrate that the material gives rise to grave suspicion. The
        opinion of the Court must rest strictly on the case as projected by the
        prosecution and not on conjectural amplification.

   372.                     On the prosecution’s own showing, out of more than
        fourteen thousand emails received in response to the public notice
        inviting comments on the Ravi Dhawan Committee Report, six emails
        are alleged to have been sponsored. Even if this assertion is accepted
        in its entirety for present purposes, the proportion and context are
        material. The consultative process was open and voluminous. The
        allegation, as framed, does not demonstrate that the process stood
        vitiated in substance or that the policy outcome was shaped, dictated,
        or materially influenced by these six communications.

373.                     It is important to note that the distinction between
        suspicion and grave suspicion may, in an appropriate case, arise even
        at the level of the allegation itself. An allegation, taken at its highest
        and presumed to be true, may still yield two possible inferences, one
        suggestive of impropriety and the other indicative of a circumstance
        too slender to sustain a criminal charge. Where the allegation, on its
        own terms, discloses no more than an isolated or peripheral feature in
        a large consultative exercise, its acceptance does not automatically
        elevate it to the level of grave suspicion.

   374.                     To attribute criminal design to an entire policy
        framework on the basis of six emails out of more than fourteen
        thousand emails is akin to attempting to pierce an elephant with a
        needle, the scale of the allegation is wholly disproportionate to the
        magnitude of the inference sought to be drawn. A circumstance which,
        even if assumed to be correct, carries no inherent gravity cannot be
        enlarged into grave suspicion merely by the seriousness of the
        conclusion sought to be attached to it. Thus, where the allegation
        itself admits of dual inferences and, even when presumed to be true,
        remains a minor or inconsequential circumstance within the broader
        consultative process, the statutory threshold for framing of charge is
        not satisfied. Even so, it would not be appropriate to discard the
        allegation in its entirety at this stage; the Court must proceed to
        examine the material placed by the prosecution in support of this

allegation to ascertain whether, upon closer scrutiny, it discloses any
        substantive nexus warranting further consideration.

   375.                     A holistic examination of the statements of PW-92
        (Zakir Khan), PW-93 (Kartikey Azad), PW-94 (Kartikey Raja), PW-95
        (Daksh Wadhwa) and PW-99 (Pulkit Bisht) reveals a uniform thread
        that significantly weakens the prosecution’s allegation of a sponsored,
        orchestrated or coordinated attempt to sway the public-consultation
        process on the Expert Committee (Ravi Dhawan) Report. PW-92, the
        then Chairperson of the Delhi Minorities Commission, makes it
        abundantly clear that he neither understood nor examined the Ravi
        Dhawan Report, had no familiarity with the Excise Policy, and did not
        even read the handwritten note later mentioned in statement. His
        interaction with the Dy. Chief Minister, as per his own account, took
        place in the context of the Commission’s financial requirements;
        during that routine meeting he was simply advised to visit the Excise
        Department’s website and submit suggestions to the official email ID
        notified for public comments.

   376.                     Nothing in his statement suggests that the A-8 dictated,
        influenced or approved any particular content, nor does PW-92
        attribute any form of sponsorship or direction to him. On the contrary,
        the broader record reflects an explicit instruction within the
        Government to keep public-consultation emails anonymous, which
        runs counter to the allegation that the A-8 sought orchestrated

responses. The internal administrative context is clarified by PW-93,
        who states that the Ravi Dhawan Report was circulated to him on
        12.01.2021 with a direction to analyse it from a legal perspective. Two
        days later, a brief written note identifying certain themes or points was
        handed over to facilitate the interns’ study of the report. Significantly,
        PW-92 himself admits that he did not read this note. The note,
        therefore, does not indicate pre-drafted or politically motivated
        content; rather, it reflects an attempt within the Commission to
        familiarise junior staff with the subject-matter on which public
        comments were invited. PW-93’s statement demonstrates that the
        exercise was internally generated, informal and academic in character,
        consistent with the training objectives associated with internships.

   377.                     PW-94’s evidence, when read alongside the material
        collected by the investigating agency, further exposes the fragility of
        the prosecution’s suggestion that a group of interns sent multiple
        emails in an organised manner. PW-94 recalls a general instruction
        from PW-92 that they should send “as many emails as possible,” and
        mentions that ten to twelve interns were in the WhatsApp group, with
        some possessing multiple email accounts. Yet, the CBI investigation
        could trace only six emails originating from this group. This stark
        disparity between the alleged instruction and the actual number of
        emails sent demonstrates the absence of any large-scale or impactful
        campaign. Against the backdrop of more than 14,000 emails received

by the Excise Department pursuant to the public notice, these six
        emails stand as numerically insignificant and devoid of any capacity
        to influence or alter the outcome of a broad-based consultation.

   378.                     The alleged scale of email activity is disproved by
        recovered evidence; the supposed sponsorship stands contradicted by
        PW-92’s own ignorance of the subject-matter; and the participation of
        interns underscores transparency rather than covert mobilisation.
        Thus, the prosecution’s theory rests not on admissible material, but on
        layered assumptions: first, that an untraceable and unread note
        constituted a directive; second, that such a note translated into
        sponsored content; and third, that six anonymous emails could
        meaningfully affect a consultation process involving thousands of
        responses. Each of these assumptions stands contradicted by the
        prosecution’s own witnesses. In essence, the consolidated statements
        of PW-92 through PW-99 establish that the Delhi Minorities
        Commission merely undertook an internal review of the Expert
        Committee Report and submitted a handful of comments through the
        same channel available to all.

        (vii) Destruction of mobile phone

   379.                     At the stage of consideration of charge, this Court is
        required to examine whether the material placed on record discloses a
        prima facie case attracting the ingredients of the offence alleged.
        Tested on this settled parameter, the allegation that the then Deputy

Chief Minister (A-8) caused the destruction of his earlier mobile phone
        so that no incriminating material may be found against him does not,
        in the opinion of this Court, satisfy the statutory requirements of
        Section 201 of the IPC. Section 201 IPC contemplates a deliberate act
        of causing disappearance of evidence of an offence, with the
        knowledge or reason to believe that such offence has been committed,
        and with the intention of screening the offender from legal
        punishment. Thus, even at the threshold, the prosecution is required to
        place material showing: (i) the existence of evidence relating to a
        specific offence; (ii) knowledge thereof on the part of the accused; and
        (iii) a conscious act of destruction undertaken with the requisite intent
        to screen oneself or another from punishment.

   380.                     In the present case, the prosecution allegation proceeds
        on the premise that the accused caused the destruction of his mobile
        phone to ensure that no incriminating material could be recovered
        against him. However, the record is conspicuously silent as to what
        incriminating material is alleged to have existed on the said device. No
        specific message, call, document, or digital communication has been
        identified as having been generated, transmitted, or stored on the
        phone which could be said, even prima facie, to constitute evidence of
        the alleged offence. The prosecution thus invites the Court to presume
        the existence of incriminating material solely on the basis of the

alleged destruction of the device. Such an approach is legally
        impermissible.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   381.                     At the stage of framing of charge, suspicion may suffice,
        but the suspicion must be founded on material placed on record, and
        not on conjecture or reverse inference. The mere allegation that a
        device was destroyed to prevent recovery of incriminating material
        cannot substitute for the foundational requirement. Section 201 IPC
        does not criminalise the act of ensuring absence of evidence in the
        abstract; it penalises the deliberate disappearance of existing evidence
        of an offence, accompanied by the requisite mens rea. It is also
        relevant to note that a simpliciter change of a mobile handset, followed
        by disposal or destruction of the earlier device, is not per se
        unlawful.

   382.                     In the absence of material suggesting that the device
        contained incriminating data, such conduct cannot be elevated to an
        inference of culpable intent. Crucially, the prosecution has not placed
        any material to show that the accused acted with the intention of
        screening himself from legal punishment by causing disappearance of
        specific evidence. The essential element of mens rea under Section
        201 IPC thus remains unsubstantiated. To permit the charge to proceed
        on the basis of a presumed existence of incriminating material would

amount to converting suspicion into admissible material, which the
        law does not countenance even at the stage of charge.

   383.                     In these circumstances, this Court is of the considered
        view that the allegation relating to destruction of the mobile phone, as
        framed, does not disclose the essential ingredients of an offence under
        Section 201 IPC. The material on record falls short of establishing a
        prima facie case, and the invocation of Section 201 IPC on this count
        cannot be sustained at the stage of framing of charge.

        (C) Final analysis qua A-8

   384.                     Having examined each allegation independently and
        cumulatively, this Court finds that the prosecution case, as projected,
        does not survive judicial scrutiny at the threshold stage.

   385.                     The fixation of the 12% wholesale margin, the structural
        decision to privatise the wholesale trade, the zoning of retail vends,
        and the formulation of the “related entities” clause have all been
        examined in the light of the Ravi Dhawan Committee Report, the
        successive draft GoM reports dated 15.03.2021, 19.03.2021 and final
        GoM report dated 22.03.2021, the Minutes of deliberations dated
        05.04.2021, the Cabinet approvals, and the contemporaneous file
        notings. When these documents are read sequentially and in
        conjunction with the statements of the relevant witnesses, what
        emerges is a process of policy evolution marked by structured

deliberation and administrative refinement. The record reflects
        continuity, consultation and institutional engagement. None of these
        clauses, whether viewed individually or collectively, discloses a
        departure so abrupt or unexplained as to justify an inference of
        criminal intent. Policy choices, even if debatable or subsequently
        reconsidered, cannot be equated with criminal conspiracy in the
        absence of material demonstrating quid pro quo, concealment or
        corrupt inducement.

   386.                     The theory of overarching conspiracy similarly fails to
        find support in the material placed before the Court. There is no
        evidence placing A-8 in any clandestine meeting or conspiratorial
        assembly. No witness has stated to his participation in any secret
        deliberation for unlawful gain. No admissible material demonstrates
        his involvement in any alleged cash transaction. The prosecution has
        not produced a single recovery, document or financial trail linking him
        with the alleged transfer of funds. The allegation of monetary
        exchange remains unsubstantiated so far as he is concerned.

   387.                     The attempt to connect A-8 with the alleged money
        movement is sought to be routed through A-3. However, there is no
        legally admissible material to establish that A-3 acted as a conduit for
        A-8. The relationship between them is inferred rather than
        demonstrated. The link sought to be drawn between A-8 and the

alleged acts of A-3 rests on conjecture and assumption rather than
        demonstrable nexus.

   388.                     More fundamentally, the prosecution narrative suffers
        from an internal contradiction that strikes at the root of the conspiracy
        theory. The contemporaneous documentary record establishes that the
        formulation and processing of the DEP-21/22 involved consultation at
        the highest executive level. The file notings record discussions with
        the Hon’ble LG, incorporation of suggestions, approval by the Council
        of Ministers, and subsequent apprisal of the Hon’ble LG. The material
        shows institutional participation of the LG Secretariat in scrutiny and
        movement of the file. It further reflects that the policy was neither
        concealed nor processed in isolation, but travelled through recognised
        constitutional channels.

   389.                     In such a scenario, the theory of conspiracy cannot
        selectively survive against one constitutional authority while being
        rendered inapplicable to another on the basis of the very same material.
        A charge of unilateral manipulation cannot logically and legally be
        sustained against the Deputy Chief Minister (A-8) alone when the
        documentary chain demonstrates deliberation, consultation and
        processing through the office of the Hon’ble LG. The same notings
        cannot, in law, exonerate one authority while simultaneously
        incriminating another, when both are reflected in the same institutional
        record.

text:
(emphasis supplied)

   390.                     The record also shows that during the relevant period,
        the power of transfer of officers, including the Excise Commissioner,
        vested with the competent constitutional authority and was exercised
        on multiple occasions. This underscores the fact that the administrative
        framework was neither static nor subordinate to a single individual.
        The Hon’ble LG and the senior officers of the LG Secretariat were
        integral to the movement and scrutiny of the file. If the prosecution
        case were to be taken to its logical conclusion on the premise of
        manipulation in policy formulation, it would inevitably extend to those
        very authorities who processed, examined and apprised themselves of
        the policy. Yet no such allegation is pressed.

   391.                     This observation does not imply that any other
        constitutional functionary ought to have been arraigned as an accused.
        On the contrary, the contemporaneous record, when objectively
        examined, discloses no unilateral manipulation by A-8. The material
        reveals a process marked by consultation, communication and
        administrative engagement at multiple levels. Once it is shown that the
        policy travelled through established constitutional channels and was
        processed in accordance with the Transaction of Business Rules, the
        foundation of a selective conspiracy allegation collapses.

   392.                     The cumulative assessment, therefore, is unambiguous.
        The structural features of the policy do not disclose criminal intent.

The alleged conspiracy lacks demonstrable agreement or meeting of
        minds. There is no material placing A-8 in conspiratorial meetings.
        There is no substantiated financial trail linking him to any cash
        transfer. There is no admissible evidence that A-3 acted as his conduit.
        The documentary record reflects institutional deliberation rather than
        clandestine orchestration.

   393.                     On the material as it presently stands, the prosecution
        has failed to establish even a prima facie case against A-8. The
        allegations, when tested against the contemporaneous record and the
        statements of the prosecution’s own witnesses, do not generate grave
        suspicion warranting trial. The edifice of conspiracy, built upon
        inference and selective reading of the record, stands dismantled when
        the documents are read as a whole.

        Allegations against A-1 and A-2

   394.                     The prosecution alleges that A-1, Kuldeep Singh, then
        Deputy Commissioner (IMFL), and A-2, Narender Singh, then
        Assistant Commissioner (IMFL), Excise Department, GNCTD, acted
        in concert with private accused persons, including accused Vijay Nair
        and A-7 Sameer Mahendru, to facilitate the grant of an L-1 wholesale
        licence to M/S Indospirits by bypassing the statutory scheme and
        policy safeguards governing excise licensing. It is alleged that upon
        receipt of a complaint dated 18.10.2021 alleging cross-funding and
        cartelisation involving M/S Indospirits and M/S KGRL, A-1 directed

that material allegations relating to EMD funding and common
        financial interest not be incorporated in the show-cause notice and that
        no effective enquiry be undertaken.

   395.                     It is further alleged that when a second L-1 application
        dated 29.10.2021 was filed, despite patent deficiencies and the
        pendency of related proceedings before the Hon’ble Supreme Court,
        A-1 and A-2 ensured that the application was processed and approved
        on 05.11.2021 in undue haste. According to the prosecution, A-2
        restrained the dealing staff from issuing the proposed deficiency
        memo, assured that he would personally procure the requisite
        documents, and caused such documents to be placed in the official file
        on 05.11.2021 without any covering letter, diarisation or proper
        receipt, following which the licence was approved with the
        concurrence of A-1.

   396.                     The prosecution further alleges that A-2 received illegal
        gratification of Rs. 30 lakhs from accused Sameer Mahendru (A-7),
        through the coordination of approver Dinesh Arora (PW-20) and at the
        instance of Accused Vijay Nair (A-3), as consideration for expediting
        and securing the L-1 licence in favour of M/S Indospirits. It is alleged
        that A-1, by his acts and omissions, abused his official position to
        extend undue favour to M/S Indospirits in furtherance of the aforesaid
        arrangement. On the basis of these allegations, the prosecution asserts

that A-1 and A-2 are liable for offences punishable under Section 120-
        B of the IPC read with Sections 7, 7A and 8 of the PC Act, 1988.

        Analysis

        File Movement and Alleged Procedural Irregularity

   397.                     The earlier excise policy was characterised by
        manufacture-controlled wholesale and retail operations as pointed by
        Ravi Dhawan report, whereas DEP-21/22 envisaged a complete
        transition to a system anchored in private wholesalers and private
        retailers operating under a newly introduced licensing regime. This re-
        engineering of the supply chain, from manufacturers to consumers,
        necessarily required the issuance of fresh licences, onboarding of new
        entities, realignment of logistics, and readiness across multiple tiers of
        administration.

   398.                     It is also of material significance that the DEP-21/22
        was scheduled to come into force on 17.11.2021, leaving a narrowly
        circumscribed time window for its operationalisation. The limited
        interregnum between notification and implementation inevitably
        required prompt administrative action to ensure that the new
        framework became functional on the appointed date, without
        disruption of supply or breakdown of lawful trade.

   399.                     Viewed in this backdrop, the expeditious movement of
        files or processing of licence applications cannot be examined in

isolation. Any such assessment must account for the scale of the
        transition mandated by the policy, the impending date of
        implementation, and the administrative imperative of continuity. The
        contextual foundation thus established is essential before evaluating
        any allegation of undue haste or impropriety.

        One day clearance of file for the grant of L-1 Licence

   400.                     The allegation of undue favour on account of one-day
        clearance of the L-1 licence is neutralised when examined in the
        undisputed context of the time-bound implementation of the
        DEP-21/22. As brought on record through Ashok Kumar (PW-7,
        Section Officer, Policy, Delhi Excise Department) and the
        contemporaneous documentary material (D-150 and D-153), retail
        sale under the DEP-21/22 was scheduled to commence from
        17.11.2021, and the old and new regimes could not operate
        simultaneously beyond the transition window. The Transition Report
        (D-153) records that a Committee was constituted “for preparing a
        transition policy,” that the transition was to be carried out “in a smooth
        and time bound manner,” and that parallel running was “bleak due to
        technical reasons” and “does not appear to be feasible,” necessitating
        a clean cut-off with advance timelines. The report further records
        uniform schedules, procedural safeguards, and the requirement of
        approximately 60 days for label approval and inventory build-up.

401.                     Read in this backdrop, the statement of PW-7 assumes
        significance. PW-7 places on record that out of thirteen L-1 licences
        granted, the file of M/S Gautam Wines Private Limited was cleared
        within a single day on 11.11.2021, that three entities were granted
        licences on the very same day as M/S Indospirits, and that licences
        were granted even on 03.11.2021, which goes against the stand of
        prosecution that it was a non working day. The urgency in processing
        licences in early November 2021 thus stands fully explained by policy
        compulsion and technical constraints, rendering the prosecution’s
        attempt to isolate the case of M/S Indospirits wholly unsustainable.

   402.                     The internal movement of the file is further clarified by
        the conjoint statements of PW-18 (Smt. Suman), the Section Officer
        handling IMFL matters, and PW-19 (Sachin Solanki), the dealing
        assistant. Read together, they present a consistent and coherent
        account demonstrating that the processing of the L-1 licence followed
        the established departmental structure and ordinary administrative
        practice.

   403.                     PW-18 consistently states that the processing of the first
        L-1 application dated 09.09.2021, the handling of the cartelisation
        complaint, the withdrawal of that application, and the scrutiny of the
        fresh application dated 29.10.2021 all occurred within the ordinary
        departmental framework. She records that “successive deficiency
        memos were issued after line-by-line examination,” and explains

routine office practice by stating that “at time of work pressure, peon
        directly gives the letters/dak to the concerned dealing assistants as per
        direction of senior officers.” She identifies her own signatures and
        those of the dealing assistant, Assistant Commissioner and Deputy
        Commissioner on the notesheets, thereby confirming supervisory
        scrutiny at every stage.

   404.                     PW-19 fully corroborates this account and sharply
        circumscribes his role, stating that “my duty is to put the
        documents/applications… in the form of noting.”            He confirms
        working under PW-18’s supervision and details issuance of deficiency
        memos dated 28.09.2021, 14.10.2021 and thereafter, all after approval
        of superior officers. In relation to the cartelisation complaint, he
        deposes that he was instructed “to put up only the issues related to L-1
        application,” and confirms that “Sh. Narender Singh… deleted the
        point No. c and last line in point No. e.” Most significantly, he states
        that the decisive recommendation note in the fresh application was
        settled by the Deputy Commissioner himself: “Sh. Kuldeep Singh, DC
        inserted in the said note the portion of the complaint which he
        considered fit… in his handwriting,” after which PW-19 merely typed
        the note and signed as instructed. He further confirms that the
        undertakings of Sameer and Geetika Mahendru “were not placed in
        the file” at the relevant time and “might have been taken and placed…
        by Sh. Narender Singh, AC or Sh. Kuldeep Singh, DC.”

405.                     The chronology surrounding the first L-1 application
        dated 09.09.2021, its subsequent withdrawal, and the later grant of
        licence to M/S Indospirit is of material relevance while examining the
        prosecution’s allegation of conspiracy and recoupment. The initial
        application was moved in the name of IMPL (Joint Venture partnership
        firm) with Indospirit Distribution Limited and Indospirit Marketing
        Pvt. Ltd. as its constituent partners. The same is evident from the
        contents of the application form dated 09.09.2021 as well as the
        undertaking dated 25.08.2021. The relevant extract of application
        form and undertaking thereof is reproduced below for the sake of
        ready reference:

                “….3) That in case of joint venture firm:
                (i) Indospirit Distribution Limited individually have liquor
                distribution turnover of minimum Rs. 150 Crore per annum.
                (ii) Indospirit Distribution Limited is one of the Joint Venture
                partner and individually have therequired experience of 5 years
                in wholesale distribution of liquor and;…”.


                “….Ref. No.: MK/BD/DL/GEX/21/08/769 25th August 2021

                                        UNDERTAKING
                We, Indospirit Marketing Private Limited, with registered of-
                fice at B-230, Okhla Phase-1, New Delhi-110020, hereby de-
                clare that the turn over and experience of joint venture partners
                i.e. Indospirit Marketing Private Limited and Indospirit Dis-
                tribution Limited have not been added for the purpose of
                qualifying the minimum eligibility criteria…”.

    Misleading Projection of Record by the Investigating Officer an impact on
                  fair trial

   406.                     At this stage, it also becomes necessary to juxtapose
        paragraph 16.20 of the charge-sheet with the contemporaneous
        document forming its basis. Paragraph 16.20 reads as under:

                 “16.20 The investigation revealed that as per joint venture
                 agreement submitted by M/S Indospirit Marketing Pvt Ltd, in
                 pursuance to its application dated 09.09.2021 for grant of L1
                 license, the partners were M/S Indospirit Distribution Ltd
                 (35%), Shri Buchi Babu (16.25%), Shri Prem Rahul Manduri
                 (32.5%) and Shri A.R. Pillai (16.25%). As per ROC records,
                 Sh. Sameer Mahendru and his wife Smt Geetika Mahendru are
                 the major shareholders in M/S Indospirit Distribution Ltd.”
   407.                     Read   plainly,   the   above    paragraph     conveys          in
        unequivocal terms that, at the time of the application dated 09.09.2021,
        the joint venture partners included A-11, A-5 and PW-275. The natural
        and immediate impression created is that these individuals formed part
        of the applicant entity from the very inception of the L-1 application
        process.

   408.                     However, when D-73 (6003), namely the application
        dated 09.09.2021, is examined, a materially different position
        emerges. The applicant had applied as Indospirit Marketing Pvt. Ltd.
        (Joint Venture) with IMPL and IDPL as its constituent partners. The
        names now projected in paragraph 16.20 do not find place as partners
        in that original application. The composition reflected in the charge-

sheet corresponds to a later stage, after reconstitution, and not to the
        application dated 09.09.2021.

   409.                     The distinction is not trivial. The prosecution case
        proceeds on the footing of a pre-planned conspiracy and prior
        crystallisation of roles. By presenting the later composition as if it
        existed at the time of the initial application, the charge-sheet creates
        an impression of continuity and design that is not borne out by the
        document relied upon. The original application does not support the
        inference sought to be drawn.

   410.                     The manner in which paragraph 16.20 is framed, without
        clarifying that the partners mentioned therein were inducted
        subsequently, has the effect of advancing the prosecution theory of
        conspiracy. Had the document D-73 (6003) been read in its proper
        context, the foundation for suggesting that A-11, A-5 and PW-275
        were embedded in the applicant entity at the inception would not stand.
        The presentation in the charge-sheet thus departs from the
        contemporaneous record and tends to mislead by omission of a crucial
        temporal distinction.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   411.                     When the chronology is read as a whole, the initial
        application dated 09.09.2021 was in the name of IMPL (JV) with
        IMPL and IDPL as partners. The reconstitution occurred later. Any
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
attempt to retrospectively attribute the later partnership structure to the
        original application distorts the sequence of events and artificially
        strengthens the allegation of a pre-existing conspiracy.

   412.                     At that stage, A-5 and A-11 (Butchibabu Gorantala), who
        are projected by the prosecution as proxies of A-17 K. Kavitha, as well
        as PW-275 Prem R. Manduri, who is sought to be linked as a conduit
        of the approver PW-226 Raghav Magunta, were admittedly not part of
        the applicant entity. This assumes significance in view of the
        prosecution’s assertion that an amount of ₹25 crores had already been
        paid as “upfront money” pursuant to the alleged conspiracy. If such
        payment had already been effected and the roles attributed to A-5,
        A-11 and PW-275 had stood crystallised, the absence of these persons
        from the applicant JV at the time of the September 2021 application
        remains unexplained. Even after issuance of the second deficiency
        memo, though the JV was sought to be reconstituted by replacing
        IMPL Pvt. Ltd. with A-5, A-11 and PW-275, the application continued
        to suffer from inherent defects of eligibility.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   413.                     The material on record shows that IMPL (JV) failed to
        satisfy the turnover requirement in a manner permissible under the
        Policy, having relied upon impermissible agent-based turnover and
        statutory documents not standing in the name of the L-1 applicant.
        These were not curable procedural deficiencies but went to the root of

qualification, leading to withdrawal of the application dated
        09.09.2021. It was only thereafter that a fresh application was moved
        in the name of M/S Indospirit (JV), with IDL, A-5 and PW-275 as
        partners, wherein the turnover was computed in accordance with the
        Policy, documentary requirements were fulfilled or duly undertaken in
        the applicant’s own name, and the threshold eligibility of ₹150 crores
        was met. The grant of the L-1 licence to M/S Indospirit thus followed
        from objective satisfaction of eligibility conditions, and not from any
        pre-existing assurance or continuity with the earlier IMPL (JV)
        application. Viewed cumulatively, the sequence does not support the
        prosecution theory of a pre-planned conspiracy, advance payment, or
        assured mechanism of recoupment, and correspondingly weakens the
        projection of A-5 and A-11 as conduits acting pursuant to any alleged
        understanding emerging from the purported meeting at ITC,
        Hyderabad.

   414.                     The prosecution has sought to contend that, despite the
        filing of a writ petition by PW-6 Varun Chaudhary before the Hon’ble
        Supreme Court on 05.11.2021 alleging cartelisation, Accused Nos. 1
        and 2 proceeded to grant the L-1 licence to M/S Indospirit on
        05.11.2021 in undue haste and in disregard of pending judicial
        proceedings.

   415.                     The material on record does not support such a
        proposition. PW-5 has stated: “I state that the said petition is regarding

allegations of cartelization amongst Indospirits, Khao Gali, Magunta
        Srinivas Reddy, Balaji Group, etc. The said letter of Varun Chaudhary
        dt. 06.11.2021 regarding filing of the writ petition (Crl.) No.19184 of
        2021 on 05.11.2021 has been forwarded to the lawyers of the
        department on 08.11.2021 as per markings on the said letter by
        Assistant Commissioner (Litigation) Sh. Ajay Kumar Gambhir. He
        also marked the copy of the same to Assistant Commissioner,
        IMFL…”.

   416.                     PW-6 has further produced before the investigating
        agency the original receiving dated 08.11.2021 on his letter dated
        06.11.2021. It thus stands established that although the letter bears the
        date 06.11.2021, it was in fact received in the Department only on
        08.11.2021.

   417.                     At this juncture, it becomes necessary to scrutinise the
        manner in which paragraph 16.25 has been introduced in the charge-
        sheet. The prosecution proceeds on the footing that the petition was
        received in the Excise Department on 05.11.2021, evidently with the
        object of suggesting that, despite awareness of allegations of
        cartelisation and blacklisting, A-1 and A-2 acted thereafter with undue
        haste. The relevant extract reads:

                 “16.25 Investigation revealed that a petition was filed by Shri
                Varun Chaudhary before Hon’ble Supreme Court of India on
                3.11.2021 regarding the same allegations of cartelization and
                blacklisting against M/S Indospirit Group and others. The copy

of the said petition was received in the Excise Department of
                GNCT of Delhi on 5.11.22.”
   418.                     The stress placed upon the date of receipt is clearly
        deliberate. It forms the foundation of the timeline sought to be
        constructed by the prosecution so as to attribute prior knowledge to
        the departmental authorities and to advance the allegation that
        subsequent action was taken in undue haste.

   419.                     However, the record does not support this assertion.
        PW-5, the record keeper and custodian of the inward register, does not
        depose that the complaint was received on 05.11.2021. PW-6, the
        complainant himself, has categorically stated that the complaint was
        got received in the Department on 08.11.2021. The documentary trail
        and the oral evidence thus consistently indicate 08.11.2021 as the date
        of receipt.

   420.                     In this backdrop, the mention of 05.11.2021 in the
        charge-sheet stands at variance with the very material relied upon by
        the prosecution. The advancement of the date has the effect of
        artificially extending the period between receipt of the complaint and
        the impugned action, thereby attempting to lend support to the
        allegation of undue haste. Without such advancement, the foundation
        for that allegation becomes untenable.

   421.                     The investigative process demands fidelity to the record.
        Where the timeline reflected in the charge-sheet departs from the

documentary and oral evidence on record, and that departure
        operates to the prejudice of the accused, the Court cannot overlook the
        inconsistency. The duty of the investigating agency is to present the
        facts as they emerge from the record, not to adapt them to reinforce a
        predetermined narrative.

                                                            (emphasis supplied)

   422.                     The sequence is therefore unambiguous. The alleged
        intimation of filing of the writ petition is dated 06.11.2021; it was
        received on 08.11.2021; and only thereafter was it marked to the
        concerned branch. In the absence of any material showing earlier
        receipt or prior circulation, there is no basis to presume that A-1 and
        A-2 had knowledge of the filing of the petition before 08.11.2021. The
        mere date mentioned on the letter cannot substitute proof of its
        communication or receipt.

   423.                     In this backdrop, the attempt to attribute prior
        knowledge to A-1 and A-2 on the basis of the date of the petition alone,
        while ignoring the proved date of its receipt in the Department, is not
        borne out from the record. The prosecution evidence itself establishes
        the actual timeline. Any suggestion to the contrary amounts to placing
        a version before the Court that is inconsistent with its own
        documentary foundation, which raises serious concern regarding
        fairness in presentation of facts.

424.                     It is equally settled that the filing of a petition does not,
        by itself, operate as a restraint on administrative action. Unless a court
        grants an interim order or stay, statutory authorities are not precluded
        from proceeding in accordance with the governing policy and
        applicable rules. No material has been placed on record to indicate that
        any such interim protection was in force restraining the Department
        from processing or disposing of the application of M/S Indospirit at
        the relevant time.

   425.                     In these circumstances, the continuation of the licensing
        process cannot be characterised as irregular or mala fide. Tested
        against the documentary record, the allegation does not advance
        beyond conjecture.

        Unregistered Joint Venture Agreement (JVA)

   426.                     One of the allegations levelled by the prosecution is that
        M/S Indospirits was granted the L-1 licence without furnishing a
        registered Joint Venture Agreement (JVA). The said allegation, on the
        face of the record, does not withstand scrutiny. PW-17 has
        categorically addressed this issue and has stated “ On being asked
        regarding the non-registered JV agreement and grant of licence to M/S
        Indospirits on the basis of said agreement, I state that it is nowhere
        mentioned in the Policy that JV agreement should be registered,
        hence, in my opinion it was not mandatory...”.

427.                     The aforesaid statement clearly establishes that neither
        the Excise Policy nor the governing licensing framework prescribed
        registration of a Joint Venture Agreement as a mandatory pre-condition
        for consideration or grant of an L-1 licence. Thus, the very foundation
        of the allegation stands negated by the prosecution’s own witness.

   428.                     Even otherwise, there is no statutory mandate requiring
        a Joint Venture Agreement to be compulsorily registered. The
        Registration Act, 1908 exhaustively enumerates the categories of
        documents for which compulsory registration is required, and a Joint
        Venture Agreement does not fall within the ambit of such compulsorily
        registrable instruments. In the absence of any statutory requirement,
        non-registration of a JVA cannot be treated as a legal infirmity.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   429.                     A perusal of D-73 (page 5999), containing the checklist
        applicable to applicants seeking an L-1 licence, sets the issue at rest.
        Clause 4 mandates submission of the Memorandum and Articles of
        Association of the company, or the Partnership Deed under the
        Partnership Act, 1932, or the Certificate of Registration in the case of
        a Cooperative Society, or the Partnership Deed under the Limited
        Liability Partnership Act, 2008, or the Joint Venture Agreement
        together with the list of Directors/partners/members of the
        company/firm/society, or Form-32 in the event of change from the
        MOA.

430.                     Significantly, the checklist does not stipulate that the
        Joint Venture Agreement must be a registered instrument. The
        requirement is confined to furnishing the JV Agreement along with
        particulars of the Directors/partners/members, depending upon the
        constitution of the applicant entity. There is no condition that only a
        registered copy would be acceptable.

   431.                     This position finds affirmation in the deposition of
        PW-17, who has stated that the application was scrutinised and
        processed strictly in accordance with the checklist available on the
        portal. When the governing checklist itself does not mandate
        submission of a registered JV Agreement, the argument that non-filing
        of a registered copy constituted any procedural irregularity is without
        basis.

   432.                     In these circumstances, the charge on this count is bereft
        of factual support. The documentary stipulation and the oral statement
        are consistent with each other, and no infirmity is discernible in the
        processing of the application on this aspect.

   433.                     Further, where the parties to the Joint Venture
        themselves do not dispute the execution, validity, or enforceability of
        the agreement, the absence of registration does not render the
        document non-est or defective for the purposes of administrative
        scrutiny. Such a circumstance cannot, by any stretch, constitute a

deficiency warranting rejection of an application for grant of an L-1
        licence.

   434.                     It is also pertinent to note that the L-1 licence granted to
        M/S Indospirits on 05.11.2021 was expressly made subject to
        fulfilment of conditions, which were thereafter finalised on
        08.11.2021. The grant was thus conditional and provisional in nature,
        in conformity with the established licensing procedure.

   435.                     Viewed cumulatively, the allegation premised on the
        absence of a registered Joint Venture Agreement is legally
        unsustainable, contrary to the policy framework, unsupported by
        statutory mandate, and squarely contradicted by the statement of
        PW-17. The prosecution has also failed to point out any mandatory
        statutory document which was required prior to issuance of the L-1
        licence and which was allegedly dispensed with. Once eligibility
        criteria stood satisfied, A-1 had no authority in law to withhold the
        licence dehors the statutory framework.

        Disposal of complaint dated 18.10.2021

   436.                     Though the prosecution has sought to project that it was
        the duty of A-1 and A-2 to deal with the complaint dated 18.10.2021,
        the record itself brings out that the allegation of cross-funding
        pertained to the retail domain, inasmuch as the alleged relationship
        between M/S KGRL and M/S Indospirit was a matter falling within

the retail zone. Such a complaint, therefore, was required to be dealt
        with by the Retail Section, and not confined to the wholesale licensing
        stream. This position stands fortified by the institutional distribution
        of work. The issuance of retail licences (L-7V) was headed by Deputy
        Commissioner Anand Kumar Tewari and Assistant Commissioner
        Pankaj Bhatnagar, whereas wholesale licences (L-1) were processed
        in the section headed by A-1 and A-2. The allocation and distribution
        of work was carried out by Sh. Arva Gopi Krishna (PW-74), the then
        Excise Commissioner. The cartelisation complaint dated 17.10.2021
        was, in fact, marked to both sections, and the process of retail licensing
        was supervised by the TEC.

   437.                     Most decisively, D-186, being the statement under
        Section 164 of Cr.P.C. of Sh. Arva Gopi Krishna (PW-74), records that
