        the TEC examined the complaints and “recommended that there is
        no violation of tender conditions, excise policy,” that technical and
        financial bids may be opened, and that upon further examination, the
        department found “no prima facie violation of tender conditions and
        Excise Policy.” PW-74 further records that all documents, including
        EMD details, were forwarded to the Income Tax Department and that
        the department would “wait for the report of the IT.”                    This
        contemporaneous statement squarely contradicts the prosecution’s
        suggestion of suppression or falsity in relation to the cartelisation
        complaint.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
438.                     The cartelisation complaint dated 18.10.2021 was duly
        examined at the departmental level by the Retail Licence Section,
        which, at the relevant time, was headed by the then Deputy
        Commissioner, Shri Anand Kumar Tewari, and the Assistant
        Commissioner, Shri Pankaj Bhatnagar (PW-270). The complaint was
        processed through the prescribed institutional channel and subjected
        to scrutiny by the concerned branches competent to examine the
        specific allegations raised therein.

   439.                     In the course of such examination, the matter was
        referred to the Accounts Branch for verification of the alleged financial
        irregularities, including the mode and source of deposit of EMD and
        participation fees, which formed the gravamen of the cartelisation
        allegation. The findings of the Accounts Branch were formally
        recorded in the departmental notings, including D-147 (94/N), and
        were taken into consideration while dealing with the complaint.

   440.                     The   relevant   submissions,   as   recorded        in      the
        departmental file and relied upon while disposing of the cartelisation
        complaint, are reproduced below verbatim for ready reference:

                “212…..The Accounts Branch has submitted that the money
                deposited by these firms in respect of E.M.D and participant
                fees by way of demand drafts in favour of the Excise
                Commissioner, treated as financial transactions made by the
                companies. There was no such sub-clause in the clause 6 of the
                tender document to the effect that the demand draft of requisite
                value should only be prepared by the participant

company/entity itself and that too from its own bank account.
                As such, all the demand drafts of requisitioned value whether
                it pertained to EMD or as participation fees, submitted by the
                intending bidders, were accepted by the TEC and were also
                honoured by the bank as and when deposited.
                213 The Accounts branch further submitted that as the source
                of funding (terms and conditions the intending
                bidders/companies managed the funds to deposit E.M.D or
                Participant fees and further, the relation of the alleged company
                with the entity/company from whom the funds were
                managed) may be a matter of economic offence. This fact can
                only be established through intense investigation by the
                specialized investigating agency having expertise in economic
                offences and also having jurisdiction of probe outside Delhi.
                214 It is submitted that based on the documents uploaded by
                the bidder in pre-qualification bid and the clarifications
                received from these bidders later on, the TEC vide its minutes
                dated 04.08.2021 submitted its recommendations to worthy
                Commissioner for approval/consideration and the same had
                been approved and directions were issued to put for draw of
                lots & opening of technical bids and financial bids (P-33/N).
                215 Further, after going through the contents of the reply
                submitted by M/S. Magunta Agro Farms Pvt. Ltd., M/S Raisen
                Marketing Pvt. Ltd. and Khaogali Restaurants Pvt. Ltd. it
                appears that there is no prima facie violations of the relevant
                clauses of Excise policy/Tender document dated 28.06.2021
                and 13/08/2021 by the L-7Z Licensee….”.
   441.                     A conjoint reading of the above notings demonstrates
        that the allegation of cartelisation was not brushed aside mechanically,
        but was examined on objective parameters prescribed under the
        DEP-21/22 and the applicable tender conditions. The Accounts Branch
        categorically recorded that neither Clause 6 of the tender document
        nor any other provision mandated that the EMD or participation fees

must necessarily emanate from the bidder’s own bank account.
        Consequently, the acceptance of demand drafts by the TEC, and their
        subsequent honouring by the bank, was found to be fully compliant
        with the tender framework.

   442.                     Further, the decision-making process was anchored in
        contemporaneous records, including pre-qualification documents,
        bidder clarifications, and the TEC minutes dated 04.08.2021, which
        culminated in approval by the competent authority and issuance of
        directions for draw of lots and opening of technical and financial bids.
        The replies furnished by the concerned licensees were specifically
        examined, leading to a recorded conclusion that no prima facie
        violation of the relevant clauses of the Excise Policy or Tender
        Documents was made out.

   443.                     It is also significant to note that the complaint was
        disposed of only after seeking and examining replies from the entities
        concerned. It is not the case of the prosecution that the TEC or the
        officers heading the Retail Licence Section acted with any mala fide
        intent while dealing with the complaint. On the contrary, the record
        reflects that the Retail Licence Section dealt with the complaint
        diligently and with procedural propriety, confining itself strictly to
        issues falling within its statutory and administrative remit.

   444.                     Once the competent departmental authority, after
        following the prescribed procedure, recorded a finding that no prima

facie violation of the Excise Policy or tender conditions was disclosed,
        the complaint stood concluded at the departmental level. In such
        circumstances, it cannot be contended that Accused Nos. A-1 or A-2
        granted licence to M/S Indospirit by first removing or neutralising the
        allegations contained in the cartelisation complaint. The record,
        instead, demonstrates that the complaint was independently examined,
        answered on merits, and thereby negating any inference of procedural
        impropriety, collusion, or abuse of position.


   445.                     The cumulative effect of this evidence establishes that the
        file moved through a documented and hierarchical decision-making
        process, involving scrutiny at the level of the dealing assistant, Section
        Officer, Assistant Commissioner and Deputy Commissioner. The
        expeditious movement of the file stands explained by the compressed
        timeline necessitated by the implementation of the DEP-21/22, and not
        by any departure from procedure. On the contrary, the record
        demonstrates structured processing, supervisory oversight at every
        stage, and adherence to the established departmental mechanism,
        leaving no room for an inference of procedural irregularity in dealing
        with the complaint dated 18.10.2021.

                                                                 (emphasis supplied)

Alleged Bribe of ₹30 Lakhs to A-2

   446.                     At the threshold, this Court records that the allegation of
        payment of ₹30 lakhs to A-2 by A-7 for expediting and securing the
        L-1 Licence in favour of M/S Indospirits, is founded solely upon the
        statement of the approver, PW-20, who is projected by the prosecution
        as its principal witness. It is well-settled that the statement of an
        approver, by its very nature, does not attain probative assurance unless
        it is independently corroborated on material particulars. The real
        inquiry, therefore, is not confined only to whether PW-20 has levelled
        such an allegation, but whether the record discloses any legally
        sustainable independent corroboration lending assurance to his
        version.

   447.                     A careful examination of the sequence of statements of
        approver PW-20 places the Court on guard. In his first statement
        recorded under Section 161 of Cr.P.C. dated 21.09.2022, running into
        12 pages and purporting to cover the prosecution narrative in detail,
        PW-20 makes no reference whatsoever to any payment of ₹30 lakhs
        or to any demand allegedly made by A-2. The said silence persists in
        the subsequent confessional statement recorded before the Ld. Judicial
        Magistrate on 30.09.2022, consisting of 17 pages, wherein again no
        such allegation finds place. Even thereafter, when supplementary
        statement under Section 161 of Cr.P.C. was recorded on 05.10.2022,
        the record remains bereft of any such assertion.

(emphasis supplied)

   448.                     It is only in the subsequent supplementary statement
        dated 27.10.2022 recorded under Section 161 of Cr.P.C. that, for the
        first time, PW-20 introduces a version suggesting such payment, and
        that too in the nature of hearsay, by stating: “...Sameer Mahendru
        met me sometime in the end of October 2021 near Khan Market in
        Delhi and told me that his L-1 licence of Indospirits is not being issued
        by the Excise Department and he has met with Sh. Narender Singh,
        Assistant Commissioner, and paid him ₹30 lakhs…”.

   449.                     The belated surfacing of so serious an allegation, absent
        from earlier statements, especially from the confessional statement
        under Section 164 of Cr.P.C., yet introduced through a statement under
        Section 161 of Cr.P.C., calls for heightened judicial caution. At this
        stage, the Court is faced with the legal issue whether the introduction
        of a new allegation under Section 161 of Cr.P.C., which did not find
        mention in the statement recorded under Section 164 of Cr.P.C., can
        by itself carry sufficient weight at the stage of charge, and what would
        be the evidentiary worth of such an improved version. The answer to
        this question, as noted by the Hon’ble High Court of Delhi in case
        titled as Asit Mukherjee vs. State, 2024 SCC OnLine Del 1876,
        wherein it is stated that the introduction of a new allegation which does
        not find mention in the statement recorded under Section 164 of
        Cr.P.C., and is thereafter sought to be introduced through a statement

under Section 161 of Cr.P.C., would not be sufficient to charge the
        accused. The relevant extract is reproduced below for ready
        reference:

                “10….The statement of the victim/complainant u/s 164 Cr.P.C.
                was recorded on 19.02.2018 but for the reasons best known to
                her she has not levelled any allegations against the petitioner in
                her said statement. When in her first complaint dated
                17.02.2018 she made allegations against the petitioner then
                what transpired between the two days i.e. between 17.02.2018
                and 19.02.2018 that she has not made any allegations against
                the petitioner in her statement recorded u/s 164 Cr.P.C. which
                clearly shows her malafides against the petitioner. She has even
                failed to inform her husband regarding the conduct of the
                petitioner and despite that she kept on visiting the office of
                the petitioner without making any complaint in regard to his
                conduct.
                11. The supplementary statement of the victim was recorded on
                27.02.2018 but what prompted the IO to record the
                supplementary statement of the victim when her statement u/s
                164 Cr.P.C. was already recorded on 19.02.2018. Now in the
                supplementary statement the victim has stated that the
                petitioner used to talk loosely with her but she does not
                remember the context of the talks. Here again the victim fails
                to mention as to what words were used by the petitioner against
                her which were offensive and amounted to outrage her
                modesty. During the course of the arguments, it was also
                pointed out by the Ld. counsel for the petitioner that as per
                the CDR analysis no calls were found to be made by the
                petitioner to the victim….”.
   450.                     A similar concern was expressed by the Hon’ble High
        Court of Allahabad in case titled as Dharmendra and Ors. vs. State of
        U.P. (Criminal Misc. Bail Application Nos. 31695, 20006 and 30288

of 2021, decided on 01.10.2021, where the High Court took note of an
        emerging practice concerning recording of supplementary statements
        under Section 161 of Cr.P.C. after recording of statement under section
        164 of Cr.P.C and issued directions to the DGP of the State to take
        appropriate steps for discontinuing such a practice. The relevant
        extract is reproduced below for ready reference:

                “9…In the matters in hand the prosecutrix/victim after giving
                her statement under Section 161 of the Code levelling
                allegations of rape against the accused, has given up the same
                in her statement recorded under Section 164 of the Code. The
                Investigating Officer then records the statement of the
                prosecutrix/victim again under Section 161 of the Codce and
                puts specific questions to her with regards to the said variations
                in her statements and records her answers to the said
                questions.
                10. The said action of the Investigating Officer is not
                appreciable. Putting questions to the prosecutrix/victim with
                regards to the change in version by her in the statements
                under Section 161 of the Code and in the statement under
                Section 164 of the code, clearly shows disrespect to the courts
                who have recorded the statements under Section 164 of the
                Code. The said statements under Section 164 of the code
                recorded by Judicial Magistrates is in discharge of their judicial
                functions and the act of recording of the said statements was a
                judicial act which performed by a public servant while
                discharging his judicial functions. The said document is
                relevant under Section 35 of Indian Evidence Act and also
                under Section 72 of Indian Evidence Act and, as such, assumes
                the character of being a public document.
                11. The statement made by the prosecutrix/victim under section
                164 of the Code before the Magistrate stands on a high pedestal
                and sanctity during the course of investigation than that of her

statement recorded under section 161 of the Code by the
                Investigating Officer.
                12. Though the Investigating Agency has unfettered powers to
                investigate a matter, but they cannot on their whims and fancy
                adopt a procedure which would clearly be challenging the
                sanctity of an act done by a court of law while discharge of a
                judicial function. By putting questions to the
                prosecutrix/victim in her second statement under Section 161
                of the Code after recording of the statement under Section
                164 of the Code relating to different versions in the said two
                statements, the Investigating Officer cannot frustrate the same
                and also make an attempt to make the purpose of the said
                exercise look a farce.
                13. The act of putting specific questions pertaining to the
                variations in the said two statements by the Investigating
                Officer is viewed with an impression of clearly challenging the
                authority of a judicial act. The Investigating Officers have
                clearly exceeded their jurisdiction by proceedings to
                investigate in such a manner. The same appears to be with a
                sole purpose to frustrate the statements recorded by a
                Magistrate.
                14. Even the Uttar Pradesh Police Regulations while dealing
                with the particular duties of Police Officers for
                “Investigations” in its Chapter XI do not in any manner
                authorize the Investigating Officers to act as such. Although
                Paragraph-107 of the same states that the Investigating
                Officer would not act as a mere clerk while recordings of
                statements but has to observe and infer. Paragraph-109
                empowers for recording of supplementary statements. But the
                manner in which supplementary statements in the present
                matters have been recorded clearly show that they are for the
                sole purpose to put the variations to the witnesses and record
                the same.
                15. This court thus finds that the manner in which the
                supplementary statements are recorded and the purpose for
                recording of the same is only and solely for frustrating the

purpose of statements recorded under Section 164 of the Code
                and to negate and defeat the earlier statement of the
                prosecutrix/victim given under section 164 of the Code
                whether it is in favour or against the accused otherwise the
                sanctity of the statement under section 164 of the Code will
                loose its value. The same is neither the intent of Investigation
                nor is the purpose of it.
                                                             (emphasis supplied)

                16. The Director General of Police, Uttar Pradesh Lucknow is
                directed to look into the said new trend of Investigation as
                adopted and issue suitable guidelines for such matter so that the
                sanctity and authority of judicial proceedings are maintained
                and they should not be frustrated by any act done during
                Investigation….”.
                                                                 (emphasis supplied)

   451.                     These observations underscore that even if such a course
        may not, in a given case, be held to be per se illegal, it is a practice
        which cannot be encouraged, as it trenches upon the fundamental
        requirement of a fair investigation. The present case, prima facie,
        stands on an even more disquieting footing. Here, a confessional
        statement under Section 164 of Cr.P.C. of a person who was himself a
        participant to the crime had already been recorded. In such a situation,
        the investigative agency occupies a position of dominance,
        particularly when the maker of the statement thereafter seeks pardon
        from the Court. The adoption of a subsequent course of recording
        supplementary statements under Section 161 of Cr.P.C., in the above
        backdrop, has the effect of diluting the sanctity and purpose of the
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
safeguards embedded in Section 164 of Cr.P.C. The statutory
        framework incorporates stringent safeguards in relation to the
        recording of confessional statements. It unequivocally assures the
        accused that, should he choose not to make a confession, he shall not
        be remanded to police custody. It further prohibits the recording of any
        confession by a police officer, even if such officer has been vested
        with any of the powers of a Magistrate under any law for the time
        being in force. Where a confession is recorded, the Judicial Magistrate
        is obliged to record a memorandum certifying that the accused was
        duly cautioned that he was not bound to make the statement and that,
        if made, it could be used as evidence against him, and further
        certifying that the confession was made voluntarily and constitutes a
        full and true account of the statement. The relevant portion of the
        Section 164 of Cr.P.C. is reproduced below for ready reference:

        “Provided further that no confession shall be recorded by a police
        officer on whom any power of a Magistrate has been conferred under
        any law for the time being in force….(4) Any such confession shall be
        recorded in the manner provided in section 281 for recording the
        examination of an accused person and shall be signed by the person
        making the confession; and the Magistrate shall make a memorandum
        at the foot of such record to the following effect:

                “….I have explained to (name) that he is not bound to make a
                confession and that, if he does so, any confession
                he may make may be used as evidence against him and I

believe that this confession was voluntarily made. It
                was taken in my presence and hearing, and was read over to the
                person making it and admitted by him to be correct, and it
                contains a full and true account of the statement made by him.
                                                 (Signed) A. B. Magistrate…”.
   452.                     The legislature has thus incorporated detailed safeguards
        for recording the confessional statement of an accused, as compared
        to the statement of a witness, to ensure voluntariness before recording
        such confession. These safeguards operate in consonance with
        Sections 25 to 30 of the Indian Evidence Act, which embody the
        general principle that a confession to the police or while in police
        custody is inadmissible. In this factual backdrop, the resort to
        recording supplementary statements under Section 161 of Cr.P.C. for
        the purpose of introducing new incriminating assertions appears, at the
        very least, impermissible in principle. In any event, the Court would
        be obliged to examine such allegations with circumspection and to
        apply the settled test applicable to approver evidence, namely, that it
        must be independently corroborated on material particulars.

                                                                (emphasis supplied)

   453.                     The concern deepens when one notes that PW-20 was
        thereafter granted pardon on 16.11.2022, and his confessional
        statement under Section 306(4) of CrPC was recorded on 24.11.2022.
        In this post-pardon statement, he states that “on 28/29 October 2021
        Samir gave ₹30 lakhs to Narender Singh”, and he not only reiterates

the allegation of ₹30 lakhs, but further introduces a new narrative and
        new accused, implicating the then Excise Commissioner, and referring
        to certain inspectors, thereby suggesting that another payment to the
        Assistant Commissioner (A-2) was made on his behalf. The approver
        states: “shops were to be opened on 17 November 2021. Abhishek was
        facing difficulty in starting the shops. The government servants, in
        particular the Excise Commissioner and inspectors, were asking for
        money. To address the situation, Abhishek told me to meet the
        Commissioner of Excise. Vijay Nair told me to meet the Assistant
        Commissioner Sh. Narender Singh. He (Narender) agreed to take ₹3
        lakh per shop and assured that the work will be done. I gave him ₹30
        lakhs in cash at Khan Market. I made Narender and Abhishek
        coordinate through me. Total ₹2.10 crores were given to Narender
        through me …”.

   454.                     Significantly, after the recording of the statement under
        Section 306(4) of CrPC, the investigating agency again examined
        PW-20 on three occasions, 05.04.2023, 23.04.2023, and 17.10.2023,
        by recording supplementary statements under Section 161 of Cr.P.C..
        In none of these statements does PW-20 reiterate or elaborate upon the
        alleged payment of ₹30 lakhs or the payment of Rs. 2.10 crore. The
        Court finds it difficult to reconcile how an allegation of such gravity,
        if rooted in direct personal knowledge, repeatedly disappears from the
        witness’s narrative only to resurface selectively at a particular

juncture. The Court is, therefore, again confronted with the question
        as to whether the repeated recording of statements under Section 161
        of Cr.P.C. by the CBI, in the manner reflected on record, is permissible
        after the recording of his statement under Section 306(4) of Cr.P.C,
        and what would be the evidentiary value thereof for the purpose of
        charge. The question appears to arise in the same context as earlier;
        however, it assumes a distinct dimension when examined in light of
        the condition of full and true disclosure.

   455.                     The statutory scheme under Sections 306 and 308 of
        Cr.P.C. casts a clear obligation on the prosecution to ensure that an
        accused who has been tendered pardon fulfils the condition of
        “making a full and true disclosure of the whole of the circumstances
        within his knowledge relative to the offence and to every other person
        concerned, whether as principal or abettor, in the commission
        thereof.” This condition cannot be treated as a mere formality, as it is
        intended to ensure that the approver is mandatorily required: (i) to
        make a full and true disclosure; (ii) of the whole of the circumstances
        within his knowledge; (iii) relative to the offence; and (iv) concerning
        every other person involved, whether as principal or abettor. The
        subsequent supplementary statements recorded under Section 161 of
        Cr.P.C. after the statement recorded under Section 306(4) of Cr.P.C.,
        which itself was recorded on the above condition, prima facie raise a
        serious issue as to compliance with the condition on which pardon was

tendered. If the material on record suggested that the disclosure was
        not full and true, the investigating agency was expected to consider
        recourse to Section 308 of Cr.P.C. for seeking withdrawl of pardon and
        trying the approver as an accused. Instead, the investigating agency
        proceeded to record three further supplementary statements under
        Section 161 of Cr.P.C., a course which, on the face of it, warrants
        scrutiny.

                                                           (emphasis supplied)

   456.                     Where an approver’s statement contains serious
        allegations against public servants, the investigating agency is
        expected to test such disclosure for completeness and veracity and, if
        found wanting, to consider the consequences contemplated under
        Section 308 of Cr.P.C for seeking withdrawl of pardon. Any
        indifference to this statutory responsibility, whether by failure to
        examine the disclosure or by selectively overlooking inconvenient
        portions, cannot be lightly disregarded. Despite the presence therein
        of a specific allegation touching upon demand of bribe against the then
        Excise Commissioner, the prosecution has chosen to cite him as a
        witness, stating that no incriminating material was found against him.

   457.                     This Court is constrained to record, in clear and
        unmistakable terms, its serious displeasure at the manner in which the
        confessional statement under Section 306 (4) of Cr.P.C. was dealt with
        by the investigating agency.

    Conduct of the Investigating Officer and impact on fair trial

   458.                     What is even more disquieting is that the investigating
        agency initially represented to this Court that a copy of the said
        statement had not been supplied to it. However, upon the opening of
        the sealed cover and careful perusal of the record contained therein,
        it is found that the learned ACMM had categorically directed, “The
        copy of statement be given to the IO, if application is moved to said
        effect and statement alongwith application and proceedings be sent
        to concerned court in sealed envelope through proper channel.” It
        subsequently emerged that the Investigating Agency had, in fact,
        received a copy of the statement upon submission of his own
        application of the same date, wherein at the bottom of the handwritten
        application the words “submitted please” appear, coupled with the
        endorsement “Received a copy” on the first page of the proceedings
        which took place for recording of the confessional statement under
        Section 306(4) of Cr.P.C., and the original application was found
        inside the sealed envelope.

   459.                          A representation so made, which stands squarely
        contradicted by the record itself, cannot be countenanced. The conduct
        reflected from the record is wholly unsatisfactory and inconsistent
        with the duty of fairness, candour and transparency expected of an
        investigating agency. Further, the said statement was not supplied to
        the accused persons, a lapse that directly impinges upon the fairness

of the investigation and strikes at the very root of procedural
        propriety.

   460.                     The prosecution’s own stand further weakens the
        approver’s version. When the then Excise Commissioner has been
        examined as a prosecution witness on the premise that no material
        was found against him, the allegation that any bribe was demanded or
        collected on his behalf stands considerably diluted and, in the absence
        of corroboration on material particulars, cannot be sustained. Once this
        link is broken, the allegation against A-2 remains unsupported by any
        independent or objective material.

   461.                     The record reveals a circumstance of considerable legal
        significance. The Investigating Officer has, in clear and categorical
        terms, recorded a finding that no incriminating material was found
        against the then Excise Commissioner, who has consequently been
        impleaded as a prosecution witness (PW-74). This admission by the
        investigating agency is not a matter of inference but flows directly
        from its own assessment, and unequivocally reflects that the
        allegations, at least to that extent, were found to be unsubstantiated
        and devoid of factual foundation.

   462.                     Viewed in this backdrop, the subsequent conduct of the
        Investigating Agency in repeatedly recording supplementary
        statements of the approver under Section 161 of Cr.P.C., even after the
        grant of pardon, assumes critical importance. The very necessity of

recording multiple post-pardon statements is indicative of the fact that
        the disclosure made by the approver at the relevant stages was neither
        complete nor exhaustive. A pardon under the Cr.P.C. is not an
        unqualified or unconditional indulgence; it is tendered subject to strict
        and well-defined conditions. Even at the cost of repetition, these
        conditions oblige the approver: (i) to make a full and true disclosure;
        (ii) of the whole of the circumstances within his knowledge; (iii)
        relating to the offence; and (iv) concerning every other person
        involved therein, whether as a principal or as an abettor.

   463.                     The record, on its face, discloses a breach of these
        foundational conditions. The emergence of new facts, fresh
        explanations, and even additional accused persons, solely on the basis
        of supplementary statements recorded under Section 161 of Cr.P.C.
        after the grant of pardon, demonstrates that the approver did not
        comply with the essential requirement of making a full and true
        disclosure at the time when such disclosure was statutorily mandated.
        This is not a mere procedural lapse but goes to the root of the legality
        and sustainability of the pardon itself.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   464.                     What further compounds the matter is that, despite such
        apparent non-compliance, the prosecution has not deemed it necessary
        to seek withdrawal or forfeiture of the tender of pardon, as
        contemplated under the statutory scheme. The Court finds it difficult

to comprehend the rationale behind this omission. Instead of invoking
        the legal consequence of breach of pardon conditions, the investigating
        agency has chosen to rely upon successive Section 161 supplementary
        statements to progressively build, supplement, and reshape the
        prosecution narrative. Such an approach effectively permits the
        approver to enjoy the benefit of immunity, while simultaneously
        allowing the prosecution to fill gaps, introduce new versions, and
        widen the net of accused persons on the strength of statements which,
        in law, are of a limited and suspect evidentiary worth.
                                                             (emphasis supplied)

   465.                     The evidentiary value and legal admissibility of such
        post-pardon supplementary statements recorded under Section 161 of
        Cr.P.C., particularly in the context of an approver who has failed to
        adhere to the conditions of pardon, have been examined and dealt with
        in detail. For the present, it suffices to note that this course of action
        not only undermines the statutory discipline governing approver
        evidence, but also raises serious concerns regarding fairness,
        reliability, and the integrity of the investigative process itself.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   466.                     The Court also notes that the allegation regarding
        payment of ₹30 lakhs purportedly by A-2 is plainly hearsay. Such an
        assertion, in the absence of contemporaneous documentary support,
        recovery, or statement from any witness speaking from direct

knowledge, cannot be accorded evidentiary value even at the stage of
        charge. Further, the circumstance that A-1 was arrayed as an accused
        and chargesheeted at the forefront, despite the absence of any direct or
        indirect allegation against him in this narrative, accentuates the
        fragility of the prosecution’s approach. There is not even a single
        allegation in the statements of approver PW-20 naming A-1 as the
        recipient or stating that A-2 acted on his behalf. This Court notes that
        it is for the first time that it has come across a charge-sheet in which
        as many as seven statements of an approver have been recorded. No
        decision of any higher court has been placed before this Court to show
        that such a course has been adopted or approved in any other case.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   467.                     Viewed cumulatively, the allegation of payment of ₹30
        lakhs is founded on a solitary, shifting, and hearsay version of an
        approver, marked by late introduction, subsequent embellishment, and
        selective silence. The manner in which the investigating agency has
        dealt with the approver’s statements, coupled with the absence of
        independent corroboration on material particulars, renders the
        allegation legally infirm. Even at the stage of consideration of charge,
        such a solitary approver statement, unsupported by credible
        corroborative material, cannot, by itself, furnish a sound basis for
        drawing grave suspicion against the accused.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
468.                     The prosecution witnesses discloses no demand, no
        acceptance, no abuse of official position, and no meeting of minds so
        as to attract offences under PC Act, 1988. The administrative acts
        attributed to A-1 and A-2 are documented, supervised, policy-aligned
        and institutionally vetted. The allegations founded on PW-20’s
        statement stand neutralised by his own omissions in the statement
        recorded under Section 164 of Cr.P.C. Continuation of proceedings on
        such material would amount to subjecting the accused to trial on
        conjecture rather than legally admissible evidence.

   469.                     Upon a careful, close and dispassionate scrutiny of the
        material placed on record, it becomes evident that the allegations
        levelled by the CBI against A-1 and A-2 are not the product of an
        objective or impartial investigation. The record, on the contrary,
        reveals a pre-meditated and choreographed exercise, wherein roles
        appear to have been retrospectively assigned to suit a preconceived
        narrative. What is particularly disturbing is the complete disregard
        shown by the investigating officer to the fact that public servants, who
        were discharging their official duties on a day-to-day basis for the
        effective implementation of a governmental policy, have been
        subjected to criminal prosecution solely on the basis of inadmissible
        hearsay attributed to an approver, despite the investigation yielding no
        material against them.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

470.                     The Court cannot lose sight of the fact that the period
        during which their conduct is sought to be questioned coincided with
        an unprecedented national crisis, when the entire country was
        grappling with the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.
        During this phase, the officials concerned were performing their duties
        under extraordinary pressure, often at personal risk, to ensure timely
        implementation of policy measures so that essential governance
        functions continued and the State did not suffer avoidable loss of
        revenue.

   471.                     A government servant occupies an inherently vulnerable
        position, being duty-bound to take decisions and exercise discretion in
        the course of official functions. Viewed in this backdrop, the Court
        finds it difficult to comprehend how, in the admitted absence of
        incriminating material, these public servants were arrayed as accused,
        and how sanction for their prosecution came to be accorded despite
        the lack of any admissible material against A-1 and A-2. Such a
        prosecutorial construct is intrinsically fragile and cannot withstand
        judicial scrutiny when tested on the anvil of settled principles
        governing appreciation of evidence. The manner in which the
        investigation has been conducted, far from conforming to the
        discipline of a fair and lawful investigation, discloses a calculated and
        sustained assault on the foundational tenets of the rule of law.

472.                     Equally troubling is the conduct of retaining an
        individual in the column of “suspect” while simultaneously presenting
        the very same person as a prosecution witness at the stage of filing of
        the charge-sheet. In the case at hand, Arva Gopi Krishna, the then
        Excise Commissioner, and Anand Kumar Tewari, the then Deputy
        Commissioner, have been placed in Column No. 12 and Arva Gopi
        Krishna has been cited as prosecution witness, namely PW-74. This
        self-contradictory stance cannot be brushed aside as a mere procedural
        irregularity. It betrays a conscious and calculated stratagem by which
        the investigating officer has sought to keep the narrative deliberately
        fluid, relying upon the individual’s statement to prop up the
        prosecution case, while at the same time preserving the option of
        implicating that very person should the case, as projected, fail to
        withstand judicial scrutiny. Such dual positioning unmistakably
        reveals that the investigating officer was, from the outset, conscious of
        the inherent fragility of the allegations being advanced and
        apprehensive that the version placed before the Court might not
        survive close judicial examination.

                                                            (emphasis supplied)

   473.                     This approach does not reflect prudence; it reveals
        anticipatory manipulation, designed to protect the investigator rather
        than to assist the Court in its pursuit of truth. It stands in stark
        opposition to the very concept of a fair investigation, which is an

integral facet of due process. An investigating officer is not expected
        to act with tactical cleverness or strategic flexibility; he is required to
        proceed with candour, neutrality and unwavering fidelity to the factual
        record. An investigation must rest on a clear, consistent and principled
        assessment of the material collected, and not on calculated ambiguity
        intended to preserve future prosecutorial options.

   474.                     The Court is therefore constrained to observe that such a
        course of action reduces the investigative process to a self-serving
        exercise, where legal technicalities are invoked not to uncover the
        truth, but to shield investigative lapses and to construct a post-facto
        defence in the event that suppression or distortion of material facts is
        exposed during judicial scrutiny. Such conduct amounts to a conscious
        abuse of official position and strikes at the very core of the criminal
        justice system.

   475.                     In these circumstances, the course consistent with the
        duty of the Court is not merely to discount the tainted investigative
        material, but also to recommend initiation of appropriate departmental
        proceedings against the erring investigating officer for framing A-1 as
        an accused in the absence of any material against him, so that
        accountability is fixed and the institutional credibility of the
        investigative machinery is preserved. Reliance is placed upon the
        judgment of the Hon’ble Supreme Court in Gajoo vs. State of
        Uttarakhand (2012) 9 SCC 532. To permit such conduct to pass

without consequence would erode public confidence in the
        administration of criminal justice and would amount to tacit judicial
        approval of investigative impropriety, an outcome which the rule of
        law does not permit.

        Allegation against A-18

   476.                     The prosecution alleges that A-18, Arvind Kejriwal, in
        his capacity as the Chief Minister of Delhi, occupied the apex position
        in, and exercised overarching control over, the criminal conspiracy
        relating to the formulation and implementation of the DEP-21/22. It is
        alleged that the policy was approved and implemented with his
        conscious knowledge that it conferred undue pecuniary advantage
        upon select private liquor interests associated with the so-called
        “South Group”, and that Cabinet approvals, including Cabinet
        Decisions, were accorded with such awareness. The prosecution
        further alleges that A-18 was cognisant of the generation of illegal
        gratification arising from the policy framework and of its intended
        political utilisation, including for election-related purposes, and that
        he permitted the continuation of the policy and the alleged illicit
        arrangements despite knowledge of these aspects. According to the
        prosecution, his role was not limited to formal approval but extended
        to providing political sanction, protection and continuity to the acts of
        co-conspirators, thereby placing him at the apex of the alleged
        conspiracy and rendering him liable for the acts committed in

furtherance thereof by public servants, intermediaries and private
        persons involved in the excise policy matter.

        Analysis

   477.                     The prosecution seeks to connect A-18 mainly on the
        basis of one sentence in the statement of the witness, namely PW-225
        Magunta Sreenivasulu Reddy: “Thereafter, he told me that Ms. K.
        Kavitha, daughter of Shri K. Chandershekhar Rao, the then CM of
        Telangana would be contacting me in this regard.”

   478.                 At the outset, it is to be noted that the name of A-18 appears
        for the first time in the statement of PW-225 Magunta Sreenivasulu
        Reddy dated 03.01.2024. This statement was recorded in response to
        a specific query by the Investigating Officer as to whether he had met
        A-18 and whether anyone else was present at that time. The
        prosecution seeks to base the allegation against A-18 primarily on
        what is stated in that statement. The relevant extract relied upon by the
        prosecution reads as under:

                “…On 16.03.2021, I went to the Delhi Secretariat and met Shri
                Arvind Kejriwal in his chamber at around 04:30 PM. When I
                reached there, around 10–12 persons were standing to meet
                Shri Arvind Kejriwal… Shri Arvind Kejriwal offered me a
                chair and told me that we could very well do the liquor business
                in Delhi and he would be supporting us in that. Thereafter, he
                told me that Ms. K Kavitha, daughter of Shri K
                Chandershekhar Rao, the then CM of Telangana would be
                contacting me in this regard. Shri Arvind Kejriwal further told

me to provide some monetary funding to his Aam Aadmi Party.
                It was a brief meeting, which lasted around 6–7 minutes…”.
   479.                     It is this extract, and particularly the line referring to Ms.
        K. Kavitha contacting the witness, on which the prosecution rests its
        case to connect A-18 with the alleged conspiracy. The question which
        arises is whether this statement, by itself, is sufficient to prima facie
        link A-18 with the alleged conspiracy. It cannot be disputed that, in a
        given case, even a single circumstance may assume significance if it
        forms part of a larger chain pointing towards a prior meeting of minds
        and acts done in furtherance of a common object. If the prosecution is
        able to demonstrate that such a circumstance is self-sufficient and
        intrinsically incriminating, it may legitimately contribute to raising
        grave suspicion.

   480.                     However, the statement relied upon, when read in
        isolation, does not, on its plain terms, attribute any overtly illegal act.
        It does not, by itself, disclose the commission of an offence or an
        agreement to commit one. Its evidentiary value therefore depends
        entirely on whether it can be placed within a complete and coherent
        chain of circumstances. It is settled that in cases based on
        circumstantial evidence, the prosecution is not required, at the stage of
        charge, to establish the entire chain with the same degree of certainty
        as at the stage of conviction. Conspiracy is rarely proved by direct
        evidence and may be inferred from surrounding circumstances. At the
        same time, even at the prima facie stage, the circumstances relied upon

must show reasonable continuity and proximity. Where there is a clear
        disconnection, or where the circumstances do not naturally align, the
        inference of conspiracy cannot rest on assumption.

   481.                     The investigating agency may be granted some latitude
        in proving the manner in which a conspiracy was executed. But such
        latitude does not extend to foundational facts. The basic links which
        anchor the alleged conspiracy must be clearly borne out from the
        material collected. If the prosecution seeks the benefit of inference, the
        initial facts from which such inference is to be drawn must themselves
        be firmly placed on record. A conspiracy cannot remain unanchored;
        it must rest on identifiable material.

   482.                     In the present context, the case against A-18 is projected
        as resting on circumstantial evidence and on the roles attributed to
        certain other accused said to be directly associated with him. If the
        material against such persons does not, by itself, survive to raise grave
        suspicion, then the case against A-18, whose role is stated to be
        supervisory or overarching, would necessarily stand on a weakened
        footing. Liability for conspiracy cannot be inferred in isolation. It must
        arise from circumstances which are proximate, consistent and
        mutually reinforcing. In the absence of such connecting material, a
        solitary statement of the nature relied upon cannot, by itself, meet the
        legal threshold required to proceed further.

483.                     The role attributed to A-18 calls for careful and
        structured examination. It cannot be viewed in isolation, nor can it be
        assessed merely on the strength of broad allegations. The analysis has
        to proceed on two distinct but interrelated planes. First, it must be
        examined in the backdrop of the roles attributed to the other accused
        persons. Secondly, it must be examined in the context of the
        formulation and approval of the Excise Policy itself, bearing in mind
        the constitutional position occupied by A-18 as the Chief Minister at
        the relevant time.

   484.                     In this regard, the role of A-8 assumes particular
        relevance. A-8 was heading the Excise Department as the Deputy
        Chief Minister and was directly associated with the policy domain in
        question. A-18, on the other hand, was the Chief Minister. The
        prosecution seeks to project A-18 as the central figure who allegedly
        manipulated the policy for the benefit of the so-called “South Group”
        and for the purpose of recouping alleged upfront money. This
        allegation is of a serious nature and forms the foundation upon which
        the subsequent allegations are constructed.

   485.                     The prosecution further attempts to connect A-18 with
        the alleged utilisation of funds in the Goa election. However, this
        allegation is consequential and derivative. If the foundational
        allegation, namely, manipulation of policy in furtherance of a criminal
        design, does not prima facie withstand scrutiny, then the subsequent

allegation regarding utilisation of funds would automatically lose its
        footing. The latter cannot survive independently if the former fails to
        disclose the necessary ingredients of conspiracy or criminal
        misconduct.

   486.                     It is also significant that the inception of the alleged role
        of A-18 emerges for the first time in the Fourth Supplementary
        Charge-sheet. Until that stage, his name did not figure in the
        prosecution narrative in the manner now sought to be projected. The
        principal material relied upon to implicate him is the statement of
        PW-225, read in alignment with the statement of PW-226 (Raghav
        Magunta Reddy), who has been examined as an approver. It is through
        this material that the prosecution seeks to bring A-18 within the fold
        of the larger alleged conspiracy.

   487.                     In these circumstances, it would be appropriate to
        commence the analysis from the allegations contained in the Fourth
        Supplementary Charge-sheet, being the chargesheet under which A-18
        was arrayed as an accused. The Court shall therefore examine, in the
        first instance, the statement of PW-225, its contents, its legal character,
        and its capacity, if any, to connect A-18 with the alleged conspiracy.
        Only thereafter can the broader allegation of overarching control or
        political sanction be meaningfully assessed on the touchstone of the
        material placed on record.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
488.                     Even if the narration of PW-225’s in his own statement
        accepted arguendo at face value, unmistakably discloses his conscious
        and active participation in the very arrangement which the prosecution
        seeks to characterise as a criminal conspiracy. His statement does not
        place him in the position of a neutral, chance or peripheral witness. On
        the contrary, he candidly acknowledges that he decided to enter the
        Delhi liquor business, sought an appointment with the Chief Minister
        for “support and guidance”, thereafter met A-17 (Ms. K. Kavitha),
        discussed entry into the Delhi liquor business, entertained and
        negotiated a demand of ₹100 crores as “upfront money”, and then
        entrusted the actual handling of finances and logistics to his son who
        is approver Pw -226 . His own admissions, inter alia, include:

                “…I came to know that a DEP-21/22 for the year 2021-22 was
                coming in Delhi. In order to expand the business, I decided to
                enter in the liquor business at Delhi.”
                “I wanted to meet Shri Arvind Kejriwal, CM, Delhi for
                having some support and guidance for entering into the liquor
                business at Delhi…”
                “In the said meeting with Ms. K Kavitha, she told me that total
                amount of Rs. 100 Crores has to be arranged… She
                demanded Rs. 50 Crores from me…”
                “I told her that I would be discussing this matter with my son
                Raghav and get back in few days.”
                “the matter regarding the payment of upfront money was
                totally handled by my son Shri Raghav… total payment of
                Rs. 25 Crores as upfront money was made by him…”.

489.                     Read cumulatively, these admissions leave no manner of
        doubt that PW-225 is not narrating events as an external observer. His
        statement is self-incriminating in nature and discloses that both he and
        his son (PW-226) were active participants in the alleged transaction
        chain which the prosecution labels as conspiratorial. Though he has
        not been formally tendered pardon or examined as an approver, the
        intrinsic character of his statement places him squarely within the zone
        of a participant admitting engagement with the alleged scheme.

   490.                     A serious infirmity that surfaces in the present matter is
        the apparent misconception of the legal position by the investigating
        and prosecuting agencies with regard to the evidentiary value of
        certain witnesses. The record indicates that individuals who have, in
        their own statements, admitted participation in the alleged transaction
        have been examined merely as prosecution witnesses, without being
        arraigned as accused and without being tendered pardon as approvers.
        Yet, their statement appears to have been treated on par with that of
        wholly independent witnesses. It is equally possible that the agencies
        were conscious of the settled position in law, but nevertheless sought
        to project such witnesses as independent in order to lend greater
        weight to their case.

   491.                     This approach overlooks the settled distinction in
        criminal jurisprudence between an independent witness and one who
        is a participant in the alleged offence. It is undoubtedly within the

discretion of the investigating agency to examine a co-participant as a
        witness, even without formally making him an accused or an approver.
        Such latitude exists to ensure that the truth is not suppressed merely
        because a person is complicit, and to enable the investigating
        machinery to unravel complex transactions. The law does not compel
        the agency to either prosecute every participant or necessarily tender
        pardon in each case.

   492.                     However, this discretion is neither absolute nor immune
        from judicial scrutiny. It must be exercised in a fair, reasonable and
        non-arbitrary manner, consistent with the mandate of Article 21 and
        the broader principles governing criminal trials. The Hon’ble Supreme
        Court, in Laxmipat Choraria (supra) and later in A.R. Antulay (supra)
        as followed in R. Dineshkumar @ Deena (supra), has recognised the
        permissibility of examining a participes criminis as a prosecution
        witness. At the same time, the Court has been careful to underscore
        that such evidence does not assume the character of independent
        statement. It must have been borne in the mind of the Supreme Court
        that such discretion, if left unchecked, could be misused by the
        investigating agency; it is for this reason that the Court has
        consistently held that the caution applicable to accomplice evidence
        must equally govern the appreciation of statement given by such
        witnesses.

493.                     The law is explicit that the evidentiary value of such a
        witness is that of accomplice evidence. Even if the witness is not
        formally declared an approver, once he implicates himself in the
        commission of the offence, his statement stands on the same footing
        as that of an accomplice. It must, therefore, be received with the
        caution traditionally attached to accomplice statement. The rule of
        prudence, requiring independent corroboration on material particulars,
        comes into play. Trial Court is required to scrutinise such evidence
        with care, mindful of the possibility of self-exculpation, shifting of
        blame, or inducement.

   494.                     The jurisprudential concern underlying these precedents
        is evident. While the investigative agency must not be hamstrung in
        unearthing the truth, the criminal process cannot be structured in a
        manner that allows a self-confessed participant to escape the rigour of
        prosecution              while   simultaneously   furnishing   the      primary
        incriminating material against others, and yet be accorded the
        evidentiary stature of a neutral observer. To treat such statement as
        independent evidence would dilute the safeguards built into the law of
        evidence and would disturb the balance between effective
        investigation and a fair trial.

                                                                 (emphasis supplied)

   495.                     The basis for treating such statement with caution lies
        not in the description given by the prosecution, but in the nature of the

evidence itself. When a witness admits his own involvement in the
        alleged offence and at the same time seeks to implicate others, his
        statement is necessarily affected by self-interest. Merely examining
        him as a general witness does not remove the taint arising from his
        admitted participation. Unlike an approver who is tendered pardon
        through a statutory process and remains subject to the consequences
        of any deviation from full and truthful disclosure, a self-confessed
        participant examined as an ordinary witness does not undergo similar
        safeguards. In such circumstances, the possibility of aligning his
        version with the prosecution to secure protection for himself cannot be
        ruled out. For this reason, the settled rule of prudence requires that his
        evidence be approached with the same caution as accomplice evidence
        and that it be relied upon only if there is independent corroboration on
        material particulars connecting the accused with the alleged offence.

   496.                   Accordingly, the statements of witnesses who incriminate
        themselves, though examined as prosecution witnesses, cannot be
        elevated to the status of independent evidence. Their statement must
        be approached with circumspection and must find assurance from
        independent corroborative material before it can be acted upon. Any
        failure to apply this settled principle would amount to a clear
        misdirection in law.

   497.                     The prosecution has attempted to support the statement
        of PW-225 by relying upon the statement of approver PW-226. This

raises a basic question in the law of evidence: whether the statement
        of one accomplice-like witness can be treated as corroborated merely
        because it is supported by another accomplice or approver.

   498.                     On the material placed before the Court, the position is
        straightforward. PW-226 does not claim to have personally witnessed
        the alleged meeting between PW-225 and A-18. His version, insofar
        as it concerns that meeting, is based on what was allegedly told to him
        by PW-225. To that extent, his statement is hearsay and cannot
        constitute independent corroboration. Corroboration in law must come
        from a source independent of the witness whose statement is sought to
        be strengthened.

   499.                     The matter assumes further significance because
        PW-225 himself has stated that 10 to 12 persons were present at the
        time of the alleged meeting with A-18. Those persons were
        independent witnesses who, if examined, could have provided direct
        evidence as to what transpired. Their statements are not before the
        Court. It is not known whether they were never examined or whether
        they were examined but did not support the prosecution case. In either
        situation, the absence statement of such independent witnesses creates
        a serious gap.

   500.                     Even if the prosecution seeks to rely upon certain
        surrounding circumstances referred to by PW-226 as corroboration on
        material particulars, the legal difficulty remains. The question is

whether PW-225 can be treated as an independent source to
        corroborate PW-226, or vice versa. The answer must be in the
        negative. The Hon’ble Supreme Court in K. Hashim (supra), followed
        in Somasundaram (supra), has reiterated the settled principle that one
        accomplice cannot corroborate another. Corroboration must be
        independent. No exceptional circumstance has been pointed out by the
        prosecution to justify departure from this settled rule.

   501.                     The charge-sheet further records that A-18 had stated
        that PW-225 had come to meet him regarding allotment of land in
        Delhi for a trust, and that this explanation was found to be false on the
        basis of PW-225’s statement. At this stage, the defence version cannot
        be evaluated. However, the only direct assertion connecting A-18 to
        the alleged conspiracy, namely, the alleged statement that A-17 would
        call in that regard, rests solely on the uncorroborated statement of
        PW-225. The admitted presence of public persons during the
        conversation, coupled with their non-examination, leaves no material
        on record to bring the case within any recognised exception.

   502.                     This assumes added importance because the alleged
        conversation was capable of direct verification through the very
        persons stated to be present. In the absence of such independent
        evidence, the prosecution case rests on one accomplice-like statement
        being supported by another. In law, such mutual reliance does not
        amount to corroboration.

503.                     Accordingly, the statement said to directly connect A-18
        remains absolutely uncorroborated by independent evidence. In the
        absence of such corroboration, it cannot be treated as sufficient to
        sustain the allegation.

   504.                     Upon consideration of the material placed on record, this
        Court finds that, as already discussed while examining the role of A-8,
        the prosecution has failed to establish even a prima facie case of
        manipulation of the policy. The clauses incorporated in the policy
        cannot be traced to any document allegedly supplied by the so-called
        South Group. The record reflects deliberations at various levels,
        examination by the competent authorities, and a progressive
        development of the policy framework, culminating in approval by the
        Hon’ble LG. No material has been shown to suggest any prior
        agreement or meeting of minds indicative of a criminal conspiracy in
        the formulation of the policy.

   505.                     If the principal allegation against the Deputy Chief
        Minister (A-8) does not withstand scrutiny, the attempt to fasten a
        peripheral role upon Chief Minister (A-18) cannot independently
        survive. The allegation against A-18 rests primarily on a solitary line
        in the statement of PW-225, an accomplice-like witness, stating that
        A-17 would be contacting him. The said statement is alleged to have
        been made in the presence of 10 to 12 persons. Those persons were
        admittedly present; however, they have either not been examined or, if

examined, have not been cited as witnesses in the charge-sheet. The
        absence of such independent version raises serious concerns regarding
        the completeness and fairness of the investigation. Where direct
        witnesses are available, reliance on a tainted source cannot
        compensate for their non-production.

   506.                     The prosecution proceeds on the premise that the policy
        was manipulated pursuant to a criminal design. If that foundation is
        not established, the subsequent allegations necessarily lose their
        footing. A prosecution cannot be sustained by isolating a fragment and
        elevating it into a circumstance of a larger conspiracy without first
        proving the core allegation.

   507.                     A scrutiny of the record further reveals that no
        contemporaneous document, file noting, electronic communication,
        financial transaction or digital evidence has been produced to directly
        or indirectly connect A-18 with any alleged policy manipulation or
        illegal gratification. There is no material to show his presence at any
        conspiratorial meeting or to indicate his knowledge of any unlawful
        arrangement. The attempt to implicate him rests on inference drawn
        from uncorroborated accomplice-like statement.

   508.                     It is also noteworthy that PW-20, the prosecution’s
        approver whose seven statements are relied upon and who claims
        knowledge from the stage of policy formulation to the alleged
        utilisation of funds, has not attributed any role to A-18. PW-20 has

assigned roles to several other accused persons. There appears no
        reason why, if any involvement of A-18 existed within his knowledge,
        the same would not have been disclosed. His silence in this regard
        assumes significance and further weakens the case sought to be made
        against A-18.

   509.                     The mere invocation of the expression “conspiracy” does
        not dispense with the requirement of material indicating agreement
        and participation. Criminal liability cannot be inferred from the office
        held or from suspicion. In the absence of admissible material, and
        where the connection is sought to be established solely through
        uncorroborated tainted statements, the threshold required even at the
        stage of charge is not satisfied. Reliance is place upon the judgment of
        Hon’ble Supreme Court in Suresh Budharmal Kalani (supra).

   510.                 The right to life and personal liberty under Article 21 of the
        Constitution mandates that every prosecution must rest upon a fair,
        objective and complete investigation. A fair trial is inseparable from a
        fair investigation. When independent material is available but not
        placed before the Court, and reliance is placed instead upon selective
        fragments of inculpatory statements, the constitutional guarantee is put
        at risk. The liberty and reputation of an individual cannot be imperilled
        on the basis of conjecture or unsupported inference. Criminal
        proceedings are intended to adjudicate facts in accordance with law,
        not to proceed upon speculative allegations.

(emphasis supplied)

   511.                     If persons are implicated without cogent and legally
        admissible material, the effect would be to allow the investigating
        agency, rather than the Court, to determine their fate. Such a course is
        inconsistent with the rule of law. Serious allegations must be supported
        by admissible material. In the absence of foundational material
        connecting A-18 with any criminal design, and in the absence of
        independent corroboration of the statements of accomplice like
        witness, relied upon, the attribution of a central conspiratorial role
        cannot be sustained.

   512.                     The consequences are even more serious where the
        person concerned holds a constitutional office. Arrest and prosecution
        in such circumstances have implications beyond the individual. Public
        confidence in institutions is inevitably affected. If it is later found that
        such prosecution was unsupported by admissible material, the erosion
        of public trust is substantial. The power to investigate and prosecute
        carries with it a corresponding obligation of fairness, restraint and
        adherence to rule of evidence. Only by strict observance of these
        principles can both individual liberty and public faith in the justice
        system be preserved.

   513.                     Resultantly, when the statement of PW-225 is evaluated
        in its correct legal character, as a self-incriminating, participant-
        account akin to that of an approver, and tested against the complete

absence of independent corroboration on the sole material link
        attributed to A-18, the Court finds that such uncorroborated statement
        cannot, even at the threshold stage, constitute a legally sustainable
        basis to proceed against A-18.

        Failure of Case Against Public Servants — Nonetheless, Examination
        of Other Accused Continues

   514.                     The prosecution seeks to portray A-8, the then Deputy
        Chief Minister, as the principal architect of the DEP-21/22. It is
        alleged that he constituted the Ravi Dhawan Committee, chaired the
        GoM, brought about structural changes by privatising the wholesale
        segment, fixed the wholesale margin at 12%, and structured the policy
        in a manner intended to recoup alleged upfront payments of about
        ₹90–100 crores, thereby laying the groundwork for the supposed
        conspiracy. It is further alleged that illegal gratification was paid to
        A-2 for facilitating the grant of licence to M/S Indospirit, and that such
        licence was ultimately granted by A-1. The Chief Minister (A-18) is
        projected as the central figure who orchestrated the overall design.

   515.                     However, for reasons already recorded, when these
        allegations are examined in the light of the material placed on record,
        they are reduced to inferences not supported by admissible material.
        The links said to form the chain of conspiracy are not borne out from
        contemporaneous official notings, departmental records, or any
        independent documentary material. There is no demonstrable nexus

between the features of the policy and the alleged recoupment theory.
        The prosecution case, insofar as it seeks to attribute criminal
        culpability to public servants under the PC Act, 1988 thus remains
        without foundational material.

   516.                     It must be emphasised that unless there is material
        indicating demand, acceptance, or conscious abuse of official position
        for obtaining pecuniary advantage, the essential ingredients of
        offences under the PC Act cannot be said to exist. In the absence of
        such material, the very basis for proceeding against public servants
        under the said enactment stands eroded.

   517.                     Be that as it may, and in order to examine the matter in
        its entirety, this Court deems it appropriate to proceed further on the
        assumption, without so holding, that the prosecution case survives
        scrutiny against the public servants. Proceeding on that hypothesis, it
        becomes necessary to consider whether the material on record
        discloses sufficient grounds to frame charges against the private
        accused persons who are alleged to have acted in concert.

   518.                     The discussion shall now move to the second category
        of accused persons, examined role-wise for the sake of clarity and
        coherence. The enquiry shall remain confined to the limited test
        applicable at the stage of framing of charge, namely whether the
        material gives rise to grave suspicion based on admissible evidence,

or whether it rests merely on conjecture insufficient to warrant a
        criminal trial.

        Allegation against A-3

   519.                     The prosecution projects A-3, Vijay Nair, as the central
        facilitator and operational fulcrum of the alleged criminal conspiracy
        concerning the formulation and implementation of the DEP-21/22.
        Though not holding any formal office in the Government of NCT of
        Delhi, he is alleged to have exercised de facto influence by reason of
        his proximity to the political executive, particularly Accused Manish
        Sisodia (A-8) and other senior functionaries, and to have functioned
        as the principal intermediary between public servants and private
        liquor businessmen described as the “South Group”.

   520.                     It is alleged that A-3 convened, attended and coordinated
        crucial meetings-inter alia at Gauri Apartments, New Delhi, and at ITC
        Kohenoor, Hyderabad-where the prosecution claims the contours of
        the conspiracy were crystallised, including the alleged demand,
        arrangement and quantification of illegal gratification aggregating
        approximately Rs. 90-100 crores. According to the prosecution, he
        negotiated and facilitated advance payments of Rs. 20-30 crores
        through hawala channels, and thereafter played a coordinating role in
        the generation, collection and recovery of illicit funds through
        favoured wholesalers, including M/S Indospirits and M/S BSPL.

521.                     The prosecution further alleges that A-3 ensured that key
        policy features-such as the uniform 12% wholesale margin, the “one
        wholesaler per manufacturer” model, the zoning of retail vends, and
        the use of credit-note mechanisms-were operationalised in a manner
        advantageous to the alleged conspirators. He is also attributed a
        supervisory role in the routing, layering and diversion of the alleged
        proceeds of crime through commercial, media and intermediary
        entities, as well as in coordinating the political utilisation of such
        funds, including for the Goa Assembly Elections, 2022.

   522.                     On this foundation, the prosecution asserts that the
        conduct attributed to A-3 discloses continuity of involvement,
        conscious facilitation and requisite mens rea, portraying him as a key
        non-official architect and executor of the alleged conspiracy
        underlying the DEP-21/22.

        Analysis

        (a) Meeting at Gauri Apartments

   523.                     The prosecution seeks to attribute the genesis of the
        alleged criminal conspiracy relating to the formulation and
        implementation of the DEP-21/22 to an interaction stated to have
        taken place in May 2021 at Gauri Apartments, involving Vijay Nair
        (A-3), Arjun Pandey (A-10), Dinesh Arora (PW-20), Sikander Maan
        (PW-20), his nephew Virat Maan (PW-1), Abhishek Boinpally (A-4),

A.R. Pillai (A-5) and Butchi Babu (A-11), and to portray the said
        interaction as a precursor to the subsequent meeting at ITC Kohinoor,
        Hyderabad. In support of this assertion, reliance has been placed upon
        the statement of the approver Dinesh Arora (PW-20), read with the
