        statements of PW-1 and PW-2. The prosecution further attempts to
        locate the origin of the alleged conspiracy in meeting purportedly held
        at Flat No. 2, 3/4, Gauri Apartment, Rajesh Pilot Lane, New Delhi, an
        allegation founded on the statements of PW-41 (Cook), PW-42
        (Caretaker) and PW-43 (Sh. Rajiv Singh, Additional Advocate
        General), which therefore falls for close scrutiny at the threshold.

   524.                     A conjoint reading of the statements of PW-1 Virat
        Maan, PW-2 Sikander Maan, and the approver Dinesh Arora (PW-20)
        does not support the prosecution’s attempt to characterise the alleged
        May 2021 interaction as conspiratorial. What runs as a common thread
        through the statements of the aforesaid witnesses is the assertion that
        the members of the so-called “South Group” were contemplating the
        acquisition of five to ten retail zones, and that PW-1 and PW-2 could
        assist them in setting up the shops and providing staff for running the
        shops. In return, it is stated, assistance would be extended to promote
        their brand “Royal Green” at such outlets, and to facilitate the sale of
        the said brand in the Telangana market. The tenor of these statements
        unmistakably suggests that the intention attributed to the South Group

members was to enter the retail liquor business, to secure retail
        zones, and to arrange manpower if and when such entry materialised.

   525.                     At this stage, it assumes significance to note that PW-20,
        in his confessional statement recorded under Section 164 of Cr.P.C.
        prior to the grant of pardon, has nowhere stated that the members of
        the South Group were inclined to take five to ten retail zones. This
        assertion emerges only subsequently, in the statement recorded under
        Section 306(4) of Cr.P.C. after the grant of pardon, wherein PW-20
        introduces the version that the South Group was inclined to take five
        to ten zones. The belated introduction of this detail, after the grant of
        pardon, when contrasted with the earlier silence, is a circumstance
        which bears directly on the probative worth of the version now sought
        to be relied upon.

   526.                     It also bears emphasis that the investigating agency has
        not disputed the tender process, nor has it alleged any undue favour or
        irregularity in the allotment of retail zones. The integrity of the tender
        mechanism and the legitimacy of participation in the retail excise
        business thus stand undisputed on the prosecution’s own showing.

                                                                 (emphasis supplied)

   527.                     Equally relevant is the admitted position that PW-1 and
        PW-2 are themselves deeply associated with the liquor business. PW-2
        has categorically stated that he is the manufacturer of the brand

“Royal Green” and has further admitted that he is running nearly 60
        retail outlets in the State of Haryana. Despite this admitted commercial
        positioning, the prosecution does not allege any criminal conspiracy
        against PW-1 or PW-2. On the contrary, it is apparent from the record
        that PW-2, being a manufacturer associated with M/S ADS Spirits
        Private Limited, was seeking to push his own brand by proposing to
        place his staff and manpower at the retail zones which the alleged
        “South Group” proposed to operate.

   528.                     A careful reading of the statements of PW-1 and PW-2
        also reveals that the arrangements spoken of by them, particularly with
        regard to placement of staff and operational control, were, if
        anything, contrary to the stated objectives of the DEP-21/22.
        Significantly, it was PW-20 who arranged the meeting at Gauri
        Apartment, and the material on record indicates that his proximity with
        PW-2 was far closer than with the accused persons who are alleged
        to have been present at the said meeting.

   529.                     At this juncture, a hypothetical reversal of roles exposes
        the inherent asymmetry in the prosecution’s approach. Had the South
        Group members been examined as witnesses, and PW-1, PW-2 and
        PW-20 been placed in the dock, and had the accused persons deposed
        to the facts now disclosed by these PWs, it would have been
        exceedingly difficult for PW-1, PW-2 and PW-20 to contend that they
        were not acting in concert, or that they were not seeking coordinated

assistance to facilitate their commercial objectives. The conduct
        attributed to them, discussions on zones, manpower, branding, staffing
        and operational support, would, in such a scenario, readily lend itself
        to an inference of concerted action.

   530.                     It also merits notice that these PWs, except PW-2,
        admittedly attended the subsequent meeting at ITC Kohinoor,
        Hyderabad, and travelled from Delhi for the said meeting. This
        continued engagement, movement, and participation at successive
        meetings underscores that the witnesses themselves were active
        participants in the commercial discussions, rather than passive
        bystanders or mere recipients of proposals.

   531.                     The act of seeking manpower or operational assistance
        for running retail zones, by itself, does not constitute an illegal act, nor
        is there any material to suggest that such arrangements were sought to
        be effected through illegal means. Quite paradoxically, the witnesses
        who speak of facts having a self-incriminating character are projected
        as prosecution witnesses, while the accused persons are sought to be
        implicated on the basis of such statements. When the meeting at Gauri
        Apartment is examined in isolation, the material placed on record, at
        best, reflects an attempt by certain individuals to explore participation
        in the Delhi excise business, a commercial activity which, per se, is
        lawful and permissible under the policy framework.

                                                             (emphasis supplied)

532.                     It is also of significance that the witnesses have
        categorically stated that A-11 (Butchi Babu) was enquiring about the
        financial contours of the Delhi liquor market. The precise extract, as
        appearing in the record, reads as under: “Sh Butchi Babu was mainly
        asking the questions about financial aspects of the business that how
        is the Delhi market , how we can make profits .”

   533.                     This aspect assumes considerable importance when
        juxtaposed with the prosecution’s own narrative. On the one hand, the
        record reflects that in May 2021, A-11 was making elementary
        enquiries regarding the Delhi market, its profitability, operational
        contours, and commercial viability. On the other hand, the
        investigating agency projects that as early as March 2021, a sum of
        ₹10 crores out of an alleged upfront demand of ₹100 crores had
        already been delivered by the approver Raghav Magunta (PW-226),
        purportedly at the instance of A-17, out of a total projected figure of
        ₹25 crores.

   534.                     If the prosecution version were to be accepted at face
        value, it would necessarily imply that the payment of “upfront
        money” had already been crystallised, agreed upon, and partially
        executed by March 2021. Yet, the contemporaneous conduct attributed
        to A-4, A-5 and A-11, who are themselves projected as conduits of
        A-17 (K. Kavitha), reveals that they were still grappling with
        foundational questions: how retail operations would be staffed, how
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
shops would be set up, and whether the Delhi market was even
        commercially viable.

                                                                 (emphasis supplied)

   535.                     This internal inconsistency strikes at the very root of the
        prosecution theory. Viewed cumulatively, the conversations and
        statements relied upon by the prosecution disclose, at best, exploratory
        commercial discussions surrounding a lawful business activity. They
        stand in clear contradiction to the theory of a pre-meditated and
        concluded criminal conspiracy, and the prosecution’s own material,
        therefore, undermines rather than advances the case sought to be
        projected.

   536.                     The statements of all three witnesses uniformly indicate
        that the conversations, as described by them, were confined to private
        commercial engagements among businessmen, relating to exploration
        of prospective participation in the retail segment under the DEP-21/22.
        None of these witnesses attributes any role to a Government
        functionary, nor do they speak of any discussion concerning policy
        formulation, file movement, official approvals, unlawful gratification
        or quid pro quo. Of particular relevance is the categorical statement of
        PW-1 Virat Maan, who has stated that “Vijay Nair and Ashok Pandey
        did not speak in that meeting but they were listening.” This assertion
        clearly indicates that neither Vijay Nair nor Arjun Pandey were active
        participants in any discussion, much less in any alleged conspiratorial

deliberation. Mere presence, without attribution of any incriminating
        act or role, cannot be elevated to an inference of conspiracy.

   537.                     Even if one were to assume, for the sake of argument,
        that the prosecution case is stretched to its fullest amplitude, there
        remains no material to indicate that any criminal design or conspiracy
        was ever discussed, conceived, or agreed upon in the manner alleged.
        The foundational element of a meeting of minds continues to remain
        absent from the record.

   538.                     Even otherwise, a significant evidentiary hurdle
        confronts the prosecution. When viewed in their proper legal
        perspective, the statements of PW-1 and PW-2 partake the character of
        accomplice-like statement. Their versions, by their very nature,
        require independent corroboration on material particulars before they
        can be relied upon. PW-20, having been tendered pardon and
        examined as an approver, stands on the same footing so far as the rule
        of corroboration is concerned. His statement, though admissible,
        cannot be acted upon without independent assurance.

   539.                     It has already been discussed in detail in the earlier
        paragraphs that one accomplice cannot corroborate another so as to
        lend credence to the approver’s version. Corroboration, in law, must
        emanate from an independent and reliable source, and not from a
        witness who is himself tainted by participation or interested
        involvement in the alleged transaction. Reliance is placed upon the

judgments of Hon’ble Supreme Court in K. Hashim (supra),
        Somasundaram (supra), Laxmipat Choraria (supra) and A.R. Antulay
        (supra).

   540.                     The prosecution seeks to draw support from three other
        witnesses who could, in theory, furnish independent corroboration.
        However, upon a careful reading of the statements of PW-41, PW-42
        and PW-43, it becomes evident that their statements do not advance
        the prosecution case in this regard. Their evidence, which shall now
        be examined below, does not supply the requisite independent
        corroboration on material particulars so as to strengthen the
        accomplice-like versions relied upon by the prosecution.

   541.                      The prosecution’s alternative narrative, that the genesis
        of the conspiracy lies in meetings at Gauri Apartment, rests on the
        statements of PW-41 (the cook posted at the Uttam Galva Steels guest
        house), PW-42 (the caretaker of the premises), and PW-43 (Shri Rajiv
        Singh, Additional Advocate General). On a careful and conjoint
        appreciation of their statements, the Court finds that the entire body of
        material relating to the stay of certain individuals at the said premises
        is routine, peripheral, and wholly unconnected with the formulation or
        implementation of the DEP-21/22. PW-41 and PW-42 merely depose
        to the fact that accommodation was provided at the premises. PW-41
        states that A-3 (Vijay Nair) stayed there for two to three days in March
        2020, while PW-42 deposes that one “known person of Shri Vibhav,”

later identified as Shri Durgesh Pathak, MLA, stayed there in May
        2021 for over a month. Crucially, neither witness speaks of having
        seen, heard, or participated in any discussion touching upon excise
        policy. They do not describe the presence of any excise official, public
        servant, manufacturer, wholesaler, or stakeholder connected with the
        policy regime, nor do they refer to any meeting or interaction of
        relevance to the alleged conspiracy. The statement of PW-43 does not
        advance the prosecution case any further. He merely states that he
        arranged accommodation at the request of Shri Vibhav Kumar, PS to
        the Chief Minister (“I was contacted telephonically…who requested
        to accommodate Shri Vijay Nair”), and that he later learnt from the
        caretaker that “the person who stayed… was Shri Durgesh Pathak,
        MLA… and he stayed there for more than a month.” His solitary
        assertion that Shri Pathak “was facilitating various meetings including
        meeting attended by accused Vijay Nair” is expressly based on what
        “was informed to me by the caretaker”, rendering the statement
        hearsay, devoid of personal knowledge, and incapable in law of
        sustaining any inference of conspiracy.

   542.                     Significantly, none of the witnesses, PW-41, PW-42 or
        PW-43, describes any meeting pertaining to the Excise Policy, any
        interaction          with   excise   officials,   any   communication        with
        manufacturers or wholesalers, or any conduct suggestive of quid pro
        quo. There is no evidence, either direct or circumstantial, of any

policy-related deliberation, decision-making, or unlawful agreement
        having taken place at the said premises. Viewed at its highest, the
        material on record establishes no more than that certain private
        individuals were temporarily accommodated at a corporate guest
        house on personal request. The evidence does not disclose any nexus,
        either direct or inferential, between such accommodation and the
        alleged corruption in the drafting or execution of the DEP-21/22. The
        prosecution’s attempt to treat the alleged meeting or stay at Gauri
        Apartments as the genesis of a criminal conspiracy is, therefore,
        unsupported by admissible evidence and rests on conjecture rather
        than admissible material.

        (b) Absence of Coercion by A-3 in PRI’s Appointment of Indospirits

   543.                     The allegation that A-3 employed coercion or force to
        compel Pernod Ricard India (PRI) to appoint M/S Indospirit as its
        distributor cannot be examined on the basis of generalised assertions
        or in the abstract. An allegation of this nature necessarily calls for a
        clear and specific inquiry into the manner in which such coercion is
        alleged to have been exercised. It must be shown, with some degree of
        precision, as to how any arm-twisting was undertaken, what position
        of dominance, administrative, regulatory, or otherwise, was allegedly
        wielded, and in what manner such position translated into compulsion
        upon M/S PRI.

544.                      In this context, the scrutiny of the charge must rest on
        the statements of the officials of M/S PRI who were directly associated
        with, or competent to speak on, the process of distributor selection and
        whose statements are relied upon by the prosecution. Unless these
        depositions disclose the existence of a position of dominance, the
        mode of its exercise, and a discernible nexus between the alleged
        pressure and the appointment of M/S Indospirit, the allegation cannot
        travel beyond the realm of conjecture. A contextual and complete
        reading         of       the   said   statements,   when   tested   against         the
        contemporaneous documentary record, is therefore essential to
        determine whether any element of coercion is made out or whether the
        appointment of M/S Indospirit was the result of an independent
        commercial decision taken in the ordinary course of business.

   545.                          At the threshold, PW-17 unequivocally clarifies the
        status of A-3 by stating that “he was neither any officer from the
        Excise Department nor was holding any official post”, a circumstance
        which substantially weakens any suggestion of enforceable authority
        or coercive capacity. The witness further records that when Vijay Nair
        (A-3) expressed a desire to meet M/S PRI’s internal decision-maker,
        “we decided not to meet him”, expressly because he held no official
        position, demonstrating that M/S PRI did not regard him as someone
        capable of directing or compelling corporate decisions. The substance
        of Vijay Nair’s communications, as deposed by PW-17, also falls short

of coercion. The Signal message dated 09.08.2021, “Plan you
        suggested may be complete no go. Everyone is against it. Zero trust
        basically”, is explained by the witness as an expression of disapproval
        regarding the proposed appointment of M/S BSPL as L-1, and not as
        any directive to appoint M/S Indospirits. Even during the subsequent
        meeting in Mumbai on 15.08.2021, PW-17 categorically states that
        Vijay Nair “did not suggest the name of any particular party to be
        appointed as L-1, but asked to appoint the L-1 quickly” . The absence
        of any naming or insistence upon M/S Indospirits is a significant
        omission which directly undermines the prosecution’s theory of a pre-
        ordained or forced selection.

   546.                     Equally telling is the fact that M/S PRI’s own conduct
        did not change in response to Vijay Nair’s stated views. PW-17
        expressly states that, despite Nair’s disagreement, “M/S Pernod
        Ricard India Private Limited decided to go ahead with its deal with
        M/S Brindco Sales Private Limited”. The eventual collapse of the M/S
        BSPL arrangement is attributed by the witness not to any pressure or
        intervention by Vijay Nair, but to Brindco’s own commercial refusal,
        as “on 24.08.2021, Sh. Amandeep Singh Dhall informed that he does
        not agree to the commercial terms offered”, followed by a
        confirmatory email dated 23.08.2021, which is D-18. This sequence,
        as narrated by PW-17, establishes that M/S PRI was prepared to persist
        with M/S BSPL notwithstanding Nair’s views, and that the shift away

from        Brindco       was   triggered   by    independent    commercial
        considerations.

   547.                     The allegation of coercion attributed to A-3 is further
        rendered untenable when examined in the light of the statutory
        framework governing wholesale distribution under the excise regime.
        Clause 3.1.1(v) of the DEP-21/22 expressly provides as follows:

                “...Any manufacturer that wishes to sell its products in Delhi
                will have to choose one of licensed L-1 distributor holding
                wholesale license for supply of Indian and foreign liquor and
                also holding bonded warehouse licenses in the form of L-31 as
                an exclusive distributor, for all its brands….”.
   548.                     A plain and literal reading of the aforesaid clause makes
        it abundantly clear that the policy mandates exclusivity at the
        wholesale level, permitting a manufacturer to operate through only one
        L-1 distributor for all its brands. Once a manufacturer has exercised
        such choice, the policy itself forecloses the possibility of parallel or
        multiple wholesale arrangements.

   549.                     In this backdrop, once another manufacturer, namely
        Diageo, had already chosen M/S BSPL as its L-1 distributor, the policy
        framework left no scope for M/S PRI to appoint M/S BSPL as its
        distributor as well. M/S PRI was, therefore, required, by operation of
        the policy itself, to identify and appoint an alternative L-1 distributor.
        This consequence flows directly from the policy mandate and not from
        any external pressure or intervention.

550.                     Viewed thus, the suggestion attributed to A-3, even if
        accepted at face value, cannot be characterised as coercive or
        extraneous. On the contrary, such a suggestion stands wholly aligned
        with, and is a logical corollary of, the exclusivity requirement
        embodied in Clause 3.1.1(v) of the applicable excise policy. The
        decision-making space of PRI was already circumscribed by the
        statutory policy framework, and the eventual necessity to explore a
        different distributor arose from policy compliance rather than from
        any alleged compulsion.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   551.                     Accordingly, the material on record demonstrates that
        the non-appointment of M/S BSPL by M/S PRI was dictated by the
        operative clauses of the DEP-21/22 itself. Any suggestion or opinion
        expressed by A-3 in this regard merely mirrored the policy position
        and does not, either in law or on facts, disclose any element of
        coercion, pressure, or undue influence.

   552.                     When M/S Indospirits was thereafter considered, PW-17
        makes it explicit that it was not M/S PRI’s first choice. He states that,
        despite a long association, Sameer Mahendru “always had a liquidity
        issue… therefore he was not our first choice”. M/S Indospirits was
        taken up only as a “next best option” after M/S BSPL declined, and
        even then, only upon stringent financial safeguards. PW-17 records
        that M/S PRI insisted that M/S Indospirits “must provide… a bank

guarantee of 100 crores”, and when this was delayed, accepted
        substantial personal sureties running into hundreds of crores. The
        detailed description of the meeting dated 20.09.2021 at Hotel Taj
        Mahal, clarified again in the statement dated 10.05.2024, shows that
        the purpose was “to show his financial ability”, and that the investors
        “confirmed… that they are backing M/S Indospirits for its wholesale
        liquor business in Delhi”. The organisation, booking, and payment of
        this meeting by M/S PRI itself further reinforce that the decision-
        making process was internally driven and commercially evaluated.

   553.                     In this evidentiary backdrop, PW-17’s statement does
        not disclose any act of coercion, compulsion, or dictated outcome
        attributable to A-3. At its highest, the evidence shows that A-3
        expressed opposition to M/S BSPL and urged the expeditious
        appointment of an alternative wholesaler, without naming M/S
        Indospirits, without possessing any official authority, and without
        altering M/S PRI’s initial commercial course. The eventual
        appointment of M/S Indospirits, as per the witness, flowed from M/S
        BSPL withdrawal and from M/S PRI’s own assessment of liquidity
        backing and risk mitigation, not from any pressure exerted by A-3.

   554.                     On a cumulative and contextual reading of the statement
        of PW-17 (Benoy Babu), working as General Manager, M/S Pernod
        Ricard India Pvt. Ltd., recorded on 01.09.2022, 02.11.2022 and
        10.05.2024, the prosecution’s allegation that A-3, coerced or forced
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
M/S PRI to appoint M/S Indospirits as its L-1 wholesaler does not find
        evidentiary support. Consequently, the allegation that A-3 forced PRI
        to appoint M/S Indospirits as part of a larger conspiracy is not borne
        out from the statement of PW-17 relied upon the prosecution.

        (c) Corporate Guarantees furnished by Pernod Ricard India

   555.                     On a cumulative and contextual appreciation of the
        statement of PW-17 (Benoy Babu), particularly his detailed statement
        dated 02.11.2022 read with his statements dated 01.09.2022 and
        10.05.2024, the prosecution’s allegation that A-3 coerced M/S PRI to
        extend corporate guarantees to retail entities so as to confer an undue
        benefit upon Sameer Mahendru (A-7) or the so-called “South
        Group” as part of a larger conspiracy does not find support from the
        statements on record. At the threshold, PW-17 traces the genesis of the
        proposal for corporate guarantees not to any political pressure or extra-
        corporate influence, but to a commercial request initiated by private
        parties themselves, stating that in the last week of May 2021 “Sh.
        Sameer Mahendru (Indospirit), Sh. C. Suri, Sh. Ashok T. Guljarani…
        Sh. Sanjay Jain and Sh. Ajay Malhotra… approached me for financial
        assistance.” He clarifies that upon such approach, he consulted his
        internal superiors, Manoj Rai and Vimal Khanna, and that “based on
        their inputs, a business proposal was prepared by all of us and sent on
        mail,” thereby placing the entire exercise squarely within M/S PRI’s
        internal commercial decision-making framework.

556.                     PW-17 further explains that the structure of any financial
        assistance was dictated by the constraints of the DEP-21/22 itself,
        noting that “we had limited options for extending the financial
        assistance since Delhi Excise Policy does not allow the manufacturer
        to participate in retail space.” The evaluation of permissible financial
        mechanisms thereafter proceeded through formal banking channels,
        with the bank outlining available options, “Corporate Guarantee…
        Standby letter of credit… Term Deposit”, and the ultimate decision
        being taken, as PW-17 expressly records, at the higher management
        level, “with the approval of Sh. Rajesh Mishra.” He is categorical that
        the matter was thereafter “being handled by Sh. Vimal Khanna” and
        that he himself “was not party to these deliberations,” underscoring
        that the decision to extend corporate guarantees was a corporate act
        taken by PRI’s senior management after weighing policy compliance,
        commercial risk and banking advice.

   557.                     Equally significant is what PW-17 does not attribute to
        A-3. Nowhere in his statement does PW-17 state that Vijay Nair (A-3)
        suggested, demanded, directed, or even discussed the extension of
        corporate guarantees. On the contrary, when referring to Vijay Nair
        (A-3) elsewhere, PW-17 consistently emphasises that Nair “was
        neither any officer from Excise Department nor was holding any
        official post,” and that M/S PRI consciously declined to treat him as a
        decision-maker, recording that “we decided not to meet him” when he

sought access to internal decision-makers. The subject-matter of
        Nair’s communications, as narrated by PW-17, remained confined to
        expressions of opinion on distributor preference and policy rollout
        timelines; even in that context, PW-17 records that M/S PRI “decided
        to go ahead with its deal with M/S Brindco Sales Pvt. Ltd.” despite
        Nair’s stated disagreement, demonstrating that Nair’s views were
        neither binding nor determinative. The subsequent execution of
        corporate guarantees further negates any theory of targeted or
        conspiratorial benefit. PW-17 describes the process as one involving
        multiple, unrelated retail aspirants, not a single favoured entity, and
        explains that guarantees were extended only after bank scrutiny, board
        authorisation and formal documentation. The guarantees were not
        informal or concealed acts, but part of a transparent banking
        arrangement culminating in loan disbursements for EMD in favour of
        the Excise Commissioner, Delhi.

   558.                     This position is independently corroborated by the
        statements of PW-30 (Shri Priyank Kuchhal) and PW-31 (Shri Ashish
        Misra), both senior officers of HSBC Bank. Their evidence is purely
        ministerial and confined to production and explanation of certified
        banking records. Neither witness discloses any fact suggesting that the
        execution of corporate guarantees, the sanction of loan facilities, or the
        utilisation and repayment of funds bore any nexus with the
        formulation, modification or implementation of the DEP-21/22, or

with the conduct of any public servant. PW-30 categorically states that
        the credit facilities were sanctioned “for funding of EMD for bidding
        with Excise Department, GNCTD,” and PW-31 confirms that the
        funds were utilised through demand drafts issued in favour of the
        Excise Commissioner, ordinary commercial banking transactions
        undertaken to meet statutory tender requirements. Neither witness
        refers to any communication, direction or involvement of A-3 or any
        public authority. Significantly, no official of M/S PRI has been
        arraigned as an accused, and none of the company’s officers examined
        has alleged any pressure, coercion or inducement by A-3 or by any
        public functionary. In this evidentiary backdrop, the material on record
        establishes that the corporate guarantees were the outcome of
        commercial requests, internal corporate evaluation, policy-driven
        constraints, banking advice and senior-management approval, and not
        the product of any coercion, inducement or conspiratorial design. At
        its highest, the evidence discloses an internal corporate decision taken
        in the ordinary course of business to facilitate participation in the retail
        tender process; it does not disclose any act by A-3 compelling M/S
        PRI to extend such guarantees, nor any material suggesting that the
        guarantees were a vehicle to unlawfully benefit Sameer Mahendru
        (A-7) or any alleged “South Group” participant as part of a larger
        conspiracy.

(d) Allegation of Demand of Bribe by A-3 for Incorporation of
        Favourable Clauses in DEP-21/22

   559.                     The allegation levelled against A-3, is that, during
        interactions with industry stakeholders, he demanded illegal
        gratification for the inclusion of favourable clauses in the DEP-21/22.
        A careful, contextual and holistic scrutiny of the evidence on record,
        however, renders this allegation wholly unsustainable. A plain reading
        of the statement of PW-104, Vinod Giri, Director General of the
        Confederation of Indian Alcoholic Beverage Companies (hereinafter
        referred to as “CIABC”) establishes that his evidence is strictly
        confined to his role as an industry representative participating in an
        open, structured and consultative policy-making process. His
        statement does not disclose, even remotely, any circumstance
        suggestive of corruption, quid pro quo or undue influence in the
        formulation or implementation of the DEP-21/22. On the contrary,
        PW-104 categorically affirms that CIABC addressed multiple written
        representations to the Excise Department, the Lieutenant Governor,
        the Chief Minister and the Deputy Chief Minister, raising policy-level
        concerns regarding wholesale margins, cost reimbursement, parity
        between domestic and imported products, zoning structure,
        cartelisation risks and ease of doing business. These representations
        were routed through formal institutional channels, duly documented
        and placed in the public domain, and were plainly in the nature of

stakeholder feedback rather than any covert or extra-institutional
        intervention.

   560.                     Significantly, PW-104’s evidence brings out that CIABC
        consistently cautioned the Government against the risk of monopolies
        and cartelisation arising from the proposed zoning structure,
        particularly where a single entity could be allotted a large cluster of
        vends within one zone. His statement reflects that CIABC’s
        engagement was directed towards seeking safeguards against
        monopolistic practices, over-charging, brand pushing and coercive
        conduct vis-à-vis suppliers, and towards urging corrective measures
        wherever necessary. These concerns were reiterated even after the
        GoM’ recommendations were placed in the public domain, thereby
        negating any suggestion that the industry was seeking to preserve a
        “status quo” or to secure policy concessions through improper
        means.

   561.                  As regards the meeting with A-3 in the first week of April
        2021 at the Oberoi Hotel, Gurugram, PW-104’s statement is clear and
        unequivocal. He states that the meeting was arranged through
        Amandeep Singh Dhall (A-9) and that A-3 introduced himself as being
        associated with the Aam Aadmi Party and as advising the Delhi
        Government on excise policy matters. The discussion, as narrated,
        remained confined to policy concerns already articulated by CIABC
        in its written representations, particularly the apprehension that large

retail zones could facilitate cartelisation and monopolistic behaviour.
        Crucially, PW-104 does not attribute to A-3 any demand for money,
        gratification, donation or benefit of any nature, nor does he suggest
        that any such demand was even obliquely made. On the contrary,
        PW-104 records that while A-3 explained the policy rationale for
        larger zones, namely, ensuring the financial capacity and stability of
        bidders, PW-104 maintained a differing viewpoint and reiterated the
        need for adequate safeguards against monopolisation. Any assurance
        attributed to A-3 was limited to taking measures to prevent
        cartelisation, and any request made by him was confined to seeking
        industry support for the proposed policy framework. There is a
        complete absence of any allegation that such support was sought or
        offered in exchange for money, or that any “status quo” was to be
        maintained through financial consideration.

   562.                     Equally material is PW-104’s categorical statement that,
        following the said meeting, neither A-3 nor any person acting on his
        behalf contacted him again. He further asserts, without ambiguity, that
        CIABC did not make any donation or payment to the Aam Aadmi
        Party or to any individual for securing favourable provisions in the
        Delhi Excise Policy. This aspect of his statement directly contradicts
        and undermines the prosecution narrative sought to be constructed on
        the basis of the alleged handwritten notepad attributed to I.P. Suresh
        Menon (PW-101) and put to PW-103, suggesting that CIABC paid

money to maintain a “status quo”. No such assertion finds any support
        in the statement of PW-104, who was the principal functionary of
        CIABC and the person directly involved in all policy-related
        interactions.

   563.                     When PW-104’s statement is read alongside that of
        PW-101, Secretary General of the International Spirits and Wines
        Association of India, and PW-110, the broader policy context becomes
        unmistakable. The record demonstrates that the pre-existing excise
        regimes, though revenue-generating, were afflicted by structural
        loopholes and systemic inefficiencies, shortcomings expressly
        identified in the Expert Committee Report chaired by Shri Ravi
        Dhawan and echoed in the recommendations of the GoM. These
        deficiencies have not been seriously disputed even by the prosecution,
        whose objections remain confined to selected clauses alleged to
        facilitate cartelisation or monopoly. Beyond this limited challenge, the
        necessity for reform of the earlier framework stands largely
        uncontroverted. The evidence further reveals that revenue accretion
        under the earlier policies had reached a stage of stagnation, with
        increases being driven largely by incremental duty hikes, intensified
        enforcement and periodic price adjustments, rather than by organic
        growth or structural efficiency in the alcobev sector. As reflected in
        PW-101’s statement, the policy framework had exhausted its capacity
        for further meaningful growth in the absence of comprehensive re-

design. This stagnation, coupled with policy liberalisation in
        neighbouring States and the resultant cross-border diversion of
        consumer demand, rendered maintenance of the status quo neither
        economically viable nor administratively sustainable. Within this
        setting, the statements establish that any genuine reform necessarily
        had to address the architecture of the supply chain, particularly at the
        wholesale and retail levels.

   564.                     PW-101’s evidence indicates that while manufacturers
        broadly supported retail privatisation to address consumer-facing
        inefficiencies, superficial or piecemeal interventions would not have
        sufficed. Absent restructuring at the wholesale level, reforms confined
        to retail alone could not have achieved the stated objectives of market
        efficiency, consumer retention or revenue optimisation. The
        restructuring of the wholesaler, retailer framework thus emerges as an
        intrinsic component of systemic correction, not as a targeted favour to
        any individual or entity. It is also relevant that several prosecution
        witnesses are themselves stakeholders within the alcobev industry, and
        their statements naturally reflect commercial perspectives. Yet, when
        read cumulatively, these statements converge on a consistent theme:
        that the DEP-21/22 was shaped by market realities and structural
        policy considerations, and not by any corrupt design or improper
        inducement. Finally, when PW-101’s statement is assessed together
        with the categorical evidence of PW-91, the alleged role attributed to

A-3 is further diluted. PW-91 unequivocally places A-3 as a party
        volunteer, holding no formal post, statutory authority or role in
        governmental decision-making or policy formulation. The record
        discloses no material from which it could be inferred that he exercised
        any determinative, advisory or influential role in the formulation or
        implementation of the DEP-21/22.

   565.                     Moreover, PW-101 has, in his statement, categorically
        stated that the recommendations of the Ravi Dhawan Committee were,
        in principle, acceptable to ISWAI. He has further deposed that, apart
        from the recommendations contained in the said report, ISWAI had
        also forwarded certain additional suggestions which do not find
        mention in the Ravi Dhawan Report. One such suggestion, as
        specifically highlighted by PW-101, was that there should be no price
        comparison with other States and that manufacturers ought to be
        permitted to fix the Maximum Retail Price (MRP) of their products.

   566.                     The   very   nature   of   the   aforesaid      suggestion
        unmistakably demonstrates that ISWAI, representing the interests of
        manufacturers, was seeking policy outcomes beneficial to its
        constituents under the proposed excise regime. PW-101 has further
        stated that neither the additional suggestions made by ISWAI nor the
        recommendations of the Ravi Dhawan Committee were ultimately
        accepted. It is well settled that the commercial interests of
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
manufacturers cannot, either in law or in principle, be equated with the
        interests of the Government or those of the consumer.

   567.                     The statement of PW-101 further reveals that the earlier
        excise policy was, admittedly, favourable to manufacturers, which
        explains their consistent effort to maintain the status quo, as it placed
        them in a dominant and advantageous position enabling effective
        control over the distribution and sale of liquor. Their evident
        dissatisfaction with the DEP-21/22 clearly suggests that their position
        stood diluted by the introduction of private wholesalers, a structural
        reform which was not acceptable to them.

   568.                     It is significant that the investigating agency has, from
        the very inception of the case, maintained that A-8, A-3 and A-18 were
        in favour of the DEP-21/22, particularly the introduction of private
        wholesalers and retailers. Viewed in this backdrop, the reliance placed
        by the prosecution on the statement of PW-101 materially undermines
        the very hypothesis sought to be advanced by the investigating agency,
        namely, that the aforesaid accused persons were opposed to the
        recommendations of the Ravi Dhawan Report and sought to introduce
        policy changes to favour the so-called “South Group”.

   569.                     PW-101 has further stated that A-3 expressed that
        ISWAI may also project favourable media coverage on visual media
        (television), after PW-101 conveyed that ISWAI was supporting the
        Ravi Dhawan Report in print media. In his words: “I also said that

ISWAI could only support the recommendation of the Ravi Dhawan
        Committee through favourable media stories, which we had already
        been doing in print media. On this, Shri Vijay Nair said that he wanted
        favourable media stories on visual media too.” This statement, read in
        its proper context, does not disclose any demand for illegal
        gratification, but merely reflects a request for public articulation and
        media support.

   570.                     If A-3 was, as stated by PW-101, supporting the Ravi
        Dhawan Report, it necessarily follows that he was acting contrary to
        the alleged conspiracy, since the recommendations of the said report
        were not in favour of private wholesalers, which, according to the
        prosecution itself, constitutes the foundational premise for the alleged
        payment of “upfront money”.

                                                            (emphasis supplied)

   571.                     This aspect assumes further significance when read
        alongside PW-101’s own statement that ISWAI was, in fact, desirous
        of a Government-controlled wholesaler. The prosecution case, from its
        inception, proceeds on the assertion that the collection of “upfront
        money” was premised upon, and incentivised by, the privatisation of
        the wholesale segment. The admitted preference of ISWAI for a
        Government wholesaler stands in direct contradiction to this premise.
        Consequently, the prosecution’s attempt to introduce an indirect

demand in the form of “some offer” rests on fundamentally flawed
        assumptions and collapses under its own weight.

                                                             (emphasis supplied)

   572.                     Thus, even on a prima facie evaluation, acceptance of
        the prosecution’s interpretation of the expression “some offer” would
        introduce an internal inconsistency in the prosecution narrative,
        thereby eroding the very foundation concerning the alleged motive,
        object and beneficiaries of the purported conspiracy. The use of the
        expression “offer”, in the context in which it appears, can only be read
        as relating to media support and public articulation, and not to any
        under-hand payment; otherwise, the prosecution case would stand
        vitiated at its very foundation and lose all legal significance.

   573.                     Viewed in its entirety, the evidence of PW-104, read
        conjointly with PW-101 and PW-91, affirmatively establishes that
        industry engagement with the policy process occurred through
        transparent, documented representations and limited stakeholder
        interaction, and that even in the solitary meeting with A-3 there was
        neither a demand nor an offer of any illegal gratification. The
        allegation that A-3 demanded a bribe for incorporation of favourable
        clauses is thus not merely unsubstantiated, but stands squarely
        contradicted by the prosecution’s own evidence, warranting its
        complete rejection at this stage.

Outcome of Evaluation

   574.                     The prosecution attributes a central and pivotal role to
        A-3. He is portrayed as the representative or conduit of A-8, allegedly
        present at various meetings with other accused persons and, by virtue
        of such presence, in a position to influence proceedings or exert
        pressure. According to the prosecution, he figures at every stage of the
        alleged conspiracy, whether in the formulation of the policy, its
        implementation, coordination concerning the alleged upfront amount,
        the purported recoupment thereof, or the indirect coordination of funds
        said to have been channelled to Goa for electoral utilisation.

   575.                     On the prosecution’s own case, his role is described as
        both direct and indirect. It is termed direct in the sense that he is stated
        to have attended meetings and coordinated between parties. At the
        same time, it is indirect because he is not alleged to have personally
        paid any bribe to A-2, nor to have directly received any upfront
        amount. It is not alleged that he derived any identifiable pecuniary
        benefit. His company is not shown to have held any wholesale or retail
        licence under the impugned policy. There is no material to indicate that
        he was a beneficiary of the policy framework in any tangible manner.

   576.                     In these circumstances, it was incumbent upon the
        prosecution to place prima facie foundational facts demonstrating how
        and in what manner A-3 occupied a central position in the alleged
        conspiracy. Mere presence at meetings, even if assumed, does not by

itself establish participation in a criminal design unless supported by
        material reflecting agreement, intention, or overt acts in furtherance
        thereof.

   577.                     In cases of conspiracy, the prosecution may rely upon
        circumstantial           evidence   and   connecting   links   which,       taken
        cumulatively, may indicate a meeting of minds. A certain latitude is
        therefore available at the stage of charge. However, that latitude cannot
        extend to replacing material with conjecture. Where the surrounding
        circumstances clearly reflect coordinated action towards an unlawful
        object, the prosecution’s task is simplified. In the present case,
        however, the foundational premises themselves remain unsupported
        by admissible material.

   578.                     There is no admissible material to show that the
        formulation of the policy was the result of a conspiracy. There is no
        admissible material establishing payment of any bribe. There is no
        material to indicate that wholesale licences were granted in violation
        of the policy framework. In the absence of these cumulative elements,
        the role attributed to A-3 remains unsupported by objective evidence
        and rests on inference.

   579.                     More significantly, the attribution of role to A-3 rests
        substantially on the statement of the approver. It is settled law that a
        charge cannot be founded solely on the uncorroborated statement of
        an approver. At the very least, there must be prima facie corroboration

in material particulars connecting the accused with the alleged offence.
        In the absence of such corroborative material, the prosecution case,
        insofar as it concerns A-3, does not meet the threshold required for
        framing of charge.

        Allegations against A-7

   580.                     The prosecution alleges that A-7, Sameer Mahendru
        (M/S Indospirits), acted as a private beneficiary and facilitator within
        the larger conspiracy relating to the formulation and implementation
        of the DEP-21/22. It is alleged that, pursuant to pre-arranged
        understandings with other private accused and public servants, A-7
        was positioned to secure undue commercial advantage through the
        grant of L-1 wholesale licence in favour of M/S Indospirits. According
        to the prosecution, M/S Indospirits was enabled to emerge as a
        favoured wholesaler for certain manufacturers, particularly PRI,
        allegedly through manipulated processing of licence applications,
        suppression of adverse material, and expedited approvals. It is further
        alleged that A-7 was aware of, and a willing participant in, the broader
        conspiracy involving policy clauses such as wholesaler margins and
        exclusive distribution arrangements, and that the benefits accruing to
        Indospirits were not the result of ordinary commercial selection but
        flowed from a concerted design among the conspirators. The
        prosecution thus projects A-7 as a key private link through whom the

alleged policy manipulation translated into concrete commercial
        gain.

        Analysis

        (I) Alleged Wholesaler–Retail Cartel, Funding of EMD, and the
        Mahandru/Indospirit Control Theory

   581.                     The prosecution alleges that the so-called Indospirit
        group, purportedly headed by A-7, sought to exercise impermissible
        control over retail zones by funding EMDs, holding ownership
        interests, and thereby creating a wholesaler, retail cartel in violation of
        the object and scheme of the DEP-21/22. This allegation is sought to
        be built primarily around M/S KGRL, M/S Bubbly Beverages Pvt.
        Ltd., and M/S Indospirit Retail Pvt. Ltd., by attributing to them a
        common thread of Mahandru/Indospirit control.

        Evidentiary Assessment

   582.                     The prosuection has relied on the statements of PW-27,
        Shri Arun Kumar Singh (Assistant Registrar of Companies), PW-28,
        Smt. Vimal Khanna (General Manager, Strategic Planning, Pernod
        Ricard India Pvt. Ltd.), and the certified banking records proved
        through PW-34, Ms. Mohini Rane (Deputy Branch Manager, ICICI
        Bank), to establish that the three entities formed part of, or were
        controlled by, the alleged Indospirit/Mahandru group in relation to the
        DEP-21/22.

Alleged that M/S KGRL was controlled by A-7

        (i) The funding for EMD and application fee

   583.                     The NEP-20/21 was framed with the clear objective of
        dismantling monopolistic structures, preventing cartelisation, and
        introducing a competitive and transparent market regime. To give
        effect to this objective, the policy itself incorporated specific
        safeguards, including the concept of “related entities”, as expressly
        defined in the relevant clause. The policy thus consciously set out the
        precise circumstances in which common ownership or control would
        attract disqualification, while equally demarcating what conduct
        would remain permissible.

   584.                     The prosecution seeks to build an allegation on the
        footing that the EMD and application fee for retail zone bidding by
        M/S KGRL were funded through amounts transferred from M/S
        Indospirit Marketing Pvt. Ltd., whereafter the EMD and application
        fee were prepared from the account of the bidding entity. This
        allegation does not withstand scrutiny on a plain reading of the policy.
        There is no clause in the DEP-21/22 which mandates that the EMD
        must be sourced exclusively from the bidder’s own independent funds,
        nor is there any prohibition against financial assistance or fund
        transfers from another entity for the purpose of depositing EMD or
        application fee, provided the bidder satisfies the eligibility conditions
        and does not violate the expressly defined “related entity” restrictions.

This position stands reflected in the contemporaneous departmental
        record, including the noting of the Accounts Branch {D-147 (94/N)},
        and is corroborated by the statement of PW-270, Shri Pankaj
        Bhatnagar, then Assistant Commissioner, who clarified that the policy
        did not impose any source-based restriction on the EMD.

   585.                     The central issue, therefore, is whether an act which is
        not prohibited by the policy, and which conforms to its express
        conditions, can nonetheless be treated as culpable merely by invoking
        the object of the policy. Such an approach is legally untenable. Penal
        consequences cannot be imposed on the basis of assumptions as to
        what the policy ought to have provided. Criminal liability must rest on
        the breach of a clearly defined prohibition, not on an inferred or
        postulated restriction.

   586.                     What the prosecution’s case effectively seeks to do is to
        read into the policy a condition which does not exist, and then to treat
        compliance with the actual text of the policy as suspicious. This
        exercise is impermissible. The regulatory framework derives its
        authority and certainty from its written terms. If the rule-making
        authority considered it necessary to restrict the source of EMD, it was
        open to it to do so by express provision. In the absence of such a
        stipulation, an entity acting within the framework of the policy cannot
        be faulted for taking advantage of what the policy itself permits.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

587.                     It is a settled principle that lawful conduct does not
        become criminal merely because it results in a commercial benefit or
        because, in hindsight, a different regulatory design might have been
        preferable. Acting within the four corners of the governing rules does
        not amount to an illegal act, nor does it satisfy the ingredients of
        conspiracy, which require an agreement to commit an offence or to
        achieve a lawful object by unlawful means.

   588.                     In these circumstances, the prosecution’s attempt to
        characterise the funding of the EMD and application fee through inter-
        entity transfers as evidence of indirect control, cartelisation, or
        conspiracy is devoid of legal foundation. In the absence of any
        violation of the express provisions of the DEP-21/22, the allegation
        rests on conjecture rather than law and is liable to be rejected at the
        threshold.

        (ii) Geetika Mahendru was the director of Geetech Dynamic Systems Pvt.
        Ltd. which was the holding company of M/S KGRL

   589.                     At the threshold, the prosecution seeks to draw an
        inference of control and cartelisation on the premise that the wife of
        A-7 was a director of M/S Geetech Dynamic Systems Pvt. Ltd. till
        30.03.2021 and that the said company subsequently became the
        holding company of M/S KGRL. This allegation, when tested against
        the statutory record and the statement of PW-27, does not withstand
        scrutiny.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
590.                     The statement of PW-27, Sh. Arun Kumar Singh,
        Assistant Registrar of Companies, is of central relevance. From his
        deposition, the corporate existence and structure of M/S KGRL stand
        clearly established on the basis of ROC records. PW-27 states that “the
        company namely M/S Khao Gali Restaurants Pvt. Ltd. was
        incorporated on 08.08.1994” and was registered at “B-115, 2nd Floor,
        DDA Shed, Okhla Phase-I, New Delhi.” At incorporation, “500 shares
        were subscribed by Shri Shyam Kapur s/o Kundanlal Kapur, 500 by
        Geetam Kapur w/o Shri Shyam Kapur and 500 shares were with Tarun
        Kalra,” and “all these 03 shareholders were also the Directors of the
        company at the time of incorporation and continued as such till
        30.03.2021 when Ms. Geetam Kapur ceased to be the Director of the
        company.”

   591.                     PW-27 further explains the later shareholding position
        by recording that “as per annual return for the FY 2020-21, the total
        shares towards subscribed capital are 10,000,” out of which “99% of
        share holding (9,900 shares) of Khao Gali Restaurants Pvt. Ltd. is
        owned by M/S Geetech Dynamic Systems Pvt. Ltd., while remaining
        1% (100 shares) is being held by Shri Shyam Kundan Lal Kapur.” He
        clarifies that this restructuring occurred because “during the year
        2020-21, 4,500 shares held by Ms. Geetam Kapur, 4,400 shares held
        by Shri Shyam Kundan Lal Kapur and 1,000 shares held by Shri Tarun
        Kalra were transferred to M/S Geetech Dynamic Systems Pvt. Ltd.”

592.                     The financial position of M/S KGRL is also placed on
        record by PW-27. He states that “as per Financial Statement for the
        FY-2020-2021, the company incurred a loss of Rs. 19,867/-,” and that
        only “Rs. 4,600/- was taken as loan from M/S Indospirit Distribution
        Ltd.” For the earlier year, he records that “Rs. 10,440/- & Rs. 2,400/-
        were taken as loan from M/S Indospirit Distribution Ltd. & M/S
        Indospirit Marketing Private Limited,” with similar losses and
        marginal borrowings reflected for FY-2019-20 and FY-2018-19. These
        figures, by their very magnitude, demonstrate that the company was a
        loss-making entity and that the borrowings were nominal and
        insignificant.

   593.                     PW-27 also establishes the corporate profile of M/S
        Geetech Dynamic Systems Pvt. Ltd., stating that it “was incorporated
        on 06.02.1998 at the address D-98, Anand Niketan, 3rd Floor,
        Delhi-110020.” At incorporation, “500 shares were subscribed by Shri
        Shyam Kapur s/o Kundanlal Kapur and 500 by Geetam Kapur w/o
        Shri Shyam Kapur,” and “both these shareholders were also the
        Directors of the company at the time of incorporation.” He traces the
        subsequent changes in directorship and records that “as per annual
        return for the FY 2020-21, the total shares towards subscribed capital
        are 10,000, out of which 90% of share holding (9,000 shares) of the
        company are held by Shri Shyam Kundan Lal Kapur while the
        remaining 1,000 shares are with Tushar Kapur,” further noting that

“during the year 2020-21, 2,000 shares held by Ms. Geetam Kapur
        were transferred to Shri Shyam Kundan Lal Kapur.” PW-27 also notes
        that “Rs. 99,000/- was invested in M/S Khao Gali Restaurants Private
        Limited,” thereby explaining the shareholding link between the two
        companies.

   594.                     What clearly emerges from this material is that M/S
        KGRL became a subsidiary of M/S Geetech Dynamic Systems Pvt.
        Ltd. on the basis of share transfers duly reflected in ROC records.
        Equally significant is what does not emerge: PW-27 does not state
        anywhere that A-7 or his wife ever held any shareholding, directorship,
        or managerial position in M/S KGRL. The only reference to Indospirit
        entities is confined to nominal unsecured loans of Rs. 4,600/-, Rs.
        10,440/- and Rs. 2,400/-. Such trivial amounts, on their face, cannot
        establish ownership, control, dominance, or any group integration, and
        are wholly insufficient to support an allegation of cartelisation or
        conspiratorial control.

   595.                     In law, a director of a holding company who holds no
        shares therein, and who has no shareholding or directorial position in
        the subsidiary, cannot be attributed control over the subsidiary merely
        by virtue of such office. Control flows from legally enforceable rights
        in shareholding or from statutory or contractual powers recognised by
        law, not from a managerial designation in another juristic entity. The
        subsidiary remains a distinct corporate person; its voting rights,

management and affairs vest exclusively in its shareholders and duly
        appointed directors. In the absence of any proprietary interest,
        contractual authority or statutory mandate linking A-7 or his wife to
        M/S KGRL, the prosecution’s attempt to infer control, ownership or
        cartelisation is founded on conjecture rather than evidence. At the
        stage of charge, such an allegation, unsupported by any legally
        cognisable indicia of control, stands dismantled at the threshold.

        (iii) Bubbly Beverages Pvt. Ltd. and the Allegation of Cross-Funding /
        Control by A-7 to M/S Magunta Agro Farms Pvt. Ltd.

   596.                     What emerges from the record is that M/S Bubbly
        Beverages Pvt. Ltd. transferred an amount of ₹25 crores to M/S
        Magunta Agro Farms Pvt. Ltd., which the prosecution seeks to
        characterise as “cross-funding” of EMD for obtaining an L-7Z licence.
        It is, however, an admitted position that approver Raghav Magunta
        Reddy (PW-225) was not a named partner in M/S Indospirit, the L-1
        wholesaler licence holder. The further attempt to attribute this
        transaction to A-7 on the premise that he was controlling M/S Bubbly
        Beverages Pvt. Ltd., and that such alleged control was exercised to
        influence or dominate retail zoning through EMD funding, finds no
        support from the record.

   597.                     From the statement of PW-27, Sh. Arun Kumar Singh,
        Assistant Registrar of Companies, and the statutory ROC records
        proved through him, the corporate position of both M/S Indospirit

Retail Pvt. Ltd. and M/S Bubbly Beverages Pvt. Ltd. stands clearly
        established. PW-27 records that M/S Indospirit Retail Pvt. Ltd. was
        incorporated on 21.11.2012 with a subscribed capital of 10,000 equity
        shares, initially held by M/S Indospirit Distribution Ltd. through
        Sameer Mahandru (9,000 shares) and Sudershan Lal Mahandru (1,000
        shares), both of whom were directors. PW-27 further records that by
        31.03.2021, the entire shareholding stood transferred to Nitin Kapoor
        (9,000 shares) and Soni Singh (1,000 shares), and that Sameer
        Mahandru resigned from the directorship on 30.03.2021 and
        Sudershan Lal Mahandru on 10.07.2021. Thus, with effect from
        31.03.2021, M/S Indospirit Retail Pvt. Ltd. stood wholly owned and
        controlled by Nitin Kapoor and Soni Singh, with no subsisting
        shareholding or managerial role of A-7.

   598.                     As regards M/S Bubbly Beverages Pvt. Ltd., PW-27’s
        statement and the ROC filings show that Ms. Geetika Mahandru never
        held any position of director, shareholder, or manager at any stage.
        PW-27 attributes to her no shareholding or managerial role
        whatsoever. The involvement of A-7 in Bubbly Beverages was
        confined to a minority shareholding of 10% up to 31.03.2020. PW-27
        further records that in March 2021, the shares held by A-7 were
        entirely transferred, resulting in him holding zero shares with effect
        from 31.03.2021. Thereafter, 99% of the shareholding of Bubbly
        Beverages stood with M/S Indospirit Retail Pvt. Ltd. and 1% with

Nitin Kapoor, followed by the resignation of A-7 from the directorship
        on 20.07.2021. The board thereafter comprised Nitin Kapoor and Soni
        Singh. Thus, during and after the relevant period, neither A-7 nor his
        wife exercised any ownership or managerial control over Bubbly
        Beverages.

   599.                     In this background, the prosecution’s theory that A-7
        controlled M/S Bubbly Beverages Pvt. Ltd. and, through it, sought to
        control retail zoning by alleged EMD cross-funding is not borne out
        from the statutory record. Even otherwise, as already discussed, the
        Excise Policy does not prohibit funding of EMD by one entity for
        another. Mere funding or financial assistance, in the absence of any
        change in shareholding or directorship, does not result in transfer of
        control. Inter-corporate loans and monetary assistance are well-
        recognised commercial arrangements in corporate law and, by
        themselves, cannot be treated as devices to create cartelisation or
        confer control.

                                                             (emphasis supplied)

   600.                     On a cumulative assessment, the record does not
        disclose any material to show that the ₹25-crore transaction resulted
        in, or was intended to result in, ownership, control, or dominance of
        retail zones by A-7. The allegation rests on assumption rather than
        admissible material and stands contradicted by the ROC material and
        the statement of PW-27.

(iv) Allegation of Cross-Funding of EMD by Zenab Pvt. Ltd. (Magunta
        Group) to M/S KGRL

   601.                     The prosecution has alleged that a sum of ₹25 crores
        was transferred by M/S Zenab Pvt. Ltd., a company stated to be
        associated with the Magunta group, to M/S KGRL, and that such
        transfer constituted “cross-funding” intended to create cartelisation in
        the excise retail tender process. On a careful scrutiny of the material
        placed on record, this allegation does not withstand examination.

   602.                     The prosecution itself relies heavily upon the statement
        of the approver, Raghav Magunta Reddy (PW-226). A significant
        aspect of his deposition, however, runs contrary to the prosecution
        narrative. PW-226 categorically states that the amount of ₹25 crores
        transferred to M/S KGRL was subsequently returned. This admission
        is of decisive relevance. The return of the entire amount clearly
        establishes that the transaction was not in the nature of an investment,
        capital contribution, or consideration for any assured benefit, but was,
        at best, a temporary financial accommodation or friendly loan.

   603.                     The very fact of repayment negates the essential premise
        of cartelisation. Cartelisation, by its very nature, presupposes a
        continuing alignment of commercial interests, mutual assurance of
        benefit, or a sustained financial stake in the business operations of
        another entity. A transaction which is fully reversed, without any
        evidence of retained benefit, ownership interest, or managerial

influence, cannot be characterised as a cartel-forming device. There is
        no material to suggest that the transfer of funds resulted in any change
        in shareholding, directorship, or control of M/S KGRL, nor is there
        any evidence that Zenab Pvt. Ltd. acquired any proprietary or
        beneficial interest in the said company.

   604.                     Further, there is no provision in the Excise Policy which
        prohibits an entity from receiving financial assistance or loans for
        arranging the EMD, so long as the eligibility conditions prescribed
        under the policy are otherwise fulfilled. Mere funding of EMD, in the
        absence of any statutory bar, does not ipso facto amount to
        cartelisation. To elevate such a transaction to a criminal conspiracy,
        there must be material showing that the funding translated into control,
        dominance, or coordinated conduct in restraint of competition. No
        such material is forthcoming on the record.

   605.                     In the present case, the prosecution’s own approver
        demolishes the allegation by admitting that the ₹25-crore amount was
        returned. This admission is wholly inconsistent with the theory of
        cartelisation or cross-holding of interests. A repaid loan or friendly
        financial assistance, without anything more, cannot be treated as
        evidence of a collusive arrangement or an attempt to manipulate the
        tender process, which even otherwise has not been disputed.

   606.                     Accordingly, on the basis of the statement of approver
        PW-226 read in the absence of any corroborative material indicating

continuing benefit, control, or concerted action, this Court finds that
        the allegation of cross-funding of EMD by Zenab Pvt. Ltd. to M/S
        KGRL as a device for cartelisation is unsupported by the evidence and
        rests on conjecture rather than legally sustainable material.

        (v) Legal Position

   607.                     The DEP-21/22 contains in-built safeguards to prevent
        vertical integration, cartelisation and conflict of interest. A central
        safeguard is the definition of “related entities” / “sister concerns”,
        which is consciously structured around ownership, control and
        management, and not the mere source of funds. Under the policy,
        entities are treated as related only where there exists common
        proprietorship, partnership or directorship, or where majority
        ownership (51% or more) vests in the same person or group of persons
        across such entities.

   608.                     The touchstone is effective control and beneficial
        ownership. In this statutory framework, mere funding of EMD for
        bidding in retail zones by a wholesaler or manufacturer does not, by
        itself, constitute a violation of the policy. Funding, simpliciter, does
        not ipso facto result in acquisition of ownership or transfer of control.
        The statutory disability is attracted only where such funding
        culminates in the wholesaler or manufacturer acquiring 51% or more
        ownership or decisive managerial control in the retail entity.
        Conversely, where financial assistance, whether by way of loan,

advance, guarantee or facilitation of EMD, is extended without any
        corresponding shift in shareholding, partnership rights or directorial
        control, the essential ingredients of disqualification remain absent. The
        policy does not prohibit commercial funding arrangements per se; it
        proscribes concentration of ownership and control beyond the
        prescribed threshold.

   609.                     Applying this settled legal position, the allegation sought
        to be raised in relation to M/S KGRL does not give rise to any statutory
        disqualification vis-à-vis M/S Indospirit. Quite apart from the legal
        principle that funding alone is insufficient, the factual foundation itself
        is missing. There is no material establishing that the EMD or bid
        amount of M/S KGRL was funded by M/S Indospirit, nor any evidence
        of common ownership, management or majority control between the
        two. Across all three entities, the evidence of PW-27 remains confined
        to statutory ROC filings; PW-28 speaks only to internal corporate
        compliance and risk-assessment processes of a private manufacturer;
        and PW-34’s banking evidence does not establish ownership, control
        or policy-field activity. In the absence of any legally cognisable indicia
        of ownership or control, and in the face of independent due-diligence
        findings categorising the entities as Low Risk, the prosecution’s
        attempt to subsume M/S KGRL, M/S Bubbly Beverages Pvt. Ltd. and
        M/S Indospirit Retail Pvt. Ltd. within an alleged “Indospirit
        network” is unsupported by the record.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
610.                     In sum, the DEP-21/22 draws a clear and deliberate
        distinction between prohibited ownership/control structures and
        permissible commercial financing arrangements. Unless funding
        results in acquisition of majority ownership or effective control, it
        neither violates the policy nor disentitles a wholesaler from
        consideration for, or grant of, an L-1 licence. The material on record,
        taken at its highest, fails to disclose any such prohibited nexus or
        cartelisation.

        (II) Alleged Generation and Transfer of Proceeds of Crime by Active
        Participation of A-7 through Transfer of 61% of Profits of M/S
        Indospirits to A-5

   611.                     At this stage, the Court finds it necessary to distinctly
        separate the allegation as projected by the prosecution from the
        governing legal principles applicable to partnerships and joint
        ventures, and to test the allegation against the contemporaneous
        documentary record placed on file. The prosecution proceeds on the
        premise that M/S Indospirits functioned as a joint venture in which
        M/S Indospirit Distribution Pvt. Ltd. held 35%, Prem Rahul Manduri
        (PW-270) held 32.5%, and A.R. Pillai (A-5) held 32.25%, and that
        approximately 61% of the profits were ultimately transferred to A-5.
        This circumstance is sought to be portrayed as suspicious and
        indicative of the generation of “proceeds of crime”.

612.                     At the very threshold, however, this premise stands
        contradicted by contemporaneous documentary material, namely
        Document D-9, being the letter dated 07.11.2022, which is brought on
        record by PW-26. Document D-9 records, in clear and unequivocal
        terms, that from the inception of the partnership there existed a mutual
        understanding and arrangement among the three partners, Indospirit
        Distribution Pvt. Ltd., Prem Rahul Manduri (PW-270) and A-5, that
        PW-270, who was the associate/friend/partner of A-5; that the act and
        management of the affairs of the firm on behalf of Prem Rahul
        Manduri will be done by A-5; and that it was verbally agreed between
        the partners that the share of profit of the firm attributable to both A-5
        and PW-270 would be disbursed either to A-5 or as per his instructions.
        The document further records that Prem Rahul Manduri had no
        objection whatsoever to this arrangement and that, in pursuance
        thereof, a total amount of Rs. 29,29,99,124/-, representing the
        combined profit share of A-5 and PW-270, was transferred by the firm
        either to A-5 or as per his directions. This position has been affirmed
        in the statement of PW-26, dated 08.11.2022, which is relied by the
        Investigating Agency.

   613.                     It is expressly clarified by PW-26 that, owing to this
        prior mutual understanding and express consent of PW-270, no
        amount was paid directly to him towards his share of profits. Of
        considerable significance is the fact that there is nothing on record to

show that this arrangement was ever objected to, disputed, or
        considered unacceptable by any of the partners, and in particular by
        Prem Rahul Manduri (PW-270), whose profit share is alleged to have
        been routed in the aforesaid manner. There is no complaint, protest,
        civil claim, correspondence, or contemporaneous material suggesting
        dissent, coercion, or absence of consent on his part. On the contrary,
        the documentary record affirmatively reflects acceptance and
        acquiescence, consistent with the mutual understanding recorded in
        D-9. Once this contemporaneous explanation, emanating from the
        firm itself and furnished to the investigating agency, is taken into
        account, the prosecution’s attempt to portray the flow of profits as
        suspicious appears wholly artificial. The document does not disclose
        any        clandestine      diversion,    concealment,    or    unauthorised
        appropriation; rather, it evidences a consensual inter-se arrangement
        between partners, operating from the inception of the partnership, with
        full knowledge and consent of the concerned partner.

   614.                     Even at this stage, the prosecution does not point to any
        statutory prohibition, any contractual bar in the Joint Venture
        Agreement or partnership arrangement, or any provision of the Excise
        Policy which restricts or regulates the manner in which profits or inter-
        se partner adjustments may be structured or routed. The mere fact that
        profits may ultimately accrue disproportionately to one participant
        does not, by itself, attract criminality. There exists no principle in law

which mandates that profit distribution must invariably mirror
        shareholding percentages, nor is any deviation from pro-rata
