        distribution ipso facto illegal. Commercial practice recognises that
        profits or economic benefits may legitimately flow unevenly on
        account of operational control, managerial responsibility, prior
        understanding, or inter-se adjustments agreed between partners.
        Document D-9 squarely places the present case within this legitimate
        commercial domain by recording that the routing of profits was the
        result of a prior mutual understanding and express consent, and not a
        unilateral act or covert diversion.

   615.                     Even when examined through the lens of partnership
        law, the legal position remains well settled. A conjoint reading of the
        provisions of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932 places contractual
        autonomy at the centre of the partnership framework. Section 4 defines
        partnership as a relationship founded on agreement to share profits.
        Section 13(b) expressly provides that partners are entitled to share
        profits equally unless otherwise agreed, thereby recognising unequal
        or disproportionate profit sharing pursuant to contract. Sections 13(a),
        13(c) and 13(d) further recognise legitimate inter-se financial
        adjustments, including remuneration, interest, indemnification and
        reimbursement, which may naturally result in one partner receiving
        substantially higher monetary inflows than another. The Act prescribes
        no ceiling or proportional limit on profit allocation and does not

prohibit a dominant or majority flow of profits to one partner pursuant
        to consented arrangements.

   616.                     At this juncture, the prosecution has attempted to
        superimpose an additional narrative by portraying PW-270 (Prem
        Rahul Manduri) as a mere conduit or proxy acting on behalf of
        approver Raghav Magunta Reddy (PW-226). This theory, however,
        does not find support either from the contemporaneous documentary
        record or from the logical chain of circumstances emerging on record.
        If PW-270 were indeed acting only as a front or benami for another,
        there exists no rational explanation as to why he would expressly
        consent to his contractual share of profits being routed to the account
        of A-5 (Arun Ramachandran Pillai), rather than to any entity or
        account connected with the alleged principal. Such conduct is wholly
        inconsistent with the prosecution’s own theory of proxy ownership or
        concealed beneficial interest. It is in this context that the prosecution
        has sought to rely upon the statement of PW-270 to dilute the
        evidentiary impact of the Joint Venture Agreement (JVA), dated
        29.10.2021 which is D-72 (5660-5666) itself. However, this attempt is
        legally untenable. PW-270 has unequivocally admitted his signature
        on the JVA and has stated that he “received the aforesaid documents
        through post and after signing sent them back”. Once such admission
        stands on record, the execution of the document stands proved within
        the meaning of Section 67 of the Indian Evidence Act. Upon proof of

execution, the contents of the written instrument attract the statutory
        bar contained in Sections 91 and 92 of the Evidence Act, which
        prohibit oral contradiction, variation or disclaimer of the terms of a
        written contract. The law raises a settled presumption that a person
        who appends his signature to a written instrument does so with
        knowledge of its contents and with the intention of being bound
        thereby. A bare assertion that the witness was unaware of the contents,
        without any legally recognised vitiating plea, is inconsequential and
        cannot dilute the evidentiary sanctity of the document.

                                                            (emphasis supplied)

   617.                     Significantly, PW-270 has not alleged, either in his
        statement or otherwise, that the Joint Venture Agreement (JVA) was
        executed under fraud, misrepresentation, coercion, undue influence, or
        any other circumstance recognised in law as vitiating consent. He has
        not claimed that the document was blank or incomplete at the time of
        signing, nor has he alleged deception as to the nature of the instrument.
        In the absence of such foundational pleas, the belated attempt to
        disclaim the contents of the JVA amounts to nothing more than an
        impermissible oral contradiction of a written contract, expressly
        barred under Section 92 of the Evidence Act. The Court is, therefore,
        constrained to hold that the statement of PW-270, insofar as it seeks to
        dispute or deny the contents of the JVA after admitting his signature
        thereon, is legally inadmissible and does not create even a prima facie

dent in the evidentiary value of the JVA. The Court proceeds on the
        settled presumption that the Joint Venture Agreement was validly
        executed with full knowledge of its contents by all signatories. The
        subsequent conduct relied upon by the prosecution namely, the
        application moved by PW-270 for exiting the Joint Venture
        Agreement, also does not advance the conspiracy narrative as he
        himself in his statement dated 12.10.2022 has stated that he was forced
        to exist the firm as he was not able to give bank guarantee. Withdrawal
        from, or restructuring of, a commercial arrangement at a later stage is
        a business decision and, in the absence of any contemporaneous
        incriminating circumstance, cannot retrospectively convert an
        otherwise lawful profit-sharing arrangement into a criminal
        conspiracy. No material is shown to suggest that the exit from the JVA
        was triggered by exposure of illegality, receipt of illicit funds, or any
        enforcement action, nor is it shown to be temporally or causally linked
        to any alleged offence. Commercial disengagement, without more,
        remains legally neutral.

   618.                     Crucially, for the prosecution’s theory to even prima
        facie qualify as involving “proceeds of crime”, it must establish a clear
        causal nexus showing that the profits were generated as a consequence
        of an illegal act and that their transfer was in pursuance of such
        illegality. In the present case, no illegal clause in the JVA is identified,
        no violation of the Excise Policy is demonstrated, and no evidentiary

linkage is shown between the profit routing and any act of corruption,
        abuse of office, or policy manipulation. On the contrary, Document
        D-9 affirmatively demonstrates a lawful, consensual, and pre-existing
        commercial               arrangement   governing   the   manner      of      profit
        disbursement.

   619.                     Viewed thus, the prosecution’s attempt to characterise
        the alleged transfer of approximately 61% of profits as inherently
        suspicious stands dismantled both factually and legally. Absent proof
        of a prohibitory contractual clause, a statutory violation, or an illegal
        source of income, and in the face of contemporaneous documents
        evidencing mutual understanding, consent, and absence of objection,
        the allegation rests on assumption rather than law and does not
        disclose even a prima facie case.

        (III) Outcome of Evaluation

        Conspiracy-Absence of Participation, Contingency-Based Theory, and
        Conduct Inconsistent with Alleged Design

   620.                     At the outset, it bears emphasis that A-7 was concededly
        not a member of the so-called “South Group” that is alleged to have
        travelled to Delhi and stayed at Hotel Oberoi between 14th and 17th
        March 2021. It is equally undisputed that A-7 was not a participant in
        the meetings purportedly held during 21.05.2021 at Gauri Apartment,
        nor was he present at the meeting allegedly convened at ITC Kohinoor,

Hyderabad, on 19.06.2021, which, according to the prosecution, is
        where the conspiracy is said to have crystallised and where an alleged
        decision was taken to pay an upfront amount of ₹20-30 crores to A-3
        for “tweaking” the policy.

   621.                     On the prosecution’s own showing, therefore, A-7 stood
        entirely outside the meetings that are projected as the formative and
        decisive moments of the alleged conspiracy. The edifice of conspiracy
        sought to be erected against A-7 is thus not founded on participation,
        presence, or contemporaneous conduct, but rests on a narrative
        constructed in hindsight.

   622.                     More fundamentally, the conspiracy theory propounded
        by the prosecution is inherently contingent and speculative. It
        proceeds on the presupposition that M/S Indospirits would first secure
        an L-1 licence, and thereafter be appointed as a distributor by M/S
        PRI. This two-stage sequence was not within the control of any of the
        alleged conspirators. The grant of an L-1 licence is a statutory and
        regulatory process, and the subsequent appointment of a distributor is
        a commercial decision of the manufacturer. Significantly, neither M/S
        PRI nor M/S Diageo is alleged to be a participant in the conspiracy.
        These were not ancillary or peripheral contingencies; they were the
        very foundations on which the prosecution’s theory of “recoupment”
        of alleged upfront payments rests. Absent these events, the alleged

conspiracy would be commercially irrational and incapable of
        fruition.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   623.                     The actual course of events during the implementation
        of the policy does not support the prosecution’s case of a pre-planned
        and effectively executed conspiracy. M/S KGRL failed to secure an
        L-7Z licence even in the first round. M/S Indospirits (IMPL) was
        required to withdraw its initial application for grant of an L-1 licence
        after issuance of three show-cause notices, the last of which was issued
        in the final week of October. This is so despite the allegation that A-7
        had already paid ₹30 lakhs to A-2. If an arrangement of the nature
        alleged, operating at the highest levels, had in fact existed, such
        repeated regulatory impediments would not have arisen.

   624.                     The inconsistency becomes more pronounced when it is
        noted that, notwithstanding the allegation of receipt of substantial
        “upfront” amounts, the persons said to be party to the conspiracy were
        unable to secure even routine regulatory approvals. The assertion that
        the Dy. CM (A-8) and CM (A-18) were in a position to ensure
        favourable outcomes stands at variance with the record, which shows
        that M/S Indospirits encountered repeated regulatory obstacles and did
        not obtain the L-1 licence with ease, if at all.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
625.                     The record also reflects that M/S Indospirit Marketing
        Pvt. Ltd. (IMPL – JV), by application dated 09.09.2021, initially
        applied for grant of an L-1 licence showing only two partners, M/S
        IMPL and M/S Indospirit Distribution Pvt. Ltd. (IDPL). No entity
        alleged to form part of the “South Group” was shown as a partner at
        that stage. If, as suggested, it had already been decided that
        recoupment would be effected through this entity, there was no reason
        for excluding the supposed beneficiaries from the partnership at
        inception. The structure of the application does not indicate a settled
        or pre-existing design.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   626.                     It is a matter of record that at a later stage accused
        persons associated with the South Group were inducted. Even
        thereafter, the application did not receive any preferential treatment.
        Three deficiency memos were issued, and ultimately the application
        was withdrawn as the entity failed to meet the prescribed turnover
        eligibility of ₹150 crores. The sequence indicates scrutiny and non-
        compliance rather than facilitation.

   627.                     The contradiction becomes sharper when examined in
        the context of the allegation concerning the second draft GoM report.
        The prosecution asserts that the draft was prepared from pages
        supplied by members of the South Group and that the turnover
        criterion was enhanced to ₹500 crores per year for the preceding five

years. Had such a stipulation been retained, entities such as M/S
        Indospirit would have been rendered ineligible altogether. The very
        condition said to have been introduced at their instance would have
        defeated the alleged object of recoupment.

   628.                     On a cumulative reading, these circumstances do not
        disclose acts in furtherance of a conspiracy. Acceptance of the
        prosecution case as it stands would lead to the conclusion that the
        alleged beneficiaries introduced eligibility conditions that disqualified
        themselves. Such a position does not accord with ordinary
        probabilities and exposes a fundamental inconsistency in the theory
        advanced.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   629.                     Further, M/S KGRL was subjected to proceedings by the
        Income Tax Department, initiated at the instance of the very Excise
        Department that is alleged to have favoured the group. Even the
        approver, Raghav Magunta Reddy (PW-226)-who claims to have paid
        ₹10 crores in March and ₹15 crores in June-could not secure a No
        Objection Certificate for operating the Airport Zone. These facts are
        wholly inconsistent with the prosecution’s thesis of undue favour,
        assured outcomes, or policy-level manipulation.

                                                             (emphasis supplied)

630.                     In sum, the contemporaneous conduct and objective
        outcomes during the execution of the policy demonstrate persistent
        regulatory resistance rather than preferential treatment. The
        difficulties faced by the so-called “South Group” and by A-7 at every
        material stage decisively negate any inference of undue favour or pre-
        arranged benefit. Far from supporting a conspiracy of the magnitude
        alleged, the record reveals a sequence of events that is antithetical to
        the very notion of a successful, centrally controlled conspiratorial
        design.

        Allegation against A-6

   631.                     A-6 Mootha Gautham is alleged to have provided the
        corporate infrastructure and financial channels necessary for layering
        and integration of proceeds derived from the manipulated wholesale
        arrangement. It is stated that entities effectively under his control,
        including IANPL, APPL, CDG Broadcasting Pvt. Ltd., and Zeus
        Networking Pvt. Ltd., received substantial amounts either directly
        from M/S Indospirits or indirectly through accused Arun Pillai (A-5),
        without any legitimate commercial basis. Transfers described as
        payments for a “programme” or as “loans” are alleged to be
        unsupported by agreements, broadcast records or genuine loan
        documentation, with key witnesses asserting they were made to sign
        as attesting witnesses without understanding the contents. The
        prosecution contends that A-6 knowingly facilitated the masking of

tainted funds as business receipts or repayments in furtherance of the
        conspiracy.

        Allegations against A-4

   632.                     The prosecution describes A-4, Abhishek Boinpally, as a
        key member of the “South Group” and attributes to him a participative
        role in the alleged conspiracy. It is alleged that he was in Delhi
        between 14.03.2021 and 17.03.2021. During this period, Vijay Nair is
        stated to have met the South Group on 14.03.2021, and it is alleged
        that a 36-page printout was handed over to him, which is said to be the
        second draft GoM report dated 19.03.2021, later finalized on
        22.03.2021.

   633.                     It is further alleged that A-4 attended the meeting
        arranged at Gauri Apartment on 21.05.2021 and was also present at
        the meeting held at ITC Kohinoor on 19.06.2021. These meetings are
        relied upon by the prosecution as forming part of the sequence of
        events connected with the alleged conspiracy.

   634.                     The prosecution also alleges that A-4 acted as a mediator
        in relation to the payment of ₹15 crores to A-17 K. Kavitha by Raghav
        Magunta. According to the prosecution, the said amount was delivered
        to A-21 Vinod Chauhan through Ashok Kaushik, Personal Assistant to
        A-17 K. Kavitha, and was thereafter routed towards Goa. It is further
        alleged that on 20.09.2021, A-4 was present at a meeting where A-7

Sameer Mahendru introduced him and A-5 Arun R. Pillai as potential
        investors in M/S Indospirits.

   635.                     On the financial aspect, it is alleged that A-4 invested
        ₹1.29 crores in M/S India Ahead News by purchasing its logo. The
        prosecution further states that ₹3.85 crores were received from A-6
        Mootha Gautam, stated to have emanated from M/S Indospirits, out of
        which ₹3.70 crores were transferred to CDG Broadcasting, described
        as being owned by A-4 Abhishek Boinpally and A-6 Mootha Gautam,
        and ₹85.5 lakhs were transferred to Pankaj Arora of CDG.

        Allegation against A-5

   636.                     The prosecution portrays A-5, Arun Ramchandra Pillai,
        as a member of the alleged “South Group” and attributes to him
        participation in certain meetings said to form part of the broader
        conspiracy. It is alleged that he was present in Delhi between
        14.03.2021 and 17.03.2021, during which period Vijay Nair (A-3) met
        the South Group on 14.03.2021 and was handed over a 36-page
        printout stated to be the second draft GoM report dated 19.03.2021
        later finalized on 22.03.2021. He is further alleged to have attended
        the meeting at Gauri Apartment on 21.05.2021 and the meeting at ITC
        Kohinoor on 19.06.2021.

   637.                     It is also alleged that he invested in M/S Indospirits with
        32.5% shareholding, the investment being stated to have been

arranged by A-17 K. Kavitha. While the shareholding is described as
        32.5%, the actual amount invested is stated to be ₹3.40 crores. The
        prosecution further alleges that approximately 61% of the profits of
        M/S Indospirits, quantified at about ₹29.29 crores, were received by
        him or distributed at his instance as part of a recoupment plan, a
        portion of which was shared with A-4 Abhishek Boinpally.

        Consolidated Consideration of Allegations against A-4, A-5 and A-6
        under the “Media-Transaction Theory”

   638.                     The allegations pertaining to A-4, A-5 and A-6 are being
        examined conjointly at this stage for reasons of convenience and
        continuity. The prosecution has projected a composite narrative
        linking these three accused in relation to transactions involving APPL
        and IANPL It is alleged that certain monetary credits were made by
        A-4 and A-5 to the aforesaid entities and that the acquisition of the
        logo/trademark of the “India Ahead” news channel formed part of the
        broader design attributed to them. This cluster of allegations has been
        described by the prosecution as forming part of what may conveniently
        be referred to as the “Media Transaction Theory”.

   639.                     While the principal financial dealings are stated to have
        taken place between A-4 and A-6, the prosecution seeks to weave A-5
        into the same framework on the premise of an overarching conspiracy.
        It is alleged that substantial sums, far in excess of declared
        investments, were received from M/S Indospirits’ profits and

thereafter routed onwards to entities associated with A-6 and
        ultimately to entities controlled by A-4 under the guise of loans or
        commercial transactions.

   640.                     A-6 is alleged to have provided the corporate
        infrastructure and financial channels for layering and integration of the
        alleged proceeds of crime, with entities under his control, including
        media and networking companies, receiving funds described as
        programme                payments   or   loans,   allegedly   unsupported         by
        contemporaneous agreements, broadcast records or genuine loan
        documentation. According to the prosecution, these interlinked
        financial movements constituted the mechanism by which the alleged
        advance funding was repaid and profits were distributed among the
        conspirators, thereby rendering the participation of all three accused
        integral to both the financing and profiteering facets of the alleged
        conspiracy.

   641.                     In addition, the meetings stated to have taken place at
        Gauri Apartment, Delhi, and at ITC Kohinoor, Hyderabad, are also
        relied upon by the prosecution as part of the same sequence of events.
        Since these allegations are projected against A-4 and A-5 in a
        connected manner, they are being considered together for the purpose
        of appreciating the prosecution narrative in its entirety.

642.           After addressing the common allegations and overlapping
        circumstances, the contentions specific to A-4 and A-5 shall be
        examined separately on their individual merits.

        Media–Transaction Theory:
        (A) Loan Agreement dated 18.02.2022
   643.                     The prosecution has sought to cast a cloud over the
        transaction involving the transfer of ₹3.85 crores between A-5, A-6
        and A-4 by assailing the authenticity of the Loan Agreement dated
        18.02.2022, which is D-29. The objection rests solely on two planks:
        first, that the witnesses to the document signed it at the instance of A-6
        without being aware of its contents; and second, that the document is
        neither registered nor notarised. In support, reliance has been placed
        on the statements of PW-14 Pottipochayalu Madhan and PW-29 Asif
        Baba. Upon a close and careful scrutiny of the record, this line of
        reasoning is found to proceed on a clear misapprehension of law and,
        more importantly, to stand contradicted by the prosecution’s own
        evidence.

   644.                     Both PW-14 and PW-29 have unequivocally stated that
        they appended their signatures on the Loan Agreement dated
        18.02.2022 and on the Asset Purchase and Trademark Assignment
        Deed dated 10.06.2022 in the capacity of witnesses and on the
        instructions of the Managing Director, Mootha Gowtham. They have
        further identified the signatures of A-6 and A-4 on the said documents

on the basis of familiarity acquired during the course of their
        employment. Significantly, neither witness has disputed his own
        signatures nor questioned the signatures of the accused on the Loan
        Agreement. They also did not have made any suggestion, let alone an
        allegation, that the document was fabricated, forged, ante-dated, or
        executed without the consent of the parties concerned.

   645.                     The limited evidentiary role of an attesting witness is too
        well settled to admit of debate. Such a witness is required only to speak
        to the factum of execution of the document. He is neither expected nor
        required in law to have knowledge of, or to depose about, the contents
        of the document or the commercial rationale underlying the
        transaction. The prosecution’s attempt to impeach the agreement on
        the ground that the witnesses were unaware of its contents betrays a
        fundamental              misunderstanding   of   the   principles       governing
        admissibility of private documents.
                                                                 (emphasis supplied)
   646.                     The fallacy in the prosecution’s approach becomes even
        more apparent when tested against the scheme of the Indian Contract
        Act, 1872, which recognises the validity and enforceability of oral
        contracts. The law does not mandate attestation as a condition
        precedent to the validity of a contract. Even in the absence of any
        witness, a contract does not become void or suspect merely for want
        of attestation. To therefore discredit a written loan agreement on the

ground that the attesting witnesses did not know its contents is to
        import a requirement which the law itself does not recognise.
                                                                (emphasis supplied)

   647.                     If such a line of reasoning were to be accepted, it would
        enable the investigating agency to brand any private commercial
        document as sham on the basis of conjecture, without disclosing a
        single legally cognisable infirmity in its execution. This would amount
        to permitting narrative to displace evidence, an approach wholly alien
        to criminal jurisprudence.

   648.                     The prosecution’s further objection based on the absence
        of registration or notarisation is equally untenable. There exists no
        statutory mandate requiring compulsory registration or notarisation of
        a private loan agreement of this nature. The Registration Act, 1908
        restricts        compulsory     registration   to   documents     specifically
        enumerated therein, and a simple loan agreement does not fall within
        that category. The absence of registration or notarisation, by itself,
        carries no adverse legal consequence and cannot be treated as a
        circumstance undermining the genuineness of the document.

   649.                     Viewed in its entirety, the reliance placed on the
        statements of PW-14 and PW-29 does not advance the prosecution
        case in the slightest. On the contrary, their evidence affirmatively
        establishes execution of the Loan Agreement dated 18.02.2022 and
        dispels any suggestion of fabrication or impropriety. The challenge
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
mounted by the investigating agency is thus founded on a legally
        unsound premise and an evidentially hollow hypothesis, and cannot be
        permitted to sustain even a prima facie doubt as to the genuineness of
        the transaction.

        (B) Pre-Existing Financial Dealings as Admitted by PW-29

   650.                     The prosecution’s narrative further suffers a serious
        setback from the statement of PW-29, who admits that an aggregate
        amount of Rs. 6.53 crores was received in the personal account of A-6
        through nine transactions commencing from 10.11.2020. These
        transactions originate from a period anterior to the timeframe during
        which the prosecution alleges that the accused entered into any
        conspiracy relating to the Excise Policy. Once the prosecution’s own
        witness acknowledges substantial financial dealings prior to the
        alleged conspiracy, the theory that subsequent transactions necessarily
        represent circulation of “proceeds of crime” becomes untenable. The
        record instead discloses an ongoing business relationship which has
        retrospectively been sought to be given a criminal colour.

   651.                     The position is further fortified by another material
        portion of PW-29’s statement, wherein he states: “On being asked I
        state that I know Mr. Abhishek Boinpally, because my MD Mr.
        Mootha Goutham introduced me probably in October 2020 with him
        as a potential investor in India Ahead News Pvt. Ltd. and Shri
        Boinpally Abhishek wanted to see the financial statement of company

Andhra Prabha Publication Ltd. and India Ahead New Pvt. Ltd. for
        which Mr. Boinpally was handed over some financial documents of
        both the company.”

   652.                     The extract is significant. It establishes that as early as
        October 2020, A-4 had been introduced as a prospective investor in
        IANPL, and had sought access to the financial statements of APPL and
        IANPL Such a request is consistent with customary commercial due
        diligence undertaken by an investor prior to entering the media
        business.

   653.                     The chronology is decisive. October 2020 not only
        precedes the period during which the alleged conspiracy is said to have
        taken shape, but also aligns with the commencement of the financial
        transactions spoken of by PW-29. Both the financial dealings and the
        preliminary steps in the media domain thus trace back to a time
        anterior to the projected conspiracy period. The subsequent purchase
        of the logo and the acquisition of CDG Broadcasting Pvt. Ltd. and
        Zeus Networking Pvt. Ltd. appear to be a natural progression of an
        intention that had already crystallised in October 2020. The sequence,
        from examination of financial records to structured corporate
        acquisitions, bears the hallmarks of a continuing commercial
        engagement in the media sector. When viewed in this light, the attempt
        to attribute a criminal complexion to transactions demonstrably rooted
        in pre-existing business dealings does not sustain scrutiny.

(C) Acquisition of CDG Broadcasting Pvt. Ltd. and Zeus Networking
        Pvt. Ltd.

   654.                     Upon a careful and conjoint reading of the statements of
        PW-15 Smt. Lalita Dutt and PW-16 Sh. Pankaj Arora, this Court finds
        that the acquisition of shares of M/S Zeus Networking Pvt. Ltd. stands
        explained through contemporaneous corporate records and formal
        documentary instruments, which significantly pre-date the period
        during which the prosecution alleges the hatching of conspiracy.

   655.                     PW-15, who was associated with the accounts and
        financial records of CDG Broadcast Pvt. Ltd., first delineates the
        shareholding structure of Zeus Networking Pvt. Ltd. and identifies the
        issuance of share certificates. She categorically states: “...On being
        asked I state that following are the shareholding pattern of this
        company:..”.

   656.                     She thereafter records that CDG Broadcast Pvt. Ltd. held
        30,00,000 shares, Sh. Pankaj Arora held 45,000 shares, and Smt.
        Arpita Arora held 5,000 shares, making a total of 30,50,000 shares.
        PW-15 further identifies the contemporaneous share certificates by
        stating: “...On being asked about the documents available at page 53-
        60, I state that vide these documents Director of Zeus Networking Pvt.
        Ltd. issue share certificate of shareholder of Zeus Networking Pvt.
        Ltd. i.e. CDG Broadcast Pvt. Ltd. vide certificate No. 08 to 11 all dated
        18th March of 2021…”.

657.                     She also identifies the signatures of PW-16 Sh. Pankaj
        Arora and Smt. Arpita Arora on these share certificates in their
        capacity as Director and authorised signatories. Thus, the documentary
        record unequivocally establishes that as on 18.03.2021, the
        shareholding position of Zeus Networking Pvt. Ltd. stood formally
        recorded and crystallised.

   658.                     Thereafter, both PW-15 and PW-16 speak to the
        commencement of acquisition of shares by A-4 and A-5 through deeds
        of pledge, beginning immediately after the issuance of the share
        certificates. PW-16 Sh. Pankaj Arora states in clear terms: “….On
        being asked I state that three deeds of pledge executed between
        Director of CDG Broadcast Pvt. Ltd. i.e. me and my wife Ms. Arpita
        Arora and the Acquirer of shares of company Zeus Networking Pvt.
        Ltd. vide deeds of pledge dated 24.03.2021, 23.08.2021 and
        29.09.2021….”.

   659.                  He further explains the nature of the transaction by stating:
        “...Director of Zeus Networking Pvt. Ltd. pledge shares to the
        acquirers i.e. Mr. Mootha Gautam and Mr. Abhishek Boinpally equal
        to the amount received from them….”.

   660.                     PW-15 corroborates this position by identifying the
        same set of pledge deeds and signatures, thereby confirming that the
        acquisition process was structured through recognised corporate
        instruments and unfolded over a defined timeline commencing from

24.03.2021. As regards consideration, PW-15 identifies the consent
        documents permitting sale of shares and records:

                “...Director of CDG Broadcast Pvt. Ltd. has signed consent
                letter for disposing of / selling of 30,00,000 (98.36%) shares of
                CDG Broadcast Limited holding in Zeus Networking Pvt. Ltd.
                on an agreed value of Rs. 5.70 Crores….”.
   661.                     Neither PW-15 nor PW-16 attributes the movement of
        consideration to any cash transaction or informal channel. On the
        contrary, the witnesses consistently speak to the transaction having
        been carried out through banking channels, supported by corporate
        approvals, consent letters, pledge deeds and share certificates.

   662.                     What emerges from the above evidence is a continuous
        and documented corporate transaction, commencing with issuance of
        share certificates on 18.03.2021, followed by execution of pledge
        deeds beginning 24.03.2021, and culminating in eventual transfer of
        shares. This entire sequence preceded by the alleged meeting and
        alleged hatching of conspiracy relied upon by the prosecution.

   663.                     In this backdrop, the prosecution’s theory that the
        acquisition of Zeus Networking Pvt. Ltd. was a product of a later
        conspiracy or a mechanism for layering of alleged proceeds of crime
        is rendered fundamentally flawed. The very foundation of the alleged
        layering collapses when the prosecution’s own relied-upon witnesses
        demonstrate that the acquisition process was already underway
        through formal corporate documentation and regulated banking

transactions much prior to the alleged conspiratorial period. The
        evidence of PW-15 and PW-16, far from supporting the prosecution
        narrative, instead discloses a pre-existing commercial transaction,
        thereby striking at the core of the allegation that the acquisition of
        Zeus Networking Pvt. Ltd. was conceived or executed as part of any
        criminal conspiracy.

        (D) Examination of Trademark Acquisition in the Context of the
        Alleged Recoupment Theory

   664.                     The record reflects that the trademark “India Ahead”,
        together with its goodwill, was transferred by A-6 (APPL) to A-4 for
        a consideration of Rs. 1.30 crores through a duly executed and
        registered Assignment Deed dated 10.06.2022 (D-87) and Invoice
        dated 31.07.2021. The consideration moved through normal banking
        channels and the transaction is supported by formal documentation.
        On the face of it, the arrangement bears the character of a commercial
        transfer of intellectual property.

   665.                     The prosecution has attempted to suggest that this
        transaction was a means for recoupment of alleged amounts through
        A6. However, the contemporaneous material does not support such a
        conclusion. The financial dealings between A4 and A6 commenced in
        October 2020, which is prior to the period during which the alleged
        Excise Policy conspiracy is projected to have taken shape. The initial
        advancement of funds thus precedes the alleged policy deliberations.

The sequence of events does not lend any support to the inference that
        the trademark acquisition was conceived as part of a recoupment
        mechanism connected to a later alleged conspiracy.

   666.                     When the transactions are considered cumulatively,
        beginning with the infusion of funds, followed by the acquisition of
        the “India Ahead” intellectual property, and thereafter the acquisition
        of ZNPL, they indicate a consistent commercial course of conduct.
        The record shows that A-4 was exploring entry into the media and
        broadcasting sector, and the steps taken were accompanied by formal
        instruments, banking entries and regulatory compliances. Such
        features are consistent with a bona fide business arrangement.

   667.                     Notably, there is no material on record showing any
        nexus between the acquisition of the trademark and alleged
        recoupment from M/S Indospirit. No document, correspondence or
        witness statement connects this transaction with the liquor business or
        with any understanding under the Excise Policy. In the absence of such
        linkage, the allegation rests on assumption. The material presently
        available points to a commercial transaction rather than to a device for
        recoupment within the alleged conspiracy.

        (E) Advance Payment for Proposed Marketing Campaign by A-5 to
        A-6
   668.                     The prosecution alleges that the remittance of Rs. 1.70
        crores by A5 to entities connected with A-6, Rs. 1 crore to APPL on

28.02.2022 and Rs. 70 lakhs to IANPL on 14.03.2022, was not towards
        any genuine marketing campaign but formed part of the alleged larger
        conspiracy. This allegation is founded principally on two
        circumstances: first, that unlike earlier campaigns executed by APPL
        for clients such as GoDaddy and Sporta Technologies Pvt. Ltd.
        (Dream11), no formal written agreement has been placed on record in
        the case of M/S Indospirits; and second, that the payment was made in
        advance, whereas in earlier assignments payments were structured
        after execution. On this basis, the transaction is described as lacking
        commercial substance.

   669.                     On scrutiny, the allegation does not advance the
        prosecution case. It is not in dispute that the amounts were transferred
        through regular banking channels. The record further shows that
        concept papers relating to the proposed campaign were prepared and
        later produced before the investigating agency under Production
        Memo dated 08.11.2022 (D-89, Pgs. 6783–6796). The existence of
        these contemporaneous documents is of relevance and supports the
        position that preparatory steps had in fact been taken.

   670.                     The absence of a formal written agreement between
        private parties, by itself, does not render a commercial transaction
        unlawful. Business engagements are often initiated on the basis of
        mutual understanding, particularly where advance consideration is
        paid and preliminary work begins pending formal documentation.

There is no statutory requirement that payment for services must
        invariably follow completion of work. Advance payments are a
        recognised feature of commercial practice, and the timing or structure
        of payment depends upon the arrangement between the parties. A
        difference in payment modality, when compared with other
        transactions, cannot by itself justify an inference of criminality.

   671.                     No material has been placed on record to indicate that
        the funds were diverted, concealed, or applied for any unlawful
        purpose. The preparation of campaign documents, traceable to specific
        records, further belies the suggestion of a sham arrangement. If the
        payment had no underlying commercial intent, there would have been
        little occasion to prepare and preserve detailed concept material.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   672.                     The non-execution of the campaign is explained by the
        subsequent arraignment of A-5 in the present case. A commercial
        proposal that does not culminate in execution due to intervening events
        cannot, without more, be treated as evidence of conspiracy. The mere
        fact that a project did not fructify does not retrospectively alter the
        character of an advance payment.

   673.                     On the material presently available, the transaction
        reflects a proposed commercial engagement supported by banking
        entries and contemporaneous documentation. No material has been

brought on record to establish a nexus between this payment and the
        alleged Excise Policy conspiracy. The inference suggested by the
        prosecution is not supported by demonstrable material.

        (F) Presence of A-5 and A-6 in the Meeting at Gauri Apartments

   674.                     The allegation regarding the inception of the conspiracy
        at Gauri Apartments has already been examined in detail. Even at the
        cost of repetition, the present discussion is confined to the role
        attributed to A-4 and A-5 in that meeting.

   675.                     The prosecution relies upon three participants as its
        witnesses, namely PW-1, PW-2 and the approver PW-20. The specific
        allegation against A-4, A-5 and A-11 is that they were discussing the
        taking of five to ten retail zones. It is further stated that PW-1 and
        PW-2 could assist in setting up the shops and providing staff for
        running them. In return, assistance would be extended to promote the
        brand “Royal Green” at such outlets and to facilitate its sale in the
        Telangana market.

   676.                     Read in context, these statements indicate that certain
        private individuals were contemplating entry into the retail liquor
        business, with an intention to secure retail zones and arrange
        manpower if such entry materialised. A discussion about the number
        of retail zones and the requirement of staff is, by its nature, preparatory
        and commercial. It does not, by itself, disclose a criminal design.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
677.                     Even if the prosecution case is accepted at its highest, it
        is not shown that either A-4 or A-5 applied for any retail zone under
        the DEP-21/22. There is no material to suggest that they secured any
        licence, participated in the bidding process, or undertook any retail
        operations pursuant to the policy. The record does not reflect their
        involvement in the retail segment in any tangible manner.

   678.                     Equally important is the absence of any allegation in
        these discussions of policy manipulation, influence over decision-
        making, quid pro quo, or bribery. There is no reference to altering the
        Excise Policy, no assertion of illegal gratification, and no material
        suggesting that the conversation travelled beyond a proposed
        commercial arrangement.

   679.                     At best, what emerges is that certain business persons
        were exploring the possibility of entering a regulated trade and were
        discussing logistical aspects such as staffing and brand promotion. In
        the absence of any material linking such discussions to unlawful acts
        or corrupt intent, the allegation does not rise beyond a prospective
        business proposal.

        (G) Meeting at ITC Kohinoor, Hyderabad — Alleged Finalisation of
        Conspiracy and Mode of Recoupment
   680.                     The prosecution case, in its simplest articulation, is that
        the meeting held on 19.06.2021 at ITC Kohinoor, Hyderabad,
        constituted the stage at which the alleged conspiracy attained finality

in terms of structure and execution. It is alleged that the wholesale
        profit margin under the L-1 licence was enhanced from 5% to 12%
        with a predetermined objective, that out of the enhanced 12% margin,
        6% would be siphoned as “upfront money” for the benefit of A-3. The
        two wholesale entities projected as instrumental in this arrangement
        are M/S Indospirit (associated with A-7) and M/S BPSL (associated
        with A-9).

   681.                     According to the prosecution, the mechanism of
        recoupment differed between the two entities. In the case of M/S
        Indospirit, the recovery of the alleged upfront component is stated to
        have been effected through transfer or routing of profits to A-5. In the
        case of BPSL, the alleged recovery was to be achieved by issuance of
        additional credit notes to retail zones purportedly controlled by the so-
        called “South Group”. Thus, the entire architecture of enhancement,
        payment of upfront money, and subsequent recoupment is stated to
        have been crystallised in the Hyderabad meeting.

   682.                     The principal foundation for this narrative rests upon the
        statement of approver PW-20, who admittedly attended the said
        meeting. The investigating agency has relied upon three statements of
        PW-20: (i) his statement under Section 161 of Cr.P.C dated
        21.09.2022, (ii) his statement under Section 164 of Cr.P.C dated
        30.09.2022 (pre-pardon), and (iii) his post-pardon confessional
        statement recorded under Section 306(4) of Cr.P.C dated 24.11.2022.

683.                     A comparative reading of these statements reveals
        variations in figures, description of the mechanism, and attribution of
        knowledge. However, at the stage of framing of charge, this Court does
        not embark upon a minute dissection of inconsistencies unless they are
        of such magnitude as to completely demolish the substratum of the
        prosecution case. The statements of approver PW-20 are the basis on
        which the prosecution has built its case of enhancement of margin,
        division of 6% out of 12%, and utilisation of Indospirit and BPSL as
        vehicles of recoupment.

   684.                     Yet, an important nuance emerges. The alleged modus
        operandi, as narrated by PW-20, is largely premised upon what was
        conveyed to him by A-3. Though he was physically present in the
        meeting, the structure of profit distribution and recovery is not
        consistently attributed to his personal knowledge. In one version, he
        states that A-3 informed him; in another, he suggests that the “South
        investors” explained the arrangement somewhere after the retail vends
        were not being opened, which must be the period after bidding of retail
        zones; and in yet another, he presents the structure as told by A-3. This
        shift assumes significance because, if his confessional statements as
        well as statement under Section 161 are accepted in their entirety, the
        knowledge of the finalised conspiracy, particularly its financial
        structuring, appears to be derived from what was told to him rather

than from acts personally executed or observed by him in the
        meeting.

   685.                     This does not directly affect the acts allegedly performed
        by PW-20 in furtherance of the conspiracy, such as coordination of
        payments.           However,     it   renders   the   confessional     narrative
        comparatively fragile in so far as the conceptual architecture of the
        conspiracy is concerned. The tender of pardon was premised upon the
        expectation of a full and true disclosure. While this Court does not, at
        this juncture, enter into an adjudication on the truthfulness of the
        disclosure, it is evident from the recording of supplementary
        statements under Section 161 of Cr.P.C that the narrative evolved over
        time. Whether such evolution constitutes incompleteness or otherwise,
        nevertheless, it reinforces the settled rule of prudence that accomplice
        evidence requires independent corroboration on material particulars
        before it can safely be acted upon.

   686.                     The necessity of corroboration is accentuated in the
        present case, particularly in light of the multiple supplementary
        statements recorded by the investigating officer and the progressive
        refinement of the alleged modus operandi. The meeting at ITC
        Kohinoor, though attended by PW-20, is, in part, presented through a
        lens of information conveyed to him. It is conceivable that he
        articulated the events in a manner that minimised his participatory

role; equally, it is possible that he narrated what was explained to
        him.

   687.                     Even so, at the present stage, this Court proceeds on the
        footing most favourable to the prosecution. Without discarding the
        statement of the approver, it is provisionally treated as a complete and
        truthful disclosure for the limited purpose of examining whether the
        alleged modus operandi coheres with the surrounding circumstances.
        The analysis, therefore, shall proceed in two distinct but interrelated
        dimensions:

                            First, on a factual plane, whether the enhancement of
        wholesale margin, the alleged payment of upfront money, the
        projected modes of recoupment through Indospirit and BPSL, the
        movement of funds to Delhi and thereafter to Goa, and the alleged
        utilisation in electoral activity, collectively form a chain consistent
        with the modus operandi described.

                            Second, on the evidentiary plane, whether this central
        component of the prosecution case, namely the finalisation of the
        conspiracy and its financial structure at the Hyderabad meeting, stands
        independently corroborated on material particulars beyond the
        uncorroborated word of the approver.

   688.                     It is only after applying both tests that a holistic view
        can be formed as to whether the prosecution’s projected

circumstances, if assumed to be true at this stage, reasonably advance
        the alleged design or whether the edifice rests primarily upon
        uncorroborated accomplice statement. This exercise is confined to an
        even more superficial scrutiny than a prima facie assessment, limited
        to the allegations concerning what is stated to have transpired at the
        meeting at ITC Kohinoor, Hyderabad.
                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   689.                     On the first aspect, the documentary trail itself raises
        serious doubt about the alleged finalisation of a conspiratorial design
        at the ITC Kohinoor meeting. It is the prosecution case that a 36-page
        document was handed over by members of the so-called South Group,
        namely A-4, A-5, A-11 and A-23, with A-4, A-5 and A-11 acting on
        behalf of A-17, and that this document formed the basis of the second
        draft GoM Report dated 19.03.2021. However, a plain reading of the
        second draft indicates that it contained provisions which, on the
        prosecution’s own theory, would operate against the interest of the
        alleged conspirators. The clause limiting the wholesale margin to 12%
        stands in contrast to the first draft GoM Report dated 15.03.2021,
        which, far from fixing the margin at 5% as is now sought to be
        suggested, merely prescribed a minimum of 5% without any upper
        cap. The absence of a ceiling in the first draft would have enabled the
        margin to rise beyond 12%, thereby potentially conferring greater
        commercial advantage upon any wholesaler. If the “South Group”

were indeed shaping the policy for their own enrichment, it is difficult
        to reconcile why they would introduce a restrictive ceiling of 12%,
        instead of retaining the open-ended formulation that could have
        yielded greater profit.

   690.                     Similarly, the clause enhancing the turnover requirement
        of ₹500 crores per year for the past five years would have had the
        direct consequence of placing M/S Indospirit outside the zone of
        eligibility for the L-1 licence. Such a stipulation would hardly advance
        the interest of the very entity through which, according to the
        prosecution, the recoupment mechanism was to operate. On the
        prosecution’s narrative, the “South Group” was acting in concert to
        secure advantage through Indospirit; yet the very draft attributed to
        them incorporates conditions detrimental to that objective. The
        internal logic of the conspiracy theory thus begins to unravel on its
        own terms.

   691.                     The prosecution case in the main charge-sheet projected
        the genesis of conspiracy as commencing in April/May. Subsequently,
        the narrative was shifted backward to March, with the allegation that
        A-4, A-5 and A-11 were acting as conduits of A-17 during the drafting
        stage itself. This alteration is not a mere refinement of detail; it re-
        anchors the entire conspiracy at an earlier point in time. Such
        repositioning, when viewed alongside the contents of the March draft
        itself, renders the theory self-contradictory.

692.                     The position becomes even more untenable at the stage
        of implementation. It is an admitted fact that M/S KGRL failed in the
        first bidding round. More importantly, M/S Indospirit initially filed its
        application dated 09.09.2021 for grant of L-1 licence without any
        accused belonging to the South Group as partner, which stands in clear
        contrast to what is alleged to have been decided in the meeting at ITC
        Kohinoor, Hyderabad. This aspect assumes decisive significance in
        light of the post-pardon confessional statement of PW-20, wherein he
        stated: “There were two L-1. (1) M/S Indospirits, 65% partnership
        will be of Arun Pillai, who was with Abhishek and 35% will be of
        Sameer Mahendroo.”

   693.                     Contrary to this assertion, the initial application was
        filed by M/S IMPL (JV), with IMPL and IMDL as partners. The very
        persons projected in the alleged modus operandi as recipients and
        vehicles of recoupment were not part of the original application
        structure. If the conspiracy stood crystallised in June with a defined
        recovery mechanism through specific partners, their absence from the
        foundational application strikes at the root of the projected design.

   694.                     An equally significant omission relates to approver
        Raghav Magunta (PW-226), who, as per the prosecution, had already
        paid ₹25 crores as upfront money. The charge-sheet subsequently
        introduces Prem Rahul Manduri (PW-270) as a proxy of PW-226 and
        as a partner in M/S Indospirit. Yet there is no reference to this

arrangement in the alleged meeting at Hyderabad, nor does it form part
        of the articulated modus operandi described by PW-20. When both the
        payment of upfront money and the corresponding mode of recoupment
        fail to find structural consistency with the contemporaneous record,
        the discussion does not even superficially cross the threshold of a
        prima facie case.
                                                                (emphasis supplied)

   695.                     On the second aspect, it is well settled that the statement
        of an approver can be acted upon only when it receives corroboration
        in material particulars. In the present case, there is no independent
        witness examined to substantiate the alleged finalisation of the modus
        operandi at the Hyderabad meeting. PW-1 has candidly stated that
        though he was present at the venue, he was asked to leave before any
        substantive discussion took place. His evidence, therefore, can at best
        corroborate the factum of the meeting; it does not and cannot
        corroborate the alleged financial structuring or recoupment
        mechanism.

   696.                     This assumes greater significance when the confessional
        statements of PW-20 themselves create the impression that the
        financial architecture was narrated to him by others. To that extent, his
        account borders on hearsay regarding the design of the conspiracy,
        even though he may have participated in certain acts thereafter. When
        the central plank of the prosecution, namely, the finalisation of

enhancement, upfront payment and recoupment, rests upon such
        statements, the absence of independent corroboration in material
        particulars becomes a serious infirmity.

   697.                     Thus, both on the internal consistency of the projected
        modus operandi and on the evidentiary requirement of corroboration,
        the prosecution case encounters substantial difficulty at its very
        foundation, and this Court has no hesitation in observing that it does
        not even superficially disclose a prima facie case.

        (H) Alleged Role of A-4 and A-5 in the 36-Page Printout and the
        Second Draft GoM Report dated 19.03.2021
   698.                     The prosecution has laid considerable emphasis on the
        allegation that members of the so-called “South Group”, particularly
        A-4 and A-5, stayed at Hotel Oberoi between 14.03.2021 and
        17.03.2021 and, during this period, caused a 36-page document to be
        printed. It is alleged that this document was handed over to A-3,
        thereafter reaching A-8, and that it ultimately formed the foundation
        of the second draft of the GoM Report dated 19.03.2021. This issue
        has already been examined in detail in paragraphs 326 to 339, wherein
        the material on record and the sequence of events were analysed clause
        by clause.

   699.                     As noted in the earlier discussion, the clauses contained
        in the second draft GoM Report do not, on their plain reading, reflect
        any structural advantage to M/S Indospirit. On the contrary, certain
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
conditions incorporated in the draft, most notably the requirement of a
        minimum turnover of ₹500 crores per annum for the preceding five
        financial years, would, if applied, have rendered M/S Indospirit
        ineligible for consideration of an L-1 licence. It is not disputed that
        A-5 was a partner in M/S Indospirit. The record further indicates that
        even when the eligibility threshold was subsequently reduced to ₹150
        crores per annum for the preceding three years, the entity faced
        difficulty in meeting the criteria and securing the L-1 licence.

   700.                     In this context, the prosecution’s narrative presents an
        inherent inconsistency. If A-5 was indeed acting with the object of
        securing benefit for M/S Indospirit and facilitating recoupment of
        alleged “upfront money”, it is difficult to reconcile such an objective
        with the introduction or endorsement of a clause that effectively
        disqualified the very entity in which he held a partnership interest. A
        turnover requirement of ₹500 crores for five years operates as an
        exclusionary condition. It does not appear tailored to advance M/S
        Indospirit’s eligibility; rather, it places it outside the zone of
        consideration. No satisfactory explanation has been offered as to why
        a participant in the alleged conspiracy would support a stipulation
        detrimental to his own firm.

   701.                     The prosecution nevertheless seeks to rely upon the
        subsequent receipt of ₹29.29 crores by A-5 as profit from M/S
        Indospirit, projecting it as indicative of recoupment and as lending

support to the broader conspiracy theory. However, profit distribution
        within a partnership, in the absence of material demonstrating an
        unlawful source or a direct nexus between the impugned policy clause
        and the alleged gain, cannot by itself sustain such an inference. When
        the chronology of events and the substantive content of the draft
        clauses are considered alongside the financial position of M/S
        Indospirit at the relevant time, the allegation that the 36-page
        document was conceived as an instrument of preferential treatment or
        structured recoupment does not withstand close scrutiny.

   702.                     It has already been discussed that the alleged printout
        taken from Hotel Oberoi is stated to be of 36 pages, whereas the
        Second GoM Report runs into 38 pages. The prosecution attempts to
        reconcile this difference by suggesting that if the first and last pages
        are excluded, the remaining 36 pages correspond to the printout. On
        that basis, it is argued that certain pages were handed over to the
        Personal Secretary and thereafter to the stenographer for typing,
        thereby connecting the hotel printout with the Second GoM draft.

   703.                     This reasoning does not withstand scrutiny. The printout
        itself was never recovered. In the absence of the original document,
        identity cannot be established merely by referring to the number of
        pages. A document is proved by its contents, not by arithmetic. Even
        if two documents contain an equal number of pages, that by itself does
        not establish that they are identical.

704.                     The prosecution’s own witnesses on this aspect, PW-71
        and PW-72, do not support the present theory. PW-71 has stated that
        the document was around 20–25 pages. PW-72 has stated that it was
        approximately 25–30 pages. Neither witness refers to a 36-page
        document. If these two witnesses are relied upon as independent links
        in the chain, their statements assume significance. Their version is
        plainly inconsistent with the suggestion that the printout was of 36
        pages.

   705.                     When the page count spoken to by the witnesses does
        not match the figure now sought to be relied upon, the foundation itself
        gets eorded. The attempt to equate a supposed 36-page printout with a
        38-page draft by excluding two pages is, at best, speculative,
        particularly when the primary document is not before the Court.

   706.                     In these circumstances, the theory advanced by the
        prosecution stands contradicted by its own evidence. After examining
        the statements of PW-71 and PW-72, it ought to have been apparent
        that the allegation lacked factual support. The introduction of such an
        allegation, unsupported by the prosecution’s own witnesses, gives rise
        to a legitimate concern that it was inserted to cast a cloud over the
        process and to create an impression of impropriety. Sensationalism can
        never be the objective of an investigating agency. The sole object of
        investigation must remain the discovery of truth.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

(I) Alleged Proxy Induction of A-5 and Recoupment Theory —
        Assessment in the Context of Profit Distribution and larger
        conspiracy.
   707.                     The controversy regarding the transfer of approximately
        61% of the profits from M/S Indospirit to A-5 has already been
        comprehensively addressed. Even at the cost of repetition, it is
        observed that on examination of the contemporaneous record,
        particularly Document D-9 and the Joint Venture Agreement, it was
        found that the routing of profits was founded on a prior mutual
        understanding among the partners, was consensual in nature, and was
        not shown to contravene any statutory provision, contractual
        restriction, or clause of the Excise Policy. No material was identified
        to suggest clandestine diversion, illegality, or linkage with any act of
        corruption. The legal position under the Partnership Act and the
        Evidence Act was also analysed, and it was concluded that
        disproportionate distribution of profits, by itself, does not attract
        criminality in the absence of a demonstrated illegal source or causal
        nexus with an unlawful act.

   708.                     Even so, when the matter is revisited from the standpoint
        of alleged conspiracy, the prosecution’s further projection requires
        scrutiny. It has been suggested that the induction of A-5 into the
        partnership of M/S Indospirit was engineered on the premise that he
        was merely a nominee or front for A-17 (K. Kavitha) and that the
        substantial portion of profits routed to him represented recoupment for

her benefit. This assertion, though pressed with emphasis, is
        unsupported by any material demonstrating that A-5 held his interest
        benami or that the profits credited to him were ever transferred
        onward, shared with, or placed under the dominion or control of A-17
        (K. Kavitha). There is no documentary trail, banking evidence,
        communication, or witness statement establishing any obligation on
        his part to account for such profits to her. A theory of recoupment
        necessarily presupposes proof of the onward flow of funds to the
        alleged ultimate beneficiary. In the absence of even a specific
        allegation identifying the manner, mode, or occasion of such transfer,
        much less proof thereof, the proxy narrative remains without factual
        foundation.

   709.                     It is true that conspiracies are seldom proved by direct
        evidence and may legitimately be inferred from surrounding
        circumstances. However, such inference must arise from a firmly
        established chain of material facts pointing towards a meeting of
        minds and a shared unlawful object. Each link in that chain must be
        supported by tangible evidence, and the cumulative circumstances
        must reasonably exclude an innocent explanation. The mere fact that
        profits accrued in a particular proportion, or that one partner received
        a dominant share, does not by itself constitute evidence of conspiracy
        in the absence of proof that the income was illegally generated or
        diverted. Criminal liability cannot be inferred from commercial

structuring alone. Where contemporaneous documentation reflects a
        lawful and consensual arrangement, and where no material connects
        the impugned profits to the alleged beneficiary, the superimposition of
        a conspiracy theory rests on suspicion rather than substantiated
        inference and does not disclose even a prima facie case.

        (J) Allegation against A-4 for Coordinating the Amount Received from
        Approver PW-226

   710.                     Upon a conjoint reading of the main charge-sheet as well
        as the supplementary charge-sheets, the prosecution case emerges to
        the effect that the alleged “upfront money” was initially generated by
        the so-called South Group, transferred to Delhi, and thereafter routed
        to Goa through hawala channels with the assistance of Angadia
        operators. The total quantum of such alleged illegal gratification is
        projected to be in the range of ₹90–100 crores. Out of this amount, a
        sum of ₹44.5 crores is stated to have been transported to Goa and
        attributed to A-16.

   711.                     Significantly, out of the aforesaid ₹44.5 crores, an
        amount of ₹25 crores is alleged to be the very sum paid by the
        approver PW-226 at the instance of A-17, K. Kavitha. As per the
        prosecution, this ₹25 crores moved from PW-226 through PW-227
        (stated to be a Personal Assistant at the Chennai office) to certain
        unidentified persons. At this juncture, the chain of movement
        admittedly breaks. Thereafter, the prosecution seeks to re-commence

a separate chain, allegedly beginning from Delhi, tracing movement
        of cash through Dinesh Arora (PW-20), Ashok Kaushik (PW-195),
        Vinod Chandel (A-21), Mohit (A-22), Chandan Mishra (Angadia,
        Delhi), and thereafter through an Angadia firm (Kantilal group), via
        PW-180 (Sagar Patel), culminating in alleged delivery to A-16.

   712.                     The specific allegation against A-4 is that, out of the said
        ₹25 crores, he personally coordinated a sum of ₹15 crores forming
        part of the amount allegedly paid by PW-226.

   713.                     The approver PW-20, in his statement, asserts that the
        cash amount constituting the alleged “upfront money” reached Delhi
        through hawala channels. However, the material on record is
        conspicuously silent as to any evidentiary link demonstrating that the
        amount allegedly paid at Chennai by PW-226 was ever transported to
        Delhi. In the absence of any such material, a fundamental question
        arises as to how it can be assumed that the amount which allegedly
        reached Goa was the very same amount paid by PW-226.

   714.                     This lacuna assumes heightened significance for the
        additional reason that PW-227 has failed to disclose essential
        particulars such as the place, date, mode, identity of the recipient, or
        even the phone numbers involved in the alleged payment of ₹15
        crores. The prosecution material is entirely silent on these foundational
        aspects.

715.                     It is no doubt settled that, at the stage of charge, even a
        broken or incomplete chain may, in a given case, be sufficient for
        consideration. However, where the witnesses relied upon are
        themselves participants in the alleged movement of large cash
        amounts, having admittedly aided the purported conspiracy by acts of
        abetment, their statement cannot be treated as independent
        corroboration of the approver PW-226 on material particulars. Such
        witnesses fall within the category of accomplice-like witnesses, whose
        statements require independent corroboration from unimpeachable
        material. It is also well settled that one accomplice cannot corroborate
        another. Reliance is placed upon the judgments of Hon’ble Supreme
        Court in K. Hashim (supra), Somasundaram (supra), Laxmipat
        Choraria (supra) and A.R. Antulay (supra).

   716.                     The deficiency becomes more pronounced when it is
        noticed that there is not a single statement of any Angadia or
        intermediary who allegedly transferred the sum of ₹25 crores from
        Chennai to Delhi. The absence of such evidence is material,
        particularly because this ₹25 crores is the sole amount which the
        prosecution seeks to connect directly to the South Group through the
        statement of PW-226.

   717.                     It is this very amount which the prosecution alleges was
        decided upon in the meeting dated 18.06.2021 at ITC Kohinoor,
        Hyderabad, where it is claimed that a sum ranging between ₹20–30

crores was to be paid by A-4 (South Group) to A-3. However, even
        this allegation suffers from material inconsistencies. In the main
        charge-sheet, the period of payment is projected as July to September,
        whereas in the supplementary charge-sheet, the timeline is shifted to
        June. Further, the payment allegedly made by PW-226 through
        PW-227 is stated to comprise ₹10 crores in March and ₹15 crores in
        June.

   718.                     The prosecution material is conspicuously silent on the
        identity of the person who received the alleged cash, the manner of its
        delivery, and the route by which it allegedly reached Delhi. Despite
        this, the prosecution projects this chain as the only “complete” chain
        connecting the South Group to the alleged funds reaching Goa.

   719.                     In the absence of evidence any material continuity of
        movement, identity of recipients, corroboration by independent
        intermediaries, or documentary support for inter-city transfer of cash,
        the prosecution’s theory of movement of proceeds of crime rests on
        assumptions and inferential leaps rather than legally admissible
        material. Consequently, the alleged linkage between the payment
        attributed to PW-226, including the ₹15 crores alleged to have been
        coordinated by A-4, and the funds allegedly reaching Goa through
        Delhi remains unsubstantiated and incapable of sustaining a prima
        facie inference of a continuous, unified money trail.

        (K) Impleadment of A-6, Mootha Gautham

720.                     In this factual backdrop, the Court finds no legally
        sustainable basis for impleading A-6 as an accused. The prosecution
        does not allege that he participated in the conspiracy, nor does it
        attribute to him knowledge of the alleged conspiracy or awareness that
        the monies received by him were tainted. The sole circumstance relied
        upon is receipt of funds through disclosed banking channels. In the
        absence of any allegation of mens rea, agreement, or conscious
        facilitation, such material is insufficient to attract criminal liability.
        The impleadment of A-6 has, in turn, subjected media entities, IANPL
        and APPL, to extensive investigative scrutiny without any
        foundational material demonstrating their nexus with the alleged
        excise policy conspiracy. The investigation appears to have expanded
        beyond its legitimate scope, converting ordinary commercial and
        media transactions into objects of criminal suspicion without
        establishing the essential ingredients of any offence.

   721.                     When the above material is read as a whole, two features
        stand out:               (i) the prosecution challenges ordinary private
        documentation                 on     a    legally     incorrect           premise
        (registration/notarisation), and (ii) the prosecution simultaneously
        ignores its own chronology showing pre-existing investment intent
        (October 2020), pre-existing transactions (from 10.11.2020), and
        continous and documented corporate transactions beginning, well
        before the alleged conspiracy is said to have taken shape. The narrative
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
now projected is, therefore, not an inference flowing from evidence; it
        is a post-facto construction which attempts to fit pre-existing
        commercial activity into a conspiracy framework by reversing the
        sequence of events. Such an approach does not assist the Court; it risks
        misleading the Court into treating chronology-defying suspicion as
        incriminating material. At the stage of framing of charge, conjecture
        and narrative cannot substitute for legally admissible circumstances
        disclosing the ingredients of the alleged offences.

        Allegation against A-9

   722.                     The prosecution attributes to A-9 (Amandeep Singh
        Dhall) a role in the alleged conspiracy on the premise that Brindco
        Sales Pvt. Ltd. (BSPL), as a wholesaler, issued credit notes, trade
        incentives and other commercial adjustments to retail licensees, which
        are alleged to have functioned as a conduit for generation and layering
        of illicit funds linked to the DEP-21/22. It is further alleged that these
        mechanisms facilitated undue benefit to select retail entities and were
        utilised, directly or indirectly, for diversion of funds towards political
        purposes, including the Goa Assembly Elections 2022.

   723.                     The case against A-9, as projected, does not rest on any
        allegation of his participation in policy formulation or interaction with
        public servants at the decision-making stage. Rather, it proceeds on an
        inference drawn from post-policy commercial transactions undertaken
        by M/S BSPL in the course of wholesale operations, sought to be

characterised as being in furtherance of the larger conspiracy. The
        prosecution seeks to rely on accounting entries, credit-note data and
        statements of approvers and corporate witnesses to suggest that M/S
        BSPL’s commercial practices were not merely market-driven but were
        designed to camouflage proceeds of crime.

        Analysis

        (i) Alleged Presence of A-9 in the Meeting at Gauri Apartment

   724.                     The prosecution alleges that a meeting was held at Gauri
        Apartment, Delhi on 21.05.2021. In support of the occurrence of the
        said meeting, reliance is primarily placed upon the statements of PW-1
        and PW-2. However, a close and careful reading of their statements
        reveals that neither PW-1 nor PW-2 has named or referred to the
        presence of A-9 at the said meeting. The approver, PW-20, who is
        projected by the prosecution as a pivotal witness and whose statements
