        form the backbone of the prosecution narrative, has also not stated
        anything to suggest the presence or participation of A-9 in the said
        meeting.

   725.                     The investigating agency has nonetheless sought to
        project that, during the said meeting, discussions took place to the
        effect that A-9 would issue credit notes to retail zones allegedly
        controlled by the so-called “South Group”. This assertion, however,
        stands in stark contrast to the prosecution’s own version as set out in

the main charge-sheet. In the main charge-sheet, while referring to the
        meeting at Gauri Apartment, it is specifically stated that the meeting
        was attended by Accused Nos. A-3, A-10, A-4 and A-5, along with
        PW-1, PW-2 and approver PW-20. The omission of A-9 from this list
        is not incidental, but conspicuous. The alleged presence of A-9 thus
        finds no support from the statements of PW-1, PW-2 or PW-20, all of
        whom are prosecution witnesses and are stated to have been present
        and participating in the meeting.

   726.                     It assumes significance that the prosecution itself places
        substantial reliance on the statements of approver PW-20, including
        his statements recorded under Sections 161 and 164 of Cr.P.C. as well
        as under Section 306(4)/306(6) of CrPC after tender of pardon, which
        the investigating agency asserts to be a “full and true disclosure”.
        Despite multiple statements made by PW-20 at different stages, there
        is a complete absence of any assertion regarding the presence, role or
        involvement of A-9 in the said meeting. In this factual backdrop, the
        subsequent attempt by the prosecution to establish the presence of A-9
        solely on the basis of mobile phone tower-location data warrants close
        judicial scrutiny.

   727.                     The central question that arises is whether, in the face of
        categorical statements of the alleged participants of the meeting, who
        neither name A-9 nor attribute any role to him, the prosecution can
        nonetheless rely upon tower-location data to assert his presence. The

answer must necessarily be in the negative. Tower-location evidence,
        by its very nature, is incapable of pinpointing the precise physical
        location of a mobile phone or its user. Such evidence, at best, indicates
        a broad geographical area and cannot override direct oral statement of
        witnesses who were admittedly present at the meeting. Reliance on
        tower-location data, particularly when it runs contrary to the
        prosecution’s own primary and star witnesses, does not advance the
        prosecution case and, in fact, erodes its internal consistency. At the
        stage of framing of charge, such material does not meet the threshold
        required to sustain the allegation of A-9’s participation in the
        meeting.

   728.                     The shift in the prosecution’s stand from the main
        charge-sheet to the first supplementary charge-sheet is also of
        considerable relevance. The apparent necessity to introduce tower-
        location evidence to show the presence of A-9 indicates that, without
        such a projection, the subsequent allegation relating to issuance of
        credit notes to the South Group could not be connected to the alleged
        meeting or brought within the fold of the conspiracy narrative. The
        absence of A-9 from the said meeting, as borne out from the statements
        of PW-1, PW-2 and PW-20, renders the foundational premise of
        conspiracy qua A-9 legally tenuous and factually unsupported, even
        on the standard applicable at the stage of charge.

729.                     It is further material to note that none of the witnesses
        stated to be present at the meeting have spoken about any discussion
        relating to recoupment of alleged “upfront money” through issuance
        of credit notes. On the contrary, the discussion, as emerging from the
        statements on record, was confined to issues relating to taking of retail
        zones and arrangement of manpower for running the retail vends. This
        assumes importance, as the prosecution seeks to retrospectively graft
        the theory of recoupment through credit notes onto a meeting where
        no such discussion has been spoken to by any participant.

   730.                     Equally significant is the fact that A-9 is not shown to be
        present in any other alleged conspiratorial meeting. The prosecution
        has also not relied upon tower-location data to place him at the venues
        of other meetings said to be part of the conspiracy. Had such material
        existed, it would ordinarily have found mention in the record. The
        selective invocation of tower-location evidence, confined only to the
        Gauri Apartment meeting, further weakens the prosecution’s attempt
        to establish continuity or participation of A-9 in the alleged
        conspiracy.

   731.                     The prosecution has additionally relied upon the
        statement of Varun Chaudhary (PW-6) to suggest that a petition
        regarding cartelisation under the DEP-21/22 was filed at the behest of
        A-9. This allegation, however, sits uneasily with the prosecution’s own
        theory of conspiracy, in which A-9 is projected as a conspirator.

Admittedly, A-9 neither controlled any retail zone nor was he a
        manufacturer. He is not alleged to be a recipient of any upfront
        payment, nor is his company shown to have any association with any
        of the alleged beneficiary entities. The sole allegation against him
        pertains to issuance of so-called non-manufacturer credit notes,
        quantified by the investigating agency at ₹2.58 crores, an amount that
        appears wholly disproportionate and insignificant when juxtaposed
        against the prosecution’s own allegation of recoupment of ₹100
        crores, and that too spread over the entire period of subsistence of the
        Excise Policy.

   732.                     Viewed cumulatively, the material placed on record does
        not disclose any credible, cogent or consistent basis to establish either
        the presence or the role of A-9 in the alleged meeting at Gauri
        Apartment on 21.05.2021. Nor does it sustain the prosecution’s
        attempt to weave the allegation of issuance of credit notes into the
        broader narrative of criminal conspiracy. Even at the threshold stage
        of framing of charge, the record does not give rise to the degree of
        suspicion required in law and rests instead on conjecture and post-
        facto reconstruction rather than on reliable and consistent material.

        (ii) Cash of ₹34,23,172/- is alleged to have been collected from M/S
        Ace Finance Private Limited in lieu of an equivalent amount of credit
        notes issued by A-9.
   733.                     The allegation is that, as per an understanding and on the
        directions of A-3, A-9 (M/S BSPL) issued credit notes in favour of

M/S Ace Finance Private Limited on 18.04.2022 and 12.05.2022, and
        that, in lieu thereof, a total cash amount of ₹34,23,172/- was collected
        by the approver PW-20 from M/S Ace Finance Private Limited. It is
        further the case of the prosecution that the said amount of ₹34,23,172/-
        was ultimately handed over to A-4.

   734.                     As per the material placed on record (D-185), it emerges
        that a total of 36 credit notes are stated to have been issued by A-9
        (M/S BSPL) to M/S Ace Finance Private Limited, which admittedly
        operated two retail zones. However, the ledger (D-183) relied upon by
        the prosecution does not reflect these credit-note transactions in their
        entirety. Consequently, it becomes apparent that the said ledger does
        not depict the complete transactional dealings of M/S Ace Finance
        Private Limited, notwithstanding the fact that the period reflected
        therein spans from 1 April 2021 to 31 March 2023.

   735.                      In this backdrop, a foundational question arises as to
        whether such selective ledger entries can be treated as admissible or
        reliable under Section 34 of the Indian Evidence Act. In this context,
        it is material to note that what has been produced is an Excel-sheet
        printout in the form of a ledger containing selective entries, and not
        the complete books of account maintained in the ordinary course of
        business. The Supreme Court has authoritatively held that loose sheets
        or selective extracts, divorced from an integrated and regularly
        maintained system of accounts, do not qualify as “books of account”

within the meaning of Section 34 (Central Bureau of Investigation v.
        V.C. Shukla (1998) 3 SCC 410).

   736.                     This infirmity is further aggravated by the fact that no
        corresponding bank account entries evidencing withdrawal of the
        alleged cash amounts have been relied upon by the prosecution, nor
        has the voucher book or primary vouchers underlying the ledger
        entries been produced. It is well settled that entries in books of
        account, even when regularly kept, are at best corroborative and
        cannot, by themselves, fasten liability. The absence of such primary
        and corroborative material materially diminishes the evidentiary value
        of the ledger entries, which are, in any event, secondary records.

   737.                     The aforesaid deficiencies are further compounded and
        travel to the threshold of inadmissibility by the fact that PW-106 has
        categorically stated that his company stands closed and, further, that
        no certificate under Section 65-B of the Indian Evidence Act has been
        filed. Additionally, neither the electronic device nor the accounting
        system from which the ledger was generated has been seized. In the
        absence of compliance with Section 65-B, electronic records lack
        admissibility (Anvar P.V. v. P.K. Basheer, (2014) 10 SCC 473 and
        Vinubhai Haribhai Malaviya vs. State of Gujrat (2019) 17 SCC1).

   738.                     The Special Expenses Ledger (D-184) reflects two
        entries of cash payments of ₹25 lakhs each, dated 27.12.2021 and
        16.05.2022, allegedly made to PW-20 (the approver). Significantly,

these two entries have not been associated by the prosecution with any
        alleged recoupment conspiracy. This Court also finds that no
        corresponding bank withdrawal entries, withdrawal slips, or cash-
        withdrawal instruments have been brought on record to establish the
        source or even the existence of such cash.

   739.                     Equally significant is the fact that PW-20 himself has
        not stated the receipt of cash amounting to ₹34,55,912/- either in his
        confessional statement recorded under Section 164 of CrPC (pre-
        pardon) or in his statement recorded under Section 306(4) of CrPC
        (post-pardon). This alleged transaction finds mention for the first time
        only in a supplementary statement recorded under Section 161 of
        CrPC on 05.04.2023.

   740.                     It is also well settled that ledger entries, even if assumed
        to be genuine, do not constitute substantive or independent evidence
        and can be used only for corroboration. Moreover, the version of
        PW-20 has to be treated merely as approver statement, it would still
        require independent corroboration on material particulars, in
        accordance with settled law, which is conspicuously absent. Reliance
        is again placed upon the judgments of Hon’ble Supreme Court in K.
        Hashim (supra), Somasundaram (supra), Laxmipat Choraria (supra)
        and A.R. Antulay (supra), (Laxmipat Choraria (supra); R.
        Dineshkumar @ Deena (supra).

741.                     In an attempt to supply such corroboration, the
        prosecution relies upon the statements of PW-1 and PW-106.
        However, on a careful examination of their statements, it becomes
        evident that PW-1 and PW-106 cannot be treated as independent
        witnesses, as their statements disclose circumstances suggestive of
        intentional participation or facilitation in the alleged acts. Their
        evidence, therefore, attracts the settled rule of prudence applicable to
        accomplice-like witnesses and cannot furnish the independent
        corroboration required in law.

   742.                     At this juncture, an additional circumstance arises which
        further undermines the prosecution case and remains wholly
        unexplained. If M/S Ace Finance Private Limited was not a participant
        in the alleged conspiracy, no plausible explanation is forthcoming as
        to why it would agree to release cash merely upon receipt of credit
        notes. This aspect assumes significance in light of the statement of
        PW-2 (Sikander Maan), who is stated to be associated with ADS
        Spirits and is the uncle of PW-1 (Virat Mann), and who has stated that
        the cash amount was released by PW-106, the owner of M/S Ace
        Finance Private Limited, at his request.

   743.                     PW-2 has stated that his relationship with A-4 had
        become strained on account of A-4 having removed the staff provided
        by him, which he has described in the following words:
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
“Mera karya in logon ke sath theek raha lekin February 2022
                main Abhishek Boinpally ne mere saare aadmiyon ko apni
                sharan ke dukaanon se hatha diya aur meri koi bhi madad karne
                se mana kar dia aur phone uthana band kar dia.”
   744.                     In the face of such admitted strain in relations with A-4,
        the prosecution has offered no explanation as to why Virat Mann
        would nonetheless facilitate or assist the approver PW-20, who is
        projected to be acting on behalf of A-4. This aspect renders the
        prosecution version inherently improbable and remains unaccounted
        for on the material placed on record.

   745.               The ledger entries themselves record narrations such as:

        • “18.04.2022 – Being cash sent to Hauz Khas, approved by Virat
        Sir”

        • “12.05.2022 – Being cash paid to Harjinder Ji (Brindco)”

   746.                     Notably, neither of these entries names PW-20 (Dinesh
        Arora) or Vijay Nair (A-3), against whom the principal allegations are
        sought to be levelled. This omission assumes significance, particularly
        when contrasted with the Special Expenses Ledger, where PW-20 is
        expressly referred to by the code name “Mango”. The absence of any
        reference to PW-20 or A-3 (Vijay Nair) in the impugned entries
        materially weakens the prosecution’s attempt to link these ledger
        notations to the accused persons.

747.                     It is also pertinent to observe that it is not the
        prosecution’s case that M/S BSPL itself received the cash amounts.
        Had that been so, one would reasonably expect the ledger entries to be
        supported by corresponding bank credits, acknowledgments, or
        voucher-level documentation, none of which have been relied upon.
        On the contrary, the entries placed on record do not support such a
        theory. While some witnesses have suggested that the cash payment
        entries ought to have been made after receipt of rebate, particularly
        with reference to the entry dated 12.05.2022, such assertions rest
        solely on interpretation of the ledger entries, and not on any
        independent banking, voucher, or contemporaneous documentary
        evidence.

   748.                     Viewed cumulatively, the material relied upon by the
        prosecution, being selective ledger extracts, unsupported by
        corresponding bank withdrawal entries, voucher books, primary
        vouchers, electronic certification, or consistent independent oral
        statement, falls short of the legal threshold required even at the stage
        of charge and does not, by itself, give rise to a grave or legally
        sustainable suspicion against the accused.

        Issuance of Credit Notes

   749.                     Under the DEP-21/22, the wholesale and retail liquor
        trade stood fully privatised. In such a market structure, the issuance of

credit notes by manufacturers to retailers, routed through wholesalers,
        formed part of ordinary commercial practice. Owing to fixed margins
        and high operating costs, manufacturers issued credit notes to support
        sales or to adjust earlier transactions. The wholesaler acted only as a
        conduit in the supply chain and exercised no independent discretion in
        this regard. A credit note did not involve any payment of cash and
        operated solely as an accounting adjustment against future supplies.

   750.                     It is an admitted position that the issuance of credit notes
        was not per se illegal and did not violate the DEP-21/22. Viewed in
        this background, the allegation that credit notes were issued to the so-
        called “South Group” as a mode of recoupment requires careful
        scrutiny and must rest on clear and independent evidence, and not on
        inferences drawn merely from a lawful commercial practice.

        Issuance of Credit Notes by UBL to Certain Entities for Alleged
        Adjustment of Amounts Kept for the South Group by A-9

   751.                     The material relied upon by the prosecution in relation
        to the issuance of credit notes by the manufacturer, United Breweries
        Limited (UBL), indicates that credit notes aggregating to ₹14.78
        crores (D-130) were issued to the wholesaler for onward adjustment at
        the retail level. The prosecution does not dispute the issuance of these
        credit notes in their entirety; its objection is confined to a sum of ₹2.78
        crores, which is alleged to have been passed on during November 2022
        and February-March 2023 to certain retailers, namely M/S JSN

Infratech, M/S Samaria Technologies Pvt. Ltd., M/S Grow Tradex and
        M/S Adharv Enterprises, against the sale of beer. The allegation
        proceeds on the premise that the said amount represented an
        adjustment of sums allegedly meant for certain retailers after
        registration of the case.

   752.                     It is also relevant that the DEP-21/22 came into force on
        17.11.2021 and remained operative only for a limited period, before
        being withdrawn and replaced after 31.08.2022. The abrupt
        withdrawal of the policy created a situation that was not contemplated
        by the manufacturer, the wholesaler or the retailers at the time when
        their commercial arrangements were structured. The liquor trade
        operates on a daily basis, involving continuous movement of stock and
        a constant need to meet demand and supply. In such circumstances,
        post-withdrawal accounting adjustments, including reconciliation of
        credits and incentives earned on the basis of prior sales, cannot be
        treated as simple or mechanical exercises.

   753.                     The manner in which the allegation is framed is also of
        relevance. The disputed credit notes are not projected as part of the
        original conspiracy but are sought to be characterised as a subsequent
        act, allegedly undertaken after registration of the case, either to
        conceal earlier transactions or to avoid criminal liability. Even if taken
        at face value, such an allegation attributes the conduct to a post-

registration stage and does not, by itself, disclose a prior meeting of
        minds or a continuing conspiratorial arrangement.

   754.                     It is further of significance that the quantum of the
        disputed amount is, by itself, wholly disproportionate to the allegation
        of recoupment of ₹100 crores. Even assuming the prosecution case at
        its highest, no material has been placed on record to show that the said
        amount was earmarked, reserved or intended for the so-called South
        Group. There is no documentary trail, instruction or supporting
        material connecting the impugned credit notes with any such alleged
        beneficiary. At the highest, even if the prosecution version is stretched
        to its outer limits, the allegation would amount to a commercial or
        contractual dispute between private parties rather than the commission
        of a criminal offence.

   755.                     The prosecution further proceeds on the assumption that
        the manufacturer approved or issued credit notes merely at the instance
        of the wholesaler. The record, however, indicates that the credit notes
        were issued by the manufacturer pursuant to declared schemes linked
        to volume of sales. The liquor trade under the DEP-21/22 was
        regulated, with lifting, sales and payments being subject to
        contemporaneous data and regulatory oversight, shared among the
        relevant stakeholders. The issuance of credit notes thus remained
        linked to recorded sales performance and is not shown to be capable
        of unilateral manipulation by the wholesaler.

756.                     It is also material that the manufacturer has not disputed
        the issuance of the impugned credit notes and has stated that they were
        issued strictly in accordance with its sales-based schemes. No material
        has been placed on record to suggest that these credit notes were issued
        dehors the declared scheme or in deviation from actual sales data.

   757.                     The   considered cumulatively material does not rise
        above conjecture and, at best, falls short of even raising a reasonable
        suspicion, far less the grave suspicion required in law to justify the
        framing of charge.

        Outcome after Evaluation

        Failure of the Prosecution’s Conspiracy Theory qua A-9

   758.                     The prosecution seeks to project the existence of a wider
        criminal conspiracy involving public servants, certain private
        individuals described as the “South Group”, and selected business
        entities, with the alleged object of influencing policy formulation,
        securing favourable licensing outcomes, and generating illegal
        gratification through upfront payments and commercial arrangements.
        The sustainability of such a charge necessarily depends upon the
        establishment of a prima facie meeting of minds, a discernible role
        attributed to each accused, and an identifiable unlawful gain flowing
        from the alleged conspiracy.

759.                     Even in relation to M/S Indospirit, the prosecution
        attempts to construct a chain of circumstances by referring to the grant
        of the L-1 licence, the allegation of payment of ₹30 lakhs (upfront
        amount) as illegal gratification, the cartelisation complaint involving
        M/S KGRL attributed to A-7, the participation of A-5 and PW-275
        (Prem R. Manduri) as partners allegedly representing the “South
        Group”, the projected involvement of A-4, and the allegation that
        A-3 exerted pressure upon M/S PRI to appoint M/S Indospirit as its
        distributor.

   760.                     No such narrative, however, exists qua M/S BPSL or
        A-9. The prosecution has not alleged that A-9 played any role in policy
        formulation, influenced any public servant, facilitated the grant of any
        licence, participated in cartelisation, or exercised pressure upon any
        manufacturer or distributor. More importantly, there is a complete
        absence of any allegation or material suggesting any interaction, direct
        or indirect, between A-9 and any member of the so-called “South
        Group” in relation to coordination, financial dealing, or concerted
        action between A-9 and those who are alleged to have made upfront
        payments.

   761.                     At the stage of framing of charge, the court is required to
        assess whether the material on record gives rise to grave suspicion.
        Such suspicion cannot rest on conjecture or association by proximity.
        It must be founded on material indicating a meeting of minds and a

role played in furtherance of the alleged conspiracy. Equally material
        is the requirement to show what unlawful gain or advantage A-9 stood
        to derive from the alleged arrangement. In the present case, the
        prosecution has failed to indicate what benefit, commercial, monetary,
        or otherwise, could have accrued to A-9 or M/S BPSL from the alleged
        conspiracy. There is no allegation of payment of bribe by A-9, no
        allegation of receipt of illegal gratification, and no assertion of any
        quid pro quo involving public servants.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   762.                     The case against A-9 rests primarily on vague references
        to an “arrangement” attributed to the approver, whether PW-20 or
        PW-226, without particulars, contemporaneous documentation, or
        independent corroboration. Such unparticularised assertions, standing
        alone, are insufficient in law to establish even a prima facie meeting
        of minds.

   763.                     This conclusion is reinforced by admitted and objective
        circumstances. There is no admissible material to suggest that A-9
        attended any meeting at Gauri Apartment. The spot identification
        memo dated 01.10.2022 (D-95) does not record his presence at the
        said location. It is undisputed that A-9 was not present at the alleged
        meeting at ITC Kohinoor, Hyderabad. Thus, the prosecution’s own
        material excludes A-9 from the meetings which are projected as
        pivotal to the alleged conspiracy.

764.                     Further, the prosecution relies upon the filing of a
        petition before the Hon’ble Supreme Court by Advocate Varun
        Chaudhary (PW-6), allegedly at the behest of A-9, challenging
        cartelisation and monopoly under the DEP-21/22. Such conduct is
        fundamentally inconsistent with the prosecution’s theory of
        conspiratorial alignment. A person who is part of a conspiracy to
        cartelise or monopolise a policy framework would not ordinarily
        sponsor or support proceedings before the highest constitutional court
        alleging cartelisation and monopoly under that very policy. This
        circumstance militates against the existence of any shared intent or
        common design.

   765.                     On   a   cumulative   assessment,   the   prosecution’s
        conspiracy theory does not sustain itself insofar as A-9 is concerned.
        The absence of interaction with the “South Group”, the lack of any
        attributed role in policy manipulation or licensing, the failure to
        demonstrate any unlawful gain, and the exclusion of A-9 from alleged
        conspiratorial meetings, render the allegation speculative. In this
        backdrop, any alleged deficiency relating to the issuance of credit
        notes cannot be examined in isolation. Such allegations must be
        assessed in the context of the prosecution’s failure to establish a
        meeting of minds or motive-linked gain, both of which are essential to
        meet the threshold of grave suspicion at the stage of charge.

Allegation against A-10

   766.                     As per the case set up by the prosecution, A-10, Arjun
        Pandey, is alleged to have functioned as a close associate and operative
        of accused Vijay Nair (A-3) and to have played an active role in the
        alleged criminal conspiracy connected with the formulation and
        implementation of the DEP-21/22. It is alleged that he, along with A-3,
        met the Secretary General of ISWAI and raised demands for undue
        gratification from liquor manufacturers on the assurance that
        favourable provisions would be incorporated in the Excise Policy. The
        prosecution further alleges that he participated in meetings held at
        Gauri Apartments, New Delhi on 21.05.2021 and thereafter at ITC
        Kohinoor, Hyderabad on 19.06.2021, where the modalities of benefit-
        sharing and recovery of alleged upfront payments were discussed.

   767.                     It is further the prosecution’s case that, during the
        relevant period, A-10 was working as President (Sales and Marketing)
        of India Ahead News, and that India Ahead News received an amount
        of ₹1 crore from M/S Indospirits, while APPL received ₹85 lakhs,
        purportedly as part of the alleged recoupment of bribe amounts under
        the guise of media-related transactions. It is alleged that India Ahead
        News, in turn, paid a sum of ₹85 lakhs to A-10 as consultancy charges.
        The prosecution also attributes to him the role of facilitating additional
        credit notes of approximately ₹1 crore for retail zones allegedly
        controlled by Raghav Reddy through accused A-9 (Amandeep Singh
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
Dhall), and alleges that he remained in constant touch with accused
        A-15 (Arvind Kumar Singh) at the time when funds were allegedly
        being routed to Goa.

   768.                     It is further alleged that A-10 was in contact with Ashok
        Kaushik (PW-195), the personal assistant of K. Kavitha, who is stated
        to have been involved in the transfer of alleged upfront money to Goa
        through Vinod Chauhan via hawala channels. On the basis of the
        aforesaid allegations, the prosecution seeks to portray A-10, as a
        facilitator forming a link between the alleged policy-level decisions,
        media entities, and the purported financial flows said to constitute the
        criminal conspiracy.

        Analysis

        (ii) Presence of A-10 in the meeting at Gauri Apartment

   769.                     It is not in dispute that during the period relevant to the
        alleged conspiracy relating to the formulation and implementation of
        the DEP-21/22, A-10 was working as the Sales and Marketing Head
        of India Ahead News Channel. His professional engagement, as borne
        out from the record, was thus confined to the media domain and did
        not, even remotely, place him within the policy-making or policy-
        implementing framework of the Excise Department.

   770.                     The prosecution seeks to draw an adverse inference
        against A-10 primarily on the basis of his alleged presence in two

meetings, one at Gauri Apartments and another at Hotel Taj Palace,
        New Delhi. However, the prosecution’s own evidence materially
        weakens this assertion. PW-1, who admittedly attended the meeting at
        Gauri Apartments, has categorically stated that although A-10 was
        present, he remained silent throughout and did not participate in the
        discussion. PW-1 and PW-2, who were also present, have consistently
        deposed that the meeting was confined to seeking manpower
        assistance, as certain private parties intended to apply for multiple
        retail zones as already discussed in detail. A careful reading of their
        statements does not disclose any discussion pertaining to manipulation
        or tweaking of the Excise Policy, involvement of public servants, or
        payment of any alleged upfront money. From the statement of the
        prosecution’s own witnesses, nothing incriminating emerges against
        A-10 beyond his mere presence, which, in law, cannot be elevated to
        culpable participation.

   771.                     With regard to the alleged meeting at Hotel Taj Palace,
        the prosecution relies solely on the presence of A-10 alongside Vijay
        Nair. The witness (PW-101) who has spoken of an alleged demand of
        bribe has not attributed any role to A-10; the allegation, such as it is,
        is specifically directed against A-3. As already discussed in this order,
        even that allegation does not find consistent support from the
        prosecution witnesses themselves. In any event, mere presence at a
        meeting, without any material showing participation before or after

the meeting or any conduct in furtherance of the alleged discussion,
        cannot be construed as aiding or abetting a conspiracy. This assumes
        added significance in light of the admitted position that A-10 neither
        directly nor indirectly applied for any wholesaler (L-1) or retail (L-7Z)
        licence under the DEP-21/22, and that IANPL likewise did not submit
        any application for such licences in respect of the works undertaken
        by him.

   772.                     The investigating agency has next attempted to link
        A-10 by referring to payments of ₹1 crore and ₹70 lakhs made by M/S
        Indospirits to APPL and IANPL The allegation has already been
        discussed. However, even at the cost of repetition it is being discussed
        to give it completion. The prosecution does not dispute that India
        Ahead was engaged in media-related activities, nor does it dispute that
        M/S Indospirits had proposed to engage the channel for
        advertisements. The transaction is sought to be characterised as sham
        merely because the amount was paid in advance and the
        advertisements were allegedly not carried out in the same manner as
        with other clients. This contention does not withstand scrutiny. The
        concept paper (D-89) itself reflects that M/S Indospirits was exploring
        engagement with India Ahead. Advance payment, by itself, is a
        common commercial practice and cannot, without anything further,
        render a transaction fictitious or colourable. Significantly, the
        aggregate amount of ₹1.7 crores is wholly inconsequential when

contrasted with the prosecution’s own allegation of illegal gratification
        running into ₹90–100 crores, thereby further eroding the suggested
        inference. If routine banking transactions are to be treated as
        incriminating circumstances, every commercial counter-party of an
        accused company would stand exposed to prosecution, a proposition
        plainly inconsistent with settled principles of criminal law. It also
        bears reiteration that even the person alleged to be controlling IANPL
        has been found to have no substantive role in the alleged conspiracy.

   773.                     The prosecution has further sought to implicate A-10 in
        the alleged movement of cash through angadias for the Goa elections,
        resting primarily on Call Detail Records showing telephonic contact
        with A-15. It is an admitted position that A-15 was working with India
        Ahead News Channel. Mere telephonic connectivity between two
        persons working in the same organisation, without any supporting
        material, cannot establish participation in the movement of funds. This
        Court also cannot ignore the inconsistency in the investigative
        approach: where CDRs exist, they are pressed into service; where they
        do not, the prosecution conveniently suggests communication through
        web-based calls. In the absence of any transcript, content, such
        material, in isolation, is incapable of sustaining any incriminating
        inference. Serious criminal liability cannot be founded on conjecture
        drawn from bare call records.

774.                     Finally, finding nothing of substance, the investigating
        agency has sought to raise suspicion on the ground that A-10 was
        drawing a salary of ₹5 lakhs per month, which is portrayed as
        exorbitant and therefore suggestive of involvement in the alleged
        conspiracy. This Court finds no basis for such an assumption. A-10
        was admittedly holding a senior position as President/Sales and
        Marketing Head of a news channel, and no material has been placed
        on record to demonstrate that the said remuneration was either
        abnormal for such a role or indicative of any illicit consideration.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   775.                     Taken individually or cumulatively, the circumstances
        relied upon by the prosecution, namely, the admitted silence of A-10
        in the meeting at Gauri Apartments, the absence of any role attributed
        to him in the alleged demand of bribe, the commercial advance paid
        by M/S Indospirits to IANPL, the bare CDRs reflecting contact with a
        co-employee without any transcript or corroboration, and the
        allegation of a “high” salary, do not give rise to grave suspicion. On
        the contrary, they reveal that in the absence of any incriminating
        material, the prosecution has attempted to stitch together innocuous
        and disconnected facts in a bid to implicate A-10, an approach that
        falls short of the threshold required even at the stage of framing of
        charge.

Allegation against A-11

   776.                     It is the case of the prosecution that A-11, Butchibabu
        Gorantla, was an active participant in the alleged conspiracy and a key
        member of the so-called “South Group”, being a close associate and
        Chartered Accountant of A-17 (K. Kavitha). It is alleged that, during
        the period when the draft of the GoM Report was under finalisation in
        March 2021, he made frequent visits to Delhi. The prosecution further
        alleges that certain provisions relating to the Excise Policy were found
        stored in his mobile phone and that such provisions were thereafter
        incorporated verbatim in the GoM Report on the Excise Policy dated
        22.03.2021. It is also alleged that A-11 was present at a meeting held
        at Gauri Apartments, Delhi, on 21.05.2021, being the date on which
        the policy was approved through circulation during the peak Covid
        period, and that he was also present at another meeting held on
        19.06.2021 at ITC Kohinoor, Hyderabad.

   777.                     According to the prosecution, during the period August,
        September 2021, A-11 received an amount of ₹1 crore from A-4
        (Abhishek Boinpally) through A-6 (Mootha Gautam), and that his
        chats reflect the involvement of A-3 (Vijay Nair), A-23 (Sarath
        Reddy), A-17 (K. Kavitha), Magunta Reddy and others. It is also
        alleged that he acted as a mediator in facilitating payment of ₹10
        crores to A-17 (K. Kavitha) by Raghav Magunta. The prosecution
        further alleges that A-11 was instrumental in a transaction involving

₹14 crores received by A-17 (K. Kavitha), wherein he allegedly
        handled the documentation and directed Madhu Gorla (PW-235) of the
        Aurobindo Group to inflate the value of the land and reflect it at least
        at ₹28 crores on paper, while also suggesting other changes. It is
        alleged that the said transaction was a sham arrangement and was
        devised as a mode for recoupment of money.

        (i) Alleged Presence of A-11 in the Meeting at Gauri Apartment

   778.                     The allegation against A-11 is that he participated in a
        meeting at Gauri Apartment, Delhi on 21.05.2021, where the
        prosecution claims that the alleged conspiracy began to take shape. To
        establish his presence, the prosecution relies upon the statements of
        the approver PW-20, PW-1 and PW-2.

   779.                     A careful and conjoint reading of these statements does
        not, however, support the prosecution narrative. What emerges from
        the statements of PW-20, PW-1 and PW-2 is only that A-4, A-5 and
        A-11 expressed an inclination to participate in the retail liquor
        business in Delhi by seeking to obtain 5 to 10 retail zones. Such an
        expression of intent was neither impermissible nor unlawful.
        Participation in the retail segment under a policy that expressly
        permitted private entry cannot, by itself, be construed as a
        conspiratorial act.

780.                     It is significant that PW-1 and PW-2, who are cited by
        the prosecution as material witnesses, have themselves been projected
        as innocent participants. No criminality has been attributed to them,
        despite their admitted presence at the said meeting and despite the fact
        that they admittedly provided staff for operating retail zones of A-4. If
        discussions relating to participation in retail zones or the provision of
        manpower were to be viewed as incriminating, the same standard
        would necessarily apply to PW-1 and PW-2. The selective attribution
        of culpability to the accused, while absolving similarly placed
        participants, materially weakens the prosecution case.

   781.                     The record further discloses a prior and close proximity
        between A-1 and A-2 and the approver PW-20, who was admittedly
        referred to by them by the nickname “Mango”. This admitted
        familiarity and association, when contrasted with the attempt to
        portray PW-1 and PW-2 as neutral or uninvolved actors, renders the
        prosecution narrative internally inconsistent.

   782.                     None of the witnesses state that, at the alleged meeting,
        there was any discussion regarding payment of bribes, adoption of
        illegal means, manipulation of policy, or involvement of any public
        servant. The statements consistently indicate that the concern of the
        so-called South Group was limited to operational aspects of entering a
        new market. Being new to the Delhi retail liquor business, they sought
        assistance from persons already engaged in the trade.

783.                      This is reflected in the statements themselves, which
        record that PW-1 and PW-2 could assist by providing experienced staff
        to operate retail vends. Such discussions are squarely within the realm
        of ordinary commercial arrangements.

   784.                     The discussion regarding taking 5 to 10 retail zones also
        cannot be characterised as criminal in nature. The allotment of retail
        zones was through a public auction process, the outcome of which was
        uncertain and dependent upon competitive bidding. There could be no
        assurance or certainty of securing any particular number of zones at
        the stage of a preliminary discussion. Notably, the prosecution has not
        alleged any manipulation, rigging or undue influence in the auction or
        allotment process. In the absence of such allegations, a mere intention
        to participate in the auction does not give rise to any inference of
        illegality.

   785.                     Even at the cost of repetition, it is stated that PW-1 has
        clearly stated that A-11 was making enquiries regarding the financial
        aspects of the Delhi liquor market. PW-1 states: “Sh Butchi Babu was
        mainly asking the questions about financial aspects of the business
        that how is the Delhi market , how we can make profits .”

   786.                     When this deposition is read alongside the prosecution
        narrative, an evident inconsistency emerges. The record indicates that
        even in May 2021, A-11 was seeking to understand the profitability,
        operational contours and commercial feasibility of the Delhi market.

At the same time, the prosecution asserts that by March 2021 a part of
        the alleged “upfront money” had already been delivered pursuant to a
        concluded arrangement.

   787.                     If that version were to be accepted, the alleged demand
        and its partial execution would have already stood crystallised.
        However, the material attributed to A-11 reflects that basic commercial
        issues, such as staffing of retail operations, setting up of shops and
        overall market viability, were still being explored. Such conduct does
        not align with the existence of a settled and pre-determined criminal
        conspiracy.

   788.                     The later portion of the statement of PW-2 further
        undermines the prosecution case. PW-2, who was admittedly
        associated with ADS Spirits and was engaged in the manufacture of
        the “Royal Green” brand of whisky, does not speak of any continuing
        interaction with the South Group. On the contrary, he states that his
        relations with A-4 became strained in February 2022 after the staff
        provided by him were removed, and that thereafter A-4 stopped
        responding to his calls. This disclosure indicates a breakdown of
        commercial association rather than the continuation of any concerted
        or conspiratorial arrangement.

   789.                     Crucially, there is a complete absence of material to
        suggest that, at the alleged meeting of 21.05.2021, there was any
        discussion concerning formulation or implementation of the Excise
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
Policy, fixation of wholesale margins, grant of licences, or any other
        regulatory or policy matter. Even if the prosecution material is taken
        at its highest, it does not disclose any deliberation touching upon abuse
        of official position or involvement of public servants.

   790.                     Viewed in this backdrop, the allegation that the meeting
        at Gauri Apartment marked the genesis of a criminal conspiracy
        involving A-11 is wholly unsupported by the record. The material
        relied upon by the prosecution reflects, at best, preliminary and lawful
        commercial discussions, devoid of any illegal objective or meeting of
        minds to commit an offence.

        (ii) Alleged Bank Transfers from A-6 to A-11 Projected as a Money
        Trail Originating from M/S Indospirit

        Analysis

   791.                     The prosecution alleges that amounts of ₹25 lakhs on
        02.08.2021, ₹20 lakhs on 07.08.2021, ₹15 lakhs on 24.08.2021 and
        ₹40 lakhs on 27.09.2021 were transferred from the bank account of
        A-6 to the account of A-11. On this basis, an attempt is made to project
        a money trail allegedly emanating from M/S Indospirit, with a further
        insinuation that A-7 was instrumental in facilitating or routing such
        funds.

   792.                     This Court is unable to discern how the said
        transactions, by themselves, can be connected to the alleged

conspiracy. As per the prosecution’s own narrative, the alleged upfront
        amount paid by the so-called South Group was to be recouped from
        future earnings generated under the DEP-21/22 through an enhanced
        wholesale margin of 12%, out of which 6% was allegedly meant for
        recoupment. Such recoupment, even on the prosecution’s case, was
        contingent upon the commencement of retail operations. Admittedly,
        retail vends commenced only on 17.11.2021.

   793.                     The transactions relied upon by the prosecution pertain
        to the period August and September 2021, a stage prior to the
        commencement of retail operations and prior to any possibility of
        revenue generation under the new policy framework. These transfers,
        therefore, cannot be reconciled with the prosecution’s own theory of
        recoupment. Rather than lending support to the allegation of
        conspiracy, the timing of these transactions negates the very
        foundation of the prosecution case on this aspect.

                                                             (emphasis supplied)

   794.                     The material placed on record, at best, indicates that
        certain financial transactions took place between accused persons.
        However, the investigating agency cannot be permitted to ascribe a
        conspiratorial colour to every such transaction in the absence of a
        demonstrable nexus with the alleged object or mechanism of the
        conspiracy. Criminal liability cannot be inferred merely on the basis

of financial dealings, unless such dealings are shown to be intrinsically
        connected with the alleged offence.
                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   795.                     Viewed in this light, the transactions relied upon by the
        prosecution do not advance its case in any manner. On the contrary,
        they undermine the prosecution’s own theory and fail to disclose any
        prima facie linkage with the alleged conspiracy. Even at the threshold
        stage, the material falls short of raising a grave suspicion so as to
        justify the framing of charge on this count.

        (iii) Allegation of A-11 Acting as a Conduit for A-17 and Alleged
        Coordination of ₹10 Crore Delivery (March 2021)

   796.                     The prosecution alleges that A-11 acted as a conduit for
        A-17 and coordinated the delivery of a sum of ₹10 crores in March
        2021. It is alleged that A-11 approached the approver (PW-226) to
        persuade him to arrange an upfront payment of ₹50 crores for entry
        into the Delhi liquor business.

   797.                     In the main charge-sheet, the prosecution projected the
        meeting at Gauri Apartment as the starting point of the alleged
        conspiracy. Subsequently, upon the introduction of PW-226 as an
        approver, the alleged genesis of the conspiracy has been shifted to a
        period prior thereto. This change is not merely temporal but strikes at
        the consistency of the prosecution narrative, as the alleged

commencement              of   the   conspiracy   is   altered   without        any
        contemporaneous documentary or independent evidentiary basis.

   798.                     As per the revised version, PW-226 allegedly agreed to
        make an upfront payment of ₹25 crores, out of which a part payment
        of ₹10 crores is stated to have been made in March 2021 at the instance
        of A-11. The prosecution claims that the said amount was delivered
        through PW-227, who was working as a personal assistant to
        PW-226.

   799.                     It is a settled principle that the statement of an approver
        cannot be relied upon unless it is independently corroborated on
        material particulars. Corroboration must come from a source which is
        reliable and independent; repetition of the approver’s version by
        persons who are themselves participants in the alleged transaction
        does not satisfy this requirement.

   800.                     The prosecution seeks to rely upon PW-225, PW-226
        and PW-227. PW-225 is admittedly projected as a participant in the
        alleged conspiracy, though examined as a prosecution witness. His
        statement, therefore, is to be treated as that of an accomplice-like
        witness. In law, an accomplice cannot corroborate the statement of an
        approver; both require independent corroboration from a source
        untainted by participation or interest.

801.                     This leaves PW-227 as the only witness sought to be
        projected as an independent link. However, his statement does not
        withstand scrutiny. PW-227 claims to have delivered the alleged
        amount but is unable to state the mobile number which was allegedly
        provided by A-11 for the purpose of delivery. He does not disclose the
        name of the person to whom the amount was delivered, nor does he
        specify the exact flat or premises where the delivery allegedly took
        place. This omission is significant, particularly when PW-227 states
        that he has been residing in Chennai for about 25 years and had
        allegedly visited the place of delivery on two occasions.

   802.                     Further, while the investigating agency has relied upon
        tower-location data to suggest meetings at places such as the Oberoi
        Hotel and Gauri Apartment no corresponding tower-location or digital
        evidence has been produced to support the allegation of delivery of
        ₹10 crores. The selective reliance on technical evidence, coupled with
        the absence of similar material for the alleged delivery, leaves a clear
        evidentiary void.

   803.                     It is also relevant that PW-227 has been associated with
        the Magunta family for over two decades. His long-standing
        association renders his statement derivative in nature and closely
        aligned with the version of the approver. His statement does not
        corroborate the approver on any material particular such as the identity

of the recipient, the exact place of delivery, or any contemporaneous
        record evidencing movement or handling of such a substantial sum.

   804.                     On a cumulative assessment, the allegation that A-11
        coordinated the delivery of ₹10 crores rests solely on the
        uncorroborated statement of the approver, sought to be supported by
        accomplice-like witnesses and a derivative account lacking material
        particulars. In the absence of independent corroboration, whether
        documentary, digital or circumstantial, the prosecution version
        remains speculative and insufficient to sustain the allegation even at
        the stage of framing of charge. Reliance is again placed upon the
        judgments of Hon’ble Supreme Court in K. Hashim (supra),
        Somasundaram (supra), Laxmipat Choraria (supra) and A.R. Antulay
        (supra).

        (iv) Contextual Evaluation of WhatsApp Chats Dated 06.03.2021 and
        20.03.2021- Policy Manipulation on the threshold of Grave
        Suspicion

   805.                     The prosecution has relied upon these chats to contend
        that on 06.03.2021 there was a plan for “tweaking” the excise policy
        and that the chat dated 20.03.2021 contains material which later found
        place in the final draft report of the GoM. In order to evaluate this
        contention, the entire content must be seen contextually; no isolated
        expression can be read divorced from the surrounding material.

806.                 The record reflects that these were not exchanges with any
        co-accused, public servant or third party. The content was transmitted
        from one device of A-11 to another device operated by him. In
        substance, therefore, the material is in the nature of personal notes or
        self-compiled drafts and not inter se communications evidencing any
        agreement or concert.

   807.                     On a plain reading, the document titled “Excise policy
        Notes” appears exploratory and descriptive rather than prescriptive in
        nature.

   808.                     The note begins with a general observation:

                “At present, Delhi government is trying to reduce the
                Government intervention, minimize the bureaucracy and
                leaving the market to market forces.”
   809.                     This statement does not contain any directive or
        proposal; it merely records a perception regarding the policy direction.
        The subsequent line continues in the same vein: “It means, the
        consumers will be benefited, government revenue will be increased.
        Also its works in favor of the mid and premium segment brands and
        not the cheap liquor.”

   810.                     These are broad commercial inferences drawn from an
        anticipated shift toward market-oriented regulation. They read as
        commentary on the perceived economic impact of a policy framework,
        not as suggestions for altering it.

811.                     It is relevant to note that at the material time the Ravi
        Dhawan Report regarding restructuring and privatization of retail
        zones was already in the public domain. Stakeholder meetings and
        deliberations were underway, and media reports had extensively
        covered the proposed shift towards privatization and reduction of
        governmental control. Seen in that backdrop, the observations
        recorded in the note cannot be treated as exclusive, confidential or
        internally sourced inputs. They reflect matters already circulating in
        public discourse. The note then expressly acknowledges uncertainty:

                “In the given scenario, as a liquor manufacturer, distributor or
                end shop owner the exact business opportunity is not known.”
   812.                     This sentence demonstrates that the author did not claim
        knowledge of any finalised structure or assured commercial benefit.
        On the contrary, it records lack of clarity regarding business
        opportunity across the spectrum, manufacturer, distributor or retailer.

   813.           The next line states:

                “In this regard, we have appointed a consultant who will give
                us the policy tweaking and give us the ins and outs of the policy
                required and presentable business opportunity.”
   814.                     When read in context with the preceding sentence, the
        expression “policy tweaking” cannot be isolated. The sentence, taken
        as a whole, reflects an attempt to understand the “ins and outs of the
        policy” and to evaluate a “presentable business opportunity.” It
        conveys commercial due diligence rather than authorship or alteration

of governmental policy. The reference to appointing a consultant
        indicates that professional assistance was sought to understand the
        contours of the policy and its business implications.

   815.                     The note further records:

                “From that view we are required make 2/3 delhi visits, detailed
                discussions, freezing the policy etc., then we know the final
                business opportunity”
   816.                     This indicates that even at that stage, the policy was not
        considered final from a commercial standpoint and required
        clarification through visits and discussions. The language suggests
        assessment and understanding, not intervention.

   817.                      The concluding portion reads:

                “However, sure short business opportunity is logistics
                management and security label printing and other security
                contracts. We are required to know the eligibilities norms”
   818.                     This   identifies   ancillary   commercial   possibilities,
        logistics management, security label printing, security contracts, and
        the need to understand eligibility norms. These are operational and
        compliance-oriented aspects. They do not relate to drafting clauses,
        determining margins, restructuring statutory provisions, or influencing
        governmental authorities.

   819.                     Another message sent shortly thereafter on 06.03.2021
        seeks information regarding the number of shops, value and volume,
        number of cases category-wise, present fees and rate structure, shops

per 10,000 population, liquor fees and duties, violation penalties,
        timings of bars, number of dry days, profits to end shop owners for the
        last three years, slab variations, brand launching formalities, and
        comparable data for Uttar Pradesh, Haryana and Punjab. The tenor of
        this message demonstrates a request for basic regulatory and statistical
        particulars. It indicates absence of familiarity with the framework and
        an attempt to gather data before assessing feasibility. The reference
        to “2/3 Delhi visits” and “detailed discussions” likewise suggests that
        further understanding was required before arriving at any conclusion
        regarding business opportunity.

   820.                     Taken together, the chats dated 06.03.2021 show: (i)
        lack of clarity regarding the business opportunity; (ii) appointment of
        a consultant for understanding the policy framework; (iii) collection
        of regulatory and statistical data of the adjoining States like Utter
        Pradesh, Haryana and Punjab and (iv) preliminary assessment of
        logistics and compliance issues. There is nothing in these messages to
        indicate         participation   in   drafting,   shaping,   or     influencing
        governmental policy. No communication is addressed to any public
        authority. No financial clause, margin structure, or revenue design is
        discussed.

   821.                 The chats dated 20.03.2021 are similarly in the form of
        internal notes. One of them is captioned:
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

“DIRECTOR WHOLE SALE OPERATIONS (new designation)
        REPORTING        TO        THE      COMMITTEE
        HE WILL DO MONITOR and AUTHORITY TO
        1 Unfair trade practices, operations and supervision of wholesale
        dealers
        2 Demand supply patterns, normalization of supplies, adhoc powers to
        regulate and monitor supplies
        3 Regular the spurious and unadulterated                suppliers/shop
        owners/distributors licenses approvals, cancellation
        4 Stocks distribution modalities
        5 Wholesale dealers Advertisements (its not allowed).
        6 Surprise checks on shops/distributor go downs.
        7 CG camera implementation at all go downs.
        8 No compounding of offence unless approved by the director and
        then committee
        9 He is a nominated person from your group who is 100% trustworthy
        and your person…
        10 On top of director, there is a committee belongs exclusively
        responsible only to you”


   822.                     This extract outlines supervisory and regulatory
        functions of a proposed “Director Whole Sale Operations.” It does not
        advert to enhancement of wholesale margin, financial structuring, or
        any revenue design.

   823.                     The second message dated 20.03.2021, under the
        heading “Elite stores,” reads: “Elite stores

1. no experience required, (other than turnover earned from
        operating an alcohol vend/store) (can we place a possible partner here
        who is eligible)
        2. can be done in a JV with a partner (who has operated or operates a
        premium store)
        3. elite stores can not be operated by a distributor or a manufacturer
        4. minimum turnover for a store owner should be Rs 50 crores (from
        one store ? per year or the last … 3 years ?)
        5. no pending cases should be there in any Delhi state ? / across
        India”
   824.                  The language is exploratory and interrogative. The figure
        mentioned is “Rs 50 crores,” framed as a query. There is no reference
        to enhancement of wholesale margin from 5% to 12%, nor to any ₹500
        crore turnover stipulation for five years, which the prosecution treats
        as central to the alleged generation of recoupment funds. There is no
        discussion of any financial mechanism or structured benefit.

   825.                     Further, as per the prosecution’s own case, a photocopy
        of the GoM Report had already been handed over which form the basis
        of second draft GoM report dated 19.03.2021 and ultimately became
        the final report. If that chronology is accepted, the report stood
        prepared prior to the chats dated 20.03.2021. The sequence of events
        does not substantiate the contention that these notes had any bearing
        on the recommendations of the GoM, nor does it establish that there
        existed any occasion or necessity for A-11 to record such notes when
        the GoM’s recommendations had already been finalized.

826.                     When read in their entirety and in light of the fact that
        the Ravi Dhawan Report and stakeholder deliberations were already
        in the public domain, the chats dated 06.03.2021 and 20.03.2021
        reflect exploratory commercial inquiry and internal assessment of
        regulatory structure and eligibility norms. They do not disclose
        participation in governmental deliberations, drafting of policy clauses,
        or any nexus with the financial components forming the basis of the
        prosecution case. Even if taken at face value, the material does not
        disclose the essential ingredients of the alleged conspiracy and does
        not give rise to grave suspicion so as to warrant framing of charge.

        (v) Examination of the Alleged Land Transaction between A-17 and
        A-23 and the Attributed Role of A-11

   827.                     So far as A-11 is concerned, the allegation regarding the
        land transaction is founded essentially on certain communications and
        his position as Chartered Accountant of A-17 (Ms. K. Kavitha).

   828.                     The record indicates that a draft Agreement of Sale
        reflecting a consideration of ₹14 crores was forwarded by A-11 to
        officials of the Aurobindo Group. Thereafter, the Agreement of Sale
        dated 12.07.2021 reflected a total consideration of ₹28 crores, with
        ₹14 crores payable as advance. Reliance is placed by the prosecution
        on a WhatsApp message attributed to A-11 stating, inter alia, “Keep at
        least 28 on paper” and suggesting removal of the interest clause. On

that basis, it is alleged that A-11 played a role in enhancing the
        consideration and structuring the agreement.

   829.                     Thus, qua A-11, the case rests primarily on: (i)
        forwarding of the draft agreement, (ii) the WhatsApp communication
        regarding enhancement of value and deletion of the interest clause,
        and (iii) subsequent messages said to indicate urgency of payment and
        sharing of allotment-related information. These circumstances are
        relied upon to suggest facilitation of the impugned transaction.

   830.                     Admittedly, the land transaction pertains to July 2021.
        The prosecution seeks to portray it as a mode of payment of alleged
        “upfront money” or as recoupment thereof. However, even in the
        conspiracy narrative set out in the charge-sheets, there is no specific
        allegation that recoupment was to be effected through retailers. There
        is no case that recovery of any alleged upfront payment was to be made
        by means of retail transactions.

   831.                     It is also not alleged that A-23 was associated with any
        wholesaler or that he had paid any upfront amount necessitating
        recoupment. The material shows that A-23 participated in bidding for
        retail zones. There is no allegation that he was involved in wholesale
        operations or that he stood to gain through wholesale margins. In the
        absence of such linkage, the premise that a land transaction involving
        him constituted recoupment lacks foundation.

832.                     Though it has been generally alleged that A-23 was
        favoured in securing five retail zones, no material has been produced
        to demonstrate manipulation of the auction process. The allotment of
        retail zones was conducted through an auction mechanism. The
        investigating agency has neither alleged that the bidding process was
        compromised nor that eligibility conditions were violated. In the
        absence of any material indicating interference or procedural breach,
        the allegation of favouritism remains unsubstantiated.

   833.                     It is further an admitted position that the land transaction
        was never fully executed and that the advance amount was returned.
        There was no completed transfer of property. No enduring financial
        benefit arising from the transaction has been demonstrated. In such
        circumstances, characterising the transaction as a conduit for
        recoupment requires clear material establishing such nexus, which is
        not forthcoming.

   834.                     A plain reading of the record shows that the agreement
        to sell the land relates to a period when the alleged recoupment is not
        even stated to have commenced. On the face of it, the land transaction
        does not bear any connection with the Excise Policy. Even if the
        WhatsApp chats are accepted in the manner suggested by the
        prosecution, they do not demonstrate any nexus with the policy; in the
        absence of such linkage, they lose relevance.

835.                     At this stage, the discussion is confined only to the role
        attributed to A-11. The allegation, insofar as it concerns A-17, shall be
        considered separately and in appropriate detail.

   836.                     A plain reading of the record shows that the agreement
        to sell the land relates to a period when the alleged recoupment is not
        even stated to have commenced. On the face of it, the land transaction
        does not bear any connection with the Excise Policy. Even if the
        WhatsApp chats are accepted in the manner suggested by the
        prosecution, they do not demonstrate any nexus with the policy; in the
        absence of such linkage, they lose relevance.

   837.                     At this stage, the discussion is confined only to the role
        attributed to A-11. The allegation, insofar as it concerns A-17, shall be
        considered separately and in appropriate detail.

   838.                     Criminal liability is personal and cannot be inferred
        solely on the basis of association or contemporaneous commercial
        dealings. In the absence of statutory provision, vicarious liability has
        no application in criminal law. Guilt by association is not recognised.
        Suspicion, cannot take the place of legally admissible material prima
        facie showing participation in an unlawful agreement.

   839.                     Viewed thus, the attempt to link the unexecuted land
        transaction with the broader conspiracy narrative rests on inference

rather than demonstrable material connecting A-11 or A-23 with any
        criminal design.

        Allegation against A-17

   840.                     According to the prosecution, A-17, Ms. K. Kavitha,
        occupied a central and facilitative role in the alleged criminal
        conspiracy relating to the formulation and implementation of the Delhi
        DEP-21/22. It is alleged that she acted in concert with members of the
        so-called “South Group” and with accused Vijay Nair (A-3), and that
        she functioned as a political and strategic conduit for select private
        liquor interests seeking favourable policy outcomes. The charge-sheet
        proceeds primarily on approver statements to assert that she was
        associated with the raising, conveyance and facilitation of an alleged
        demand for an “up-front” payment of about ₹100 crore in
        consideration of incorporation of favourable provisions in the policy
        and advantageous outcomes in the tendering and licensing process.
        She is further alleged to have had an indirect beneficial interest in the
        L-1 wholesaler, M/S Indospirits, through associates or proxies, and to
        have received proceeds of illegal gratification camouflaged as
        legitimate transactions, including, a purported land transaction of ₹14
        crore, and a CSR donation routed through an NGO stated to be
        connected to her.

   841.                     In furtherance of this alleged arrangement, accused A-11
        (Butchibabu Gorantla) is stated to have acted as a field-level

coordinator on behalf of the “South Group”, having approached the
        Magunta side to arrange funds and facilitated alleged cash deliveries
        through intermediaries or employees, including purported deliveries at
        Chennai, which are treated by the prosecution as part-payment of the
        alleged illegal gratification. The Magunta side, namely Magunta
        Sreenivasulu Reddy (PW-225) and his son approver Raghav Magunta
        (PW-226), are alleged to have had business interests under the new
        excise regime, including participation in the L-1 wholesaler M/S Indo
        Spirits and acquisition of retail zones, and to have been approached
        with a demand for payment in lieu of favourable policy and business
        outcomes; Raghav Magunta, having been granted pardon under
        Section 306 of Cr.P.C., is relied upon as an approver to support the
        allegation of demand, arrangement and partial payment through
        intermediaries. The prosecution further alleges that persons connected
        with Aurobindo-linked entities (A-23) benefited from allotment of
        retail zones under the policy and formed part of the alleged financial
        arrangements, asserting that funds originating from such entities were
        routed to A-17 through transactions projected as lawful, including the
        aforesaid land deal and other payments, that such entities had advance
        access to information regarding successful bidders, and that even after
        withdrawal of the policy, outstanding dues payable to the L-1
        wholesaler were permitted to remain unpaid as a continuing benefit
        within the alleged conspiracy.

Analysis

        (i) Land Deal — Alleged Recoupment of “Upfront Money” by A-17

   842.                    The record indicates that a draft Agreement of Sale dated
        12.07.2021 (D-302), reflecting a consideration of ₹14 crores, was
        forwarded by A-11 to officials of the Aurobindo Group. Thereafter, the
        Agreement of Sale dated 12.07.2021 reflected a total consideration of
        ₹28 crores, with ₹14 crores payable as advance. The prosecution relies
        upon this land transaction to contend that it constituted payment of the
        alleged “upfront money” or recoupment thereof. In the Third
        Supplementary Charge-sheet (para 16.40), it is asserted that “the
        investigation has further revealed that the accused Ms. K. Kavitha has
        also recouped the payment of the upfront money by way of obtaining
        Rs 14 crores from the company of Sh. Sarath Chandra Reddy in guise
        of land deal.”

   843.                     When this allegation is examined in the backdrop of the
        prosecution’s own conspiracy narrative, it does not withstand scrutiny.
        The charge-sheets consistently project recoupment as a mechanism
        linked to profits generated at the wholesale level under the L-1 regime.
        The prosecution theory is that a portion of the enhanced margin was
        to be recovered through profit-sharing arrangements within wholesale
        entities, including by induction of members of the so-called South
        Group into the partnership structure of wholesalers such as M/S
        Indospirit. There is neither allegation nor material to show that A-23

had any role, share, control, or association, directly or indirectly, with
        the wholesale layer, whether in M/S Indospirit or in BSPL.

   844.                     It is separately alleged that A-23 was controlling five
        retail zones. Even assuming that allegation at face value, the
        prosecution does not contend that the allotment of those retail zones
        was vitiated by corruption, manipulation, or deviation from policy.
        None of the charge-sheets assail the grant of retail zones as having
        been secured in violation of rules or regulations. More significantly,
        there is no specific allegation in the conspiracy narrative that
        recoupment was to be effected through retailers before they receive
        credit notes. The prosecution case does not suggest that recovery of
        any alleged upfront payment was to be made through retail
        transactions.

   845.                     The inconsistency becomes evident when the allegation
        is tested against commercial logic. If recoupment was to arise from
        wholesale profits, and A-23 had no demonstrated stake in the
        wholesale regime, there was no occasion for him to make any payment
        by way of recoupment. The record does not disclose how or why A-23,
        who is not shown to have derived any share in the wholesale layer,
        would part with ₹14 crores for such purpose.

   846.                     The timeline further weakens the prosecution theory.
        The retail vends, as per the prosecution’s own case, commenced
        operations only in or around November 2021. If recoupment is to be
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
linked to earnings under the policy, the question arises as to how an
        agreement to sale allegedly made in July 2021, prior to the operational
        phase of the retail regime, could represent recovery of profits not yet
        earned. On the prosecution’s own showing, the alleged recoupment
        precedes the very accrual of any profit stream from which it could
        have been sourced.

   847.                     Even otherwise, reliance is placed upon the statements
        of GTSL Prasad (PW-234) and Madhu Gorla (PW-235). A perusal of
        those statements merely establishes the existence of the agreement to
        sell; they do not attribute any criminal intent or unlawful design to the
        accused. The documentary record further shows that M/S Mahira
        Ventures issued a legal notice dated 30.05.2022 (D-303) seeking
        refund in respect of the land transaction, pointing out non-fulfilment
        of obligations by the seller. Pursuant thereto, the advance
        consideration was returned to the company. The transaction did not
        culminate in sale of the land, and admittedly the payment stood
