        refunded.

   848.                     The date of the transaction, coupled with its complete
        misalignment with the pleaded mechanism of conspiracy, indicates
        that it was an independent contractual arrangement having no nexus
        with the Excise Policy. On a cumulative consideration of the material,
        the attempt to treat the land transaction as a vehicle for recoupment is
        not borne out by the prosecution’s own pleaded mechanism, nor by the

timeline, nor by the documentary record. The allegation is internally
        inconsistent and, when tested against the prosecution narrative itself,
        does not support the inference sought to be drawn.

        (ii)      Corporate Social Responsibility (hereinafter referred to as
        “CSR”) Contribution Allegation

   849.                     The prosecution alleges that the CSR contribution of
        ₹80 lakhs made by Aurobindo Pharma Limited to Telangana Jagruthi
        in June 2021 was not a genuine CSR expenditure, but a concealed
        mode of transferring illegal gratification to A-17. Though reflected as
        a CSR payment and routed through banking channels, it is suggested
        that the contribution formed part of the broader conspiracy alleged
        under the Delhi DEP-21/22.

   850.                     On scrutiny of the material relied upon, this allegation
        does not disclose the basic ingredients necessary to sustain such an
        inference. The prosecution has not shown that the payment was
        anything other than a CSR contribution duly recorded in the statutory
        books of the donor company and in the financial records of the
        recipient organisation. The amount was transferred through regular
        banking channels and is supported by disclosed financial
        documentation. There is no allegation of cash movement,
        concealment, falsification of accounts, or diversion for personal
        benefit.

851.                     It is of significance that the payment was made in June
        2021. The prosecution’s own theory of conspiracy, as examined in
        detail earlier, projects the alleged “recoupment” mechanism as a
        subsequent arrangement, to operate after implementation of the policy
        and upon accrual of profits. The attempt to characterise a June 2021
        CSR contribution as recoupment is inconsistent with that framework.
        A payment made prior to the stage at which recoupment is stated to
        have arisen cannot, in the absence of supporting material, be read into
        that theory.

   852.                     Further, no contemporaneous material has been placed
        on record to indicate that the contribution was made in consideration
        of any public act, licence, policy decision, or official favour. There is
        no allegation of demand, solicitation, or acceptance of an undue
        advantage by A-17 in relation to any public duty. The inference sought
        to be drawn rests merely on an assumed association between the donor
        company and liquor business interests, and between the recipient NGO
        and the accused, without establishing any legally sustainable nexus
        with the exercise of official influence.

   853.                     Even with respect to A-23, the material does not advance
        the prosecution case. He is not shown to have any connection with a
        manufacturer or wholesaler. The only allegation is that he was holding
        five retail zones. The allotment of those retail zones is admittedly not
        under challenge. In the absence of any demonstrated illegality in such

allotment, or any material linking the holding of retail zones with the
        CSR contribution in question, the suggested connection remains
        speculative.

   854.                     On   the   material    presently   available,      the       CSR
        contribution appears as a disclosed and accounted transaction,
        unsupported by evidence of demand, quid pro quo, concealment, or
        misuse. The allegation rests on inference rather than demonstrable
        linkage to any corrupt act. Even at the stage of charge, it does not give
        rise to grave suspicion against A-17. To treat a lawful and documented
        CSR contribution as criminal, without any material of corrupt intent
        or nexus with a public function, would amount to attributing
        culpability by presumption, which is impermissible in law.

        (iii) Allegation of Indirect Equity Interest of A-17 through A-5 in M/S
        Indospirit

   855.                     It is alleged by the prosecution that A-17 held an indirect
        equity interest of 32.5% in M/S Indo Spirits through accused A-5
        (Arun R. Pillai), projected as her proxy, while M/S Indospirit
        Distribution Ltd. of accused A-7 (Sameer Mahendru) held 35%. The
        prosecution alleges that A-5 invested Rs. 3.40 crores in M/S Indospirit
        and that, out of this amount, Rs. 2.90 crores was sourced from
        associates of A-17. In support of this allegation, reliance is placed
        upon the statements recorded under Section 161 of CrPC of PW-242

to PW-245. The individual transactions reflected in the record are as
        follows:

                            (a) Kiran Kumar Luvanath (PW-243) advanced Rs. 50
        lakhs on 16.11.2021, which was returned on 18.03.2022. He stated that
        A-5 was his client and that the loan was given on the basis of personal
        understanding. Although he acknowledged knowing A-17 in a general
        sense, he has nowhere stated that the loan was advanced at her
        instance.

                            (b) Kalpesh Jain (PW-242) advanced Rs. 40 lakhs on
        16.11.2021, repaid on 19.03.2022. He categorically stated that he did
        not know A-17. The amount was provided at the request of Kiran
        Kumar Luvanath and not on any directions of A-17.

                            (c) Shashank Boyenpalli (PW-244) advanced Rs. 1 crore
        on 17.11.2021, returned on 25.08.2022. He had known A-5 since
        2019–2020 and granted the loan at A-5’s request. He expressly stated
        that he did not know A-17 and did not attribute the transaction to her.

                            (d) V. Srinivas Rao (PW-245) advanced Rs. 1 crore on
        16.11.2021, which was returned on 10.12.2021. The prosecution relies
        heavily upon one sentence in his statement wherein he states that he
        granted the loan on the directions of A-17. However, the relevant
        portion must be read in its entirety. PW-245 states: “… on 15.11.2021,
        along with Sh. Arun Pillai, I met at Hotel 36 situated at Road No. 36

in Hyderabad. There, Sh. Arun Pillai requested me to lend Rs. 1
        crore as a short-term loan for around 15 days for business purposes.
        He assured me that he would return the money within 15 days.
        I gave him the money on the directions of Ms. K. Kavitha, MLC. I
        transferred an amount of Rs. 1 crore to Sh. Arun Pillai through RTGS
        from the account of M/S Nirmitee Developers.”

   856.                     The statement itself records that the request for the loan
        originated from A-5. The transfer was effected through RTGS from the
        bank account of a firm to the bank account of A-5. It was not a cash
        transaction. The amount was returned in full within a short period. It
        is not the prosecution’s case that the amount remained unpaid or that
        it was diverted.

   857.                     As regards the remaining three lenders, their statements
        do not indicate that the loans were advanced at the instance of A-17.
        PW-242 does not know A-17. PW-244 has denied knowing her.
        PW-243’s acquaintance is limited to a professional interaction relating
        to interior work. Such limited familiarity cannot reasonably be
        elevated to an inference that substantial loans were advanced at her
        behest, particularly when the witnesses themselves deny any such
        direction.

   858.                     There is also no material placed on record to show that
        the alleged investment of Rs. 2.90 crores was repaid by A-5 out of
        funds supplied by A-17. No corresponding financial trail from A-17 to

A-5 has been demonstrated. Their statements, in fact, run contrary to
        what has been projected by the investigating agency.

   859.                     The position would have been materially different had
        the prosecution been able to demonstrate that A-17 herself provided
        cash or funds which were then routed through intermediary accounts
        and ultimately credited to A-5, or that the investment made by A-5
        resulted in a demonstrable return or benefit to A-17. However, that is
        not the prosecution case. Even if the prosecution version is accepted
        at its highest, that A-17 facilitated introductions or that persons
        acquainted with her extended financial assistance to A-5, such facts,
        by themselves, do not give rise to a legally sustainable inference that
        A-5 was acting as a proxy or benami for A-17.
                                                            (emphasis supplied)

   860.                     Criminal liability cannot be founded on conjectural
        extensions of association or acquaintance. The concept of “proxy” or
        “acting on behalf of” in criminal law requires clear and cogent
        evidence of control, direction, or beneficial ownership. Mere
        facilitation, recommendation, or acquaintance-based financial support
        does not satisfy this threshold. To accept the prosecution’s inference
        would be to collapse the distinction between civil association and
        criminal culpability, and to import into criminal jurisprudence a form
        of vicarious liability which is impermissible in the absence of a
        specific statutory provision.

861.                     If such an inference were to be accepted, it would lead to
        the untenable proposition that any person receiving funds from third
        parties, merely because of their acquaintance or proximity to another
        accused, could be treated as a proxy for that accused, thereby
        rendering both liable. Such a standard would stretch criminal
        culpability beyond its permissible limits and would effectively
        criminalise ordinary financial transactions unsupported by evidence of
        control, benefit, or mens rea. Criminal law does not recognise guilt by
        association, nor does it permit the attribution of liability on the basis
        of speculative linkage or assumed influence.
                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   862.                     On a cumulative consideration of these circumstances,
        the material reflects short-term loans routed through banking channels,
        extended on the basis of personal familiarity and repaid within defined
        timelines. The record does not disclose any coordinated funding
        mechanism attributable to A-17. In the absence of evidence
        demonstrating direction, control or financial contribution by A-17
        towards the alleged investment, no inference of conspiracy can be
        drawn against A-5 or any other accused on this basis. The allegation
        appears to be an attempt to connect A-17 with A-5, which does not
        cross the threshold required even at the stage of charge.

(iv) Allegation of Undue Benefit Through the Alleged Sham Land
        Deal between A-17 and A-23, in Turn Getting Favour in the Auction
        of Retail Zones under DEP-21/22

   863.                     The prosecution alleges that A-23 conferred an undue
        benefit upon A-17 through a purportedly sham land transaction, which
        is sought to be projected as the quid pro quo for the award of retail
        liquor zones under the Delhi DEP-21/22. Though the land transaction
        has been adverted to in the preceding paragraphs, it is necessary to
        address this allegation in its correct legal perspective.

   864.                     It is an admitted position on record that the alleged land
        deal was never consummated. The agreement to sell did not culminate
        in any transfer of title, and the amount paid pursuant to the agreement
        was admittedly returned. Notwithstanding this, the prosecution has
        advanced a speculative theory that A-17 entered into the agreement
        only to temporarily park funds in her account, allegedly to utilise the
        same during the intervening period before returning it. Crucially, the
        prosecution has failed to disclose any material whatsoever
        demonstrating how the said amount was utilised, for what purpose, or
        in what manner it was connected to the alleged conspiracy relating to
        the Excise Policy. In the absence of any such foundational material,
        the hypothesis remains conjectural.

   865.                     The law is well settled that an investigating agency
        cannot supply motives, invent purposes, or attribute criminal intent in

the absence of cogent evidence. A simple commercial transaction,
        namely, execution of an agreement to sell, payment of advance, failure
        of the transaction, and refund of the amount, has been sought to be
        converted into incriminatory material by superimposing an
        unsubstantiated allegation that the property was agreed to be sold at a
        price higher than the prevailing market value. This Court finds it
        difficult to discern how such an allegation, even if assumed to be
        correct, establishes any nexus between A-17 and the formulation or
        implementation of the Excise Policy.

   866.                     The entire allegation thus rests on the hypothesis that
        companies linked with A-23 were conferred undue benefit in the award
        of retail zones, and that such benefit constituted the quid pro quo for
        the alleged land transaction. This foundational assumption, however,
        collapses upon scrutiny. The award of retail zones was conducted
        through a public auction process, supervised by the TEC, and in
        accordance with the prescribed statutory and procedural framework.
        Significantly, the investigating agency does not dispute the legality,
        regularity, or procedural compliance of the tender process itself. Once
        the validity of the auction and the award of zones stands undisputed,
        the prosecution’s theory that the allotment of retail zones constituted
        an illegal favour or undue benefit is rendered inherently
        unsustainable.
                                                              (emphasis supplied)
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
867.                     The maxim sublato fundamento cadit opus, when the
        foundation is removed, the superstructure falls, aptly applies. Where
        the very foundation of the prosecution’s case, namely the existence of
        an illegal or irregular award of retail zones, is absent, the
        superstructure built upon it, alleging quid pro quo through a sham land
        deal, cannot survive. The law does not permit an inference of
        corruption or conspiracy to be drawn merely because two events are
        temporally proximate, in the absence of proof of causative linkage or
        unlawful benefit.

   868.                     Equally instructive is the principle post hoc ergo propter
        hoc, which cautions against the fallacy of assuming that because one
        event follows another, the former must be the cause of the latter. The
        prosecution’s case, in the present context, rests precisely on this
        impermissible reasoning, seeking to infer quid pro quo solely on the
        basis of sequence, without establishing nexus, intent, or benefit.

   869.                     Viewed thus, the allegation that A-17 received undue
        benefit through a sham land deal in consideration of favour shown to
        A-23 in the award of retail zones is bereft of evidentiary foundation.
        In the absence of any material that the land transaction was a facade,
        that the funds were utilised for any unlawful purpose, or that the tender
        process was manipulated to confer benefit, the allegation remains
        speculative and legally unsustainable. At the stage of consideration of
        charge, such conjecture cannot substitute for prima facie material

establishing the essential ingredients of quid pro quo, conspiracy, or
        abuse of official position.


        Outcome of Evaluation

   870.                     On a plain reading of the record, the very inclusion of
        A-17 and A-18 in the present case rests substantially upon the
        statements of PW-225 and his son, PW-226, who was later tendered
        pardon. It is essentially through these two witnesses that A-17 and
        A-18 are brought within the alleged conspiracy. It is equally
        significant that, on the basis of these statements, the timeline of the
        alleged conspiracy itself shifts. The prosecution initially projected the
        conspiracy as having taken shape around April/May. After reliance
        upon PW-225 and PW-226, the starting point is pushed back to March.
        The chronology, therefore, stands altered primarily on the strength of
        accomplice-like statement.

   871.                     The only material relied upon to indicate any linkage
        between A-17 and A-18 is the statement of PW-225. According to him,
        when he met A-18, he was told that A-17 would call him. Beyond this
        assertion, no circumstance, meeting, communication, or overt act is
        attributed to them jointly. Notwithstanding the absence of any further
        material, they have been portrayed as principal actors operating
        through intermediaries.

872.                     In this admitted background certain features deserve
        notice:

        1. It is not the case of the prosecution that A-17 or A-18 attended any
        meeting in Delhi.
        2. It is not alleged that they attended any meeting in Hyderabad.
        3.A-17 never met A-8 during the relevant period.
        4. A-17 and A-18 never met each other during the period of the alleged
        conspiracy.
        5. A-17 did not come to Delhi during the relevant period.
   873.                     The prosecution version further states that PW-225
        visited the residence of A-17 in March, where she allegedly stated that
        she had to arrange ₹100 crores as “upfront money.” The manner in
        which this allegation is presented suggests that, even before the
        alleged June meeting of co-conspirators, the entire arrangement stood
        settled. This would mean that one person had already anticipated a
        collective decision that was yet to take place. Instead of strengthening
        the case, the introduction of PW-225 and PW-226 renders the theory
        internally strained.
                                                             (emphasis supplied)

   874.                     The link sought to be drawn with A-23 is through a land
        transaction in July, described as sham and treated as recoupment. Yet
        the prosecution’s own theory suggests that recoupment was to begin
        only after implementation of the policy and generation of profits.
        Profits would arise only upon commencement of sales, and credit

notes could follow only thereafter. Credit notes cannot exist in the
        absence of sales. The timeline emerging from the record does not sit
        comfortably with the alleged mode of recoupment.

   875.                     To add weight to the narrative, it is alleged that ₹10
        crores were received from PW-226. The attempt to corroborate this
        through PW-227 remains unsatisfactory, as he does not specify the
        exact date, place, or time of delivery. The link, therefore, remains
        incomplete.

   876.                     It is further alleged that ₹10 crores and ₹15 crores were
        received at Chennai, not Hyderabad, and thereafter routed to Delhi and
        then to Goa. This gives rise to a simple and natural question: if the
        destination was Goa, and the prosecution itself relies upon
        Angadia/hawala channels, why was the amount not sent directly to
        Goa? Instead, several intermediaries are introduced. PA Ashok
        Kaushik is then shown as collecting the amount from approver PW-20.
        This again raises a basic query, why was the amount not delivered
        directly to him or directly to A-21? Why was it passed through
        multiple hands, thereby increasing risk and complexity?

   877.                     Most importantly, how did the amount reach Delhi in the
        first place? On this aspect, the prosecution narrative remains silent.

   878.                     At this stage, while the Court may grant the prosecution
        reasonable latitude, it cannot dispense with a meaningful application

of mind. Even if the material is taken at face value, a straightforward
        reading raises doubts as to whether the investigation has traced a
        coherent chain, or whether isolated events have been placed together
        to create the appearance of a larger design.

   879.            The case is projected against a background of sensational and
        striking features:

        1. A 36-page printout allegedly becoming the GoM report.
        2. Allegations of ₹90–100 crores in illegal gratification.
        3. Involvement of public servants at high levels, businessmen, and
        media persons.
        4. Allegations of bribe-taking by government officials.
        5. An alleged connection with Goa elections.
        6. Multiple participants turning approvers and giving successive
        statements.
   880.                     Viewed casually, such elements may create an
        impression of a sweeping and well-organised conspiracy. The
        narrative appears structured. The scale of the alleged amounts and the
        range of persons involved can lend it an air of inevitability.

   881.                     But criminal law does not proceed on impression. It
        proceeds on admissible material. On closer examination, the apparent
        coherence rests largely on statements of witnesses who stand on
        similar footing. One accomplice-like witness is shown to support
        another. The approver’s version is said to be strengthened by a witness

whose own role, as per the prosecution, is not free from suspicion.
        This is not independent corroboration; it is mutual reinforcement.

   882.                     The settled rule of prudence is that an accomplice may
        be examined, but his statement requires independent corroboration on
        material particulars. One tainted statement cannot lend legitimacy to
        another equally tainted statement. When PW-225, PW-226 and others
        forming part of the same alleged chain are relied upon to support each
        other, the Court must look for something outside that circle,
        documentary proof, financial trail, or electronic record, standing
        independently. If such independent material is absent, the narrative
        does not appear internally consistent and remains legally fragile.

   883.                     Even when each statement is assumed to be true, the
        structure does not appear intact when taken together. The fragility
        becomes more pronounced when each link is examined separately,
        date, place, mode of transfer, route of movement, whereupon the gaps
        become visible. Essential facts are left to inference. The route of
        money is unclear. The timing does not align. The alleged recoupment
        precedes the very profits from which it is said to arise.

   884.                     This is one of those cases where, unless the material is
        tested on the touchstone of admissibility and relevance, the story may
        appear complete. The magnitude of the allegations can overshadow
        the weaknesses. Yet, when examined in the light of established

principles governing accomplice statement and corroboration, the
        apparent superstructure begins to lose stability.

   885.                     Courts cannot permit the force of a narrative to replace
        the discipline of evidence. However serious the allegations may
        appear, they must withstand scrutiny under settled legal principles.
        When so examined, what is projected as a single, coherent design may,
        in truth, consist of a chain of assertions resting upon one another,
        without firm and independent support. The maxim sublato
        fundamento cadit opus aptly applies, when the foundation is removed,
        the structure falls. Like a pack of cards, once the base is unsettled, the
        entire arrangement begins to give way. That is precisely what has
        occurred here. Once the primary reliance on mutually supporting
        accomplice-like statements is tested, the apparent coherence dissolves,
        and the larger structure cannot sustain itself.
                                                                (emphasis supplied)


        Allegation against A-19

   886.                     As per the prosecution case set out in the Fourth
        Supplementary Charge-sheet, A-19, Durgesh Pathak, is alleged to have
        played a role in the utilisation of the purported proceeds of crime
        arising out of the alleged Excise Policy conspiracy for political
        purposes, specifically in connection with the Goa Assembly Elections,
        2022. The prosecution projects A-19 as the AAP Prabhari/In-charge

for Goa during the relevant period and alleges that, by virtue of this
        position, he exercised supervisory and coordinating control over the
        party’s election campaign in the State.

   887.                     It is alleged that, during the course of the Goa election
        campaign, A-19 approached candidates and party workers and assured
        them that their election expenses would be borne by the party.
        According to the prosecution, such assurances indicated the existence
        of a centrally managed funding mechanism for the campaign. The
        prosecution relies upon statements of certain AAP candidates and
        witnesses to allege that election-related expenditure in Goa was
        incurred substantially in cash and that candidates were informed that
        they need not independently arrange campaign funds.

   888.                     The prosecution further alleges that cash amounts
        transferred to Goa through hawala/angadiya channels, described as
        part of the alleged upfront money generated from the Excise Policy
        conspiracy, were utilised for meeting election-related expenses under
        the supervision of the Goa campaign leadership. In this context, it is
        alleged that A-19 utilised such funds through accused Chanpreet Singh
        Rayat (A-16), who is stated to have handled and disbursed cash
        payments to various vendors, assembly managers, booth in-charges,
        volunteers and other personnel engaged in the Goa election campaign.
        The prosecution thus attributes to A-19 a coordinating role in the
        utilisation of the alleged cash funds through on-ground operatives.

889.                     In support of the broader conspiracy narrative, the
        prosecution also relies on circumstances relating to meetings and
        logistics in Delhi. It is alleged that on 21.05.2021 certain accused
        persons, described as members of the so-called “South Group”, met
        accused Vijay Nair (A-3) and others at Gauri Apartment near
        Claridges, Delhi, and that this meeting was connected with the alleged
        conspiracy relating to the Excise Policy. In this backdrop, it is
        specifically alleged that the said guest house/apartment had been
        booked by Sh. Bibhav Kumar, Personal Secretary to accused Arvind
        Kejriwal (A-18), for A-19. The prosecution cites this circumstance as
        part of the chain suggesting coordination among political functionaries
        and other accused during the relevant period.

   890.                     The prosecution further alleges that the transfer of funds
        to Goa was undertaken with the object of financing the AAP’s Goa
        election campaign and that A-19, as Goa Prabhari, played a role in the
        political utilisation of such funds. According to the prosecution, the
        alleged cash disbursements formed part of a larger plan to deploy the
        proceeds of the alleged Excise Policy conspiracy for electoral
        expenditure, and A-19 is alleged to have been one of the key political
        coordinators in Goa in this regard.

   891.                     It is the prosecution’s stated position that the acts
        attributed to A-19 are not connected with the discharge of any official
        duty, and on that basis it is asserted that no sanction under Section 19

of the PC Act is required in respect of A-19. The prosecution alleges
        that, on the aforesaid factual matrix, A-19 was a participant in the
        criminal conspiracy relating to the utilisation of alleged proceeds of
        crime for political purposes, in furtherance of the overall conspiracy
        alleged in the Fourth Supplementary Charge-sheet.


        Analysis

   892.                     The prosecution seeks to attribute criminal liability to
        A-19 primarily on the premise that, being the Goa Prabhari of the party
        during the Goa Assembly Elections, 2022, he approached prospective
        candidates and assured them that the party would bear election-related
        expenses. Even if this allegation is assumed to be correct in its entirety,
        such conduct, by itself, does not disclose any violation of the election
        law framework.

   893.                     Under the scheme of the Representation of the People
        Act, 1951, election expenditure incurred by or authorised by a political
        party is legally distinct from the personal election expenditure of a
        candidate. Section 77(1) of the Representation Act, 1951 (hereinafter
        referred to as “R.P. Act, 1951”) mandates that a candidate shall
        maintain a correct account of expenditure “incurred or authorised by
        him” in connection with his election. The Explanation to Section 77,
        read with settled election law jurisprudence, clarifies that expenditure
        incurred by a recognised political party or by persons other than the
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
candidate, without the candidate’s authorisation, does not form part of
        the candidate’s election expenditure. Political parties are statutorily
        permitted to campaign for, support, and financially assist their
        candidates, subject to disclosure norms applicable to the party. There
        is no prohibition in law against a political party funding or meeting the
        campaign expenses of its candidates, and such funding, per se, does
        not attract any penal consequence under the Act.
                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   894.                     Further, the regulatory framework under Section 29C of
        the R.P. Act, 1951, expressly contemplates party funding and mandates
        disclosure of contributions received by political parties beyond the
        prescribed threshold. The alleged assurance by A-19 that the party
        would bear election expenses, even if taken at face value, therefore
        falls squarely within the domain of permissible political conduct and
        cannot, without more, be elevated to criminality.

   895.                     Significantly, the prosecution has not placed any
        material to show that A-19 either provided cash, arranged cash,
        directed cash payments, or acted as a conduit for the alleged cash
        utilised in the elections. The statements relied upon by the prosecution,
        including those of PW-273 and PW-274, do not attribute any act of
        cash handling, transfer, receipt or disbursement to A-19, nor do they
        suggest that any cash was provided by him or on his behalf. The mere
        assertion that party volunteers or campaign functionaries incurred

expenditure in cash does not, in the absence of linkage evidence,
        establish any role of A-19 in the alleged funding trail.

   896.                     The Court further notes that political supervision of
        elections by a party functionary is a routine and legitimate
        organisational activity. The role of a ‘Prabhari’ is inherently
        supervisory and coordinative in nature. Such supervision cannot be
        criminalised merely because the prosecution alleges that some party
        workers or volunteers may have utilised cash during the campaign. To
        fasten criminal liability on A-19 on a theory of vicarious responsibility,
        the prosecution was required to demonstrate that the alleged recipients
        or handlers of cash were acting as his agents, co-conspirators or at his
        behest. No such material has been placed on record.

   897.                     It is also an admitted position emerging from the charge-
        sheet itself that A-19 was not present at any of the meetings projected
        as the genesis or crystallisation of the alleged conspiracy, including
        the meetings at Gauri Apartment, ITC Kohinoor, Taj Hotel or Hotel
        Oberoi. His name does not figure in the confessional or approver
        statements of PW-20 or PW-226, nor in the statements of any angadia,
        hawala operator or witness connected with the alleged cash movement.
        None of the witnesses who speak of alleged transfer of funds from
        Delhi to Goa have named or implicated A-19 in any capacity.

   898.                     The sole foundation of the prosecution case against A-19
        thus rests on the assertion that he was supervising the Goa elections

while alleged cash was received and spent by party volunteers. Such a
        premise, in the absence of evidence of knowledge, participation,
        control or linkage with the alleged proceeds of crime, is legally
        insufficient to sustain a criminal charge. Criminal conspiracy cannot
        be inferred from organisational hierarchy or political position alone; it
        must be founded on material demonstrating a meeting of minds and
        conscious participation, which is conspicuously absent in the present
        case.

   899.                     In the absence of any allegation or evidence that A-19
        was instrumental in the generation, transfer, receipt or utilisation of
        the alleged cash, or that he was connected in any manner with the
        formulation or implementation of the Excise Policy, there is no
        material whatsoever to justify his arraignment. The attempt to rope
        him in on the basis of a broad and impermissible theory of vicarious
        liability does not meet the threshold required even at the stage of
        framing of charge.

   900.                     The Court expresses its serious disapproval of the
        manner in which the investigating agency has sought to implicate A-19
        without placing on record any material indicative of his knowledge,
        participation or involvement in the alleged conspiracy or the alleged
        proceeds of crime. Criminal liability cannot be fastened on the basis
        of political position, organisational role or supervisory responsibility.
        To compel an individual to face criminal prosecution on the strength

of conjecture and association is wholly impermissible and runs
        contrary to settled principles of criminal jurisprudence, where the
        process itself cannot be permitted to operate as punishment.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   901.                     The investigating agency is expected to act with fairness
        and restraint, particularly in cases carrying grave consequences for
        personal liberty, reputation and dignity. The present prosecution
        reflects an unwarranted expansion of the net in the absence of evidence
        and a failure to distinguish between legitimate political activity and
        criminal conduct. Continuation of proceedings founded on such
        tenuous premises would amount to an abuse of process and result in a
        miscarriage of justice.

        Allegation Against A-20

   902.                     It is the prosecution case that A-20 Amit Arora, owner
        and controller of M/S Buddy Beverages Pvt. Ltd., emerged during
        investigation as a participant in the alleged conspiracy relating to the
        Delhi DEP-21/22. It is alleged that he acted in concert with accused
        Vijay Nair (A-3) and approver Dinesh Arora to extract an illegal
        commission of 6% out of the 12% wholesale margin introduced under
        the DEP-21/22.

   903.                     According to the prosecution, M/S Mahadev Liquors, a
        wholesale licensee in Delhi, was targeted for payment of the said

commission. Upon refusal, A-20 is alleged to have adopted coercive
        measures, including misuse of alleged influence with Punjab Excise
        authorities, resulting in abrupt closure of liquor manufacturing units
        linked to Ms. Jasdeep Kaur Chadha (PW-298) in Punjab. It is alleged
        that such actions were intended to pressurise M/S Mahadev Liquors to
        comply with the demand.

   904.                     The prosecution further alleges that the distilleries of
        Ms. Jasdeep Kaur Chadha (PW-298) were closed without prior notice,
        followed by issuance of a show-cause notice, and that she was
        thereafter directed to donate ₹51 lakhs to the Chief Minister’s Relief
        Fund, Punjab, after which orders for reopening were issued. It is
        alleged that continued pressure led to surrender of the wholesale
        licence of M/S Mahadev Liquors on 25.05.2022.

   905.                     It is also alleged that approver Dinesh Arora (PW-20)
        confirmed that closure of the Punjab units was orchestrated to exert
        pressure for payment of the 6% commission, and that after Mahadev
        Liquors exited the wholesale business, alternative entities, M/S Dewan
        Spirits and M/S Shiv Associates, were identified to whom the business
        could be shifted on terms involving sharing of the commission. The
        prosecution relies upon statements of certain witnesses, including Sh.
        Sanjit Padhi and Sh. Prabhjot Singh, to allege that A-20 Amit Arora
        was a participant in these arrangements and thereby played a role in

extraction of illegal commission and coercive restructuring of
        wholesale arrangements under the DEP-21/22.

        Analysis

   906.                     At the very threshold, it requires emphasis that A-20
        Amit Arora is admittedly not shown to have been present in any of the
        meetings which, according to the prosecution itself, are projected as
        forming the fulcrum or crucible of the alleged conspiracy, namely, the
        meetings at Gauri Apartments, ITC Kohinoor, Hyderabad, Taj Hotel,
        or Hotel Oberoi. His absence from each and every meeting said to have
        shaped, advanced, or operationalised the alleged conspiracy is borne
        out from the record and, significantly, stands undisputed by the
        prosecution.

   907.                     This absence assumes added significance when viewed
        in the backdrop of the prosecution’s own foundational narrative. In the
        principal charge-sheet, the prosecution proceeds on an entirely
        different and self-contained axis. The alleged conspiracy is premised
        on the assertion that major manufacturers, particularly M/S PRI and
        Diageo, together commanded nearly 65% of the market share, and that
        the DEP-21/22 was allegedly manipulated to enable control over
        distribution so as to facilitate recoupment of so-called “upfront
        money.” Within this core narrative, M/S Mahadev Liquors, an L-1
        wholesaler, does not figure at all. There is not even a remote allegation
        connecting A-20 Amit Arora either with the alleged payment or with

the alleged recoupment of upfront money. The subsequent
        introduction of an altogether new strand involving M/S Mahadev
        Liquors, without any demonstrable linkage to the original conspiracy
        framework, thus constitutes an unexplained and material departure
        from the prosecution’s own central theory.

   908.                     It is also an undisputed position that no role whatsoever
        is attributed to A-20 at the stage of formulation of the DEP-21/22. He
        is neither alleged to be a manufacturer, nor a wholesaler, nor a retailer,
        except in relation to the Airport zone through Buddy Retails Pvt. Ltd.,
        under the DEP-21/22. There is no allegation that he influenced,
        approached, or interacted with any public servant in connection with
        policy        drafting,    Cabinet   approval,   movement     of     files,      or
        implementation. His name is conspicuously absent from any
        contemporaneous policy-level discussion, official correspondence, or
        decision-making record pertaining to the Excise Department. This
        absence from the policy domain materially weakens any attempt to
        attribute to him a role in a policy-centric criminal conspiracy.

   909.                     Equally telling is the complete absence of any
        allegation, direct or indirect, linking A-20 with the delivery,
        movement, receipt, or handling of any alleged cash, whether at
        Chennai, Delhi, or Goa. None of the witnesses examined in relation to
        hawala transactions, angadiya operations, or alleged cash movement
        have named A-20. He does not find mention in the statements of the

approvers, including PW-20 or PW-226, in relation to the alleged cash
        trail or election expenditure. The prosecution material, therefore,
        discloses no financial or transactional nexus between A-20 and the
        alleged proceeds of crime.

   910.                     When the focus shifts to M/S Mahadev Liquors, the
        record itself discloses multiple and mutually inconsistent versions
        regarding its control and operation. The first version emanates from
        approver PW-20 Dines Arora, who stated that PW-298 (Ms. Jasdeep
        Kaur Chadha) was the owner of M/S Mahadev Liquors, “Mahadev
        Liquor ke owner hai Madam Chaddha”, as reflected in the confession
        statement recorded under Section 164 of Cr.P.C.. A second version,
        again attributed to approver PW-20, suggests that PW-298 was
        running the business though Sunny Marwah (PW-279), as disclosed in
        the statement recorded under Section 161 of Cr.P.C. dated 21.09.2022.
        A third version, disclosed by PW-298 and PW-279 themselves, is that
        they were merely family friends and that PW-279 was the owner of
        M/S Mahadev Liquors.

   911.                     The investigating agency has consciously chosen to
        adopt and rely upon the third version. The reason for this selective
        reliance becomes apparent on closer scrutiny. Acceptance of either the
        first or the second version would inevitably lead to the inference that
        a manufacturer was effectively running a distributor/wholesaler, a
        situation expressly prohibited under the NEP-20/21, particularly when

PW-298 admittedly controlled liquor manufacturing entities such as
        Tite Beverages, Medusa Beverages, Adie Browson Breweries, and AB
        Grains Spirits Pvt. Ltd. This circumstance also bears directly on the
        manner in which Sunny Marwah (PW-279) was initially named as an
        accused in the FIR. It is pertinent that while A-7 and A-9, being
        wholesalers, have been charge-sheeted, neither Sunny Marwah nor
        Jasdeep Kaur Chadha has been charge-sheeted. The third version,
        therefore, aligns conveniently with the investigative narrative by
        insulating both Jasdeep Kaur Chadha (PW-298) and Sunny Marwah
        (PW-279) from the rigours of a prohibited relationship, while
        simultaneously rendering their statements amenable to prosecutorial
        use.

   912.                     Proceeding   on   this   constructed   premise,         the
        investigating agency seeks to link the alleged closure of distilleries
        belonging to PW-298 with an alleged attempt to exert pressure upon
        PW-279, projected as one of the owners of M/S Mahadev Liquors. The
        prosecution further suggests that, being a family friend and having
        suffered inconvenience and financial loss, PW-298 influenced the
        decision of M/S Mahadev Liquors to surrender its L-1 licence. This
        theory of “arm-twisting,” however, does not withstand scrutiny. Such
        a hypothesis might have carried some plausibility had there been an
        allegation that PW-279 extended financial assistance to PW-298 to
        offset her alleged losses. Instead, the prosecution’s own case is that

M/S Mahadev Liquors was running a successful L-1 wholesale
        business with nearly 20% market share in Delhi under the DEP-21/22
        and was projected as the third-largest wholesaler in the city. PW-279
        is stated to have been dealing with as many as 14 brands. Against this
        commercial backdrop, the suggestion that a profitable wholesaler
        would voluntarily surrender its licence merely out of sympathy or
        familial concern, without any corresponding financial or commercial
        benefit, appears inherently implausible. In this backdrop, if the theory
        is to be accepted as giving rise to grave suspicion, the prosecution was
        required to show, at least prima facie, that there existed a relationship
        of such a nature that PW-298 was compelled or constrained to
        surrender the licence. No such material is forthcoming on record. On
        the contrary, another view equally arises from the circumstances, that
        the surrender was occasioned by the withdrawal of the Excise Policy
        itself. Unless this alternative is ruled out on the basis of cogent
        material, the prosecution’s suggestion cannot be said to cross the
        threshold beyond mere conjecture.

   913.                     The prosecution case then suffers a decisive and fatal
        jolt with the admitted denial of sanction under Section 17-A of the PC
        Act qua the Punjab Excise officials. The relevant extract of the order
        dated 30.08.2023 of the competent authority, marked as D-368, is
        reproduced for ready reference:
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
“…..GOVERNMENT OF PUNJAB DEPARTMENT OF
                PERSONNEL (I.A.S. BRANCH)
                                             ORDER
                        The Central Bureau of Investigation, New Delhi, vide
                Memo No. 5365/RC 53(A)/2022/CBI/ACB/DLI dated
                30.08.2023, had sent a proposal regarding seeking of
                permission u/s 17A of PC Act. 1988 (as amended in 2018)
                against Sh. KAP Sinha, IAS (Punjab-1992), the then Financial
                Commissioner, Excise & Taxation, Punjab.
                2.       On receipt of the aforesaid proposal, the Financial
                Commissioner (Taxation) was requested vide Memo No.
                SV-3/134 dated 08.09.2023 to give factual position in this case.
                The Financial Commissioner (Taxation) has communicated the
                factual report, vide his Memo No. 2056 dated 09.10.2023.
                3.        Based on the above factual position placed before the
                Competent Authority, it has come out that the Department of
                Excise and Taxation conducts routine inspections of the
                distilleries and bottling plants from time to time. So, as a part
                of routine practice, 15 inspections of various manufacturing
                units were conducted in the months of April and May, 2022. It
                becomes clear that the units of M/S A.B Grains Spirits Pvt. Ltd.
                and M/S Adie Broswon Pvt. Ltd. were not specifically targeted
                for inspections. It has been reported that similar inspections
                had been conducted in the past also. As a result of such routine
                inspections in four units during the month of Nov. 2021, action
                as per law was initiated which resulted into imposing of penalty
                of Rs. 80 Lakhs in the month of April 2022 in three cases each,
                and in one case, the license of the unit remained suspended for
                fifteen days.
                4.      It clearly shows that the Department has been
                handling such cases as per the provisions of the Punjab Excise
                Act and the Excise Rules. Similarly, in cases of M/S A.B
                Grains Spirits Pvt. Ltd. and M/S Adie Broswon Pvt. Ltd.,
                action as per law was taken by the competent officer and
                nothing malafide can be attributed to the competent officer

when he has duly discharged his duties. It is also pertinent to
                mention here that neither any appeal nor any revision was filed
                by the aforesaid liquor companies before Shri KAP Sinha, IAS,
                the then Financial Commissioner, Excise & Taxation, Punjab.
                5.       Further, linking the surrender of L-1 (wholesale)
                license by M/S Mahadev Liquors in New Delhi with the
                departmental action, taken as per law, against a manufacturing
                unit in Punjab run by Smt. Jasdeep Kaur Chadha is not tenable.
                As per the factual record as received from the CBI, M/S
                Mahadev Liquors is a proprietorship concern with Sh. Sunny
                Marwaha as an authorized signatory. There is nothing on
                record which establishes any linkage of M/S Mahadev Liquors
                with Smt. Jasdeep Kaur Chadha or her concerns in Punjab.
                6.      From the sequence of events and the facts placed on
                record, the Competent Authority is of the view that giving a
                colour of arm twisting to the routine legal departmental action
                taken against M/S A.B Grains Spirits Pvt. Ltd. and M/S Adie
                Broswon Pvt. Ltd., is unjustified. Moreover, the CBI itself has
                mentioned categorically in the proforma that they do not have
                any information in respect of any bribe giver.
                7…..The ingredients of Section 477A of IPC has been gone
                through in light of the documents provided by CBI in the
                proposal but no falsification of accounts done by Shri K A P
                Sinha, IAS has been mentioned anywhere in the documents
                provided by CBI, nor it has been found on perusal of the record
                of the Department of Excise, Punjab related to Shri K A P Sinha
                IAS. Thus, no case of section 477A of IPC is made out
                against Shri K A P Sinha, IAS.
                8…… In regard to an allegation under the aforesaid Section of
                IPC, it is mentioned that as per the copy of FIR provided by
                CBI, M/S Mahadev Liquors is a proprietorship concern having
                Sh. Sunny Marwaha as an authorized signatory. No fact of
                linkage of M/S Mahadev Liquors with Smt. Jasdeep Kaur
                Chadha has been mentioned in the copy of FIR nor in any other
                supporting documents provided by CBI. Further, it has been
                found that no other document or evidence has been provided

by CBI, which can possibly attract any ingredient invoking
                section 120B of IPC against Sh. K A P Sinha IAS.
                9….. In regard to an allegation under this Section of PC Act,
                it is mentioned that in para 8 of the proposal received from CBI
                seeking permission u/s 17A PC Act, 1988 against Shri K A P
                Sinha, IAS, it is stated that there is no information available
                with CBI in respect of any bribe giver. Moreover, as per the fact
                finding report of Excise Department, neither any
                document/evidence has been found from record of the Excise
                Department nor from the proposal received from CBI which
                indicates any deliberate disruption in the functioning of the
                afore-mentioned Units, as claimed by CBI. Further, as already
                mentioned above, no fact of linkage of M/S Mahadev Liquors
                with Smt. Jasdeep Kaur Chadha has been mentioned in the
                copy of FIR nor in any other supporting documents provided
                by CBI. Thus, no ingredient of Section 7 of PC Act, 1988 (as
                amended in 2018) has been made out in the case of Shri K A
                P Sinha, IAS.
                10.     Further, at the time, Shri K A P Sinha, IAS was posted
                as Additional Chief Secretary Finance with Additional Charge
                of Additional Chief Secretary Excise and Taxation. Holding
                these two positions simultaneously, his most important
                assignment at that time was to prepare the maiden budget of the
                new Government which was to be presented on 27th June,
                2022. His additional charge as Additional Chief Secretary
                Excise and Taxation was only for a short duration of 2 months
                18 days.
                11.     In view of the aforegoing, Competent Authority, after
                having examined in depth the request of the CBI coupled with
                the facts as stated above, is of a categorical view that no case
                whatsoever is made out to grant any sort of "permission" under
                Section 17A of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988
                against Shri K A P Sinha, IAS, the then Financial
                Commissioner, Excise & Taxation, Punjab who has carried out
                his official functions/duties in a bona-fide manner. The
                provisions of Section 17A were also examined, which postulate

a mandatory pre-requisite of previous approval before
                conduct of any inquiry, enquiry or investigation against a
                Public Servant. No case for such previous approval is made
                out. Though, the CBI has sought for ‘permission’, but the
                statute distinctly uses the expression ‘previous approval’.
                Obviously, ‘previous approval’ would be of a distinct nature
                than a mere 'permission'. The Competent Authority is satisfied
                that the accusations set forth in the CBI's proposal does not
                disclose a prima facie criminality in the acts of the concerned
                public servant. As stated above, not even a prima facie case is
                made out for according any previous approval under Section
                17A (supra) and accordingly, the request of the CBI is hereby
                declined.
                12.    This issues with the approval of the Competent
                Authority.
                                   Chief Secretary to the Government of Punjab
                                            Endst. No. 2/7/2023-IAS(1)/1044
                                            Dated, Chandigarh 28.11.2023…”.


   914.                     The alleged closure of distilleries belonging to PW-298
        in Punjab constitutes the very foundation of the prosecution’s theory
        of coercion and misuse of official machinery. However, the competent
        authority declined sanction to investigate the said officials, and the
        denial order (D-368) admittedly remains unchallenged by the CBI.
        This omission has serious legal consequences. The Supreme Court in
        case titled as Karnataka Emta Coal Mines Ltd. V. CBI, 2024 SCC
        OnLine SC 2250, has consistently held that where sanction to
        prosecute a public servant is refused and such refusal is not assailed,
        allegations of conspiracy involving private persons premised upon the
        conduct of such public servants cannot be sustained. Non-challenge to

the denial order, therefore, amounts to acceptance of the findings of
        the competent authority by the investigating agency itself. The
        relevant extract is reproduced below for ready reference:

                                                          (emphasis supplied)

                “….12. DENIAL OF SANCTIONS BY THE SANCTIONING
                AUTHORITIES AND THE EFFECT ON THE
                APPELLANTS
                12.1. It is relevant to note that the very same Audit objections
                taken by the CAG and relied upon by the respondent-CBI to
                allege conspiracy and loss to the public exchequer were
                thoroughly examined and found to be meritless by two separate
                set of Sanctioning Authorities. When it came to Mr. R.
                Nagaraja, the then Director (Finance) of KPCL and the
                nominee Director on the Board of KECML, the Sanctioning
                Authority, i.e., the Board of KPCL went through several
                documents during its deliberations including the MoU between
                the KECML and GCWL forwarded by the respondent-CBI for
                seeking sanction to prosecute him. The reasons for holding that
                the CAG Report was without any factual basis, were
                elaborately dealt with as below:
                12.2. It is apparent from the above that after Sanctioning
                Authority had scrutinized all the relevant documents and the
                depositions as many as of 67 witnesses submitted by the
                respondent-CBI, it observed that there was no evidence to
                show that any rejects generated by washing of coal had been
                sold or that KPCL had suffered an unlawful loss during the
                process. As a result, the Board of KPCL refused to grant
                sanction to the respondent-CBI to prosecute Mr. R. Nagaraja
                for offences alleged to have been committed by him. It is
                noteworthy that no appeal has been filed by the respondent -
                CBI against denial of sanction.
                12.3. Similarly, the request made by the respondent-CBI for
                seeking sanction to prosecute Mr. Yogendra Tripathi, the then

Managing Director, KPCL was denied by the Competent
                Authority in the Central Government in terms of the letter
                dated 16th April, 2018, issued by the DoPT. The order passed
                by the DoPT shows that it took note of the Report of the
                respondent-CBI, the records submitted by it along with the
                Report, the advice received from the CVC and then
                summarized the allegations levelled by the respondent-CBI
                that formed the basis of its proposal to seek sanction for
                prosecution of the aforesaid officer. The said request was
                finally rejected by the Competent Authority in the Central
                Government with the following observations:
                12.4. The aforesaid order reveals that before applying its mind,
                the Competent Authority in the Central Government had
                sought comments from the Government of Karnataka who had
                stated that there was no material produced by the respondent-
                CBI in support of the allegation that Mr. Yogendra Tripathi had
                conspired to illegally dispose off the coal rejects or
                with malafide intention deferred the agenda in the 41st Board
                Meeting of the KPCL. The Competent Authority separately
                sent the said proposal submitted by the respondent-CBI to the
                CVC for seeking advice. After examining all the records sent
                by the investigation agency including the evidence submitted
                by it, the Office of the Prime Minister who is the Competent
                Authority in the Central Government, approved the proposal to
                decline the sanction for prosecuting Mr. Yogendra Tripathi. Yet
                again, no appeal has been filed by the respondent - CBI
                before the court questioning the said decision.
                12.5. The respondent-CBI having accepted the decision taken
                by the Sanctioning Authority in respect of Mr. R. Nagaraja and
                the decision of the Competent Authority in the Central
                Government in respect of Mr. Yogendra Tripathi, both senior
                most serving officers of KPCL and were also on the Board of
                KECML, cannot be permitted to argue that these were merely
                administrative decisions and even if permission to prosecute
                the aforesaid officers has been denied, the Department can still
                proceed against the appellants based on the very same set of
                material/documents/evidence etc. that have been minutely

scrutinized by different authorities at the highest level and they
                have independently arrived at an identical conclusion of
                refusing to grant sanction to prosecute senior functionaries of
                KPCL. Simply because the said senior functionaries of KPCL
                were public servants, does not detract from the fact that the
                respondent-CBI has described them as co-accused in a criminal
                conspiracy and attributed similar motives to them as the
                appellants herein. If they have been let off the hook and the
                respondent-CBI has not challenged the said decisions, there is
                no reason to proceed against the appellants herein on the basis
                of the very same set of facts and material gathered during the
                course of investigation.
                (d) The Competent Authority in the Central Government who
                was approached by the respondent-CBI for sanction to
                prosecute Mr. Yogendra Tripathi, the then Managing Director
                of KPCL sought comments from two separate sources. The
                Government of Karnataka opined that no criminal intent
                could be attributed to the said officer. A proposal was also
                sent to the CVC for their advice. The CVC too recommended
                that the sanction for prosecuting the officer ought to be
                declined. The Competent Authority in the Central Government
                after going through the entire documents and material
                including the evidence submitted by the respondent-CBI and
                the opinions solicited, declined sanction for the prosecution of
                the aforesaid officer.
                (e) The respondent-CBI did not approach the Court to
                challenge the aforesaid decisions. Having accepted the
                decision taken by the Sanctioning Authority/Competent
                Authority in the Central Government and dropping the charges
                against the seniormost functionaries in KPCL, who were also
                holding positions in the Board of KECML, there is no
                justification to press charges against the appellants herein
                whose role is similar to them…”.
   915.                     Even otherwise, the prosecution narrative is riddled with
        internal inconsistencies of such magnitude that they render the

allegations highly improbable. If M/S Mahadev Liquors had already
        surrendered its four brands, Radico Khaitan, Modi Distillery,
        Alcobrew, and Gemini Distillery, on 12 May, as allegedly demanded
        by A-20, the subsequent issuance of a show-cause notice calling
        PW-298 for personal hearing by the Punjab Excise Department
        becomes difficult to reconcile. Likewise, the allegation that Ms.
        Jasdeep Kaur Chadha was compelled to donate ₹51 lakhs to the Chief
        Minister’s Relief Fund, Punjab, by cheque and not in cash to any
        person, after surrender of the licence, does not logically advance the
        prosecution case of quid pro quo or policy-linked conspiracy. There is
        no allegation that the said amount was routed as cash, diverted towards
        election expenditure, or otherwise connected with the alleged Excise
        Policy conspiracy.

   916.                     Prima facie, therefore, no causal or transactional nexus
        emerges between the surrender of the wholesale licence in Delhi and
        the administrative action taken against distilleries in Punjab. This
        conclusion is further reinforced by the undisputed circumstance that
        the DEP-21/22 itself was due to expire in May, coinciding with the
        period of surrender. If A-20 and approver PW-20 were acting in
        furtherance of a criminal conspiracy, it remains unexplained what
        tangible benefit could have accrued from pressuring the surrender of
        an L-1 licence when the policy itself was nearing expiry and was
        ultimately extended only for two months by an order dated 20 May.

The hypothesis of extracting substantial benefit for such a fleeting
        period does not comport with ordinary commercial or conspiratorial
        logic. Taken cumulatively, the surrounding circumstances do not
        support the prosecution case; rather, they dismantle it.

   917.                     The   attempt    to   braid   these   independent           and
        jurisdictionally distinct strands into a single Excise Policy conspiracy
        is thus unsupported by cogent or reliable material. At the highest, the
        allegations, even if accepted at face value, may point towards a
        separate and independent grievance, but they do not disclose any
        material connection with either the formulation or the implementation
        of the DEP-21/22, nor with the alleged conspiracy underlying it.

   918.                     It is also of relevance that upon surrender of the licence
        by M/S Mahadev Liquors, the business was allegedly taken over by
        M/S Dewan Spirits and M/S Shiv Associates. Despite being the
        immediate beneficiaries, neither entity has been implicated as an
        accused. PW-307 Surjan Reddy of M/S Dewan Spirits has disclosed
        that approver PW-20 approached him for a 50% partnership. Approver
        PW-20, in his confessional statement, stated: “....On 30 aprail she
        surrendered the license and I got all her work I got L-1 license instead
        of Mahadev liquor. I got three companies and 1 company was given to
        M/S Deewan spirits….”.

   919.                     This disclosure squarely implicates Surjan Reddy and
        Prabhjot Singh of Shiv Associates. Considered cumulatively, these

statements indicate that the witnesses, including Sunny Marwah and
        Jasdeep Kaur Chadha, are accomplice-like witnesses as showing
        proximity of manufacturer with wholesaler, whose statements require
        independent corroboration in material particulars. One accomplice
        cannot corroborate another, and uncorroborated statements of such
        nature cannot be acted upon even to raise a grave suspicion. Reliance
        is placed upon the judgments of Hon’ble Supreme Court in K. Hashim
        (supra), Somasundaram (supra), Laxmipat Choraria (supra) and A.R.
        Antulay (supra).

   920.                     In the complete absence of any role in policy
        formulation, absence from alleged conspiracy meetings, absence of
        involvement in any alleged cash movement, and absence of linkage to
        public-servant conduct or policy outcomes, this Court is constrained
        to hold that there is no prima facie material connecting A-20 Amit
        Arora with the alleged conspiracy relating to the DEP-21/22.

   921.                     Viewed thus, the material placed on record falls
        manifestly short of the essential ingredients of criminal conspiracy.
        Conspiracy in law presupposes a prior meeting of minds, an
        agreement, tacit or express, to commit an illegal act or a legal act by
        illegal means, and conscious participation in furtherance of the
        common design. Mere suspicion, association, parallel circumstances,
        or post-facto allegations, howsoever serious, cannot be treated as a
        material of such agreement. In the present case, there is no material
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
indicating that A-20 Amit Arora was a participant in any policy-
        shaping discussion, any conspiracy meeting, any agreement for
        extraction of alleged illegal gratification, or any act in furtherance
        thereof. In the absence of evidence disclosing knowledge, intent, or
        participation, the foundational requirement of conspiracy remains
        wholly unfulfilled. Subjecting A-20 to trial on such slender and
        conjectural material would amount to permitting the prosecution to
        proceed on surmise rather than substance, which the law does not
        countenance.

        Allegations against A-23

   922.                     The prosecution alleges that A-23, Sarath Chandra
        Reddy, was a member of the so-called “South Group” and was part of
        the larger conspiracy relating to the DEP-21/22. It is alleged that an
        amount of ₹14 crores was obtained from him in the guise of a land
        transaction and that a further sum of ₹80 lakhs was paid by him to an
        NGO associated with A-17 (Ms. K. Kavitha). According to the
        prosecution, these payments were linked to the alleged conspiracy. It
        is further alleged that, though the policy capped allocation at two retail
        zones per entity, he secured control over five retail zones and thereby
        derived undue benefit.

   923.                     The prosecution also relies on his presence in Delhi
        between 14.03.2021 and 17.03.2021, during which meetings are stated
        to have taken place between members of the South Group and A-3

(Vijay Nair), and a draft GoM Report was allegedly handed over and
        later formalised. Reference is also made to the meeting dated
        16.03.2021 and to the clearance of the Excise Policy file on
        21.05.2021, which is described as having been processed with unusual
        haste. A meeting at Gauri Apartments on the same date is projected as
        part of the alleged plan to maximise profits.

   924.                     It is additionally alleged that he supported and secured
        the GoM recommendation in favour of M/S Indospirits and that he
        attended a meeting on 16.03.2021 at Taj Mahal Hotel, Delhi, along
        with other named individuals. The prosecution further states that he
        received excess credit notes amounting to ₹1.57 crores from A-9
        (Amandeep Singh Dhall). Lastly, it is alleged that upon withdrawal of
        the Excise Policy on 31.08.2022, an amount of about ₹60 crores
        remained outstanding in relation to the five retail zones under his
        control, out of which ₹46,88,78,307/- is stated to be unpaid, and that
        he was favoured by being permitted not to pay the said amount. These
        are the allegations as projected against A-23.


        Analysis

   925.                     This Court has failed to comprehend the basis on which
        A-23 has been arrayed as an accused. It is an admitted position that he
        was not part of any meeting at Gauri Apartments or at ITC Kohinoor,
        Hyderabad, both of which are projected by the prosecution as the most

significant meetings where the alleged conspiracy and its modus
        operandi were crystallised.

   926.                     The only allegation sought to be attributed to him is his
        purported association with the episode concerning the 36-page
        printout, which is alleged to have been supplied to A-3, thereafter
        reaching A-8, and ultimately forming the Second GoM Report dated
        19.03.2021. This aspect has already been examined in detail,
        particularly in light of the statement of PW-71 and 72 the
        contemporaneous record, and it has been found that the said allegation
        does not withstand scrutiny.

   927.                     The Second GoM Report, on its plain terms,
        incorporated turnover clauses which, had they been reflected in the
        final Excise Policy, would have operated to the detriment of M/S
        Indospirit. Further, by prescribing an upper cap of 12% on the
        wholesale margin, the Second GoM Report removed the absence of a
        ceiling that existed in the earlier draft. The earlier position, where no
        upper cap was fixed, would, on the prosecution’s own theory, have
        been more advantageous to any wholesale entity seeking recoupment.
        The fixation of an upper limit, therefore, cannot logically be
        characterised as a measure favouring the so-called South Group.

   928.                     It is also not in dispute that A-23 is the only accused
        who had no interest whatsoever in the wholesale or manufacturing
        layer. In the absence of participation in the alleged foundational

meetings, absence of demonstrated commercial stake in the wholesale
        structure, and in view of the infirmities surrounding the 36-page
        document theory, the basis for implicating A-23 remains wholly
        unclear on the material presently on record.

   929.                     The allegation concerning the CSR contribution of ₹80
        lakhs and the so-called “sham” land transaction of ₹14 crores has
        already been examined in detail. The material on record demonstrates
        that the land transaction was an independent contractual arrangement,
        executed as a distinct commercial engagement. There is nothing to
        indicate that it bore any nexus, direct or indirect, to the formulation or
        implementation of the Excise Policy, nor to the alleged mechanism of
        recoupment of the so-called “upfront amount.” The same conclusion
        applies to the CSR contribution. Both transactions were routed
        through regular banking channels, supported by documentation, and
        reflected in the financial records of the concerned entities. The
        prosecution has been unable to establish any linkage between these
        transactions and the alleged conspiracy.

   930.                     If these transactions are sought to be forcibly subsumed
        within the conspiracy narrative, the internal coherence of the
        prosecution’s theory stands undermined rather than strengthened. The
        prosecution has consistently projected recoupment as a structured
        recovery of profits through the wholesale layer. An independent land
        contract and a CSR contribution, transparently executed through

banking channels, do not align with such a mechanism. To characterise
        them as conspiratorial acts would introduce inconsistency into the very
        architecture of the prosecution’s case.

   931.                     Equally significant is the complete absence of material
        demonstrating any benefit accruing to A-23 so as to justify his alleged
        participation in the conspiracy. He was not present at the meetings at
        Gauri Apartments or ITC Kohinoor, which are projected as the
        foundational stages of the alleged design. His non-participation in
        these critical meetings assumes relevance when the prosecution’s own
        case treats those meetings as decisive in shaping the modus operandi.

   932.                     The further allegation that A-23 was present at a meeting
        relating to the grant of distributorship by M/S PRI to M/S Indospirit
        does not advance the prosecution’s case. There is no material to
        suggest that A-23 had any direct or indirect interest in M/S Indospirit.
        He is not shown to have held any stake in the wholesale or
        manufacturing segment, nor is there any allegation that he received
        credit notes, profit transfers, or any other pecuniary advantage arising
        out of the distributorship arrangement. Mere presence at a business
        meeting, absent proof of stake, influence, or benefit, cannot substitute
        for evidence of conspiratorial participation.

   933.                     The issue of credit notes further accentuates the
        incongruity in the prosecution narrative. It has already been discussed
        that A-9 was not favourably disposed towards M/S Indospirit securing

M/S PRI’s distributorship. If that be so, the suggestion that A-9 would
        then extend credit notes to entities allegedly controlled by A-23 runs
        contrary to commercial logic. A party dissatisfied with a
        distributorship outcome would scarcely incentivise the alleged
        beneficiary of that outcome. This internal contradiction strikes at the
        root of the theory that A-23 was positioned to receive or channel
        financial advantages arising from the wholesale structure.

   934.                     Viewed cumulatively, the absence of demonstrable
        benefit, the lack of participation in decisive meetings, the independent
        character of the CSR and land transactions, and the inherent
        contradictions surrounding the credit-note theory leave the allegation
        against A-23 resting on conjecture rather than cogent material.

   935.                     The allegation that A-23 Sarath Chandra Reddy
        impermissibly operated through “multiple entities” to secure retail
        licences proceeds on a fundamental misreading of Clause 4.1.2 (ii) of
        the Delhi DEP-21/22 and the concept of “related entities” embedded
