        therein. Clause 4.1.2 (ii) does not prohibit participation by more than
        one company per se; it only restricts allotment of retail zones where
        entities are shown to be “related” within the meaning assigned by the
        Policy, namely by reference to shareholding, control, management, or
        beneficial ownership crossing the prescribed threshold. The mere fact
        that entities belong to a broader corporate group, or are commercially

associated, does not ipso facto render them “related entities” for the
        purposes of disqualification or clubbing under the Policy.

   936.                     The prosecution has neither pleaded nor demonstrated,
        even prima facie, that the entities allegedly associated with A-23
        satisfied the Policy-defined criteria of relatedness so as to attract the
        embargo under Clause 4.1.2 (ii). There is no material placed on record
        establishing common shareholding beyond the prescribed limit,
        common            directors   exercising   controlling   influence,     or      any
        arrangement of beneficial ownership designed to defeat the policy cap.
        In the absence of such foundational facts, the allegation of misuse of
        multiple entities collapses into a bald assertion, unsupported by the
        statutory tests governing eligibility and disqualification.

   937.                     It is also material that the Excise Policy itself
        contemplated bidding by distinct legal persons, and the scrutiny of
        “related entities” was an institutional exercise entrusted to the Excise
        Department at the stage of tender evaluation. Once the competent
        authority accepted the bids and allotted retail zones after applying the
        Policy criteria, the prosecution cannot, by hindsight, recast lawful
        participation as criminal conduct without demonstrating fraud,
        suppression, or misrepresentation at the bidding stage. Criminal
        liability cannot be fastened merely because a commercial group
        lawfully succeeded in the tender process.

938.                     Viewed thus, the allegation that A-23 secured retail
        zones through “multiple entities” does not disclose any infraction of
        Clause 4.1.2 (ii) or the “related entity” clause under DEP-21/22.
        Absent          proof    of   policy-defined   relatedness   or       deliberate
        circumvention, the prosecution’s case on this aspect rests on
        assumption rather than statutory violation, and is insufficient to sustain
        a charge of conspiracy or undue benefit.

   939.                     Lastly, it is alleged that upon withdrawal of the Excise
        Policy on 31.08.2022, an amount of about ₹60 crores remained
        outstanding in relation to the five retail zones under his control, out of
        which ₹46,88,78,307/- is stated to be unpaid, and that he was favoured
        by being permitted not to discharge the said liability. This contention
        does not, on its face, sustain the allegation of conspiracy. The
        withdrawal of the policy was a subsequent administrative
        development. At the time when the alleged conspiracy is said to have
        been conceived or acted upon, there is nothing to indicate that any
        participant could have anticipated that the policy would be withdrawn
        on 31.08.2022. An uncertain future event cannot be treated as part of
        a prior criminal arrangement in the absence of clear material showing
        such foresight or design.

   940.                     It is also not shown that non-recovery of dues was
        confined to entities stated to be under the control of A-23. If
        outstanding amounts existed in respect of other retail licensees as well,

the issue assumes the character of a commercial consequence
        following the discontinuance of the policy. In the absence of material
        demonstrating selective treatment or a prior understanding, the
        inference of favour remains unsubstantiated.

   941.                     There is no material to suggest that the alleged non-
        payment was conceived at the inception as a mechanism of
        recoupment. The prosecution’s theory of recoupment rests on distinct
        allegations and timelines. To equate subsequent outstanding dues with
        a pre-determined conspiratorial benefit would require specific
        evidence establishing such linkage, which is not forthcoming.

   942.                     At best, the matter appears to arise out of commercial
        transactions between wholesaler, manufacturer and retailer under a
        policy framework that was later withdrawn. Disputes relating to
        recovery of such dues ordinarily fall within the realm of contractual
        remedies. The fact that litigation has taken place between the parties
        further indicates the commercial nature of the controversy.

   943.                     Viewed thus, the allegation regarding outstanding dues
        does not, by itself, disclose any act in furtherance of a criminal
        conspiracy. The material relied upon by the prosecution is not
        sufficient to raise grave suspicion against A-23.

Collapse of the Prosecution Case Alleging Policy Manipulation,
        Criminal Conspiracy, and Generation of Proceeds of Crime in the
        Form of Upfront Money:

   944.                     The very foundation of the prosecution case rests on the
        assertion that the formulation and implementation of the DEP-21/22
        were deliberately engineered to confer undue pecuniary advantage
        upon the so-called “South Group”. The alleged indicia of such design
        are projected to be the fixation of a 12% wholesaler margin, the
        stipulation of one manufacturer, one wholesaler, and the definition of
        “related entities”. On this premise, it is alleged that an up-front
        payment of ₹90–100 crores, purportedly quantified as 6% of
        anticipated profits, was agreed to and generated as illegal gratification,
        later stated to have been utilised for the Goa Assembly Election.

   945.                     As noticed and discussed in the preceding paragraphs,
        the record placed before the Court renders this narrative wholly
        unsustainable. It stands conclusively established that A-1 and A-2
        granted the L-1 licence to M/S Indospirits strictly in accordance with
        the notified eligibility criteria. The contemporaneous record discloses
        no deviation, indulgence, or extraneous consideration in the grant of
        such licence. Notably, the prosecution has failed to place on record
        any material whatsoever indicating either demand or receipt of illegal
        gratification by A-1 and A-2, or by any public servant, in connection
        with the said licensing process.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
946.                     Equally fragile is the allegation of manipulation in the
        framing of the DEP-21/22. The documentary trail demonstrates that
        the policy was formulated through the prescribed institutional route,
        in consonance with the Transaction of Business of the Government of
        NCT of Delhi Rules, the Allocation of Business Rules, and the Cabinet
        Secretariat Manual of Procedures. The prosecution has been unable to
        identify any unlawful intervention, surreptitious authorship, or
        distortion of the established decision-making process. In the absence
        of proof of policy manipulation, the very substratum on which the
        alleged conspiracy is sought to be erected stands demolished.

   947.                     Once the alleged foundational acts, policy manipulation
        and grant of licence for illegal consideration, are found to be devoid
        of evidentiary support, the superstructure of conspiracy necessarily
        collapses. The theory of generation of “proceeds of crime” is entirely
        derivative of these unsubstantiated premises. Where the genesis itself
        is missing, the question of accrual, layering, or utilisation of proceeds
        of crime does not arise. The chain of circumstances projected by the
        prosecution as forming an unbroken sequence of conspiracy does not
        merely suffer from missing links; it disintegrates altogether.

   948.                     What emerges instead is a troubling picture of an
        investigation steered by a preconceived outcome rather than by
        objective evaluation of evidence. Lawful administrative actions and
        policy decisions appear to have been selectively extracted, stripped of

context, and artificially interlinked to manufacture an appearance of
        conspiracy. Such an approach reflects a marked departure from the
        settled principles governing fair investigation and betrays an effort to
        substitute inference and conjecture for proof.
                                                            (emphasis supplied)

   949.                     Nevertheless, even in the face of these fundamental
        infirmities, this Court does not consider it appropriate to leave any
        allegation unanswered or any issue unexamined. Conscious of its duty
        to subject every charge to judicial scrutiny, the Court shall, therefore,
        proceed further to examine the specific allegations relating to the
        accused persons who are stated to have utilised the alleged cash
        amounts in the Goa Assembly Election, so that the record may be
        tested comprehensively and no contention remains unaddressed.


        Allegation against A-12
   950.                          So far as A-12, Rajesh Joshi is concerned, the
        prosecution case, as projected in the Second Supplementary Charge-
        sheet, proceeds on the footing that he acted as a key Delhi-side
        conduit/handler in the alleged movement of cash stated to be part of
        the purported proceeds of crime, which cash is alleged to have been
        transported from Delhi to Goa for utilisation in connection with the
        Goa Assembly Elections, 2022. The prosecution does not project A-12
        as a recipient at Goa; rather, he is alleged to have operated at the

source/dispatch end in Delhi, coordinating and arranging cash
        movement through angadiya channels.

   951.                     In particular, the prosecution attributes to A-12 a
        quantified linkage under the Asil Corporation channel (June–
        December 2021). It is alleged that A-12, jointly with A-13 (Damodar
        Prasad Sharma), arranged and provided cash aggregating to
        ₹11,93,30,000, which was allegedly handed over to Ashok Chandulal
        Shah (PW-183), proprietor of M/S Asil Corporation, for onward
        transfer to Goa through angadiya networks, since Asil Corporation
        allegedly had no Goa branch. The prosecution relies on PW-183 to
        attribute this Delhi-side source to A-12, and seeks to dovetail it with
        the angadiya delivery chain spoken to by PW-182 and PW-180, and
        with the Goa-side physical handover process described by PW-181,
        thereby projecting A-12 as the provider/dispatcher of the said cash
        segment.

   952.                     The prosecution further alleges that the cash, after being
        handed to PW-183, was routed through the angadiya network of M/S
        R. Kantilal Finance & Courier Services, and delivered at Goa during
        the period 21.06.2021 to 31.12.2021, with recipients named as
        Chanpreet Singh Rayat @ Preet (A-16), Rajiv Ashok Mondkar
        (PW-181) and Prince Kumar (A-14). In this structure, A-12 is alleged
        to be the person who arranged the cash at Delhi and caused its dispatch

through intermediaries, with the delivery-side witnesses being relied
        upon to show transmission and receipt at Goa.

   953.                     Apart from the above quantified attribution, the
        prosecution case also projects A-12 as a person involved in the broader
        cash-transfer architecture, in the sense that he is alleged to have been
        in contact with intermediaries and angadiya operators involved in
        routing cash from Delhi through transit points to Goa. However,
        within the specific framework emerging from paras 16.14 to 16.23 (as
        relied upon), the quantified monetary attribution against A-12 remains
        centred on the ₹11,93,30,000 segment alleged to have been arranged
        and provided by him (with A-13) for onward angadiya transfer to
        Goa.

   954.                     Accordingly, the prosecution’s allegations against A-12
        Rajesh Joshi, as projected, are that he functioned as a Delhi-side
        organiser/provider/dispatcher of cash forming part of the alleged
        proceeds of crime, and that his role is sought to be established through
        the Asil Corporation → R. Kantilal route, culminating in delivery at
        Goa to the recipients named in the prosecution narrative.


        Allegations against A-13
   955.                     In so far as A-13, Damodar Prasad Sharma, is
        concerned, the prosecution case, as projected in the Second
        Supplementary Charge-sheet, is that he acted in close concert with

A-12 (Rajesh Joshi) in facilitating and arranging the alleged
        movement of cash from Delhi to Goa through hawala/angadiya
        channels. The prosecution does not attribute to A-13 any role as a
        recipient of cash at Goa; rather, he is projected as operating at the Delhi
        end, assisting in the collection, arrangement and dispatch of cash
        which is alleged to form part of the proceeds of crime.

   956.                     The principal and quantified allegation against A-13
        arises under the Asil Corporation channel (June–December 2021). The
        prosecution alleges that A-13, acting as an employee/associate of
        A-12,        jointly     arranged   and   provided   cash   aggregating         to
        ₹11,93,30,000, which was allegedly handed over at Delhi to Ashok
        Chandulal Shah (PW-183), proprietor of M/S Asil Corporation, for
        onward transfer to Goa through angadiya networks. This attribution of
        source is founded almost entirely on the statement of PW-183, who
        states that “Shri Rajesh Joshi and his employee Shri Damodar” sent
        cash through M/S Asil Corporation from Delhi to Goa during the
        period July 2021 to December 2021.

   957.                     The prosecution further alleges that A-13 was in
        telephonic contact with angadiya operators and intermediaries
        involved in the routing of cash during the said period, and that he
        assisted A-12 in coordinating the logistics of dispatch. On this basis,
        A-13 is projected as having an active role in the arrangement and

facilitation of the Delhi-side cash movement, though no independent
        handling, custody or receipt of cash by A-13 is alleged at Goa.

   958.                     According to the prosecution narrative, the cash
        allegedly arranged by A-13 (with A-12) was thereafter routed through
        M/S Asil Corporation and transmitted via the angadiya network of M/S
        R. Kantilal Finance & Courier Services, with delivery at Goa between
        21.06.2021 and 31.12.2021 to Chanpreet Singh Rayat @ Preet (A-16),
        Rajiv Ashok Mondkar (PW-181) and Prince Kumar (A-14). In this
        structure, A-13’s role is confined to the alleged Delhi-side facilitation
        and instruction, and the prosecution relies on delivery-side witnesses
        only to establish transmission and receipt at Goa.

   959.                     Beyond   the   aforesaid   quantified   segment,         the
        prosecution also seeks to portray A-13 as part of the broader alleged
        conspiracy to route cash through angadiya channels for political
        expenditure in Goa. However, within the specific factual framework
        emerging from paragraphs 16.14 to 16.23 of the Second
        Supplementary Charge-sheet, the only quantified monetary attribution
        against A-13 remains the ₹11,93,30,000 segment, alleged to have been
        jointly arranged and dispatched by him along with A-12.

   960.                     Accordingly, the allegations against A-13, Damodar
        Prasad Sharma, as recorded by the prosecution, are that he functioned
        as a Delhi-side facilitator and coordinator, acting in conjunction with
        A-12 in arranging and dispatching cash through the Asil Corporation

angadiya route, culminating in alleged delivery at Goa to the recipients
        named in the prosecution narrative.



        Allegation against A-14

   961.                     In so far as A-14, Prince Kumar, is concerned, the
        prosecution case, as set out in the Second Supplementary Charge-
        sheet, projects him as a Goa-side recipient of cash, allegedly delivered
        through hawala/angadiya channels during the period June 2021 to
        December 2021. Unlike A-Nos. 12 and 13, Prince Kumar is not alleged
        to have operated at the Delhi end or to have arranged or dispatched
        cash; rather, his role is confined to the receipt of limited and
        specifically quantified amounts at Goa.

   962.                     The prosecution attributes to A-14 a specific and
        quantified sum of ₹16,08,000, allegedly received through hawala
        transactions on three occasions. As per paragraph 16.22 of the charge-
        sheet, the said amounts are stated to have been delivered as follows:
        ₹6,00,000 on 22.09.2021, ₹3,00,000 on 23.09.2021, and ₹7,08,000 on
        03.12.2021. These deliveries are sought to be established primarily
        through the delivery-side angadiya evidence of PW-180 (Sagar Kumar
        Patel), who claims to have effected delivery at Goa and to have
        recorded the same in his handwritten delivery records.

963.                     Apart from the aforesaid quantified amount, the
        prosecution further names Prince Kumar as one of the recipients
        within the broader June–December 2021 delivery segment
        aggregating to ₹11,93,30,000, which is alleged to have been routed
        through M/S Asil Corporation and thereafter through the angadiya
        network of M/S R. Kantilal Finance & Courier Services. However,
        beyond the sum of ₹16.08 lakhs, no additional specific or segregated
        quantum is attributed to Prince Kumar individually in the charge-
        sheet.

   964.                     The prosecution narrative places Prince Kumar (A-14)
        alongside Chanpreet Singh Rayat @ Preet (A-16) and Rajiv Ashok
        Mondkar (PW-181) as a recipient at Goa, relying upon the delivery-
        side statements to show that cash parcels were handed over at Goa
        through angadiya intermediaries. Prince Kumar is not alleged to have
        had any role in the sourcing of cash, the routing decisions, or the
        coordination of angadiya networks, nor is he alleged to have issued
        instructions to angadiya operators.

   965.                     Accordingly, the allegations against A-14, Prince
        Kumar, as projected by the prosecution, are limited in scope and
        nature. He is sought to be implicated as a recipient of relatively small,
        specifically quantified amounts of cash at Goa, allegedly delivered
        through hawala/angadiya channels, and as a named recipient within
        the larger June–December 2021 delivery segment, without any

independent attribution of source-side activity, facilitation, or control
        over the alleged cash movement.



        Allegation against A-15

   966.                     In so far as A-15, Arvind Kumar Singh, is concerned, the
        prosecution case, as emerging from the Second Supplementary
        Charge-sheet, projects him as a Delhi-side financier and facilitator in
        respect of a distinct and isolated tranche of alleged cash movement
        during January 2022. Unlike A-12 and A-13, whose alleged roles are
        linked to the June–December 2021 period through the Asil
        Corporation channel, A-15 is not associated with that segment. His
        alleged involvement is confined to what the prosecution describes as
        the K.S. Enterprises channel.

   967.                   The prosecution alleges that during the period 04.01.2022
        to 10.01.2022, a sum of ₹7,10,92,500 was arranged at Delhi by A-15
        and thereafter routed to Goa through hawala/angadiya channels. The
        attribution of the Delhi-side source of this January 2022 tranche is
        founded exclusively on the statement of PW-183 (Ashok Chandulal
        Shah), who states that, apart from the Asil Corporation route, there
        existed a separate arrangement involving K.S. Enterprises, wherein
        cash was arranged at Delhi by Arvind Kumar Singh and routed through
        Devang Solanki. PW-183 places this arrangement squarely in the

January 2022 period and does not state that the said cash passed
        through Asil Corporation.

   968.                     The prosecution further alleges that the cash so arranged
        was transmitted through the angadiya network of M/S R. Kantilal
        Finance & Courier Services. The delivery at Goa during January 2022
        is sought to be established through PW-180 (Sagar Kumar Patel), who
        states that he maintained handwritten delivery records and certifies
        that deliveries effected between 04.01.2022 and 10.01.2022
        aggregated to ₹7,10,92,500, applying the convention of adding three
        zeros to the figures recorded. PW-180 identifies Chanpreet Singh
        Rayat @ Preet (A-16) as the recipient of these January 2022 deliveries.
        However, PW-180 does not depose to the source of the funds, nor does
        he attribute any instruction or role to A-15 (Arvind Kumar Singh) or
        Devang Solanki.

   969.                     The prosecution also relies upon PW-192, PW-193 and
        PW-194 to corroborate the delivery mechanism through the R.
        Kantilal angadiya system. These witnesses speak to the routing of cash
        through angadiya channels and the procedure of delivery at Goa,
        including the use of token or note numbers. None of these witnesses,
        however, attributes the source or funding of the January 2022 tranche
        to A-15, and their statements are confined to the factum of routing and
        delivery through angadiya intermediaries.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
970.                     It is thus the prosecution’s case that A-15, acted as a
        Delhi-side funder/conduit for the January 2022 tranche of
        ₹7,10,92,500, which is alleged to have been routed through Devang
        Solanki of K.S. Enterprises and delivered at Goa to Chanpreet Singh
        Rayat @ Preet through the angadiya network of M/S R. Kantilal. No
        allegation is made that A-15 received any cash at Goa, or that he was
        involved in the earlier June–December 2021 segments. His alleged
        role, as projected by the prosecution, is thus confined to the funding
        and facilitation of the January 2022 cash movement, as recorded in
        paragraphs 16.14, 16.22 and 16.23 of the Second Supplementary
        Charge-sheet.



        Allegation against A-16

   971.                     In so far as A-16, Chanpreet Singh Rayat @ Preet, is
        concerned, the prosecution case, as projected in the Second
        Supplementary Charge-sheet, places him at the centre of the alleged
        cash-movement narrative and portrays him as the principal and
        ultimate recipient of cash at Goa. The prosecution alleges that A-16
        received substantial amounts of cash routed from Delhi through
        hawala/angadiya channels during the period June 2021 to January
        2022, and that such cash constituted part of the alleged proceeds of
        crime utilised in connection with the Goa Assembly Elections, 2022.

972.                     According to the prosecution, the alleged receipt of cash
        by A-16 spans multiple segments and channels. It is alleged that during
        the period 21.06.2021 to 10.01.2022, cash aggregating to ₹44.54
        crores was delivered to A-16 at Goa through different angadiya routes.
        This aggregate figure is arrived at by combining several sub-segments
        of alleged delivery. The prosecution asserts that a sum of
        ₹17,38,14,500 was directly delivered at Goa through M/S R. Kantilal
        Finance & Courier Services, with PW-180 (Sagar Kumar Patel) acting
        as the delivery conduit. In addition, a further sum of ₹27 crores is
        alleged to have been collected by PW-181 (Rajiv Ashok Mondkar)
        from the angadiya network and thereafter handed over to A-16 at
        Goa.

   973.                  The prosecution further alleges that A-16 was a recipient
        within        the        June–December   2021    segment    aggregating          to
        ₹11,93,30,000, which is stated to have been routed from Delhi through
        M/S Asil Corporation and thereafter transmitted via the angadiya
        network of M/S R. Kantilal Finance & Courier Services. Under this
        segment, A-16 is named alongside Rajiv Ashok Mondkar and Prince
        Kumar (A-14) as recipients at Goa. The Delhi-side sourcing of this
        segment is attributed by the prosecution to Accused Nos. 12 and 13,
        while A-16 is projected as the Goa-side recipient.

   974.                      A further and distinct allegation relates to the January
        2022 tranche. The prosecution alleges that during the period

04.01.2022 to 10.01.2022, a sum of ₹7,10,92,500 was delivered at Goa
        to A-16 through the angadiya network of M/S R. Kantilal. This tranche
        is stated to have been funded at Delhi by A-15 (Arvind Kumar Singh)
        and routed through Devang Solanki of K.S. Enterprises, with A-16
        being identified as the ultimate recipient at Goa.

   975.                     In addition to the above, the prosecution also names
        A-16 as a recipient in the third chain involving routing through
        multiple Delhi-based angadiyas via a freelance angadiya. Under this
        chain, cash aggregating to ₹25.50 crores is alleged to have been routed
        through Kirtikumar Ambalal Angadiya, Maa Ambey Angadiya and
        Nilkanth Enterprise, coordinated by PW-189 (Chandra Kumar Tripathi
        @ Chandan), and thereafter delivered at Goa through the R. Kantilal
        network, with A-16 and PW-181 (Rajiv Ashok Mondkar) named as
        recipients.

   976.                   The prosecution further alleges that A-16 exercised control
        over the logistics of receipt at Goa. Reliance is placed on the statement
        of PW-181, who states that on multiple occasions during November–
        December 2021, he collected sealed box parcels containing cash from
        PW-180 (Sagar Kumar Patel) at Goa and handed over the same to A-16
        at locations directed by him. On this basis, the prosecution projects
        A-16 not merely as a passive recipient, but as a person who directed
        the collection and handover of cash at Goa.

977.                Accordingly, the allegations against A-16, Chanpreet Singh
        Rayat @ Preet, as projected by the prosecution, are that he functioned
        as the principal Goa-side recipient and handler of cash, allegedly
        routed from Delhi through multiple hawala/angadiya channels during
        June 2021 to January 2022, aggregating to ₹44.54 crores, and that such
        cash was received and utilised under his directions as part of the
        alleged proceeds of crime connected with the Goa Assembly Elections,
        2022.



        Allegation against A-21

   978.                 It is the prosecution case that A-21 Vinod Chauhan acted as
        a key conduit in the alleged criminal conspiracy relating to the Delhi
        DEP-21/22, particularly in the transfer and routing of alleged proceeds
        of crime from Delhi to Goa for utilisation in the Goa Assembly
        Elections 2022. It is alleged that A-21 maintained close association
        with senior functionaries of AAP, including accused Arvind Kejriwal
        and accused Manish Sisodia, and that this association is reflected from
        digital evidence recovered during investigation.

   979.                 According to the prosecution, data extracted from the Apple
        iPhone of A-21 Vinod Chauhan revealed WhatsApp chats with a
        mobile number saved under the contact name “HCM AK”, stated to be
        used by A-18 (Arvind Kejriwal). It is alleged that multiple mobile

numbers attributed to A-18 (Arvind Kejriwal), as well as contact
        details of A-8 (Manish Sisodia) and other AAP functionaries, were
        found saved in the phone of A-21. It is further alleged that images of
        WhatsApp chats relating to arranging meetings with senior leaders,
        birthday wishes, and other communications were retrieved from the
        device.

   980.                    It is the prosecution case that PW-195 Ashok Kaushik,
        former Personal Assistant to A-17 (Ms. K. Kavitha), alleged during
        investigation that on two occasions he handed over bags containing
        cash to accused Vinod Chauhan on the instructions of A-4 (Abhishek
        Boinpally). It is alleged that the cash was delivered in bags at the
        places directed and was received by A-21 (Vinod Chauhan), forming
        part of the alleged transfer of proceeds of crime in connection with the
        Excise Policy conspiracy.


   981.                   The prosecution further alleges that images of GC Notes of
        ₹10 denomination were recovered from the mobile phone of A-21, and
        that the serial numbers of these notes corresponded with those
        allegedly used in hawala transactions involving transfer of about ₹18
        crores to A-16 (Chanpreet Singh Rayat) and Rajiv Ashok Mondkar. It
        is also alleged that screenshots containing serial numbers of ₹10
        currency notes received from the mobile phone of A-16 were found
        stored in the device of A-21 Vinod Chauhan.

982.                     On the basis of the aforesaid material, the prosecution
        alleges that A-21 Vinod Chauhan acted on behalf of A-18 Arvind
        Kejriwal and AAP as a conduit for transferring alleged ill-gotten
        money generated from the Excise Policy conspiracy to Goa through
        hawala channels. It is alleged that the cash so transferred was utilised
        by A-16 Chanpreet Singh Rayat for making payments in cash to
        vendors, assembly managers, booth in-charges, volunteers and other
        persons engaged by AAP for the Goa Assembly Elections 2021–22.



        Allegation against A-22

   983.                     It is the prosecution case that A-22 Ashish Chand
        Mathur acted in close coordination with A-21 Vinod Chauhan in the
        alleged transfer and routing of proceeds of crime arising out of the
        Excise Policy conspiracy. It is alleged that A-22 functioned as an
        intermediary and facilitator in the hawala/angadiya network used for
        moving cash from Delhi to Goa.

   984.                     According to the prosecution, A-22 Ashish Chand
        Mathur was associated with Delhi-based angadiya operators and
        freelance angadiyas, including Chandan Kumar Tripathi @ Chandan,
        through whom large amounts of cash were allegedly routed to Goa. It
        is alleged that A-22 provided cash to such angadiyas for onward

transmission through hawala channels to recipients in Goa, including
        A-16 Chanpreet Singh Rayat and Rajiv Ashok Mondkar.

   985.                     The prosecution further alleges that call detail records
        and digital evidence establish telephonic contact between A-22 Ashish
        Chand Mathur and various persons involved in the alleged cash
        movement, including angadiya operators and other co-accused. It is
        alleged that A-22 acted in coordination with A-21 Vinod Chauhan and
        accused Vinod Chauhan’s network to ensure delivery of cash amounts
        forming part of the alleged ₹25.50 crores routed to Goa.

   986.                     It is alleged that the role of A-22 Ashish Chand Mathur
        was not independent but was integrally connected with the activities
        of A-21 Vinod Chauhan, and that together they acted as conduits for
        transferring alleged illicit funds to Goa for use in election-related
        expenditure of AAP during the Goa Assembly Elections 2022.


        Analysis

        (i) Chain 1. M/S Ashil corporation

   987.                     PW-182, Shri Ashokbhai Prahladbhai Shah, who was
        working as the Manager at the CG Road Branch of M/S R. Kantilal
        Finance and Courier Service, Ahmedabad, has stated that he was the
        person responsible for making and maintaining the entries relating to
        cash transactions at the said branch. He states that the documents

seized by the investigating agency pertain to routine Angadiya
        transactions recorded during the normal course of business. PW-182
        further clarifies that the entries relating to cash transferred to Goa were
        communicated by him to PW-180 (Sagar Patel), who was managing
        the Goa operations, for onward delivery.

   988.                     The statement of PW-182 clearly indicates that the
        Ahmedabad branch acted only as an intermediate transit point. The
        cash was received at Ahmedabad from third parties and thereafter
        transferred to the Goa branch of M/S R. Kantilal Finance and Courier
        Service for delivery to the end recipient, as per the instructions
        received.

   989.                     PW-183, Shri Ashokbhai Chandulal Shah, the proprietor
        of M/S Ashil Corporation and a freelance Angadiya operator, explains
        the source and movement of this cash. He states that he facilitated the
        transfer of cash amounts on the instructions of Rajesh Joshi (A-12)
        and his employee Damodar (A-15). According to PW-183, the money
        was first handed over to Angadiya firms at Delhi, then routed through
        Ahmedabad or Mumbai, and finally delivered at Goa through M/S R.
        Kantilal Finance and Courier Service. He categorically states that
        during the period July 2021 to September 2021, cash aggregating to
        approximately ₹5–7 crores was transferred to Goa in several instances,
        and that one additional transfer of ₹5 crores was effected at the end of
        December 2021.

990.                     PW-183 further clarifies that the December 2021
        transfer of ₹5 crores was over and above the earlier transfers made
        during July–September 2021. He states that the recipient at Goa for
        these transfers was “Preet” during the earlier period, and “Rajiv” in
        the December 2021 transaction. He also admits that his role was
        confined to arranging and facilitating the transfer through Angadiya
        networks and receiving confirmation of delivery; he does not state that
        he personally counted, verified, or physically handled the cash at the
        destination point.

   991.                     Read conjointly, the statements of PW-182 and PW-183
        bring out a simple picture:

        (i) the cash originated from Delhi-based persons (identified by
        PW-183 as Shri Rajesh Joshi and Shri Damodar), (ii) it was routed
        through Angadiya firms operating at Delhi, Ahmedabad and/or
        Mumbai,

        (iii) the Ahmedabad branch of M/S R. Kantilal Finance functioned
        only as a transit node, and (iv) the deliveries at Goa took place over a
        defined period, namely July 2021 to September 2021, with one
        additional instance in December 2021, aggregating to approximately
        ₹10 crores in total, as per PW-183’s own estimation.

992.                     On a conjoint reading of the statements, the prosecution
        version regarding the movement of cash may be depicted in a clear
        and sequential manner as under:

                            Rajesh Joshi / DamodarSharma
                                 (A-12 & A-13, Delhi)
                                           │
                                           ▼
                              Ashokbhai Chandulal Shah
                                       (PW-183)
                          Angadiya – M/S Ashil Corporation
                                           │
                                           ▼
                     M/S R. Kantilal Finance & Courier Service
                             Ahmedabad Branch, Gujarat
                 (Manager: Ashokbhai Prahladbhai Shah – PW-182)
                                           │
                                           ▼
                     M/S R. Kantilal Finance & Courier Service
                                      Goa Branch
                          (Manager: Sagar Patel – PW-180)
                                            │
                                            ▼
                               Final Recipients at Goa
                      • “Preet” – during July to September 2021
                   (alleged as Accused No. 16 – Charanpreet Rayat)
                          • “Rajiv” – during December 2021
                                  (examined as PW-181)
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
993.                     As per the prosecution witnesses themselves, the alleged
        cash originated from Rajesh Joshi and Damodar Sharma (A-12 and
        A-13) at Delhi. The said cash was first entrusted to PW-183
        (Ashokbhai Chandulal Shah), who functioned as an Angadiya through
        M/S Ashil Corporation. From there, the cash was routed to the
        Ahmedabad branch of M/S R. Kantilal Finance & Courier Service,
        where PW-182, as Branch Manager, maintained the accounts and
        facilitated onward transmission.

   994.                     Thereafter, the cash was sent to the Goa branch of M/S
        R. Kantilal Finance & Courier Service, which was managed by
        PW-180 (Sagar Patel). The final delivery at Goa, as per the prosecution
        case, was made to “Preet” (alleged A-16) during the period July to
        September 2021, and to “Rajiv” in December 2021, the latter having
        been examined as PW-181.

   995.                     Thus, the prosecution’s own version delineates a linear
        Angadiya chain involving multiple intermediaries across Delhi →
        Ahmedabad → Goa, with each witness attributing to himself a limited,
        facilitative role confined to routing and delivery, without any assertion
        of personal verification, counting, or independent knowledge of the
        contents of the cash parcels at the point of final delivery.


        (ii) Chain-2 (K.S. Enterprises) attributed to A-15

996.                     In Chain-2, the prosecution seeks to attribute a cash
        amount of ₹7,10,00,000/- to A-15. The foundation of this allegation
        rests primarily on the statements of PW-191, Shri Devang Dhirubhai
        Solanki, stated to be in charge of the Delhi office of K.S. Enterprises,
        whose statement under Section 161 of Cr.P.C. was recorded on
        08.05.2023, followed by his statement under Section 164 of Cr.P.C. on
        18.05.2023 (D-239). PW-191 alleges that A-15 handed over cash to
        him on five to six occasions, which was thereafter delivered at Goa
        through M/S R. Kantilal & Sons to A-16.

   997.                     To lend support to this allegation, the prosecution relies
        upon the statement of PW-180, Shri Sagar Patel, Manager of the Goa
        office of M/S R. Kantilal Finance and Courier Service. PW-180
        translates certain handwritten pauti records and asserts that the figures
        recorded therein are truncated and that the actual amount delivered is
        to be ascertained by adding three zeroes to the figures mentioned.

   998.                     It appears that the entries translated by PW-180 in his
        statement, existing at Serial Nos. 17, 18, 19, 20 and 21, pertain to the
        period 04.01.2022 to 10.01.2022, with the amounts written as ₹9,900,
        ₹9,950, ₹13,432, ₹29,850 and ₹7,960, which, upon application of the
        witness’s own method, translate to ₹99,00,000/-, ₹99,50,000/-,
        ₹1,34,32,000/-, ₹2,98,50,000/- and ₹79,60,000/- respectively. On the

prosecution’s showing, these entries are sought to be treated as
        reflecting deliveries at Goa in early January 2022.


        (iii) Chain-3:Cash Transfer through Delhi-based Angadias via
        Freelance Angadia PW-189 (Chandan Kumar Tripathi)

   999.                     Sub-Chain (A): Alleged Transfer of ₹3.50 Crores
        (28.09.2021–29.09.2021) PW-189 (Sarvesh Kumar Yadav) states that
        on 28.09.2021, a sum of ₹1,50,000/- was collected from Ashish
        Mathur at an office situated opposite Lodhi Hotel, Delhi Jal Board
        premises, and on 29.09.2021, a further sum of ₹2,crores was collected
        from C-97, First Floor, Defence Colony, New Delhi. According to
        PW-189 the said amounts were collected jointly by him and PW-190 ,
        transported in multiple instalments of approximately ₹50 lakhs per
        trip, and handed over in Delhi to Hashmukh Bhai of M/S Kirti Kumar
        Amba Lal Angadia Firm, Chandni Chowk. PW-189 further states that
        token/note numbers and the mobile number of the intended recipient
        were provided, and that his role ended with the delivery of cash to the
        Angadia firm in Delhi. PW-189, in material conformity with PW-190
        to this extent, also refers to the collection of an aggregate amount of
        ₹3.50 crores on 28.09.2021 and 29.09.2021 and its transfer from Delhi
        to Goa through Angadia channels.

   1000.                    However, PW-189 introduces additional elements not
        stated by PW-190, namely that the cash was transferred through M/S

Maa Ambe Angadia, and that the delivery at Goa was effected through
        M/S Kantilal Courier Service, managed by Sagar, to Preet, whom the
        prosecution seeks to project as A-16. Thus, while PW-190’s statement
        is confined to collection in Delhi and handover to Hashmukh Bhai of
        M/S Kirti Kumar Amba Lal, PW-189 extends the chain beyond Delhi
        by asserting delivery at Goa, naming the courier firm and the recipient.
        PW-190 does not speak of M/S Maa Ambe, M/S Kantilal Courier
        Service, Sagar, or Preet, nor does he claim any knowledge of the Goa-
        end delivery.


   1001.                    Sub-Chain (B): Alleged Transfer of ₹22 Crores
        (Undated / Cumulative) In the concluding portion of his statement,
        PW-189 alone states that, apart from the ₹3.50 crores, he facilitated
        the transfer of a further sum aggregating to ₹22 crores from Delhi to
        Goa. He states that this amount was routed through multiple Delhi-
        based Angadia firms, namely M/S Kirti Amba (Hashmukh Bhai), M/S
        Maa Ambe (Jagat Bhai), and M/S Neel Kant (Vishal Bhai). According
        to PW-189, this amount was delivered at Goa through M/S Kantilal
        Courier Service, managed by Sagar, to Rajeev, and the prosecution
        seeks to attribute such receipt to Rajeev acting on behalf of A-16.
        PW-190, however, is completely silent on any such transfer of ₹22
        crores. He does not refer to any collection, transportation, handover,
        Angadia routing, or delivery, whether in Delhi or Goa, of this amount.

No date-wise breakup, source-wise attribution, or mode of collection
        of the alleged ₹22 crores finds mention in the statement of PW-190.

        (iv) Angadia “Pauti” Documents (D-Series) Tested on the Touchstone
        of V.C. Shukla (supra) (Jain Hawala Case)

   1002.                    A careful examination of the prosecution’s own
        documentary index and witness disclosures reveals that the Angadia
        evidence relied upon in the present Excise Policy case rests entirely
        upon a set of so-called “pauti” documents marked as D-series exhibits
        (inter alia D-210, D-211, D-227, D-230, D-231, D-232, D-239,
        D-243). These documents have been produced through Angadia
        witnesses including PW-180, PW-186, PW-189, PW-191 and others.
        The prosecution’s own description of these documents is of decisive
        evidentiary significance. The pautis produced by the respective
        witnesses are set out below in tabular form. In addition, certain
        scanned copies of the said pautis are reproduced for the limited

1003.                    The overwhelming majority of these exhibits are
        recorded as plain white loose sheets, photocopies of white plain sheets,
        old yellowish loose pages, bis-size loose pages, or at best isolated
        ruled register pages, uniformly handwritten in pencil, with several
        pages being partly blank and unstructured. None of these documents
        are shown to be bound, paginated, contemporaneously maintained, or
        part of any continuous or regularly kept ledger in the ordinary course
        of business.

   1004.                    A witness-wise scrutiny further reinforces this infirmity.
        PW-180 Sagar K. Patel / R. Kanti Lal Patel, produced through Sh.

Ashok Bhai Prahlad Bhai, Manager, R. Kanti Lal Finance & Courier,
        has brought on record documents D-210 & D-211 (running into
        multiple sets of pages) and D-227, described as files consisting
        entirely of photocopies of white plain sheets, handwritten, and normal
        ruled register pages written in pencil. PW-186 Hashmukh Bhai Kala
        Bhai, In-charge, Kriti Kumar Amba Lal Angadiya, produced
        documents D-230 (02 pages, plain white sheets handwritten in pencil),
        D-231 (06 pages of register handwritten in pencil), D-232 (02 pages
        of old yellowish loose sheets handwritten in pencil with headings in
        red), and D-233 (statement of Chandra Kumar Tripathi, freelance
        Angadiya). PW-189 Chandan Kumar Tripathi produced D-243 &
        D-260, described as 06 bis-size loose pages handwritten in pencil.
        PW-191 Devang Solanki, In-charge, M/S K.S. Enterprises (also
        examined under Section 164 of Cr.P.C. as Devang Dhirubhai Solanki),
        produced D-271 & D-239, again not shown to be bound, paginated, or
        maintained as part of any regular books of account. Other Angadia
        witnesses, PW-183 Ashok Bhai Chandulal Shah (Owner, Ashil Corp),
        PW-187 Ishwar Bhai Patel (Manager), PW-188 Jagat Singh G. Thakor
        (Owner, Maa Ambe Co.), PW-192 Patel Murgesh Bhai Popatlal @
        Chintu Bhai (R. Kantilal Courier & Financial Service), PW-193 Vishal
        Kumar Bhartbhai Patel (In-charge, Nilkhant Enterprises), and PW-194
        Binit Kumar Popat Lal Patel (Manager, R. Kanti Lal), are all linked to
        the same genre of informal, loose Angadia records.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
1005.                    What unmistakably emerges is that the prosecution itself
        characterises the Angadia “pauti” material as loose, detachable, pencil-
        written sheets, often partly blank, with no witness asserting that these
        papers formed part of any bound, paginated or regularly maintained
        ledger kept in the ordinary course of Angadia business.

   1006.                    This factual position brings the Angadia “pauti” material
        into direct and unavoidable comparison with the documentary
        foundation examined by the Hon’ble Supreme Court in V.C. Shukla
        (supra). In that case, searches at the premises of J.K. Jain yielded
        diaries, notebooks and loose sheets containing alleged coded entries
        of receipts and payments. The Supreme Court recorded that the entire
        edifice of the prosecution case rested on those diaries and loose papers,
        and proceeded to test their admissibility and evidentiary value under
        Section 34 of the Evidence Act. The Court authoritatively has observed
        that: “...Book’ ordinarily means a collection of sheets of paper or other
        material… fastened or bound together so as to form a material
        whole. Loose sheets or scraps of paper cannot be termed as ‘book’ for
        they can be easily detached and replaced….”.

   1007.                    Applying this test, it was categorically concluded that
        loose sheets could not be treated as books of account at all. Even in
        respect of spiral notebooks which were treated as “books”, the Court
        sounded a further and decisive caution:

“...From a plain reading of the Section it is manifest that…
                even if the above requirements are fulfilled and the entry
                becomes admissible as relevant evidence, still, the statement
                made therein shall not alone be sufficient evidence to charge
                any person with liability….”.
   1008.                    The rationale for this statutory limitation was explained
        in words of enduring relevance:

                “...Since… an element of self-interest and partisanship of the
                entrant… cannot be ruled out, the additional safeguard of
                insistence upon other independent evidence… has been
                provided for in Section 34 by incorporating the words ‘such
                statements shall not alone be sufficient to charge any person
                with liability’…”.
   1009.                    Ultimately, while dealing with allegations against Shri
        L.K. Advani and Shri V.C. Shukla, the Hon’ble Supreme Court held:

                “…..A conspectus of the above decisions makes it evident
                that even correct and authentic entries in books of account
                cannot without independent evidence of their trustworthiness,
                fix a liability upon a person….Keeping in view the above
                principles… those entries would not be sufficient to charge
                Shri Advani and Shri Shukla… for there is not an iota of
                independent evidence in support thereof….”.
   1010.                    When these settled principles are applied to the Angadia
        “pauti” material in the present case, the infirmity becomes even more
        pronounced. Unlike the Jain Hawala matter, where at least some spiral
        notebooks were treated as “books”, the D-series documents here are
        overwhelmingly loose sheets, photocopies, or isolated register pages,
        written in pencil, with no proof of regular maintenance in the course
        of business. Their detachable, incomplete and informal nature renders

them inherently vulnerable to interpolation and manipulation, and
        wholly unreliable as legal evidence.
                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   1011.                    Even assuming, for the sake of argument, that such
        “pauti” entries could be looked at for a collateral purpose, V.C.
        Shukla (supra) decisively holds that entries by themselves, howsoever
        voluminous, cannot fasten criminal liability without independent
        corroboration. No such independent evidence, whether by way of
        lawful recovery from the accused, admissible banking or financial
        trail, contemporaneous electronic records, or proof of demand,
        acceptance or conscious possession, has been placed on record in
        support of the Angadia notings.

   1012.                    Moreover, it is of decisive importance to note that the
        statements of the Angadia witnesses are not independent or self-
        contained narratives of any transaction. Their depositions are
        admittedly founded upon and derived from the so-called “pauti”
        entries. Once these entries are held to be legally inadmissible, or are
        otherwise denuded of probative value in light of the settled principles
        laid down in V.C. Shukla (supra), the testimonial edifice erected upon
        them cannot be sustained. The witnesses merely seek to explain or
        interpret the pauti notings; they do not depose to any contemporaneous
        act of payment, receipt, delivery, or conscious handling of cash by the
        accused, independent of those writings.

1013.                    The Angadia witnesses, inter alia PW-180, PW-186,
        PW-189, PW-191 and allied witnesses, are not neutral observers. By
        their own showing, they are persons allegedly involved in the very
        mechanism through which cash is claimed to have been transported or
        handled. While their statements seek to exonerate themselves by
        asserting absence of participation in any conspiracy or lack of
        knowledge regarding the origin of the cash amounts, the same
        statements nonetheless bring them within the legal contours of
        abetment. For understanding the scope of the expression “aid”
        occurring in the third clause of Section 107 IPC, reference may be
        made to Explanation 2 thereto, which reads as under:

                “….Whoever, either prior to or at the time of the commission
                of an act, does anything in order to facilitate the commission of
                that act, and thereby facilitates the commission thereof, is said
                to aid the doing of that act….”.
   1014.                    Tested on this statutory explanation, the role attributed to
        the Angadia witnesses, as emerging from their own depositions,
        renders their statement accomplice-like in character. In criminal
        jurisprudence, such evidence is inherently suspect and cannot, in law,
        form the sole basis of criminal liability without strict and independent
        corroboration. A witness cannot be permitted to corroborate his own
        legally infirm document, nor can mere repetition of such statements
        elevate them to the status of independent proof. As has been discussed
        on multiple occasions, the statement of one accomplice cannot serve

to corroborate the statement of another accomplice. In other words,
        accomplice evidence cannot be mutually corroborative in law.
        Reliance is placed upon the judgments of Hon’ble Supreme Court in
        K. Hashim (supra), Somasundaram (supra), Laxmipat Choraria
        (supra) and A.R. Antulay (supra).

   1015.                    This position stands squarely supported by V.C. Shukla
        (supra), wherein the Hon’ble Supreme Court rejected the prosecution’s
        attempt to utilise statements of certain alleged recipients to validate
        diary entries against others, holding that such statements could, at best,
        establish reliability of the entries qua the maker or recipient alone, and
        not operate as independent corroboration against third parties.

   1016.                    Consequently, the alleged “chain of payment” sought to
        be projected by the prosecution is rendered wholly speculative. With
        the foundational pauti entries excluded from consideration, the
        purported links in the chain remain suspended in mid-air, without any
        legally admissible anchor at either end. There is no lawful recovery,
        no contemporaneous banking or financial trail and no proof of
        demand, acceptance, or conscious possession of the alleged proceeds
        of crime.

   1017.                    The prosecution’s case, in substance, rests primarily and
        substantially on the pauti entries to demonstrate the movement of
        money in cash, characterised as “proceeds of crime”. Once those
        entries fail the test of admissibility and evidentiary reliability, the

entire narrative of cash movement collapses. What remains are
        allegations unsupported by legally sustainable material, denuded of
        continuity, corroboration, or evidentiary linkage.

   1018.                    Accordingly, this Court is constrained to observe that the
        prosecution has failed to cross the basic evidentiary threshold required
        even at the stage of framing of charge. Treating the Angadia witnesses
        as accomplice-like witnesses, and applying the settled principles
        reiterated in V.C. Shukla (supra), the absence of independent
        corroboration proves fatal. The narrative of cash movement and
        alleged proceeds of crime, once stripped of its inadmissible
        foundation, collapses in its entirety, leaving the allegations bereft of
        substance, continuity, or prima facie legal support.

        (v) Appreication of Statement of PW-180 (Angadiya Records and
        Cash-Delivery Entries)
   1019.                    Admittedly, PW-180, Patel Sagar Kumar, was the
        Manager of the Goa office of M/S Kantilal Finance and Courier
        Service, an Angadia firm which, as per the prosecution’s own case,
        was the only such firm operating at Goa during the relevant period. It
        is the prosecution’s categorical stand that the so-called pauti entries
        spoken to by PW-180 constitute the pivotal material relied upon to
        bridge and complete the alleged chain of delivery of cash at the Goa
        end.

1020.                    In this backdrop, the statement of PW-180 assumes a
        position of central importance. The pauti entries relied upon are not
        peripheral or corroborative in nature; rather, they are projected as the
        primary basis to establish both the factum of delivery and the alleged
        receipt of cash. Consequently, the figures recorded therein, the manner
        in which such figures are sought to be interpreted, and the method
        adopted to arrive at the alleged quantum of money received and
        disbursed cannot be accepted at face value. They necessarily warrant
        close and careful scrutiny, particularly in the absence of
        contemporaneous, systematically maintained records or independent
        corroboration.           Any   inconsistency,   exaggeration,   or      internal
        incongruity in the quantification of amounts would, therefore, strike at
        the very foundation of the prosecution’s alleged money-movement
        chain.

   1021.                    PW-180 an Angadiya associated with M/S Kantibhai
        (Kantilal) Finance and Courier Service, is projected by the prosecution
        as the author of certain handwritten “pauti” records seized during an
        Income-Tax raid at the premises of the said entity in Goa. The witness
        states that these records were prepared by him in Gujarati, in the
        regular course of business, and that the entries reflected cash receipts
        and deliveries effected through the Angadiya channel.

   1022.                    According to PW-180, the cash amounts noted in the
        pauti were received at Goa by one “Preet”, described as a Sardar, and

one “Prince”. The prosecution seeks to identify “Preet” as A-16 and
        “Prince” as A-14. On the basis of the said pauti, the prosecution
        alleges, in cumulative terms, that A-16 ultimately received cash
        aggregating to about ₹44.5 crores in Goa, and that A-14 received
        certain amounts in three transactions.

   1023.                    PW-180 further explains a crucial feature of the record-
        keeping practice followed by the Angadiya establishment. He
        categorically states that the figures written in the column titled
        “Amount” do not represent the full cash amount, and that the actual
        figure transferred is to be obtained by adding three zeroes to the figure
        mentioned. At the last para PW-180 categorically states that “ the
        actual figure transferred can be obtained by adding three zeroes in the
        finger mentioned in coloumn titled amount. It is in practice that we do
        not write last three zeroes of the actual amount transferred in our
        records. In case the amount dealt do not contain zero in last three
        places than we write the full amount and put a stroke before digit at
        hundreds place”. He clarifies that, as a matter of practice, the last three
        zeroes of the actual amount are not written; where the amount does not
        end with three zeroes, the full amount is written with a stroke before
        the digit at the hundreds place. This explanation is expressly recorded
        by the witness in the concluding portion of his statement.

   1024.                    Applying the witness’s own explanation, and translating
        the pauti entries accordingly, the amounts allegedly received by

“Preet” (attributed to A-16) are reflected in Serial Nos. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6,
        7, 8, 9 and 11 to 21 of the table relied upon by PW-180. The amounts
        attributed to “Prince” (alleged to be A-14) are reflected at Serial Nos.
        10, 11 and 16.

   1025.                    For clarity, and strictly on the basis of PW-180’s own
        statement that three zeroes are to be added, the translated chart may be
        depicted as under:

        Translated Chart (Amounts After Adding Three Zeroes, as per
        PW-180)

   1026.                    PW-180 thereafter makes a sweeping assertion that, in
        aggregate, a sum of ₹17,54,22,500/- was delivered to “Preet, Preeti
        and Prince” at Goa, and a further sum of ₹27,00,00,000/- was
        delivered to one “Raju/Rajiv” at Goa. On this basis, the prosecution
        alleges that A-14 received ₹16,08,000/- in three transactions, and that
        a sum of ₹27 crores was received by Rajiv Ashok Mondkar on behalf
        of A-16.

   1027.                    Applying PW-180’s own clarification that the “actual
        figure transferred can be obtained by adding three zeroes” to the
        amount mentioned in the pauti, the entries relating to Raju/Rajiv
        translate as under:

        C. Entries Relating to “Raju/Rajiv”:

        8             20.11.2021            10,000                          1,00,00,000

        10            22.11.2021            10,000                          1,00,00,000
        11            23.11.2021            15,000                          1,50,00,000
        12            24.11.2021            10,000                          1,00,00,000
        13            24.11.2021            15,000                          1,50,00,000

        Total (Raju/Rajiv): ₹27,00,00,000/- (₹27 crores)

   1028.                    The prosecution seeks to identify “Raju/Rajiv” as Rajiv
        Ashok Mondkar, who has been examined as PW-181. When the
        entirety of the amounts reflected under Heading ‘A’ (entries attributed
        to “Preet”), are cumulatively added with the amounts reflected under
        Heading ‘B’ (entries attributed to “Prince”) and Heading ‘C’ (entries
        relating to Raju/Rajiv, alleged to have been collected on behalf of
        A-16), the aggregate figure attributable to A-16 works out as under:

               Heading ‘A’ (Preet): ₹76,95,02,000/-

               Heading ‘B’ (Prince): ₹16,08,000/-

               Heading ‘C’ (Raju/Rajiv): ₹27,00,00,000/-

               Total Aggregate: ₹1,04,11,10,000/- (approximately ₹104.11
                crores).

1029.                    This cumulative figure, arrived at strictly by applying
        PW-180’s own stated method of adding three zeroes to the amounts
        mentioned in the pauti, stands in stark and irreconcilable contrast to
        the prosecution’s projected figure of approximately ₹44.5 crores
        allegedly received by A-16. The magnitude of this divergence
        underscores that the prosecution’s computation is not borne out by the
        internal arithmetic of the very documents and statement on which
        reliance is placed.

   1030.                    When the entries are accepted as explained by PW-180
        himself, and the amounts are mechanically recalculated by adding
        three zeroes to the figures written in the pauti, the resultant totals travel
        far beyond the figures selectively projected by the prosecution. The
        internal arithmetic emerging from the witness’s own method does not
        align with the prosecution’s stated aggregates, either qua A-16 or qua
        A-14.

   1031.                    This   figure   stands   in   stark   and   irreconcilable
        contradiction to the prosecution’s projected figure of approximately
        ₹44.5 crores allegedly received by A-16. The incongruity is not
        marginal but fundamental, and flows directly from the witness’s own
        explanation of the accounting practice.

   1032.                    Thus, when the statement of PW-180 is read as a whole,
        and applied in the manner expressly stated by him, the prosecution’s
        numerical conclusions are shown to be the result of selective

extraction and truncation of the very records relied upon. The
        statement of PW-181 does not cure this defect, as he nowhere asserts
        having verified, opened, or counted the cash allegedly delivered. Read
        conjointly, the statements of PW-180 and PW-181 render the
        prosecution theory on quantum not merely doubtful but internally
        inconsistent at the threshold stage, undermining the reliability of the
        figures sought to be projected against the accused.

   1033.                    This incongruity assumes significance at the threshold
        stage, as it demonstrates that the prosecution’s numerical conclusions
        are not a natural or inevitable consequence of PW-180’s statement, but
        depend upon selective extraction and truncation of the very records on
        which reliance is placed.

   1034.                    Thus, when the statement of PW-180 is read as a whole,
        and applied in the manner expressly stated by him, the prosecution’s
        numerical conclusions are shown to be the result of selective
        extraction and truncation of the very records relied upon. The
        statement of PW-181 does not cure this defect, as he nowhere asserts
        having verified, opened, or counted the cash allegedly delivered. Read
        conjointly, the statements of PW-180 and PW-181 render the
        prosecution theory on quantum not merely doubtful but internally
        inconsistent at the threshold stage, undermining the reliability of the
        figures sought to be projected against the accused.

1035.                    It emerges as an admitted position from the record that
        A-12, A-13, A-14, 15, 16, 21 and 22 were not participants in any
        meeting, discussion or interaction in which the alleged conspiracy to
        manipulate the DEP-21/22 is claimed to have been conceived,
        deliberated upon or executed. Equally, there is no material to suggest
        that either these accused or M/S Chariot Productions Media Pvt. Ltd.,
        APPL and IANPL had any direct or indirect engagement with any
        wholesaler or retail licensee operating under the DEP-21/22. In the
        absence of any policy-side linkage, participation or nexus, the
        prosecution’s case necessarily shifts away from acts of manipulation
        and rests entirely on a theory of alleged “knowledge”, namely, that the
        funds utilised during the Goa election campaign were purportedly
        “proceeds of crime”.

   1036.                    It is also not in dispute that M/S Chariot Productions
        Media Pvt. Ltd. undertook campaign-related work for the Aam Aadmi
        Party in Goa. The prosecution itself relies upon the statement of
        PW-91 and places on record multiple release orders, work instructions
        and execution of campaign activities. The case, therefore, is not
        founded on an allegation of fictitious or non-existent work, nor does
        the prosecution advance a case of a sham or shell entity floated to
        camouflage transactions. The gravamen of the allegation is confined
        to the asserted mode and manner of expenditure, rather than the
        absence of any underlying campaign activity.

1037.                    The prosecution seeks to bridge this gap primarily
        through angadiya witnesses, loose slips, private notings and allied
        materials, supplemented by call detail records. In law, however, such
        material does not, by its mere existence, establish either the source and
        taint of the funds, the requisite knowledge on the part of the accused,
        or any agreement or common design constituting a criminal
        conspiracy. As settled in V.C. Shukla (supra), loose sheets and private
        records maintained in the course of business do not acquire the status
        of substantive evidence merely because they are seized and produced.
        Further, angadiya witnesses, who admittedly speak to sustained cash
        movement through informal channels, bear an accomplice-like
        character, and their statement, as a matter of prudence, requires
        independent corroboration on material particulars, which is
        conspicuously absent on the present record. Reliance is again placed
        upon the judgments of Hon’ble Supreme Court in K. Hashim (supra),
        Somasundaram (supra), Laxmipat Choraria (supra) and A.R. Antulay
        (supra).

   1038.                    Call detail records and evidence of physical presence, at
        best, establish contact or connectivity. They do not disclose the content
        of the communication or the purpose of the interaction. Absent
        admissible and reliable material of the criminal context or subject
        matter of such calls or meetings, mere telephonic contact or presence
        cannot be elevated into “grave suspicion” of conspiracy or imputed

knowledge of alleged proceeds of crime. To do so would be to
        substitute conjecture for proof, and inference for evidence, a course
        impermissible even at the threshold stage of consideration.

   1039.                    On a cumulative appreciation of (i) the prosecution’s
        own structuring of the three chains; (ii) the admitted position of no
        policy-side nexus qua A-12, A-15, A-16,A-21 and A-22; (iii) the
        prosecution’s reliance on loose sheets/private angadiya records and
        accomplice-like versions; and (iv) the binding controls in Laxmipat
        Choraria (supra), A.R. Antulay (supra) and V.C. Shukla (supra), this
        Court finds that the prosecution has not supplied the legally required
        bridges of proof to sustain, even at the threshold, the allegation of
        conspiracy or conscious handling of proceeds of crime against A-12,
        A-13, A-14, A-15, A-16, A-21 and A-22.

   1040.                    The prosecution material, at its highest, demonstrates a
        narrative of alleged cash routing/delivery within the angadiya
        ecosystem. It does not, on legally admissible and independently
        corroborated material, establish (a) the criminal provenance of the
        cash as “proceeds of crime” of an excise-policy conspiracy; (b)
        knowledge or reason to believe in that provenance; or (c) a meeting of
        minds amounting to criminal conspiracy. The deficiencies are not
        minor “missing links”; they go to the root, because the prosecution’s
        edifice seeks to derive guilt from inadmissible/private records,

uncorroborated accomplice-like statement, and neutral technical data,
        an approach expressly cautioned against in V.C. Shukla (supra).

        Foundational Issues Requiring Consideration                   Before        Final
        Determination at the Stage of Order on Charge
   1041.                    Upon a holistic consideration of the entire record,
        including the material placed by the prosecution, the rival submissions
        addressed, and the analysis undertaken by this Court, it becomes
        necessary, before proceeding to the final determination at the stage of
        order on charge, to foreground certain foundational aspects of the case.
        The present matter does not involve a conventional allegation of
        bribery founded upon a direct quid pro quo between a bribe giver and
        a bribe taker. Instead, the prosecution advances a far more expansive
        narrative, alleging impropriety in the formulation of a public policy
        and seeking to implicate, in one broad sweep, public servants,
        members of the political executive, private businessmen, political
        party functionaries, and even party volunteers.

   1042.                    In doing so, the prosecution narrative travels beyond the
        traditional contours of corruption jurisprudence and enters the
        sensitive constitutional terrain of the electoral process itself, by
        attempting to link the alleged policy formulation with expenditure
        stated to have been incurred during a State election. Such an approach,
        by its very nature, raises issues of grave constitutional and institutional
        consequence, as it risks casting a generalized cloud of criminal

suspicion over the electoral process as a whole, rather than confining
        scrutiny to clearly identifiable acts constituting defined criminal
        offences.

   1043.                    It is against this backdrop that this Court considers it
        imperative to pause and examine certain fundamental questions before
        recording its final view on the issue of framing of charge. The breadth
        of the allegations, the spectrum of actors sought to be drawn within
        the prosecutorial net, and the manner in which electoral expenditure
        and political activity are sought to be subsumed within the criminal
        domain call for careful and principled scrutiny. These issues cannot be
        approached mechanically or in isolation; they demand a calibrated
        assessment, mindful of the settled limits of criminal law, the
        constitutional framework governing policy formulation and elections,
        and the degree of legal suspicion required at the stage of charge.

   1044.                    It is clarified that the issues discussed hereafter are not
        being taken as factors that have weighed with the Court while
        examining the material placed by the investigating agency. The record
        has been assessed strictly on the basis of the settled principles
        applicable at this stage, and the conclusion rests on that independent
        evaluation.

   1045.                    These issues were raised by the defence during the
        course of hearing. Since the submissions on behalf of the State have
        already been dealt with in detail, it is only appropriate to briefly deal

with these aspects as well. They are being noted to ensure that the
        discussion is complete. In a matter involving an extensive record and
        lengthy arguments, it would not be proper to leave such issues
        unaddressed. The ultimate conclusion is not dependent upon these
        aspects. They are mentioned only so that the consideration of the case
        remains full and balanced.

        (i) Intrusion into the Election Expenditure Domain — Separation of
        Powers and Electoral Federalism.
   1046.                    At the threshold, this Court considers it imperative to
        underscore that the constitutional scheme governing elections in India
        is consciously structured to insulate the electoral process from
        executive or investigative intrusion, save in strictly defined and
        constitutionally sanctioned circumstances. Article 324 of the
        Constitution of India vests in the Election Commission of India (ECI)
        the plenary power of superintendence, direction and control over
        elections, not as a matter of administrative convenience, but as a core
        constitutional safeguard designed to preserve the purity, neutrality, and
        credibility of the democratic process. This entrustment assumes
        heightened significance in the context of election campaigns, where
        allegations and counter-allegations of financial impropriety are an
        inevitable by-product of political contestation. The Constitution, fully
        cognisant of this reality, deliberately places such disputes within the
        supervisory competence of an independent constitutional authority,
        rather than the executive or its investigative arms.

1047.                    The Representation of the People Act, 1951 reinforces
        this constitutional design by constituting a complete and self-
        contained code in respect of election expenditure. Sections 77 and 78
        regulate the incurring and accounting of expenditure; Section 10A
        prescribes disqualification for failure to lodge a true and correct
        account; and Section 123(6) treats expenditure in excess of prescribed
        limits as a corrupt practice, remediable exclusively through an election
        petition under Sections 80 and 100 of the Act. The statutory
        architecture leaves no ambiguity: alleged breaches of expenditure
        norms are, in the first instance, electoral wrongs, not criminal offences,
        and are to be scrutinised by the Election Commission and adjudicated
        by the High Court exercising election jurisdiction.

   1048.                    The Act does not envisage, indeed, it consciously
        excludes, the routine or unilateral invocation of criminal machinery at
        the behest of rival political actors. This demarcation serves a
        foundational democratic purpose. If investigative agencies such as the
        CBI or enforcement authorities under the Prevention of Money
        Laundering Act, 2002 (PMLA) were permitted to enter the electoral
        arena merely on allegations of “cash spending”, “illegal funding”, or
        “unaccounted expenditure”, the inevitable consequence would be the
        criminalisation of electoral competition. Such an approach would arm
        the executive with coercive instruments capable of influencing
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
political outcomes, thereby eroding the level playing field that lies at
        the heart of free and fair elections.

   1049.                    When such allegations are sought to be re-characterised
        or “dressed up” as CBI cases or PMLA proceedings, an additional and
        more serious constitutional concern arises. The CBI has no inherent
        jurisdiction to investigate any offence; its authority flows solely from
        the Delhi Special Police Establishment Act, 1946, and may be
