        exercised only upon State consent, Central Government notification,
        or a specific judicial direction, as authoritatively held by the
        Constitution Bench in State of West Bengal v. Committee for
        Protection of Democratic Rights, (2010) 3 SCC 571. Election-funding
        disputes, absent disclosure of a distinct and independent penal offence,
        do not automatically satisfy this jurisdictional threshold.

   1050.                    To permit the CBI to independently assume jurisdiction
        over election-expenditure allegations would amount to the executive
        arrogating to itself a supervisory role over elections, a role which the
        Constitution has consciously and expressly denied to it. The position
        is no different, and indeed more restrictive, under the PMLA. The
        statute cannot be set in motion in a vacuum. It is predicated on the
        prior existence of a scheduled offence and the generation of “proceeds
        of crime” therefrom. Allegations of excess election expenditure, cash
        usage, or undeclared campaign spending do not, by themselves,
        constitute scheduled offences under the PMLA. It abundantly clear

that allegations of “hawala” or cash transactions, unaccompanied by
        independent, legally admissible evidence establishing the illegality of
        the source and its nexus with a defined offence, cannot sustain criminal
        prosecution. {Reliance is placed upon V.C. Shukla (supra)}.

   1051.                    This Court must also emphasise the rule of law
        dimension inherent in this constitutional arrangement. The rule of law
        demands that each constitutional actor operate within its assigned
        sphere. The Election Commission, as a constitutionally created and
        insulated body, is entrusted with maintaining electoral discipline and
        fairness. Investigative agencies, which form part of the executive,
        cannot be permitted to displace or supplant this constitutional
        authority by assuming functions that the Constitution has reserved for
        the ECI and the election courts. Any such substitution would not
        merely be irregular; it would represent a fundamental distortion of
        constitutional           governance,   undermining   both     democratic
        accountability and institutional balance. This Court therefore observes
        that Article 324 entrusts the Election Commission with the discretion
        to determine whether and when any matter warrants reference to
        investigative agencies. It is only upon such constitutionally anchored
        scrutiny, where material discloses a clear, standalone criminal offence,
        independent of election-law violations, that involvement of agencies
        like the CBI or the Enforcement Directorate may be contemplated. To
        permit investigative agencies to act independently, without such

referral or without disclosure of a legally cognisable scheduled
        offence, would be to invert the constitutional hierarchy, reducing the
        Election Commission to a peripheral observer in a domain where it is
        meant to be supreme.
                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   1052.                    Accordingly, this Court holds that investigations by the
        State police, the CBI, or the Enforcement Directorate cannot be
        initiated or sustained solely on allegations of election-funding
        irregularities and excess expenditure. The exclusive prerogative to
        examine such allegations, at least at the threshold, lies with the
        Election Commission of India, and the statutory remedy of an election
        petition under the Representation of the People Act, 1951 remains the
        primary judicial avenue for adjudication. Criminal law, and
        particularly the extraordinary and coercive regimes of the PC Act and
        the Prevention of Money Laundering Act, cannot be employed as a
        substitute for election-law remedies, nor as a device to convert
        political accusations into prosecutable offences, unless a clear,
        independent, and cognisable criminal offence, wholly distinct from
        election-law violations, is prima facie disclosed in accordance with
        law. Any attempt to do otherwise would strike at the very core of
        constitutional democracy, erode the rule of law, and imperil the
        neutrality and fairness of the electoral process itself.

(ii) Policy Deviation or Commercial Advantage, Without Proof of
        Mens Rea or Quid Pro Quo, Does Not Give Rise to Criminal
        Liability:
   1053.                    The issue that falls for consideration is whether an
        individual or a company alleged to have engaged in cartel-like conduct
        or practices said to result in monopolisation-acts asserted to run
        contrary to the objectives of the DEP-21/22-can, on that foundation
        alone, be exposed to criminal prosecution. The answer must be in the
        negative. A deviation from policy intent, or the securing of a
        commercial advantage within the contours of the policy framework,
        does not, by itself, attract criminal liability. Prosecution under the IPC,
        the PC Act, or any other penal statute requires the presence of specific
        acts satisfying the statutory ingredients of an offence. The
        consequences flowing from such conduct ordinarily lie in the
        regulatory and administrative sphere. These may include cancellation
        or suspension of licences, withdrawal of policy-based privileges,
        imposition of penalties, or recovery of undue gains realised contrary
        to the terms of the licence or the policy. These are matters governed
        by administrative and contractual principles regulating the relationship
        between the State and the licensee, and not by the criminal law.

   1054.                    Experience shows that whenever the Government
        revisits or restructures a regulatory regime, particularly in sectors
        moving towards public-private participation or increased private
        involvement, industry participants may seek to take advantage of

perceived gaps or flexibilities in the policy. Even if such attempts
        appear commercially opportunistic, they do not, without more, amount
        to criminality. Criminal culpability can arise only where the material
        discloses clear elements of fraud, forgery, bribery, quid pro quo,
        misappropriation, collusive abuse of official position, or any other act
        squarely covered by a penal provision. In BALCO Employees’ Union
        v. Union of India, (2002) 2 SCC 333, the Supreme Court emphasised
        that economic decisions taken by the Government, even when they
        benefit private entities or lead to concentration of economic power,
        cannot invite criminal consequences unless mala fides or statutory
        breach is demonstrated.

   1055.                    Mere financial loss to the State or commercial gain to a
        private party does not furnish a basis for criminal prosecution in the
        absence of evidence of corruption or unlawful enrichment. Even if a
        policy does not yield the desired outcome or because a private
        participant secures an advantage from operating within the policy
        framework.

   1056.                    The threshold for invoking criminal jurisdiction remains
        the existence of a culpable act that falls within the four corners of a
        penal statute; anything short of that is a matter for administrative
        regulation and not criminal adjudication.

        (iii) Policy Formulation, Reform, and the Limits of Criminal
        Prosecution

1057.                    The formulation, modification, or substitution of a
        public policy falls exclusively within the constitutional prerogative of
        the elected Legislature and the Executive. It is for these branches of
        Government to undertake an assessment of the prevailing
        circumstances, to weigh the strengths and weaknesses of the existing
        regime, to examine the lacunae that may have surfaced over time, and
        to determine whether a shift in policy is warranted in the larger interest
        of governance. Any such policy, whether newly introduced or revised,
        is subject to scrutiny in the democratic forums of Parliament or the
        State Legislature, where its objectives, effectiveness, advantages,
        limitations, and economic implications are debated and evaluated.
        These are the proper constitutional fora to decide whether a policy
        meets the socio-economic needs of a rapidly developing nation.

   1058.                    When matters squarely falling within this domain are
        thereafter viewed through a preconceived prism of conspiracy or
        presumed criminal intent, merely because complaints are drafted in a
        manner that casts aspersions on the new framework, often at the behest
        of those who had benefitted from the flaws of the earlier regime, it
        inevitably hampers the legitimate functioning of the State. Such an
        approach deters reform and discourages innovation in governance. A
        developing economy cannot afford a situation where bona fide policy
        choices are second-guessed as criminal ventures in the absence of any

statutory foundation or material demonstrating the essential
        ingredients of an offence.

   1059.                    Investigating agencies are not vested with, nor can they
        assume, the role of evaluating the economic wisdom, administrative
        soundness, or policy rationale of decisions taken by the competent
        executive authorities. Their statutory mandate is confined to
        investigating offences defined by law; it does not extend to examining
        whether a policy should or should not have been adopted. The
        initiation of criminal proceedings merely because a policy may have
        conferred incidental commercial advantage upon a private entity
        would amount to an impermissible conflation of policy outcomes with
        criminal culpability. Treating every consequence of a policy as
        potential evidence of wrongdoing not only distorts the legal
        framework but also threatens to paralyse the very process of
        governance. Such an approach creates an environment of
        apprehension among officials who act in good faith and in accordance
        with established procedure under the directions of the political
        executive.


   1060.                    Public administration cannot function in an atmosphere
        where officials are perpetually exposed to the risk of criminal
        prosecution for decisions taken within the authority of law, particularly
        when no element of mens rea or abuse of office is discernible. It is

essential for a developing nation that officers are afforded freedom
        from unwarranted harassment so that they may perform their duties
        with confidence and without fear. In the larger constitutional scheme,
        policymaking must remain insulated from investigative overreach.
        The criminal law cannot be invoked to substitute legislative debate,
        nor can it be converted into a tool to challenge the efficacy or
        correctness of policy. {Reliance is placed upon the judgment of
        Hon’ble Supreme Court in BALCO Employees’ Union (supra)}.
        Stability, certainty, and an assurance that honest administrative
        decisions will not be retrospectively subjected to criminal scrutiny are
        indispensable to the advancement of national development and the
        faithful implementation of executive decisions.

        FINAL OUTCOME AFTER EVALUATION

   1061.                    Upon examining the investigation in its sequential
        progression, this Court finds that the overall direction adopted by the
        investigating agency gives rise to a serious and legitimate concern
        touching upon the fundamentals of the rule of law and constitutional
        governance.

   1062.                    The investigation does not commence with the
        identification of essential ingredients to attract criminal offence, nor
        with the collection of legally admissible material demonstrating
        criminality in the formulation or execution of the DEP-21/22. Instead,

the investigation appears to alter its focus mid-course and proceeds in
        an ever-expanding sweep, seemingly driven by the question of who all
        can be brought within its fold. The investigative trail begins with a
        campaign-related company, then moves through small vendors and
        intermediaries, thereafter to angadiyas who admittedly operate
        organised cash-transfer networks, followed by house owners, hotel
        operators, political volunteers, contesting candidates, State-level
        office-bearers, and ultimately the national leadership. This widening
        arc does not appear to be founded on fresh or independent
        incriminating material emerging at each stage, but rather on a
        preconceived assumption of the existence of “proceeds of crime”,
        coupled with an apparent attempt to demonstrate that no segment has
        been left untouched in the purported effort to trace such proceeds.

   1063.                    A particularly troubling feature of this approach is the
        manner in which angadiyas are dealt with. Individuals who openly
        acknowledge operating systematic cash-movement syndicates are not
        proceeded against as accused, but are instead converted into
        prosecution witnesses. Their largely uncorroborated and self-serving
        statements are then employed to implicate persons placed
        progressively higher in the alleged chain. Such selective attribution of
        culpability inevitably weakens the evidentiary foundation and
        indicates an investigation structured to sustain a predetermined

narrative rather than one guided by impartial and objective fact-
        finding.

   1064.                    More fundamentally, the investigation strays into the
        constitutionally demarcated domain of election expenditure. By
        scrutinising campaign logistics, accommodation arrangements,
        political volunteers, and alleged cash payments, the investigating
        agency, in substance, undertakes a self-conducted audit of election
        spending. This field falls within the exclusive constitutional
        jurisdiction of the Election Commission of India. The assumption of
        such a role by an investigating agency amounts to an exercise of power
        not vested in it by law and runs contrary to the carefully balanced
        constitutional framework.

   1065.                    The implications of this approach are not merely legal,
        but constitutional in character. The rule of law requires that criminal
        investigation be anchored to clearly defined offences, follow a legally
        sanctioned sequence, and remain confined within jurisdictional limits.
        Constitutionalism demands that investigative power be exercised with
        restraint, sensitivity, and respect for institutional boundaries. An
        investigative environment that generates fear, where scrutiny travels
        indiscriminately from contesting candidates to small vendors who
        merely provide logistical support during elections, risks chilling
        legitimate political participation. In such an atmosphere of pervasive
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
apprehension, the foundational guarantee of free and fair elections
        stands imperilled.

   1066.                    The concern, therefore, is not with isolated investigative
        acts, but with a methodology that reverses the settled legal sequence,
        blurs constitutional boundaries, and risks converting criminal
        investigation into an instrument of overreach. Acceptance of such an
        approach would undermine the discipline of criminal law, erode
        constitutional safeguards, and strike at the very foundations of
        democratic governance.

   1067.                    This Court considers it necessary to record that the
        present matter has posed an exceptional degree of difficulty in the
        formation of a prima facie opinion for the limited purpose of
        considering the framing of charge. Ordinarily, it is expected that upon
        examining the statements of a few material witnesses, some indicative
        circumstance may surface which, when taken at face value, could lend
        support to the allegations set up by the prosecution. Guided by that
        expectation, the Court undertook a sequential appraisal of the
        statements. However, it soon became apparent that no such material
        emerged at any intermediate stage, compelling the Court to undertake
        a comprehensive examination of the statement of each witness until
        the very last. What stands out on such scrutiny is the conspicuous
        absence of any fact or circumstance which could legitimately give rise
        to even a foundational suspicion, much less a prima facie inference, of

the commission of the offences imputed to the accused persons. The
        investigation, as reflected in the charge-sheet and the accompanying
        documents, has not succeeded in disclosing a chain of events which
        satisfies even the minimal threshold required under law for proceeding
        to frame a charge. To the contrary, the contemporaneous record,
        including the movement of files, the notings recorded at various levels,
        and the manner in which the Technical Evaluation Committee
        discharged its functions, demonstrates that the formulation of the
        DEP-21/22 was undertaken through the established administrative
        channels and in furtherance of the objectives expressly set out
        therein.

   1068.                    The documentation reveals due adherence to the
        procedural safeguards and institutional checks embedded in the
        Transaction of Business framework, leaving no room to infer any
        clandestine departure from the prescribed process. In these
        circumstances, and having regard to the settled position that the Court
        at this stage must ascertain whether the material placed on record, if
        unrebutted, would constitute the ingredients of the alleged offences, it
        becomes evident that the present record falls substantially short of that
        requirement.

   1069.                    The   criminal   process   undoubtedly   vests        wide
        discretionary powers in the investigating agency, including the
        authority to array a person as an accused, to tender pardon and

examine an accused as an approver, or, in appropriate cases, to
        examine a person merely as a witness. These powers are recognised as
        legitimate procedural instruments intended to facilitate effective
        investigation and assist the Court in its truth-finding function. Their
        conferment, however, does not place them beyond the controlling
        disciplines          of   fairness,   proportionality,   reasonableness         and
        constitutional conscience. At the core of criminal investigation lies a
        delicate equilibrium between investigative efficiency and substantive
        justice, and the power to transform an accused into an approver is a
        carefully circumscribed exception to the ordinary rule of prosecution,
        justified only as a means to secure truthful disclosure of otherwise
        concealed facts. When exercised mechanically, selectively or with an
        oblique purpose, this power ceases to operate as an aid to justice and
        instead undermines both the fairness of the process and the credibility
        of the outcome.

   1070.                    A grave concern arises when a person who appears, on a
        prima facie appraisal, to be a principal or first-degree participant in the
        alleged offence is granted pardon and projected as an approver. The
        jurisprudential rationale underlying the approver mechanism is that a
        participant of comparatively lesser culpability may be pardoned to
        expose graver criminality. If this logic is inverted, by insulating one of
        the alleged architects or central actors of the offence and proceeding
        against others primarily on the strength of his statement, the

investigative process itself becomes inherently suspect. In the present
        case, PW-20, approver Dinesh Arora, is projected as a key conspirator,
        allegedly involved not merely in facilitation but even in execution of
        the alleged offence, rendering the selection of an approver vulnerable
        to serious scrutiny. Justice is not served when culpability is re-
        engineered to suit investigative convenience rather than determined on
        the basis of objective truth.

   1071.                    This concern is structurally aggravated by the incentives
        inherent in approver status. A person tendered pardon does so with a
        legitimate expectation of immunity and personal liberty. When such
        expectation is reinforced by non-opposition to bail or conduct
        suggestive of assured leniency, the approver’s statement inevitably
        falls under a cloud of suspicion. The risk of conscious or subconscious
        tailoring of the narrative to align with the prosecution theory is not
        speculative but intrinsic to the very nature of the bargain. In such
        circumstances, the approver risks degenerating from a source of truth
        into a conduit for the investigative narrative.

   1072.                    The statutory and regulatory framework reinforces this
        caution. Section 306(4) of CrPC embodies a clear legislative intent
        that an approver, until examined as a witness, should ordinarily remain
        in judicial custody. This requirement is not punitive but prophylactic,
        intended to insulate the approver from external influence, prevent
        tutoring or inducement, and preserve the spontaneity and authenticity

of disclosure. This safeguard is mirrored and strengthened by Rules 5
        and 8 of Chapter 14 of the Delhi High Court Rules and Orders. Rule 5
        recognises that the statement of an approver, being that of an
        accomplice, is prima facie of a tainted character and cannot be acted
        upon unless corroborated in material particulars, the nature and extent
        of such corroboration depending upon factors such as the nature of the
        crime, the character of the approver’s evidence and the degree of his
        complicity. Rule 8 operates as the procedural complement by
        mandating that an approver, after acceptance of pardon, should be kept
        in judicial custody until the termination of the trial, thereby
        safeguarding the conditions under which such statement is tendered.

   1073.                    This dual safeguard stands authoritatively affirmed by
        the Supreme Court in Suresh Chandra Bahri v. State of Bihar (1995
        Supp (1) SCC), wherein it was categorically held that keeping an
        approver in custody is founded on statutory principles of public policy
        and public interest, the violation of which cannot be tolerated. While
        the Court clarified that an erroneous release of an approver on bail
        may not invalidate a pardon once validly granted, it simultaneously
        underscored that such deviation directly impinges upon the credibility
        and       evidentiary     worth   of   the   approver’s   statement.       Read
        harmoniously, therefore, Rule 5 and Rule 8 function in tandem: Rule
        5 governs the weight that approver statement may carry by insisting
        on independent corroboration on material particulars, while Rule 8

governs the conditions under which such statement is to be given, so
        as to prevent contamination at its source.

   1074.                    Contemporary investigative realities further weaken any
        justification for disproportionate reliance on approver statement.
        Before elevating a co-accused to the status of an approver,
        investigative fairness demands that his version be subjected to
        rigorous preliminary scrutiny against such independent material.
        Scientific and psychological tools such as polygraphic and lie
        detection test, when employed strictly within constitutionally
        permissible and legally regulated bounds, may serve as ancillary aids
        in assessing whether the disclosure is prima facie truthful or merely
        self-serving.

                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   1075.                    Procedural   fairness   also   demands     institutional
        symmetry: if a person’s statement is sufficient to treat him as an
        accused, the converse decision to pardon him must be supported by
        demonstrable reasons grounded in relative culpability and evidentiary
        necessity. The differential treatment of PW-125 (Magunta Srinivasan
        Reddy) and PW-126 (Raghav Magunta Reddy), coupled with non-
        opposition to bail, illustrates how selective indulgence, unsupported
        by a reasoned distinction in role or responsibility, erodes public
        confidence in the fairness of the criminal process.

1076.                    Ultimately, criminal investigation is not a competitive
        exercise aimed at securing convictions at any cost. It is a
        constitutionally informed, truth-seeking function governed by the rule
        of law. The approver mechanism, when misapplied, carries the grave
        risk of shielding the guilty while imperilling the innocent. Any
        departure from the twin disciplines of substantive corroboration and
        procedural custody undermines the integrity of the approver
        mechanism and substantially weakens the probative value of such
        statement, even at the threshold stage of consideration of charge. In
        the long run, adherence to procedural fairness is not an impediment to
        effective investigation; it is the sole assurance that the criminal process
        will culminate in justice that is real, credible and enduring.

        ORDER
   1077.                    Upon an exhaustive and painstaking examination of the
        entire record, undertaken over a period exceeding two months,
        encompassing voluminous documentary material and the depositions
        of nearly three hundred prosecution witnesses, and after affording full
        opportunity of hearing to the parties, this Court is left in no manner of
        doubt that the prosecution case does not disclose even the threshold of
        a prima facie suspicion, far less the “grave suspicion” mandated by
        settled principles of criminal jurisprudence for proceeding further. The
        Excise Policy case, as sought to be projected by the CBI, is wholly

unable to survive judicial scrutiny and stands discredited in its entirety.
        While it is to the credit of the investigating agency that it has placed
        reliance upon the statement of its own witnesses even when such
        evidence runs contrary to the prosecution’s foundational allegations,
        the cumulative effect of that very evidence demolishes, rather than
        supports, the case sought to be built. To compel the accused to face the
        rigours of a full-fledged criminal trial in the stark absence of any
        legally admissible material connecting them to the alleged offences
        would not serve the ends of justice; it would instead constitute a
        manifest miscarriage of justice and an abuse of the criminal process,
        offending the most basic tenets of fairness and the rule of law.

   1078.                    The alleged conspiracy, from its very inception, has
        progressively unravelled and, upon close scrutiny, is revealed to be
        nothing more than a speculative construct resting on conjecture and
        surmise, devoid of any admissible evidence. The investigation, when
        tested against the material collected by the agency itself, reflects a
        fundamental failure to properly appreciate, evaluate, or draw lawful
        inferences from the evidence and documents on record. As a result, the
        prosecution case is rendered legally infirm, unsustainable, and unfit to
        proceed any further in law. Stated differently, this Court records that
        the theory of an overarching conspiracy, so emphatically projected,
        stands completely dismantled when tested against the evidentiary
        record.

1079.                    Upon consideration of the entire material placed on
        record, this Court is of the considered view that the prosecution has
        failed to place any material which, even prima facie, suggests that the
        DEP-21/22 was manipulated, altered, or engineered to confer any
        undue or unlawful benefit upon any private individual or the so-
        called “South Group”. On the contrary, the contemporaneous record
        clearly establishes that the policy was the outcome of a consultative
        and deliberative exercise, undertaken after engagement with relevant
        stakeholders and in adherence to the procedure prescribed under law.
        Though there was no statutory or constitutional requirement
        mandating the obtaining of suggestions from the Hon’ble Lieutenant
        Governor, the file notings unmistakably reflect that such suggestions
        were nevertheless sought, examined, and incorporated. The procedural
        integrity of the policy-making process thus stands affirmed from the
        documentary record itself.

                                                              (emphasis supplied)

   1080.                    Once the formulation of the policy is shown to be the
        product of deliberation, institutional scrutiny, and procedural
        compliance, any subsequent attempt to attribute criminality to its
        implementation becomes wholly untenable. The very foundation on
        which the prosecution seeks to construct the narrative of conspiracy,
        centred around alleged payment of “upfront money” and its purported
        recoupment, stands fundamentally eroded. In the absence of a tainted

policy or demonstrably unlawful implementation, the prosecution
        theory is reduced to conjecture. Private persons who sought to derive
        commercial advantage from a policy validly framed and lawfully
        implemented, without any established violation of policy conditions
        or statutory prohibitions, cannot be compelled to face the rigours of
        criminal prosecution. This Court finds no apparent breach of
        restrictions relating to “related entities” or any other policy condition
        which could, by itself, attract criminal liability.

   1081.                    The allegations concerning payment of upfront money
        and its alleged recoupment are equally devoid of legal substratum. De
        hors any material indicating manipulation in policy formulation or
        corruption in implementation, such allegations fail to sustain. Even
        otherwise, upon independent scrutiny, this Court finds that the entire
        alleged chain of payments rests predominantly on so-called pauti
        entries of Angadia firms, documents which are inadmissible in law,
        and on approver-like statement which remains uncorroborated on
        material particulars. These infirmities are not peripheral; they strike at
        the very root of the prosecution case and render it unsustainable even
        at the threshold stage.

   1082.                    At this stage, it must be emphasised that however
        elaborate the investigative exercise may be, and however carefully the
        narrative is sought to be constructed, the discipline imposed by the
        Indian Evidence Act cannot be diluted or deferred merely because
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
the matter is at the stage of charge. The principles embodied in the
        Evidence Act are time-tested safeguards evolved through long-settled
        jurisprudence, designed to assist courts in discovering the truth and
        testing the authenticity of allegations even at the preliminary stage. In
        the present case, these principles have operated as the governing
        framework. When the material relied upon by the prosecution is tested
        on the touchstone of admissibility, relevance, and probative value, the
        appearance of a coherent conspiracy dissolves, exposing the
        allegations to be founded on inadmissible material and post-facto
        reconstruction.

   1083.                    A cumulative appraisal of the record further reveals an
        investigative approach marked by an attempt to stitch together
        disparate fragments so as to create an impression of a vast and complex
        conspiracy, unsupported by legally admissible material. The
        investigation appears to have proceeded on a predetermined trajectory,
        implicating virtually every person associated with the formulation or
        implementation of the policy in order to lend an illusion of depth and
        credibility to an otherwise fragile narrative. The endeavour to further
        connect such allegations to the Goa Assembly elections, so as to
        project, layering, and utilisation of alleged proceeds of crime, rests
        more on inference and assumption than on legally sustainable
        material.

1084.                    The settled principles of evidence law exist precisely to
        ensure that criminal liability is founded on legally admissible material
        capable of giving rise to a sustainable inference, and not on conjecture,
        or investigative imagination. When the material on record is examined
        on this time-honoured touchstone, the prosecution case fails to
        disclose even a prima facie case, far less the grave suspicion required
        at the stage of framing of charge. The prosecution has thus failed to
        cross the minimum threshold mandated by law.

   1085.                    In view of the foregoing discussion and the reasons
        recorded hereinabove, this Court has no hesitation in holding that the
        material placed on record does not disclose even a prima facie case,
        much less any grave suspicion, against any of the accused persons.
        Accordingly, Accused Nos. A-1 to A-23 are discharged of all the
        offences alleged against them in the present case.

        Issues Warranting Judicial Notice Despite Discharge of the Accused
        Persons

   1086.                    Notwithstanding the discharge of all the accused
        persons, the record still reflects certain matters of concern which ought
        not to remain unnoticed. Recently, in Dr. Anand Rai v. State of Madhya
        Pradesh and Another, 2026 SCC OnLine SC 187, the Hon’ble
        Supreme Court once again emphasised the responsibility that rests
        upon a Trial Court at the stage of framing of charge. It was observed
        that no individual should be compelled to face a criminal trial unless

the material on record, even if taken at face value, discloses the
        essential ingredients of the alleged offence. To require an accused to
        undergo trial in the absence of such foundational material is to expose
        him to the strain, stigma and prolonged uncertainty that accompany
        criminal proceedings, without legal justification.

   1087.                    The Supreme Court also reminded courts that fidelity to
        the rule of law demands vigilance at this stage. If criminal proceedings
        are permitted to continue without adequate basis, the process itself
        may become punitive. A Trial Court, while exercising jurisdiction at
        the threshold, must therefore remain mindful of the human
        consequences of its orders and of the trust that society places in it. The
        relevant extract is reproduced below for ready reference:–

                “..21. Before parting with the matter, it is observed that at the
                stage of framing of charge or consideration of discharge, the
                Court is not engaged in an abstract legal exercise. It is
                concerned with real individuals, real anxieties, and the tangible
                burden of criminal prosecution. The responsibility cast upon
                the Court at this juncture demands circumspection, balance,
                and a candid evaluation of the material on record. The power
                to frame a charge is not to be exercised mechanically or merely
                by way of abundant caution. Where the material placed before
                the Court, even if taken at its face value, fails to disclose the
                essential ingredients of an offence, the law expects the Court to
                state so with clarity and to decline to subject the accused to
                trial.”
   1088.                    Keeping these principles in view, and bearing in mind
        the duty cast upon the Trial Court at this stage, it becomes necessary

to address certain core issues so that the jurisdiction is exercised with
        due care and in faithful discharge of that responsibility.

        (i) Fair Investigation and Procedural Integrity in Light of Article 21 of
        the Constitution of India and International Covenant on Civil and
        Political Rights Obligations

   1089.                    At the very threshold of the defence arguments, learned
        counsel appearing for each of the accused persons had assiduously
        drawn the attention of this Court to the manner in which the statement
        of the approver, Dinesh Arora, came to be recorded repeatedly under
        Section 161 of Cr.P.C., on at least four occasions, after his statement
        under Section 164 of Cr.P.C., on the basis of which pardon had been
        granted to him. At that stage, the said submission did not appear to
        weigh substantially with this Court.

   1090.                    However, upon a holistic scrutiny of the entire record,
        and after this Court reached the conclusion that the prosecution case,
        as presented in the charge-sheet, rests largely on surmises, conjectures,
        and inferential leaps unsupported by cogent material, the aforesaid
        submission assumes decisive significance. What initially appeared to
        be a routine or peripheral objection now stands revealed as an issue
        going to the very root of fair investigation and the administration of
        criminal justice.

1091.                    This Court is constrained to observe that the present case
        does not admit of such a lapse being brushed aside as a mere
        irregularity. If such a practice is permitted to pass without judicial
        scrutiny, it carries the grave potential of setting an unhealthy
        precedent, effectively normalising a method whereby an investigating
        agency, after securing pardon on the professed premise of a “full and
        true disclosure”, continues to repeatedly re-record statements of the
        approver over an extended period, ostensibly to fill gaps, improve the
        prosecution narrative, implicate additional accused, or artificially
        weave missing links in the chain of circumstances.

   1092.                    The concern is aggravated by the fact that the
        investigating agency has offered no explanation whatsoever as to why
        it found it necessary to record the statement of the approver under
        Section 161 of Cr.P.C. repeatedly, and that too over a span of nearly
        one and a half years, extending till the filing of the last supplementary
        charge-sheet. The record is conspicuously silent on any exceptional
        circumstance warranting such a course. This unexplained conduct
        reflects a disturbing departure from the settled legal principles
        governing the grant of pardon.

   1093.                    The very foundation of pardon rests on the prosecution’s
        representation to the Court that the approver has made a full,
        voluntary, and truthful disclosure of all material facts within his
        knowledge. Once such disclosure is accepted and pardon is granted,

the investigative discretion of the agency stands correspondingly
        circumscribed. The law does not contemplate a situation where an
        approver, having obtained the extraordinary indulgence of pardon, is
        thereafter subjected to repeated statement-recording under Section 161
        of Cr.P.C. so as to incrementally refine, expand, or reshape the
        prosecution case.

   1094.                    Such an approach strikes at the core of the concept of
        pardon and undermines the sanctity of the judicial satisfaction
        recorded at the stage of its grant. It gives rise to a legitimate
        apprehension that the approver’s subsequent statements are not the
        product of spontaneous disclosure, but of a prolonged and iterative
        process calibrated to suit the evolving requirements of the
        prosecution.
                                                               (emphasis supplied)

   1095.                    This Court is not embarking upon an examination of
        each and every statement of the approver, PW-20, recorded under
        Section 161 of Cr.P.C., whether prior to or subsequent to the recording
        of his confessional statement under Section 164 of Cr.P.C.. However,
        while adverting to the last statement under Section 161 of Cr.P.C.,
        recorded on 17.10.23 which forms part of the additional statements
        expressly relied upon by the investigating agency, this Court is taken
        by surprise to find an allegation relating to the delivery of an amount

of ₹1 crore stated to have been handed over to one Sarvesh Mishra
        acting on behalf of Sanjay Singh.

   1096.                    What causes serious disquiet is that the name of Sanjay
        Singh does not find mention in the main charge-sheet or in any of the
        four supplementary charge-sheets. There is no allegation anywhere on
        the record attributing to Sanjay Singh any role, direct or indirect, in
        the formulation, approval, or implementation of the DEP-21/22. While
        this Court does not, at this stage, propose to enter into the merits of the
        said allegation, its very emergence at such a belated stage is indicative
        of the manner in which the approver’s statements have been utilised
        during investigation.

   1097.                    The record reveals that the approver, who has been
        examined on multiple occasions over an extended period of more then
        1 year, has come forth with this new allegation only in the course of
        his later statements. This lends credence to the apprehension that with
        each successive examination, fresh assertions are introduced to rope
        in persons against whom no foundational material otherwise exists.
        The approver appears to have been projected as an all-encompassing
        source for the prosecution narrative, such that on one occasion he
        introduces an entirely new allegation, and on another, seeks to supply
        explanations to fill links that are otherwise conspicuously absent in the
        evidentiary chain.

1098.                    It is a settled principle of criminal jurisprudence that the
        statement of an approver is inherently suspect and is to be received
        with great caution. Yet, the approach adopted by the investigating
        agency in the present case reflects a marked departure from this well-
        established rule. The statements of the approver have been elevated
        and treated as though they constitute unimpeachable truth, and have
        been uncritically incorporated as relied-upon material forming the
        backbone of the prosecution case.

   1099.                    Needless to observe, once a confession purporting to be
        a full and true disclosure is recorded and accepted for the grant of
        pardon, the premise on which such pardon rests cannot be permitted
        to stand diluted. The repeated examination of the approver over a
        period of one year, ostensibly to elicit further statements, itself
        demonstrates that what was projected as a complete disclosure
        gradually devolved into a series of incomplete and evolving versions.
        This aspect has been noted only to underscore the manner in which the
        investigation has proceeded in the present case, and the weight that
        has been placed on the shifting statements of the approver.

   1100.                    This Court remains conscious of the need to exercise
        restraint while commenting upon the conduct of the investigating
        agency. Ordinarily, courts refrain from making observations that may
        be perceived as indictments of investigative discretion. However, there
        are situations where the lapses are so fundamental that judicial silence

would itself amount to abdication of duty. Where the exercise of
        power, though ostensibly within jurisdiction, results in the dilution of
        statutory safeguards and erosion of foundational principles of criminal
        jurisprudence, the Court cannot remain a mute spectator.

   1101.                    In the considered view of this Court, the manner in
        which the investigating agency has proceeded, by repeatedly recording
        the statements of the approver without justification and over a
        prolonged duration, reflects an exercise of discretion that cannot be
        characterised as fair or reasonable. If left unchecked, such conduct
        risks converting the exceptional mechanism of pardon into an
        instrument for narrative construction rather than truth discovery,
        thereby causing serious prejudice to the accused and eroding
        confidence in the criminal justice process.

                                                                (emphasis supplied)

   1102.                    Ignoring or glossing over such infirmities would, in the
        considered opinion of this Court, itself result in a miscarriage of
        justice. The guarantee of life and personal liberty under Article 21 of
        the Constitution of India is not confined to protection against unlawful
        detention alone, but necessarily encompasses the right to a fair and just
        investigation. Fairness in investigation is a constitutional mandate that
        restrains the exercise of State power and operates as a safeguard
        against arbitrary or capricious prosecutorial conduct.

1103.                    This constitutional guarantee is further reinforced by
        India’s international obligations under the Universal Declaration of
        Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political
        Rights, to which India is a signatory. Article 14 of the Covenant
        obligates the State to ensure equality before courts and tribunals, a fair
        and public hearing, and procedural fairness in criminal proceedings,
        while Article 15 prohibits the imposition of criminal liability except in
        accordance with law and recognised principles of criminal justice.
        These provisions collectively underscore that criminal prosecution
        must remain anchored in legality and procedural integrity, and must
        not be shaped or retrofitted through investigative practices that
        compromise fairness.

   1104.                    An investigation that departs from transparency,
        consistency, and procedural discipline, particularly by repeatedly re-
        recording statements of an approver after the grant of pardon without
        any disclosed justification, does not merely affect evidentiary
        appreciation, but strikes at the heart of these constitutional and
        international guarantees. Where investigative discretion is exercised
        in a manner that erodes the presumption of innocence or dilutes the
        sanctity of a judicially granted pardon, the process itself assumes a
        punitive character, impermissible in a constitutional democracy
        governed by the rule of law.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
1105.                    In such circumstances, judicial intervention is not a
        matter of choice but of constitutional obligation. This Court is duty-
        bound to ensure that criminal law remains an instrument of justice and
        not a means of inflicting injustice, and that the promise of liberty under
        Article 21, read in harmony with India’s international human-rights
        commitments under the ICCPR, is preserved in both letter and spirit.

        (ii) Segregation of Relied and Unrelied Documents: To Uncover the
        Truth and Safeguard a Fair Trial

   1106.                    At the stage of consideration of charge, particularly in
        prosecutions under the PC Act and in connected proceedings under the
        Prevention of Money Laundering Act, the question of classification
        and supply of documents assumes substantial significance. The
        prosecution is obliged to furnish copies of the documents upon which
        it relies and to provide inspection along with a list of documents not
        relied upon. While this arrangement satisfies procedural requirements,
        its practical impact at the stage of charge calls for closer
        examination.

   1107.                    At this stage, the Court is confined to the material placed
        by the prosecution. The accused has no right to rely upon his own
        documents, nor can he summon documents that form part of the
        unrelied record. Consequently, even where inspection of unrelied
        documents is permitted, the defence is not in a position to effectively
        invoke such material while the Court determines whether a case is

made out for trial. In effect, the Court’s scrutiny remains restricted to
        what the prosecution chooses to place in the category of relied
        documents. This concern becomes particularly acute in cases of a
        voluminous nature, where trials may extend over several years.

   1108.                    The issue becomes clearer by way of illustration. Suppose
        a person is accused of committing a murder in Delhi by firing a
        gunshot. He is arrested in Lucknow. During investigation, the police
        seize from his residence a digital device containing CCTV footage
        showing his presence at home at the relevant time. The footage
        supports a plea of alibi. If the investigating agency, instead of sending
        the device for forensic examination and placing the material before the
        Court as part of the relied documents, merely includes it in the list of
        unrelied documents without analysis, the consequences are serious. At
        the stage of charge, the accused cannot summon that material. The
        Court would be compelled to assess the prosecution case without
        considering evidence already in the custody of the State that may
        directly bear upon innocence. The accused would then have to await
        the stage of defence evidence to seek its production, by which time
        charges would already have been framed on an incomplete record.

   1109.                Such a course affects the very foundation of a fair procedure.
        Investigation is not a process of gathering only incriminating material;
        it is an effort to uncover the truth. Every document collected during
        investigation must be examined objectively before any decision is

taken to classify it as relied or unrelied. Segregation must follow due
        scrutiny; it cannot precede it. Fair trial requires that the investigating
        agency assess the evidentiary value and relevance of each document
        in a balanced manner.

   1110.                 Where a document of apparent probative value, particularly
        one capable of assisting the accused, is placed in the unrelied category,
        reasons for such a decision ought to be recorded. The recording of
        reasons ensures that exclusion of material is based on a conscious and
        reasoned determination rather than expediency. It also enables the
        Court to satisfy itself that relevant material has not been withheld from
        consideration without justification. In the absence of such
        transparency, the classification of documents risks becoming a means
        of selective presentation.

   1111.                     This Court has, on more than one occasion, noticed
        instances where documents emerging from the investigation, including
        those recovered from the accused, have been placed among unrelied
        documents despite their potential relevance. When material favourable
        to the accused is collected by the State and thereafter kept outside the
        Court’s consideration at the stage of charge, the fairness of the process
        is inevitably brought into question.

   1112.                     The purpose of investigation is to ascertain the truth,
        whether it supports the prosecution or assists the defence. The
        guarantee of a fair trial under Article 21 extends to every stage of the

criminal process, including investigation and the manner in which
        material is presented before the Court. The distinction between relied
        and unrelied documents cannot be permitted to operate in a way that
        dilutes this guarantee.

   1113.                     Before segregating documents into relied and unrelied
        categories, the investigating agency must undertake a comprehensive
        and objective examination of all material collected. If, upon such
        examination, a decision is taken not to rely upon a particular
        document, the reasons for doing so should be clearly recorded. Such
        an approach alone ensures fairness, accountability, and fidelity to the
        fundamental objective of criminal law, the discovery of truth through
        a just and even-handed process.

        (iii) Use of the Phrase “South Group”

   1114.                    The Court considers it necessary to place on record its
        concern with the repeated and deliberate use of the expression “South
        Group” by the investigating agency to describe a set of accused
        persons, ostensibly on the basis of their regional origin or place of
        residence. Such a nomenclature finds no foundation in law, does not
        correspond to any legally cognisable classification, and is wholly alien
        to the statutory framework governing criminal liability. It is equally
        significant that no comparable regional descriptor has been employed
        for the remaining accused persons; the prosecution narrative does not
        speak of any “North Group” or similar categorisation. The selective

adoption of a geographically defined label is, therefore, plainly
        arbitrary and unwarranted.

   1115.                    The concern is not confined to semantics. Region-based
        labelling carries an avoidable undertone and is capable of creating a
        prejudicial impression. It detracts from the settled requirement that
        criminal proceedings must remain dispassionate, evidence-centric,
        and insulated from extraneous considerations. In a constitutional order
        founded upon equality before law and the unity and integrity of the
        nation, descriptors rooted in regional identity serve no legitimate
        investigative            or   prosecutorial   purpose   and   are      manifestly
        inappropriate.

   1116.                    This Court is conscious that the impugned expression
        has been repeatedly employed in successive charge-sheets and, for that
        limited reason alone, this Court has been constrained to refer to it
        while summarising and analysing the prosecution case. Such reference
        cannot, however, be construed as approval or endorsement of the
        terminology itself. The continued use of this label, despite the absence
        of any legally sustainable basis, carries a real risk of colouring
        perception, causing unintended prejudice, and diverting focus from the
        evidentiary material, which alone must guide adjudication.

   1117.                    The impropriety of identity-based labelling is not a
        matter of abstract concern. It has received pointed judicial
        condemnation in comparative constitutional jurisprudence. In United

States v. Cabrera, 222 F.3d 590 (7th Cir. 2000), the United States Court
        of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit treated the issue as going to the very
        root of a fair criminal trial, and went so far as to set aside the
        conviction itself on account of the repeated use of identity-based
        terminology by the prosecution and law-enforcement witnesses, where
        such identity had no bearing on the elements of the offence.

   1118.                    The Court recorded its disapproval in unambiguous
        terms:

        “The government’s repeated references to the defendants as
        ‘Dominican drug dealers’ were improper.
        The ethnicity or national origin of a defendant is not relevant to
        proving the elements of a crime.
        Such references invite the jury to draw impermissible inferences based
        on nationality rather than evidence, and they risk appealing to bias
        rather than reason.”
   1119.                    Emphasising that this was not an isolated concern, the
        Court expressly cautioned the prosecution:

        “We have warned prosecutors before that injecting ethnicity into a
        criminal trial, when it has no bearing on the issues being tried, is
        error.
        Criminal trials must be about what the defendant did, not who the
        defendant is.”
   1120.                    The admonition was extended beyond prosecutorial
        argument to the conduct of law-enforcement officials themselves,

recognising that prejudice can be introduced through investigative
        narrative and statement:

        “The fairness and integrity of criminal trials are at stake if we allow
        police officers to make generalizations about racial and ethnic groups
        in order to obtain convictions.
        People cannot be tried on the basis of their ethnic backgrounds or
        national origin.”
   1121.                    On this reasoning, the Court held that the continued and
        unnecessary emphasis on ethnic origin had irretrievably compromised
        the constitutional guarantee of a fair trial and concluded:

        “Therefore, in order to protect Cabrera and Mulgado’s due process and
        equal protection rights to a fair trial, we are compelled to reverse their
        convictions and remand.”
   1122.                    The principle that emerges is both clear and compelling.
        Identity-based labelling, whether by ethnicity, nationality, or regional
        origin, cannot be employed as a prosecutorial shorthand where such
        identity is irrelevant to the offence. Such labelling is not a mere
        irregularity of expression; it constitutes a constitutional infirmity
        capable of undermining the fairness of the proceedings themselves.
        The central message is categorical: criminal adjudication must rest on
        conduct proved by evidence, not on who the accused is or where he
        comes from.
                                                                (emphasis supplied)

1123.                    In light of the above, the investigating agency is
        cautioned to exercise greater care, circumspection, and restraint in the
        choice of language while drafting charge-sheets and investigative
        narratives. Descriptions of accused persons must remain strictly
        neutral, evidence-based, and free from expressions that carry a
        stigmatic, divisive, or pejorative overtone. The continued use of such
        terminology bears directly upon the fairness of the criminal process
        and touches upon the guarantee of a just, fair, and reasonable
        procedure under Article 21 of the Constitution. Equally, the
        employment of descriptors founded on regional or identity-based
        distinctions, in the absence of any rational nexus with the alleged
        offence, is inconsistent with the constitutional command of equality
        and non-discrimination under Article 15. Persistence with such
        nomenclature risks undermining the due process of law and is best
        avoided in the interest of an impartial and constitutionally compliant
        administration of criminal justice.

        (iv) Constitutional Significance:

   1124.                    Before parting with the order, it becomes necessary for
        this Court to record a concern of considerable constitutional
        significance. This Court is increasingly confronted with a grave and
        recurring dilemma, wherein the liberty of an individual stands
        imperilled on account of prosecutions initiated under the Prevention
        of Money Laundering Act, 2002, premised upon a presumption that

the alleged amount constitutes “proceeds of crime” arising out of a
        scheduled (predicate) offence. The issue assumes heightened
        significance where an accused is arrested for the offence of money
        laundering and is thereafter required to surmount the stringent twin
        conditions prescribed for the grant of bail, resulting in prolonged
        incarceration even at the pre-trial stage.

   1125.                    It is noticed that, in several cases, the Enforcement
        Directorate proceeds to file a prosecution complaint primarily to
        obviate the statutory consequence of default bail, without the
        investigation in the scheduled offence having attained finality. In such
        situations, while the proceedings under the PMLA are set in motion,
        the investigation in the predicate offence continues to remain
        inconclusive, and in many cases even the filing of a charge-sheet
        therein is awaited. This Court itself is a witness to a case where the
        proceedings relating to money laundering have reached the final stage
        of arguments on charge, whereas, in the predicate offence, the
        investigation is still underway to determine whether any offence has
        been committed at all. It is also noteworthy that the accused persons
        in the PMLA case have remained in custody for a significant period.
        This anomalous situation gives rise to serious legal and constitutional
        concerns, as the continuation of proceedings under the PMLA remains
        contingent upon the very survival of the scheduled offence.

1126.                    It has been categorically held by the Hon’ble Supreme
        Court of India in Vijay Madanlal Choudhary v. Union of India, (2022)
        10 SCC 353, that where the predicate offence does not survive,
        whether on account of discharge, acquittal, quashing, denial of
        cognizance, or acceptance of a closure report, the offence of money
        laundering cannot independently subsist. The offence under the PMLA
        is thus not autonomous in its origin, but is inextricably linked to the
        existence of a legally sustainable scheduled offence. The predicate
        offence constitutes the foundational edifice upon which the allegation
        of money laundering rests; if the foundation crumbles, the
        superstructure must necessarily fall.

                                                                   (emphasis supplied)

   1127.                    Despite this settled legal position, the prevailing practice
        reveals a disturbing inversion of the statutory scheme, wherein
        coercive powers of arrest and prolonged custody are invoked even
        before the foundational facts relating to the scheduled offence are
        judicially tested. This results in a situation where an individual is
        deprived of personal liberty on the strength of an allegation whose
        legal sustainability remains uncertain and contingent upon a future
        outcome in a parallel investigation.

   1128.                    The right to life and personal liberty guaranteed under
        Article 21 of the Constitution mandates that any deprivation of liberty
        must be just, fair, and reasonable, not merely in form, but in substance.
court: Special Court (PC Act) CBI-23, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi

text:
A procedure which permits prolonged or indefinite incarceration on
        the basis of a provisional and untested allegation, while the very
        substratum of the offence remains under investigation, risks
        degenerating into a punitive process rather than a regulatory or
        investigative one. Liberty, once curtailed, cannot be meaningfully
        restored by a subsequent acquittal, nor can the passage of time
        compensate for the loss occasioned by unwarranted pre-trial
        detention.

   1129.                    At the same time, it cannot be gainsaid that the
        legislature has vested wide powers in the Enforcement Directorate to
        combat the menace of money laundering, including powers of
        attachment, arrest, and prosecution, recognising the transnational and
        clandestine nature of such offences. The object of the statute is
        undoubtedly legitimate and compelling. However, statutory power,
        howsoever wide, cannot eclipse constitutional safeguards. The
        exercise of such power must therefore be harmonised with the settled
        principle that arrest and prolonged incarceration are exceptions, and
        not the rule.

   1130.                    There is, thus, a manifest need to evolve a framework
        for striking a careful balance between the sovereign interest in the
        effective investigation of economic offences and the inviolable right
        of an individual to personal liberty. While provisional attachment of
        alleged proceeds of crime may be justified to preserve the subject-

matter of investigation, the coercive measure of arrest and the
        consequent application of onerous bail conditions cannot be permitted
        to operate mechanically in the absence of a crystallised and judicially
        cognisable predicate offence.

   1131.                    In this context, it is apposite to note that the Hon’ble
        Supreme Court in Manish Sisodia v. State (NCT of Delhi) , (2023) 9
        SCC 772, has observed that prolonged and indefinite incarceration
        without the commencement or conclusion of trial constitutes a relevant
        consideration for the grant of bail. This Court, therefore, remains alive
        to the fact that the continuation of incarceration in such circumstances
        amounts to placing the cart before the horse, allowing the consequence
        to precede the cause, so that pre-trial detention does not itself
        substitute the punishment.

   1132.                    Ultimately, the legitimacy of the PMLA regime depends
        not merely on the severity of its provisions, but on their fair,
        proportionate, and constitutionally informed application. The balance
        between the power of the investigating agency and the right to life and
        personal liberty is not a matter of legislative grace, but a constitutional
        command. Any failure to maintain this balance is likely to undermine
        both the rule of law and public confidence in the administration of
        criminal justice.

   1133.                    As the order reaches its conclusion, this Court, while
        penning the present order, has, time and again, reminded itself of the

enduring words of Martin Luther King Jr. that “injustice anywhere is
        a threat to justice everywhere,” as also of the venerable maxim fiat
        justitia ruat caelum, let justice be done though the heavens may fall.
        These principles serve as a constant reminder that the judicial task is
        neither to secure a convenient outcome nor to endorse a dominant
        narrative, but to uphold the rule of law. It is only by remaining
        anchored to these ideals that the confidence of the citizen in the
        administration of justice is preserved. With that assurance, and
        conscious of this obligation, the file is directed to be consigned to the
        record room.

        Announced in the open Court
        on 27.02.2026.
                                                                (Jitendra Singh)
                                                 Special Judge (PC Act) CBI-23

           when viewed cumulatively, discloses a concerted and pre-conceived design, the
           full conspectus of which emerges from the totality of circumstances. The material
           collected during investigation reveals a single, continuing criminal conspiracy
           commencing from the very inception of the Policy and culminating in the
           generation, layering and utilisation of kickbacks in the Goa Assembly elections.

           where the policy framework was altered to introduce a private wholesale regime
           with an enhanced margin of 12% in place of the existing 5%, and turnover criteria
           were relaxed despite expert recommendations to the contrary.

21.          It is submitted that A-3 has been summoned in the present proceedings in
      his capacity as a private individual for the alleged offences u/s 7, 7A and 8 of the
      PC Act, read with Section 120-B of the IPC. For each of the alleged substantive
      offences, the prosecution was required, at the threshold, to identify a public
      servant at least by designation or capacity and to demonstrate the specific public
      duty which was allegedly influenced, or sought to be influenced, by him. This
      foundational requirement has not been satisfied. In the absence of a prima facie
      substantive offence, the allegation of criminal conspiracy u/s 120-B IPC cannot
      survive, as conspiracy presupposes an unlawful object capable of being
      established. A-3 is a private individual who founded a private entertainment
      company, “Only Much Louder”, and later associated himself with the Aam Aadmi
      Party in 2014 as a volunteer without remuneration. Owing to his professional
      background, he assisted the media and communications team of the party by
      publicising its activities and relaying stakeholder feedback. His professional
      engagements had brought him into contact with stakeholders in the alcohol
      industry in connection with events and festivals sponsored by such entities. The
      prosecution record does not disclose any close or proximate association between
      A-3 and any of the accused public servants. There is no material to indicate that
      he acted as an agent, intermediary or representative of any public servant. Not a
      single meeting between him and any public servant during the alleged period of
      conspiracy has been demonstrated. No document or witness from the Excise
      Department attributes to him any role in the formulation or implementation of the
      New Excise Policy. His conduct must therefore be assessed strictly as that of a
      private individual operating in his personal and professional domain. As regards
      the allegation relating to meetings with industry stakeholders between February
      and August 2021, the prosecution material, even if taken at its highest, merely

      (IX) Submissions by Ld. Senior Advocate Ms. Rebecca John, Ld. Counsels Sh.

           Manish Sisodia :-

39.          It is submitted that the prosecution case rests on the erroneous premise that
      the Excise Policy 2021–22 was manipulated to favour a particular group. The
      record, however, shows that the policy was the outcome of a structured,
      consultative and inter-departmental process aimed at reforming an admittedly
      flawed earlier regime. Under the previous framework, manufacturers could
      operate as wholesalers and, through proxy arrangements, even as retailers, with
      minimal entry barriers and no effective price control. This vertical integration led
      to monopolistic conditions and profit margins up to 65%, necessitating reform.
      The new policy was formulated through constitution of an expert body, public
      consultation, deliberations of the Group of Ministers, inter-departmental scrutiny
      (Excise, Planning, Law and Finance), Cabinet consideration and reference to the
      Hon’ble Lieutenant Governor. The Ravi Dhawan Committee highlighted
      distortions in the earlier regime and recommended delinking manufacturers from
      wholesale operations; its recommendations were advisory.
40.          It is contended that the allegation of an abrupt increase in profit margin
      from 5% to 12% is misconceived. GoM reports dated 15.03.2021, 19.03.2021 and
      22.03.2021 show that drafting evolved through discussions and multiple
      iterations. The 5% figure was only a minimum suggestion without an upper cap.

                                        Page no. 21 of 48
       The final 12% cap was fixed after factoring substantially higher obligations on
      wholesalers, including ₹5 crore annual licence fee, testing labs, CCTV, anti-
      brand-pushing measures, warehousing norms and enhanced operational costs.
      Even as per the Ravi Dhawan Committee, the earlier regime enabled margins up
      to 65%; thus, the 12% cap restricted profitability rather than expanding it. The
      policy introduced consumer safeguards such as lowest ex-distillery pricing,
      mandatory pass-through of reductions, barcoding and competitive zoning through
      e-tendering into 32 retail zones. Cabinet Note dated 16.04.2021 and inter-
      departmental correspondence reflect collective decision-making. The policy was
      forwarded to the Hon’ble LG under Article 239AA(4); his suggestions were
      incorporated and approved. Official file notings, proved by LG Secretariat
      officers, show institutional participation and attract presumption of regularity
      under Section 35 of the Evidence Act.
41.          It is also contended that structurally, the policy separated manufacturers,
      wholesalers and retailers, barred cross-holding, imposed strict eligibility and anti-
      cartelisation measures, and replaced excise-duty driven revenue with high upfront
      licence fees. The earlier 5% margin and the later 12% cap operated in entirely
      different ecosystems and are not comparable. Retail pricing was governed by
      statutory rules; regulated discounts were permitted in consumer interest and later
      rationalised. Prosecution witnesses (PW-110 and PW-111) themselves indicate
      that increased landed costs reduced effective margins, especially in beer
      distribution.
42.         A substantial part of the prosecution case challenges the wisdom of the
      policy. It is settled that fiscal and economic policy lies within executive discretion
      and cannot be criminalised absent demonstrable harm to public interest, as held in
      State of Madhya Pradesh v. Sheetla Sahai, Small Scale Industrial Manufacturers
      Association v. Union of India, Parag Ice & Oil Mills v. Union of India and Vivek
      Narayan Sharma v. Union of India. The allegation that public consultation was
      manipulated through six emails out of over 14,000 is untenable. There is no
      evidence that these influenced the policy, no recovery of any handwritten note,
      and no proof of any meeting between A-8 and the alleged sender. The claim of
      suppression of legal opinions is contradicted by record, which shows that A-8
      directed all viewpoints to be placed before the Cabinet. GoM minutes of February
      2021 reflect detailed deliberations, corroborated by witnesses. The “upfront bribe”

       allegation fails on timeline: the alleged money trail begins months after policy
      decisions. There is no recovery from A-8, no evidence of demand, and no proof of
      receipt.

      proximity of offices cannot establish conspiracy. There is no recovery of the
      alleged 36-page document or any device linking it to A-8, and even the

      alleged beneficiaries. Regarding Indospirits, the initial statement of the concerned

      a direction to process the file “as per rules”. The main charge-sheet attributes
      alleged bribery to other officials; there is no basis to implicate A-8. In sum, there
      is no material showing demand, receipt or facilitation of illegal gratification by
      A-8. The prosecution seeks to criminalise a policy decision without proving harm
      to public interest or the essential ingredients of the offences. No case is made out
      against A-8.

       A-16 nor attribute any role to him. His belated arraignment, without fresh judicial

      linking A-16 with any alleged proceeds of crime or showing knowledge of their
      source. The sole allegation is that he distributed certain amounts allegedly
      received through angadias. The angadias themselves have been treated as

      rea, conscious possession or participation in any conspiracy by A-16. The
      prosecution case rests on conjecture and inference without independent
      corroboration. Accordingly, A-16 is entitled to discharge.
