77.          It is submitted that the allegations levelled by the investigating agency stand
      in direct contradiction to the contemporaneous record and the documented
      evolution of the Delhi Excise Policy 2021–22. A holistic and comparative reading
      of the Ravi Dhawan Committee Report, successive drafts placed before the Group
      of Ministers, the recommendations of the Hon’ble Lieutenant Governor, and the
      Final Policy dated 21.05.2021 clearly reveals that the provisions now impugned
      were the result of deliberation, consultation and rational modification over time.
      The material on record demonstrates an incremental policy process rather than
      any abrupt or clandestine alteration. Under the earlier regime, brand registration
      was classified into Free Pricing and Non-Free Pricing. The minimum sale
      requirement applicable to non-free pricing had been in existence for over two
      decades. The Committee noted that certain brands with negligible national
      presence were utilising the free pricing route, resulting in brand pushing in the
      Delhi market. To address this concern and to safeguard consumer interest, the
      Committee proposed tightening eligibility criteria and revising minimum sale
      requirements. Thereafter, the draft dated 18.03.2021 introduced the concept of
      fixed-cum-lowest EDP. In the subsequent deliberations dated 05.04.2021, it was


                                        Page no. 37 of 48
       clarified that inputs relating to MRP would be provided to the Excise
      Commissioner. This position found place in the Final Policy. The trajectory of
      these changes reflects regulatory tightening to prevent misuse and enhance
      consumer protection, and not the conferment of any undue advantage.
78.          It is further submitted that similarly, while the earlier policy did not permit
      discounts, the Committee recorded that there should be no objection to discounts
      or rebates by wholesalers or retailers, subject to oversight. This approach was
      consistently reflected in the drafts and ultimately incorporated in the Final Policy.
      The allowance of discounts was thus a conscious policy choice directed at market
      rationalisation and consumer benefit, duly reflected in official documents. In
      relation to the wholesale model, the Committee identified systemic issues such as
      proxy retailers, duplicate barcoding and non-payment of duty, and recommended
      that wholesale operations be placed under a government entity. The Group of
      Ministers examined models adopted in other States and recorded that under the
      revised duty structure, the earlier advantage of centralised collection stood
      neutralised.
79.          It was further observed that the Government was not immediately
      positioned to establish warehousing and logistics infrastructure necessary for
      uninterrupted supply, and that a deeper study and phased implementation would
      be required. Pending a final decision on the Committee’s model, it was resolved
      that L1 licences could be issued to private entities to ensure continuity of trade
      and revenue stability. Simultaneously, safeguards were introduced, including
      prohibition of proxy retailers, strict barcoding measures, advance receipt of duty
      and revenue, and quality control mechanisms. The decision not to adopt the
      corporation route was thus reasoned and recorded. The Committee emphasised
      prevention of monopolistic tendencies and recommended rotation of licensees and
      grant of licences only to eligible entities. The requirement of ten years’ wholesale
      distribution experience was subsequently modified to a minimum of five years in
      later drafts and retained in the Final Policy. The turnover criteria underwent
      successive revisions: from ₹100 crore for the last five years in the draft dated
      15.03.2021, to ₹500 crore, thereafter rationalised to ₹250 crore for the last three
      years, and further considered at ₹150 crore in the LG’s recommendation, before
      being reflected in the Final Policy. The annual L1 licence fee was initially ₹10
      crore and was subsequently reduced to ₹5 crore. Each of these modifications is

                                        Page no. 38 of 48
       traceable to recorded deliberations. The progressive rationalisation of experience,
      turnover and fee requirements reflects responsive policy-making, not
      manipulation.
80.         It is argued that the framework further incorporated express non-monopoly
      provisions. The L1 licence holder was kept distinct from the retailer;
      manufacturers were separated from retail operations; L1 licensees were barred
      from being manufacturers directly or through proxies; retailers were restricted to
      two zones; geo-mapping was undertaken to identify structural anomalies; and pre-
      defined zones were created to ensure equitable distribution. These measures were
      designed to dismantle proxy arrangements, prevent cartelisation and enhance
      transparency. The issue of spurious liquor was recognised, and successive drafts
      incorporated government-approved mechanisms and laboratory testing at
      warehouses for each batch, systematic checks by L1 licensees, and stringent
      consequences including cancellation of licence, criminal proceedings, permanent
      blacklisting and intimation to other States in case of violation. Such measures are
      wholly inconsistent with any allegation of regulatory dilution.
81.          It is also argued that provision was also made for Special Inspection Teams
      to monitor compliance. Violations of eligibility conditions were to entail
      permanent bans and forfeiture of licence fees. Institutional oversight was thus
      strengthened rather than weakened. Further, with respect to distributor margin,
      while earlier proposals contemplated flexible margins with a minimum 5%
      distribution fee, the policy ultimately standardised the distribution fee at 12% to
      cover operational costs, freight, insurance and reasonable profit. The recorded
      objective was to provide economic viability within a regulated framework and
      thereby eliminate unethical practices. The Committee had also recorded concerns
      regarding obsolete and discriminatory brand registration fee structures, brand
      pushing under free pricing, and poor retail experience. The Group of Ministers
      recommended abolition of slab systems, introduction of a uniform brand
      registration fee of ₹1 lakh per brand, rationalisation of fees including for foreign
      brands, and improvement in the retail experience so as to eliminate brand pushing.
      These measures were directed towards consumer choice and market
      competitiveness.
82.         It is submitted that in the retail revenue model, auction and lottery systems
      adopted in other States were studied. The draft dated 15.03.2021 introduced a

                                       Page no. 39 of 48
       formula-based reserve price calculation, comprising existing licence fee, projected
      excise and VAT revenue, and additional fee. The draft dated 18.03.2021 revised
      the formula by including estimated VAT from the HCR segment and reducing the
      additional fee component, while also extending licence validity to four years.
      Bidding was restricted to two zones per entity, with structured EMD requirements.
      These provisions were retained in the Final Policy. The formula-based
      methodology reflects objective quantification rather than arbitrary allocation.
83.          It is also submitted that the retail eligibility and operational conditions were
      detailed and comprehensive. They included non-refundable application fee,
      refundable EMD, security deposit, renewal subject to satisfactory conduct,
      prohibition of spurious liquor and brand pushing, mandatory procurement from
      L1 licensees, minimum carpet area requirements (later capped), mandatory CCTV
      installation with retention of recordings for a minimum period, prohibition of sale
      to minors, bar on manufacturers or wholesalers owning retail shops, two-zone
      restriction, and provision for cancellation and re-tendering in case of malpractice.
      Successive drafts either retained or strengthened these safeguards.
84.          Ld. Senior Advocate contended that cumulatively, the documentary record
      demonstrates that the Policy evolved through structured deliberation across
      Committee recommendations, successive drafts, LG inputs and final approval.
      Each modification is traceable to recorded reasoning. Safeguards against
      monopoly, proxy control, spurious liquor, revenue leakage and brand pushing
      were incorporated and reinforced. Eligibility, turnover and fee provisions were
      rationalised through multiple iterations. In these circumstances, the suggestion
      that the Policy was manipulated to confer undue advantage is not borne out by the
      contemporaneous record. The clause evolution itself evidences transparency,
      regulatory intent and consultative policy-making. No adverse inference can,
      therefore, be drawn against Accused No. 18 on the basis of the evolution of the
      Policy.

      witness statement, documentary material or financial trail connecting it to
      issuance of licences or inducement of any public servant. The allegation that A-23
      controlled Trident, Organomix and Avantika so as to hold five retail zones in
      excess of the policy cap, at the highest, raises a regulatory issue under the Excise
      Policy. It does not constitute an offence under the IPC or PC Act. Clause 4.1.2 of
      the Policy requires proof of common ownership or group control, which is absent.
      Allegations of cartelisation, even if assumed, do not attract penal liability in the
      absence of a specific statutory offence.The prosecution further alleges recoupment
      of bribe by non-payment of ₹46.88 crores to M/s Indo Spirits. The records show
      that out of the alleged ₹60 crores, only ₹21.56 crores related to Trident, and
      payments of approximately ₹37.81 crores were made between November 2021
      and July 2022. The amount has not been written off, and recovery proceedings are

                                        Page no. 47 of 48
    pending before the Hon’ble NCLT, Hyderabad, with separate litigation concerning
   policy deductions. These facts negate the theory of deliberate recoupment and
   demonstrate the commercial nature of the dispute.
100.            It is contended that the allegation of issuance of fake credit notes of
   ₹1.57 crores is equally unsustainable. Credit notes are routine trade discounts
   between L1 licensees and retailers. There is no material showing falsity or
   fraudulent intent. The allegation that A-23 conspired to secure distributorship for
   M/s Indo Spirits Ltd. rests only on statements showing his presence in certain
   meetings. Mere presence does not establish agreement or meeting of minds. The
   meetings of March and May 2021 did not involve any public servant. There is no
   material to show that A-23 influenced any public servant or participated in
   formulation of policy. For Section 120-B IPC, a prior agreement to commit an
   illegal act must be shown. No such agreement, overt act, inducement of a public
   servant or unlawful gain is established against A-23. In the absence of
   foundational facts constituting offences under the IPC or PC Act, continuation of
   proceedings would amount to an unwarranted trial. A-23 is, therefore, entitled to
   discharge.
